name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the presentation of the College of Commissioners and their programme by the President-designate of the Commission (2014/2811(RSP)).

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: President-elect of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in a speech I had the honour of giving before you on 15 July, I presented to you the general guidelines, in accordance with the right of the President-designate of the Commission under the Treaty. It was not an exercise in style, it was a program presentation, a project presentation, a content presentation, a presentation of ambitions. The commissioners who will form my college, if you invest it, are bound by these general guidelines. I am not asking the commissioners for blind obedience. As I said in Brussels, when I presented the college, "at my age, you don't start a career as a dictator". I would like the Commissioners to feel free. The President-designate of the Commission has been asked to do everything possible to be able to form a political college, so respect the fact that the Commissioners have political opinions and, through their reflections, inform the debates within the Commission. I was invested President of the Commission on the basis of a programme that binds me to the European Parliament. I have a contract with you, Mr President, as well as with the European Parliament, and I intend to respect the terms of the contract that I outlined before you last summer. The Commission, which will take office on 1 November, if you agree, will succeed that of José Manuel Barroso, who was president of the institution for ten years. I would like to pay tribute to José Manuel Barroso, who was president for a very difficult time. The Barroso Commission has had to deal with the economic and financial crisis and its consequences. The Barroso Commission has been able to integrate 13 new Member States into the multiple Community arrangements. I consider that José Manuel Barroso has done a good job and that, very often, he has been criticised in a way that at times has seemed painful to me. Mr Barroso has not demerited and I would like to thank him for the extraordinary work he has done.  (Applause) In July, I promised you that I would set up a Political Commission. I told you that the next Commission would be political and very political. It was like an ecumenical wish that many of you expressed. The Commission is not a gathering of anonymous senior officials. Directors-general, all competent, must obey the commissioners and not the other way around. So I've done everything I can to say it? - see "heavyweights" appointed as members of the Commission by governments and by the President-designate. The men and women who will make up my college have held important positions in their respective countries, functions, in fact, of high responsibility. The Commission will consist of four former prime ministers, 19 former ministers, three former foreign ministers, several former finance ministers, seven outgoing commissioners and eight Commissioners who have been members of the European Parliament. Their political origin reflects the fact that the Commission must be very political. I promised you a more political Commission. Its composition sufficiently indicates that it will be more political than those that preceded it. I promised you a more effective Commission in July. Again, this is an ecumenically shared wish by most of those who make up this assembly. I have chosen to reorganize the architecture of the Commission. I have chosen to appoint - which had not been done before - a first vice-president in the person of Frans Timmermans, whom I would particularly like to welcome this morning. (Applause) I made this choice because I have known him for centuries and also to bring to the Commission the political balance that the appointment of the various Commissioners has only sufficiently imposed. I have read, in most European newspapers, that Frans Timmermans will be my right hand. I hope that from time to time it will also be my left hand, but it will be difficult. I have appointed several vice-presidents. I intended to appoint the High Representative as vice-president, as the treaty provides for. My intention, at first glance, was to appoint the Commissioner of Budget Affairs as vice-chair because the development and implementation of the budget is, in fact, horizontal in nature, and I had the idea of asking former prime ministers to perform leadership functions within the college. Premiers are used to the difficult job of coordinating the work of others. Sometimes they succeed, sometimes they do not succeed, but they know what it is about when it comes to coordinating. I have therefore asked those who were prime ministers to be vice-presidents of the Commission. I decided to charge Frans Timmermans with the application of the principle of subsidiarity - better regulation, as they say in English. This is an important case. We had said and promised the voters and The citizens of Europe to make Europe a machine, a forum, an ambition, a factory that would deal with the big problems and that would abandon the small subjects who find a better answer in the respective Member Countries and at the level of local authorities. Mr. Timmermans will oversee the principle of better regulation. Heavy work than the best regulation. Heavy work, which will affect all Commissioners since all must participate in this effort to restore the European Union and its political reflexes and behaviours. I decided that Frans Timmermans would also take care of sustainable development. This is an important ambition. It is a project that carries far, a daily concern.  I could not follow the proposals of your Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Security that the "sustainable development" competence should be assigned to the Vice-President for Growth and Investment. I have chosen to ask Frans Timmermans to take care of this particularly important aspect of our collective action because the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which will constitute much of Mr Timmermans' work, already provides for respect for sustainable development, as is Article 3 of the Treaty, which prescribes it as a standard of action. The Vice-Presidents I have chosen will be responsible for the Commission's priorities, which I outlined to you in July of this year. There will be a Vice-President who will be responsible for the Energy Union in all its dimensions, including renewable and new energy. A Vice-President will be responsible for growth and investment, a second in the European digital market and a third in the euro and social dialogue.  It is not small chiefs who will instruct the other commissioners. The Commissioners of the Commission are equal in law. They are project vice-presidents, coordinators, facilitators, gatherers, organizers of ideas and initiatives. I have noted, during the parliamentary hearings and in the virtuous part of published public opinion, many doubts and questions about these "unknown animals" that are the vice-presidents coordinating the work of the Commission. I was surprised to read this. Everyone had told me that the Commission should operate more efficiently. Almost everyone had complained that the college was made up of twenty-eight commissioners, one commissioner per country, and that there were too many of them. I had a choice between a revision of the architectural organization and a fragmentation of skills so that I could distribute them among twenty-eight commissioners. So the question is simple: either you want twenty-eight Commissioners each working in their own corner, wallowing in the spirit of a bell tower, dealing with small skills, which would see the light of day after the commission's powers have been broken down and to pieces, or do you want commissioners who have nothing to do or commissioners acting under the friendly aegis of vice-presidents who would coordinate their work?  If you want a Commission like the previous one, you should have told me. But if you want a more efficient Commission, which takes care of Europe's great ambitions, which organises them, structures them, then there is no choice but to appoint a number of vice-presidents to implement the Commission's main political priorities. I will give you two examples: there is a Vice-President in charge of the euro and social dialogue, there is a Commissioner for Economic, Financial and Fiscal Affairs and another for social affairs, and there is the European semester. It is clear that someone , in fact, the vice-president in charge - must coordinate the initiatives of the Commissioner for Social Affairs and those of the Commissioner for Economic, Financial and Fiscal Affairs. The European semester is not an economic and financial semester. The country-by-country recommendations that the Commission will make must necessarily take into account the social aspects of Europe's economic and monetary construction. (Applause) There's a whole debate around triple A. Everyone loves triple A. In fact, within the euro area, there are still two countries to which triple A has been conferred: Germany and Luxembourg. Germany has a good chance of keeping it, as for Luxembourg, we'll see... But I would like the European Union to find and acquire another triple A. I would like Europe to have the social triple A, which is as important as the economic and financial triple-A. (Applause) We have appointed a vice-president of growth and investment. It will coordinate the action of all the Commissioners who will contribute to the growth and investment policy: the Commissioner for Transport, the Commissioner for the Digital Economy, again the Commissioner for Economic, Financial and Fiscal Affairs, the Commissioner for Social Affairs and Employment, the Commissioner for the Establishment of the Single Capital Market, the Commissioner for the Internal Market and so on.  If we want to present an ambitious investment package to the Europeans - and therefore first to Parliament - someone will have to organise it. Since there are several jurisdictions that need to be merged and there are several commissioners who have to bring their different policies to the centre, it is obvious that a vice-president has to coordinate the work. I want to end the silo. I want to put an end to this mode of governance that every commissioner works in his corner. I want to put an end to the bell-tower mentality which can be distinguished, very often, by observing the work of the Commission. I draw your attention to something that virtually no commentator has noticed. The big loser of this new architecture is me — I like your protests — for the simple reason that I delegated much of my presidential prerogatives to the vice-presidents. Project vice-presidents cannot be set up if the President continues to evolve at the head of the Commission as has been the case so far. But I would like to say here that, of course, in order for a item to be put on the Commission's agenda, I first want the approval of the Vice-President in charge of coordination. But the one - and I would like to say this without threat - who delegates his prerogatives, can also take them back, if he really has to. For the rest, the Vice-Presidents will be responsible for the work which, until now, was the prerogative of the President of the Commission. I promised you in July that the new Commission would have a sufficient number of women. We have nine women commissioners, as many as in the Barroso Commission. I had to fight for national governments to offer me nine women. At the end of July, two weeks after speaking to you, we had three women appointed by governments. I had to convince many governments to send a commissioner and I had to turn down a lot of male candidates. I will not tell you which ones because I do not want to embarrass the prime ministers I have managed to convince to nominate a woman commissioner. But, in fact, nine women out of twenty-eight commissioners, that is a number that remains ridiculous. (Applause) So since we are all, in principle, part of national political parties, and as, in principle, we all know our prime ministers, start raising awareness of this issue by national governments tomorrow morning. I am a little embarrassed to have to tell you this, since Luxembourg has not appointed a woman. He'll probably do it next time. Since Ms. Reding was Commissioner for fifteen years, we have not accumulated the ... (Comment off microphone by Rebecca Harms) No, in the short term I will not be able to change my sex: in the long run perhaps, but not in the very short term.  I told you, my dear friends, during the debate we had in July that I would listen carefully to the hearings. How can I not listen to the auditions? I have followed parliamentary hearings with varying interest, I must say, numbering twenty-nine in total. I told you in July that the Commission was not the Secretary General of the European Council and the Council of Ministers and that I would not be the valet of the European Parliament. But I listened to what you said and I thought it appropriate to draw a number of consequences from the hearings that took place before our eyes. The Commissioner proposed by Slovenia had to be replaced by another Slovenian Commissioner and I decided to give her the important transport portfolio. As I did not want to question the basic architecture of the Commission, I chose to appoint Mr 'Eef-ovi' As Vice-President in charge of the Energy Union, since in the past years he was already Vice-President and therefore has an idea of what the coordination work I ask him to do can represent. I have already told you that I have proposed to my friend Frans Timmermans to enrich his portfolio through all the policies related to sustainable development. I listened very carefully to all those who complained that I had disused the skills of drugs and products from the Health Commissioner's portfolio to the portfolio in charge of the internal market. I did not have the idea — and those who know me know it well — that medicines, that health products, as medical activity itself, would be a commodity like any other. Health is not a commodity. And so, sensitive to the call for me to put this division of skills in order - it was a wish expressed during the parliamentary hearings and widely taken up by many of the medical professions - I decided to reallocate these powers to the Commissioner for Health. (Applause) In my view, space policy is a promising area and it seemed to me more appropriate to assign the Commissioner responsible for the internal market for space policies, as was the case in the Commission's previous compositions. With regard to citizenship, I have followed your debates, I have been sensitive to a number of remarks which reflected unease, so I have chosen to assign the citizenship file to the Commissioner for Migration and Home Affairs - powers to be shared, of course, with the Commissioner for Justice. I also added sports to Mr. Navracsics' file. These are the conclusions I drew from the hearings that were yours. (Comment off microphone by Michèle Rivasi.) I have more than carefully followed your debates and you have seen how we have organised the situation with regard to the Commissioner you have just mentioned, in a way that is inaudible to others. Mr President, finally, I have taken note of the intense debate around the inclusion of investor-state dispute settlement in the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) negotiations. Let me, once again, state my position clearly - the position that I set out on 15 July 2014 before this House and which you will find in my political guidelines. I will not accept the jurisdiction of the EU Member States being limited by special regimes for investor-state disputes. The rule of law and the principle of equality before the law must apply in this context, as elsewhere. The negotiating mandate sets out a number of conditions that would have to be respected in such a regime, as well as an assessment of its relationship with domestic courts. There is thus no obligation in this regard: the mandate leaves it open and serves as a guide. I had thought that my commitment on this point was very clear, but I am happy to clarify it further and to reiterate it here today, as a number of you have asked me to do. In the agreement that the Commission will eventually submit to this House for approval, there will be nothing that limits the parties' access to national courts or which will allow secret courts to have the final say in disputes between investors and states. I have asked Frans Timmermans, in his role as First Vice-President in charge of the rule of law and the Charter of Fundamental Rights, to advise me on that matter. There will be no investor-state dispute clause in the TTIP agreement if Frans does not agree to it too. I am confident that, with your support, we can negotiate an ambitious trade agreement with the US along these lines, fully respecting European interests and the rule of law. I am strongly committed to the ambition of concluding the trade agreement with the US, but I have promised this Parliament, and I promised during the campaign, that I will be attentive to European rules. It may be that, in relation to European protection rules, we will have to negotiate further with our American friends to bring this agreement to fruition. However, I wanted to be as clear as possible on this specific issue. Herr President! Ich rede jetzt in der Sprache des Weltmeisters, obwohl der Weltmeister zurzeit eine erkennbare Formschwàche hat. (Heiterkeit) Der Herr President denkt, das wre eine vor-bergehende Schweche. Auch Deutsche messen sich daran gew-hnen kunnen, dass sie dauerhaft schw-cher sein kunnen. Herr President! Ich mechte einige zus-tzliche Erkl-rungen abgeben zu Punkten, die in der Debatte der letzten Woche eine hervorgehobene Rolle gespielt haben. Ich hatte Ihnen im Juli versprochen, ich wurde ein 300 Milliarden Euro schweres Investitionspaket vorlegen. Investitionen sind von vitaler Wichtigkeit fer die europeische Volkswirtschaft und fer die Menschen, die in Europa leben und arbeiten. Europa kennt eine unwahrscheinliche Investitionslacke - einen Investitionsr-cckgang von 'ber 20% im Schnitt im Direktvergleich mit dem Vorkrisenjahr 2007: 36% Investitionsr-ckgang in Portugal, 64% Investitionsr-cckgang in Griechenland. Volkswirtschaften, in denen nicht investiert wird, kunnnen nicht wachsen, und Volkswirtschaften, die nicht wachsen, kunnnen keine Besch-ftigung sicherstellen. Dieses Investitionsprogramm liegt mir sehr am Herzen. Ich mechte yesterday in go Deutlichkeit sagen, dass die Versuche, mich von diesem Vorhaben abzubringen - die inzwischen selbstverst-ndlich gestartet wurden , nicht fruchten werden. Ich werde dies tun! (Beifall) Dieses Investitionsprogramm kann nicht durch weitere Schuldenaufnahme finanziert werden. (Beifall) Wir messen Sorge dafar tragen, dass durch intelligent Einbringen 'ffentlicher Geldmittel die Privatinitiative angekurbelt wird, sich angesprochen fehlt. Die Wirtschaft muss wissen, dass auch sie eine Aufgabe in der Gesellschaft zu erf-llen hat. Nicht nur Staaten sind zustondig, um Arbeitslosigkeit zu bek-mpfen: Die Wirtschaft hat eine original eigene Verantwortung. Ich appelliere an die europeischen Wirtschaftslenker, das Ihre zu tun, damit sich die Lage auf den europeischen Arbeitsm-rkten verbessert, und dass es zu einem Investitionsfluss kommt, den wir dringend ben-tigen, um von der Stelle zu kommen. (Beifall) Ich werde dieses Investitionsprogramm nicht, wie urspr-nglich geplant, innerhalb der ersten drei Monate der Mandatsdauer der Kommission vorlegen. Der zust-ndige Vizepresident Jyrki Katainen und ich werden dies noch vor Weihnachten tun. Eile ist geboten, und wir messen dieser Forderung so schnell wie meglich gerecht werden. Dieses Investitionsprogramm wird keine Konjunkturprogramme - wie in den siebziger Jahren in einigen Mitgliedstaaten versucht - auf den Weg bringen. Konjunkturprogramme sind Strohfeuerprogramme. Was wir brauchen, sind zielorientierte Investitionen, die mittelfristig zu mehr Wachstum fàhren, Investitionen, die die Kraft der europeischen Wirtschaft stunken. Nicht einfach Geld in die Hand nehmen, nur um den Eindruck zu erwecken, man tete etwas, sondern Geld in die Hand nehmen, mit dem Privatsektor gemeinsam, um mittelfristig die Wachstumskr-fte und das Wachstumspotential in der Europischen Union zu. Das sage ich auch deshalb, weil die Hauptaufgabe, die vor uns liegt, die Bek-mpfung der Arbeitslosigkeit ist, nicht nur, aber vor allem im Bereich der skandals hohen Jugendarbeitslosigkeit in vielen unserer Mitgliedstaaten. Im Rahmen dieser Gesamtanstrengungen muss man selbstverst-ndlich auch an der europeischen Digitalagenda, am europeischen digitalen Binnenmarkt arbeiten. Der Kollege Oettinger wird sich um dieses wichtige Sachgebiet kunmmern. Allein die Besch-ftigung mit der digitalen Agenda, allein die Investitionen, die in dem Bereich get-tigt werden messen, werden einen Wachstumsschub von 250 Milliarden Euro in den nechsten Jahren zur Folge haben. Wir werden das tun. Es wurde in den letzten Monaten viel 'ber den Stabilit-tspakt moniert, diskutiert, aber wenig nachgedacht. Auch yesterday mechte ich Klartext sprechen. Ich halte mich an das, und die Kommission insgesamt auch, was der European Rat im Rahmen seiner Befugnisse am 27. Juni in Sachen Stabilit-tspakt gesagt hat. Die Regeln werden nicht ge-ndert. Alle Regierungen, 28 an der Zahl, waren im Juni der Auffassung, dass das Regelwerk nicht tangiert werden soll. Das war doch klar. Hab ich da etwas falsch verstanden? Das Regelwerk wird nicht tangiert! Aber dem Regelwerk wird jener Flexibilit-tsflankenschutz geboten, den die einschl-gigen Vertrags- und sonstigen bindenden Text uns vorschreiben. Es wird also relativ undramatisch zugehen. Wir werden das tun, wozu der European Rat uns aufgefordert hat. Wir werden das tun, was ich in meinen Ausf-hrungen yesterday am 15. Juli vorgetragen habe. Haushaltsdisziplin muss breast! Flexibility muss breast! Strukturreformen messen kommen! Ohne Strukturreformen, die dauerhaft zu einer Belebung der europeischen Wirtschaft und der europeischen Arbeitsm-rkte fàhren, kann es keine Flexibilitet geben - damit die Dinge klar sind. (Beifall) Aber ich mechte auch denen, die denken, eine 'berzogene Austerit't, eine exzessive Sparpolitik fehrt automatisch dazu, dass es zu einer Wiederbelebung der Wachstumskr-fte und der arbeitsmarktpolitischen Impulse kommt, ich mechte diesen Kollegen sagen, dass Es ist nicht so, dass Defizite und Schuldenst-nde automatisch zu Wachstum fàhren. Wenn es so wre, dass hohe Defizite und hohe Schuldenst-nde zu Wachstum fàhren wurden, dann màsste Europa wachsen wie noch nie in seiner Geschichte, denn wir hatten noch nie so viele Schulden zu verantworten, wie dies der Fall ist. Aber zu denken, dass Haushaltskonsolidierung allein wachstumsf-rdernd ist, ohne mit der notwendigen Flexibilitet von den notwendigen Strukturreformen und Investitionszielen begleitet zu werden, ist ebenso falsch. Wir brauchen beides: Haushaltsdisziplin, wachstumsorientierte Politik, Investitionen, damit wir uns mit der gebotenen Geschwindigkeit in die Zukunft bewegen kunnen.  Finally, I have observed, ladies and gentlemen, that many questions have arised around what I said in July on the issue of enlargement. I have appointed a Commissioner for Neighbourhood Policy and Membership Negotiations. A number of your commissions have proposed to rename this portfolio "Commissioner for Neighbourhood and Enlargement. I have chosen, after a meticulous debate, first with myself and then with a few of my friends, to name this portfolio "Commissioner for Enlargement Negotiations". I don't want to deceive people or people. Do not give the impression to those who are candidate countries that they could become members of the European Union in the next five years. There will be no new members during the mandate of this Commission. It is absolutely not feasible. So let's not tell stories. Let us not make those who are waiting for membership believe that it can take place in the next five years. Of course, the accession negotiations will continue with the same momentum, the same verve and the same commitment as so far. I would like to welcome the candidate countries to the European Union by telling them that the negotiations will indeed be accelerated, if necessary, but that it is not realistic to think that they could be carried out safely by 2019. Finally, there is another problem that bothers me, that bothers you and that is scandalous: it is the unpaid bills of the European Union.  (Applause) It's an old problem. I was, at the same time as Mr Verhofstadt, who does not like to be confronted with his youthful mistakes, as Minister for the Budget. Already at that time, in the "budget" Council, we had discovered unpaid invoices. However, the European Union, to be credible, cannot be a bad payer. It must honour its commitments. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, these are the few clarifications I wanted to make to our debates and to your questions, which were many. We are operating in an international context that shows us day after day that we live in an increasingly dangerous world. The so-called "Islamic State" movement is the enemy of European values. We cannot accept such acts. (Applause) The Ebola crisis requires a strong, rapid, organised and concentrated response from the European Union. I do not feel that we have been up to the task in the fight against this epidemic. (Applause) And I note, with enormous sadness, that as long as the phenomenon hit the African continent alone, we have done nothing. On the other hand, the day the epidemic arrived in Europe, we started to move. We should have done it sooner. (Applause) The problems associated with illegal migration remain unresolved. I have asked the former Foreign Minister of Greece, also a former Greek Defence Minister, to take charge of this issue, just as I have asked the Cypriot Commissioner, if I dare say, in charge of humanitarian aid, to go to Africa as soon as possible to mark the presence of the European Commission on the ground.  The problems related to illegal migration and legal migration will be treated as real priorities by the Commission, which I hope will take office on 1 November. I would like to repeat what I have already told you in July that we are rediscovering the virtues of the Community method. I would like this Commission and this Parliament to be the champion, the craftsmen and the architects of a rediscovery of the Community method. The intergovernmental method, urgently and at the moment, has its virtues, but I believe in the virtuous triangle between Parliament, the Council and the Commission. I would like us to rediscover that method. I told you that we feel bound by a five-year contract with your Parliament. The first reference body of the new Commission will be Parliament. The Parliament that made sure to draw the normal, natural consequences of the 27 May election from the expression of universal suffrage. I concede that there are those of us who were not in favour of political parties putting forward tops of the list, but that has been done and I say to you today - I say this especially to those who have not approved this process - that you will not come back to this subject.  (Applause) In 2019, the European election campaign will be a true pan-European campaign and everyone will know before going to the polls...  (Applause) Democracy is also European. It is continental, and by becoming more democratic, Europe does not take away from the importance of states and that of nations which, I repeat, are not provisional inventions of history but are made to last. Who wants Europe must respect the nations and the Member States. We do not build Europe against nations that have their traditions, their virtues, their wealth, their raison d'être. We are not building Europe against the Member States but with the good will we meet all over Europe at the level of civil society, our societies, our Member States and our national parliaments. I give you my conviction. This Commission will be the Last Chance Commission. Either we succeed in bringing European citizens closer to Europe or we fail. Either we succeed in making Europe a political whole that deals with big things and abandons small things, or we fail. Either we succeed, together with the Member States, with governments, parliaments, social partners, to drastically reduce the level of unemployment, or we fail. Either we give a perspective to young Europeans or we will have failed. I would like us to seize this opportunity to move Europe. Europe deserves this and I am counting on you, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, to support the Commission in the many tasks before us, to you and to the Europeans. (Lively and prolonged applause)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to begin by thanking you for the calm, calm speech we have heard, for the experience that has come from it and for the political approach behind it. To begin with, I would like to start by saying, on the question of the gender of the President of the Commission, simply to get rid of the appeal: stay as you are – that is how we like you, and it is a good thing! Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which I would like to remind you today that we are putting an end to the process of constitution at European level. The focus of this process was first of all on the citizens, on the voters. You have elected a few colleagues, the voters in Europe who reject Europe must be respected. In the overwhelming number, however, they have elected MEPs who want to shape Europe, who want to move Europe forward. This is expressed by bringing the Commission into office now. This is reflected in the concept that we had a leading candidate, that Jean-Claude Juncker was elected, that we were more involved than we used to be. That is why Europe has taken a major step forward in terms of democracy in recent years. We can describe this question, the citizens, the voters, with today, well with the last three weeks. As MEPs, we have the task of having exercised our right to examine the colleagues who have been proposed to us by the Member States. The hearings were a golden hour for European democracy, for the European Parliament. We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats have taken every hearing seriously, but we have also given every candidate a fair chance, regardless of nationality and political orientation, to present themselves properly and to convince us. The expectation here is not that we expect a perfect expert, but we expect a political person who is burning for Europe, who is burning for its content and who wants to work hard for the next five years. No national level knows this principle that ministers must be held accountable to a parliament in advance. That is why we should be self-confident as European democrats. We have this right, we are proud of this right, and we have also seen it in an exemplary and exemplary manner over the last three weeks. We can be proud of it. A thought for the timetable, because there was always a question of how long it takes: democracy costs time, and, by the way, money. That's so. However, I would like to remind you, even as a parliamentarian, that the discussions in the European Council on Mrs Mogherini, on the question of the High Representatives, took us more than a month to reach the results of the European Council. In this respect, I also believe that we, as parliamentarians, are in good balance with the timetable and have therefore worked well. Now back to Europe: Jean-Claude Juncker has presented us with a team and today gave us answers to the Commission hearings in the various specialist committees of this House. Thank you for that! Secondly, he has presented a concept which coordinates and concentrates with the Vice-Presidents. We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats support this. Thirdly, he thought: how can I bring the Member States on board? And if in recent years we have heard many times from the Dutch Government, for example about Frans Timmermans, what Europe should not do, then I think the approach of having a Dutchman now who says' 'Okay, I am implementing this' and explains it at home. I think it is a good idea to bring the mood of the national level into the Commission. Fourthly, he has made it clear that we are getting a citizens' commission. The citizens of Europe are at the table. the student from Spain who has to leave his homeland because he cannot find a job, the entrepreneur who has problems in the digital sector with 28 data protection requirements. It takes the citizens on board , which is important – and it seeks partnership with the European Parliament. I would like to express my sincere thanks for this. Congratulations! We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats support the proposal that Jean-Claude Juncker has made to us. I do not know, ladies and gentlemen, how you are doing. But I want to start working now. After this inaugural process, I burn on the content. I now want to work as an MEP. I am pleased that we can now get to work. The issues are certainly not easy. It is about a stable Europe, where we have to abide by the rules, it is about growth, it is about how we can meet the migration challenges of our continent. It's about Respect – once again, thanks, dear Jean-Claude Juncker – respect for the national level. This, too, is an important point for the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats. And over the next five years, the question is that, after years of looking at our own problems, Europe will turn its attention to the outside world and take care of the tasks of our time. Yesterday we saw the departure of José Manuel Barroso. He has described to us the tasks that have stood before us in recent years. The message that has stuck with me from his final report is that, despite all the challenges – if we Europeans stick together, if we are creative, if we work together, if we are committed to solving the problems, then we can do it. We solve the problems of the future if we work constructively together on the issues. With this motivation left to us by José Manuel Barroso, we can now get to work. Yes to this strong Commission! The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats wants success. Run to work! (Applause)

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Juncker, dear Commissioners, today Europe's worst enemy is not populism, it is the lack of courage of the ruling classes. You, Mr Juncker, are not the result of a downward compromise, but of the choice of citizens. We will support it by pressing it, we in the Group of the Party of European Socialists will be the critical soul of the majority, that is what the Commission needs. We have done so in the negotiations over the last few weeks, we have it in the hearings. If Frans Timmermans had not become Vice-President responsible for sustainable development, this Commission would be weaker.  Today you have said important things, you have talked about a political contract with us, we are proposing a pact with the citizens because we are interested in people's lives, not abstract politics. You spoke of one of the most important products for people's lives, medicines. You entrusted responsibility for medicines to the Commissioner for Industry and the Internal Market. But what did medicines and health have to do with the internal market? Today he announced to us that medicines and pharmaceuticals will once again be the responsibility of the Commissioner for Health. We do not want to put political flags on, but this was our battle and we are proud of your answer. He also made some timely and important statements on the TTP. For us, two points will be decisive for the European Pact that we are discussing today: the first is the investment plan, we will not accept a simple cosmetic operation. The credibility of this Commission and probably the future of the European project are at stake in investment, and you are aware of that. We will support you, in this challenge you need us, but we also need you! We need you not to allow the European Parliament to be marginalised in drawing up the plan.  Together we must challenge the most recalcitrant Member States, and I propose three horse moves: firstly, let us give part of the capital of the rescue fund to the EIB by strengthening its capital; secondly, we intelligently count European investments, which, as Europeans, do not have to be calculated in national budgets; thirdly, it goes against the current, points on culture, because today growth depends on creativity. Look at the results of the Nobel Prize last week, how many Europeans have been awarded. Today we need to increase funding for cultural programmes fivefold, it can be done, so that we will win all European citizens the most important Nobel Prize, that of growth and civilisation, and it would also be a way of erasing the shadow that culture and education are secondary subjects to be sacrificed in the name of political bartering with the weakest states and countries. The second pillar of the European Pact is social Europe: growth is not a fetish, investment and growth must serve solidarity. Here, too, we are leaving people's lives, we do not want a downward war between European workers, so we want the Posting of Workers Directive to be revised; and then action must be taken to support women, especially working women.  You have done your utmost, we recognise that in order to have adequate representation of women in the Commission. We have not succeeded, it is not his fault, but there is no need – Weber is right – to change sex. We are acting to support women, especially working women, by taking concrete measures. In this parliamentary term, we must approve the Maternity Leave Directive, which has been guiltily buried by the European Council. His speech as a statesman and pro-European was also embellished in his final jokes by a timely fresco on foreign policy and a timely reference to immigration. Here, too, we are pleased to see a change of pace and a greater ambition than with Federica Mogherini and the new responsibilities assigned to the Commissioner for Immigration, we will finally be able to cultivate; And we know how necessary it will be today in the face of the terrible emergencies that the African continent is experiencing. Mr President, Commissioners, you have a titanic task ahead of you. The Group of the Party of European Socialists will support you and invite you to be courageous, do not stop and if you stop do not worry, because we will push you. Good luck.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Juncker very much for his presentation today. Mr Juncker, I wonder if I could just start by pointing to three things that you mentioned in your speech. First of all, you described yourself as ‘the big loser’. If I were you, I would not be so harsh on yourself. Secondly, you hit the nail on the head when it came to the debate on what some call public investment and what others call debt. We need to resolve this issue. We need to make sure that we learn the lesson that you simply cannot spend more money than you have got. You simply cannot ask taxpayers for money they have not got, and we need to make sure that we have financial responsibility. Thirdly, we welcome your announcement that Luxembourg should perhaps propose a female Commissioner for the next term. We look forward to the return of Astrid Lulling in this Chamber. Yesterday we debated the legacy of President Barroso, and we looked back at his Commission and we called his Commission a Commission of crisis. What will we say about your Commission in five years’ time? In our group, we will ask: did the Juncker Commission lift its eyes from the institutional naval-gazing and look to the world beyond Europe to see those competitive economies? Our group will ask: did the Juncker Commission tackle the important issues of energy security and the digital single market and pursue open trade; and did the Juncker Commission face up to the challenges of the future rather than looking back to the past? As an open and democratic group, the ECR had a number of discussions about this Commission – in fact, probably more than I would like to mention – but that is part of being an open and transparent democratic group. So, as we cast our vote today, let me share with you some of our concerns, but also some of the things that we like about your Commission. First of all, let us be positive. We welcome the fact that the structure does not look like desperately seeking 27 places for 27 people. We like the fact that you have torn down the silos and have come up with an integrated structure focused on outcomes. That is a positive plan: it is a plan for action. We like the fact that you are looking to cut red tape and to complete the digital single market; and that you are looking at energy, the economy and competitiveness. We are impressed by some of your appointments. We like the fact, for example, that the gentleman next to you, Mr Timmermans, asked the question, ‘Does Europe need to do all this?’ Surely at times it is best to leave it to the Member States. Do we really need this regulation? Thirdly, some Members in my group feel that you have offered a genuine olive branch to us, and we hope that both sides face up to the challenge of grasping that olive branch as we look forward to working with you over the next five years. But I have to say we are also disappointed. We are disappointed that you did not support Parliament’s request for a budget control Commissioner. We see the appointment of a French socialist, given their record on the Stability and Growth Pact, as a mistake. It is rather like putting an alcoholic in charge of a wine bar. You might say that it is like putting a Houdini or an escapologist in charge of a prison. It might lead to better security, but it will also lead some people to say: if he can escape and get out of it, so can we. Some of our national delegations did not like some of the people appointed because of their record in their home Member State, but we know that the process is over. We know the deal has been done. We know that the large groups will vote for your Commission. Our group will not join this cosy consensus. We will abstain. As you get down to work, where you pursue reform, we will work with you and your Commission; and where you look back to the past, we will confront you with the challenges of the future. There is much work to do, and we wish you well. (Applause)

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I can tell you that the position of the Liberal Group is not one of abstention, it is a clear ‘yes’ for the new Commission. Have a little courage please, Mr Kamall, at the start of this new Commission! We need clear statements and clear positions. We had a lengthy discussion yesterday in our group, and our conclusion was that we will support this Commission as part of the pro-European coalition that also supported you, Mr Juncker, when you were appointed President of this Commission. This Commission has not received our support for free, however. We expect a different Commission from the previous one. We expect a Commission with ambition, a Commission with vision, a Commission that can lead us out of the crisis. We do not expect more of what we have seen over the past five years, namely a Commission that became, more and more, the secretariat of the Council, a Commission that waited first for the green light from Paris and Berlin – or rather, Berlin and Paris, to reverse the order – before it acted. To give you one example, we are still waiting in this Parliament, five years after the start of the financial crisis, for the legislative package on economic governance. That is the reason why we are giving you our support: to change the way that the Commission is operating and to return to the Community method and lead us out of the crisis. More precisely, what we hope to see from your Commission are three specific things. The first is a credible strategy on investment and growth. And I hope, colleagues, that we can end the stupid discussion we have had for five years with some saying that discipline is more important and others saying that investment is more important. Can somebody, perhaps, tell us that both are important, and that you do not have to make a choice between fiscal discipline, one the one hand, and investment and growth, on the other hand? It is impossible to have investment and growth without fiscal discipline and it is – as you said, Mr Juncker – impossible to have economic growth in the future without good, sound public finances. I hope that Mr Katainen comes up with a plan as soon as possible. You are talking about EUR 300 billion, mostly from repackaging, but you know what the problems are. The problem is that the investment gap today in Europe is not EUR 300 billion. The investment gap in Europe is currently more than EUR 800 billion. Close to one trillion is lacking in investment – private mainly – in our infrastructure, in digital, in the energy grid, in transport and in innovation. I hope that, in the coming months, you can come forward with a credible strategy and a plan for closing that gap – but not in the traditional way of saying ‘Yes, we will increase a little the amount of capital in European investment.’ You need to come forward with a credible strategy like Delors did to create the internal market for consumer goods. We need a new way forward in the integration of the European Union, in digital, in energy, in innovation and in our capital markets, which are not unified at the moment. That is what we are waiting for, and we need it as soon as possible. The second thing is: can this new structure work? We have always been in favour of coordination and clustering, and I hope it can work, but I have to tell you that I have doubts about it. In a marriage it is very clear: you do not decide everything together. In my marriage, I decide the questions of peace and war, and my wife does the finances, so there is a clear division of power, but I do not know whether appointing two Commissioners for the Stability Pact is the way forward. I think it could be a source of problems, though I hope it is not because I am very much in favour of coordinating and clustering. I hope, in any case, that we will not see internal battles in your Commission. We had a long deadlock in the European Union with discussions between Paris and Berlin on the Union’s future strategy. We cannot afford to have a deadlock because Mr Dombrovskis and Mr Moscovici have different opinions about the application of the Stability Pact and about future strategy. I want us to look at this question closely and I want you, Mr Juncker, to intervene immediately if such a deadlock exists. Lastly, the new Commissioners should also be unequivocal on European values. There is a problem there. You have already indicated the problem. Mr Navracsics may be competent to be a Commissioner, but perhaps not with the portfolio you assigned to him. You announced a few minutes ago that he should no longer be responsible for citizenship. I think that is a step forward, but does it solve the whole problem? I do not think so. Yesterday you received a letter from Mr Bernard Foccroulle, the director of the music festival of Aix-en-Provence, in the name of a long list of eminent European artists, painters, composers, actors, architects and directors of opera houses and theatres. I want to tell you that we fully back the content of that letter. If you do not have other proposals to make, I hope that the structure you have established in your Commission, with Vice-Presidents coordinating and controlling the work of the other Commissioners, will also apply to the portfolio of Mr Navracsics, and that Mr Navracsics, in doing his job, will be under the control of the different Vice-Presidents of the Commission responsible for civil liberties. That said, the credibility of this Commission is not only a question of economics. It is also a question of values, because Europe is also about democracy and about human values.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Mr Juncker, ladies and gentlemen, GUE/NGL has expressed serious reservations in all the hearings of the new Commissioners. The reason is political. The Juncker programme positions that our new Commissioners are called upon to follow are strongly opposed, as they reflect the new Commission's commitment to the neoliberal policies pursued to date and have led to the process of deindustrialisation of the European south, to further increase unemployment, particularly among young people, to deregulation of labour, to the shrinking of the social state, to poverty, to the suffocation of small and medium-sized enterprises, to memoranda and to harsh austerity.  Some of the Commissioners, such as Mr Cañete, have conflicting interests with their portfolio. Others, such as Mr Navracsics, have taken positions that are directed against the peoples of Europe. In the end, however, they remained with the same portfolios, even though they were highly critical and despite the negative climate that existed against them. As GUE/NGL we condemn this which proves that the new Commission is the product of a transaction between the EPP, the Social Democrats and the Liberals, the product of a practice that tends to ridicule the Decision-making processes of the European Union.  The European Union, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, needs a change of course, with policies that create new jobs and safeguard the social state. The solution against the crisis lies in strategies that will boost the economy and social development rather than austerity policies. We cannot and will not stand idly by in the continuation of these policies. That is why, as GUE/NGL, we will be voting against the new Commissioners and the neoliberal policies they express and represent.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Juncker, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work he has done. You all know that I appreciate Mr Juncker. I do not think I am alone in this, but I am in the good large majority in this House. Nevertheless, my group will say no to the Juncker Commission. We have decided this after a long period of consideration and intensive consultation. To take Mr Verhofstadt very seriously, I believe that the very decision to give Mr Navracsics this particular portfolio is a reason in itself to say 'no' to this Commission after the experience of the last legislature – I would remind you of Viviane Reding and her problems. But, of course, we have more reasons. I don't want to go through that in detail. I would also like to make this clear by an analysis of the things that are important for the Greens in this situation of a new beginning. Mr Juncker, it is comforting that you are breaking with this idea that economic recovery can be generated by the strictest budgetary discipline in the crisis countries. We like the investment program you are announcing. We just do not know where the money is going to come from, which is needed to an even greater extent than you have outlined so far. The second thing that really dismays us is that this idea of the investment programme has not yet been combined with an idea of how the European Union, how we want to win the future for the citizens of the European Union. I say this very seriously in relation to the forthcoming summit. The fact that, after ten years of committed climate debate, we are now preparing a climate summit to dismantle the European Union's climate policy speaks against the fact that this European Commission, old or new, has actually recognised what the challenges for the future are. (Applause) It is not acceptable for Mr Oettinger to have to conduct these pitiful negotiations on gas supplies from Russia, while at the same time preparing the Heads of State or Government to drag down the targets for renewable energy and even energy efficiency at European level. This is not about gaining sustainability, but about abandoning the goals that could actually stand for better developments. I think that this was indeed missing as a balance sheet in your speech, and also the construction, the distribution of the portfolios for climate and energy, the complete lack of the idea of sustainable development, which is really a serious reason for us to say no to this Commission. (Applause) The suspicion that growth is to be generated by deregulation alone is also fuelled by the TTIP negotiations: European achievements are being abandoned. The citizens' commitment to good agricultural policy and consumer protection could, after all, win European support. In my opinion, this has not been sufficiently recognised in the old Commission and in the new Commission. Refugee policy has been a very big issue. But a major failure in recent years lies in the refugee policy that had been promised. The fact that no portfolio of its own has been created is actually a distancing from this insane challenge. If you look at the southern side of the Mediterranean, and if you look at what we are doing so far, it is really not the responsibility of how this issue is dealt with. Let me be the last to wish Mrs Mogherini luck. Mr Juncker and Mrs Mogherini are taking over these top positions at a time when, despite the ceasefire, the war is actually continuing in Ukraine. They are assuming their responsibilities at a time when, in the face of the escalation in Iraq and Syria, we hardly know how to respond. I really hope that the Foreign Ministers in the European Union will finally recognise that good European foreign and security policy can only be achieved together and that the eternal dispute over where competence lies has brought us into this very weak situation today. (Applause)

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, as Mr Juncker presents his new Commission this morning he is telling us that they are all in the last chance saloon. Well, I tell you what, Mr Juncker, I will come and see you there, but you are going to have to introduce me to them because this is very much a bunch of nonentities, unknown. I spoke to MEPs this morning who will be voting later, and most of them could not even name half of them. The one from Britain is so obscure that his name is Lord Hill but it should be Lord ‘Who?’! The British public could not pick the bloke out of a line-up! He has never been elected to anything in his life – which means he is perfect for the job.  I do not think that the European public or commentators understand what the European Commission really is. The Commission is the executive. It is the government of Europe and it has the sole right to propose legislation. It does so in consultation with 3 000 secret committees, staffed mainly by big business and big capital, and all the legislation is proposed in secret. Once something becomes a European law, it is the European Commission itself which has the sole right to propose, repeal or change that legislation. The Community method which was championed this morning, the means by which the European Commission makes law and holds law, is actually the very enemy of the concept of democracy itself. It means that in any Member State there is nothing the electorate can do to change a single piece of European law. So we will be voting against the Commission today, not on the basis of the individuals, but on the basis of the fact that it is a fundamentally un-, in fact, anti-democratic form of government.  I suspect you are in for a tough time with this Commission. You are going to have the euro crisis which has not gone away and is going to get worse. You are also going to have the UK debate where it has now become unacceptable to the vast majority of British citizens for there to be total free movement of people extended to half a billion people to come to Britain. Mr Cameron masquerades as being an EU opponent, though I note this morning that the Conservatives are so brave that they are even going to abstain. I think this will be the last European Commission that governs Britain, because before the end of these five years we will be out of here.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr. President, dear ladies and gentlemen! Yesterday, you did not feel any sorrow when Mr Barroso was adopted. And today there is no joy in Mr Juncker being enthroned with his Commission. I can explain to you why this is the case: because both Barroso and Juncker are not candidates of the European family of nations, neither are candidates of the hearts of the peoples of Europe, and because both represent the minimum consensus of the European nomenclature and therefore, in our view, cannot have the appropriate legitimacy. Mr Juncker, what if you said ' you have to lie when things get serious'? And, Mr Juncker, what is it like when you said: 'You are continuing to move the train of centralisation and you are waiting to see if there is not enough resistance from the population, and then you move on'? I can tell you that we reject you as a person, we reject your Commission. We reject it because it is not sufficiently democratically legitimised, and we also reject it because many people are intertwined with economic and industrial interests. And if we do that today and reject it, we are in favour of Europe and of the European family of nations.

name: Herbert REUL
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for his Some speeches expose themselves. There is nothing more to say about this. It's just embarrassing. There are speeches in this House that make me think. Speeches, as the GUE or the Greens are talking about today, which basically require a Commission to present 100% of its own party programme, a Commission that is staffed by all the Member States. It is hard to understand how such standards can be applied. The question that arises is whether this Commission has an idea, in terms of occupation and concept, for how to deal with the problems in Europe in these difficult times. I find it interesting and courageous to tackle a new structure. Nor do I know whether this idea works 100%. But this is at last an attempt to get more effectiveness into the work of the Commission. Finally, there is someone who is not just swearing about the need to concentrate on doing what is important and essential and perhaps leaving the details to the Member States. Everyone has been chatting about this for years. Now it is finally being documented in the form of a structure, in the form of a Vice-President. But, of course, President Juncker, we also want to see action. That's clear. We also want to see the results afterwards. But the structure offers the opportunity. And it is a Commission – and I think this is very interesting and exciting, and much more support would have to be organised for this – with weaknesses and strengths. All people are never equal, but it focuses on the issues that are crucial for the future of the people of Europe. That is the reality of the people. Let's do something! Let us create something that improves living conditions, that working conditions improve, that growth is created. What is the point of these sayings from all these programmes if they are not effective? That is why it is right to say that we must look carefully at where we are having an effect and by what means. That is why it is right to say that we cannot organise a straw fire, simply burn the money, but it must have an effect. That is why we need to consider whether the money we are already spending is always spent correctly and effectively. That is why it is also right that, of course, austerity must be at the beginning. If you're constantly wasting your money, you'll have no chance of designing. It is also right that priorities are being set – and I have been talking about this far too little today – in research, innovation and shaping the future. That is why it is right to argue with the Council about where these priorities should be made in the future. I find it annoying that savings are being made in the 2015 budget, and particularly in the field of research. That is nonsense. We are all talking about innovation and investment. Yes, investment must take place in this area. The Socialist Group has just said that Nobel laureates are increasingly coming from Europe. Do you also know where they are being promoted? At our European institutions. I think it's a great attempt. He deserves support, not stupid talk.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for his excellent work. It is a serious phrase to speak of the 'Commission of last chance'. But it's a correct sentence. We wish this Commission the last chance, we wish it success, but above all we wish it sincerity and courage. This offer of cooperation can only work if we approach each other with sincerity and courage. Sincerity means that we must pronounce things as they are, and we must put an end to the beauty of the situation. No, we will not be in a much better economic situation in the next three years, because the last seven years have cost us so much that the efforts must be longer-term. But we have to start now. Mr Juncker, do not let this course for more investment be turned away! Nor do you be persuaded that these efforts can only be made with the least effort. On the contrary, you have to measure them by the maximum result and the most productive way around the resources, but not the least effort. We must put an end to this policy of white ointment, which constantly lies about the situation without effectively addressing the problems. You have our support for this, and we wish you luck. This is a support that does not exclude anyone who is also happy to call for everyone in this House to be able to take part, if you all realize that it is indeed the last chance that Europe has. We want to work in this spirit!

name: Ryszard Antoni LEGUTKO
text: Mr President, there was a lot in President Juncker’s presentation which I found interesting, but I am slightly confused at the same time. On the one hand, Mr Juncker, you were preaching flexibility, and on the other hand you were advocating discipline. On the one hand you were urging to strengthen the Community method, and on the other you were defending the nation states and the autonomy of the nations. Now, I am a simple minded man. I believe that if you take one, you cannot have the other. If you have the other, you cannot have the first. The world is logical, and political programmes should also be logical; this should not violate the laws of logic. I would be grateful for some enlightenment on this.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: Mr President, I would like to say to Mr Juncker that ALDE will support his European Commission, but Mr Juncker, let us be clear, we support you in the vote today; that does not mean that you will have a blank cheque for the next five years. Our support is not automatic and you will have to work very hard to get our support for every single proposal that you put forward. But you will get our support for anything taking Europe forward, making it more democratic, more efficient and better able to act and to face the challenges and the crises of today. We need to get out of the economic crisis, but Europe also needs to take up its responsibility on the world stage. For that we need a strong European Commission. ALDE voters went to the ballot box for a stronger, better, different and reformed European Union. We want better regulation, yes. But better regulation in our view does not mean dismantling the achievements of the European Union. The voters on the right side of the House – there are very few people left there – they also want a change; they want to dissolve the European Union. That is not the solution proposed by ALDE, but we do want Europe to move, and I would be very worried to see a so-called Große Koalition, which seems to be a paralysing embrace leading to stagnation and status quo. Europe needs to move. We have talked a lot about the economy, about foreign affairs, about an energy union – lots of concrete things – but I have heard very little about values. Values are not a side issue. They are actually the essence, the core, of European integration and if we want to operate as a political union now we need a community of citizens based on shared values. So I expect initiatives for stronger instruments to promote and protect democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. But we also expect better enforcement if these values are under pressure in one of the Member States and I am looking in particular to Mr Timmermans, your, let us say, Prime Minister, who will be in charge of this task. So Mr Juncker, today, you have our support and you will find us at your side – if you take Europe forward.

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: Thank you, Mr President, you have appointed as Commissioner for Energy, a man in business with the oil industries, and a person from the City should deal with financial transparency and the Vice-President of a government that has passed laws against press freedom as Commissioner for Culture.  We no longer know whether to criticize his choices or compliment his sense of humor. In particular, the case of Mr Navracsics, who admitted during the hearing his political responsibility for passing laws that are contrary to the fundamental values of the Union, is serious. That is why the Committee on Culture voted against, accepting many appeals from civil society. You ignored this vote and decided to confirm the choice through a gimmick. Mr Navracsics is still the wrong man in the wrong place, and you know that too, Mr President.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: Mr. President! Mr Juncker, we all know that in recent years the more than strict economic policies of many countries, with the approval, support and demand of the troika, have been very hard hit on the citizens. At the same time, however, control of the states, apart from financial control, was invisible or weaker. What measures – not what words – do you and your Commission intend to take in the current mandate, where everything should end, to name and actively control those states that violate the fundamental rights or the laws and directives of this Parliament? Our institutions, including the European Commission, should be an example of democratic attitude.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Despite the different views on this Commission, I want to congratulate the new Commission and wish it a good job. I believe that the Commission will be approved and the new Commissioners will take up the work as soon as possible, because time and, what is particularly important, is not waiting for the problem. The Commission must work as one well-stringed instrument as a single team and pursue the common objective of bringing the European Commission's decisions and all the European Union's activities closer to citizens' expectations in all The European Union countries, including Lithuania. I recall J.-C. Juncker said: "We had to repair the burning plane during the flight, so sometimes we had to burn our fingers." I wish those finger burns were not an obstacle, but an incentive for successful work in the future. Today, it is essential that the new Commission focuses on investment in jobs, poverty reduction programmes, support for small and medium-sized businesses. The European Union should make more progress and move towards sustainable growth, job creation and poverty reduction. Another important point is a unified approach to problems, particularly on issues of unity in energy and foreign policy. There must be a common position between all the institutions and states of the European Union, as far as possible, because only in this way can we achieve the optimal desired result. I am particularly pleased and congratulated by The Commissioner Vytenis Povilis Andriukaite, appointed by Lithuania, and I wish him to join the joint team and to work successfully for the benefit of the European Union and Lithuania.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: It is impossible to set up a college of Commissioners capable of doing its job. Commissioners are ministers of the Union. There are no 28 isolated areas. Member States do not nominate for assignments. Most candidates have no prior experience in the field they're going to control. It is typical for a candidate deemed fit for one portfolio to be redirected to another area, and the relevant committees applaud how brilliantly prepared they are for stereotypical responses in five days. The whole procedure is tragicomic. It is not tragic because Commissioners do not actually have a decisive role to play in the most important decisions that define the Union. These most important decisions shall be made to the chairman of the committee at all times.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: First of all, I would like to congratulate President Juncker on the way in which he has chosen to set up the Commission and the principle that is to guide it in the course of its activities. It is very important to move away from fragmenting the portfolio of Commissioners. I also hope that it will pass the test with a task-oriented structure with the coordinating commissioners and the various portfolios of committee vice-chairs.  Mr President, I support your idea of combining the tasks of commissioners in an interdisciplinary way: energy and climate, industrial policy, entrepreneurship and the market – to at least name a few. The most important task that I have heard in your speech is to get out of the effects of the economic crisis (they are still being felt), namely to restore economic growth through investment, but not only, and the return of jobs to the Member States of the European Union, to the whole of the European Union, to maintain the free movement of people, because attempts are being made to restrict that freedom (we have also heard about it in this House today), or the full implementation of the Services Directive. , which can also have positive effects in economic development. Economic growth will not be possible without a rational energy and climate policy, which must be adapted to the development of the Member States on the basis of their own energy resources. The Ukrainian-Russian crisis shows that its own resources can be the basis of security. Many of us, including myself, are ardent supporters of the approach to legislative work under the banner of better regulation. It is untenable that the bodies holding the initiative and, consequently, the Parliament, are uncoordinated when draft directives or regulations overlap with areas already regulated.  Mr President, I will congratulate you if these objectives can be achieved by your Commission.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, Mr Juncker, there is an urgent need for you to be able to implement a number of commitments that you make before us. But if you make commitments, it means that you also agree to be put under surveillance for their implementation. That's where we'll be there. When you talked about this $300 billion plan, you indicated that you would present it with Mr. Katainen. It seems to us that your neighbour, your left hand or your right hand, depending on the day, Mr Frans Timmermans, will also have to be directly and fully committed to this $300 billion plan as a plan for a sustainable development strategy. In this plan, you wanted to promote the energy transition and we thank you for that. We are with you to do this, but we also need to think about a digital plan. If we are also in favour of a digital economy, we know that we will not make progress towards such an economy without directly, precisely, effectively touching on the issues of taxation in this area. When you make proposals to us on this $300 billion plan, take into account the investment gap that you have identified that leads you to put this proposal on the table, but also remember that there are other debates behind that $300 billion and that this $300 billion proposal cannot be paid for. Do not forget that it is also there because there are differences between the economies of the European Union, that this cannot be a plan with a logic of fair return, that it must be a plan to correct the asymmetries of the European economies, fatal for working together among peoples, and that everyone finds a reason to hope in the European project. I wish you the best of luck.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, Mr Juncker, I would like to thank the President for his work The major challenge for the new Commission is Europe's weak growth. This slowdown in growth is worrying, because Europe is on the brink of recession and deflation. They should think about why, because all the other countries in the world have now overcome the consequences of the financial crisis, except the eurozone. It is not only the crisis countries of the eurozone that are in trouble, but now – as you said – the world champion also has a lack of form. The world champion, you said, has to get used to the fact that he may not be well in the long run. And while you've been thinking about football, unfortunately it's the same for the economy. For Germany, Germany is now shrinking, France is shrinking, Italy is shrinking. The crisis has at the heart of the European Union, it has not been overcome. You should start to think about whether the eurozone crisis has something to do with the euro. Your words about the triple-A of the eurozone's social standard must sound like mockery in the ears of those who are unemployed in southern European countries. The promises that the euro will lead to growth and prosperity are worth as much as a junk bond, not as much as a triple-A. Since, like Mr Verhofstadt, you have only learned your economic recipes from John Maynard Keynes and seem to have learned nothing since the 1930s, all AfD MPs will vote against you today.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Mr President, despite the fact that some of the Commissioners-designate did not give an impressive and convincing performance, and also despite the fact that the transport portfolio has been reshuffled, somehow disrespecting the unanimous view of the Committee on Transport and Tourism – and I would have rather expected a redesign of Mr Navracsicsʼs portfolio – I have to say that we – I myself, my delegation and the ALDE Group – will vote in favour of Mr Junckerʼs Commission.  But, Mr Juncker, I do expect that your Commission will use the right of initiative and that it will be independent – unlike the previous one – from the Member States. I also expect that you will have the courage to demand reforms – structural reforms – from the Member States, that you will take the initiative, that you will have the courage and that you will provide leadership, which is precisely something that we have missed in the past. Now may I refer, very briefly, to Mr Timmermans? I am very happy that this position has been established and that better regulation is high on your agenda. Apart from what you yourself have said, this will provide for growth so that we will need less burdensome regulation in the future and more common policies. So good luck and ʽbon courageʼ.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: Mr President, Mr Juncker, with this programme and this College of Commissioners, the markets can rest assured: they will continue to rule in the corridors of the Commission.  Mr Juncker presented as its main objective to have a social triple A in the European Union. It is still surprising that he only spoke of unemployment in the 34th minute of his speech and only for 30 seconds. You have dedicated 30 seconds to the biggest problem in the European Union. It's very significant.  Mr Juncker says his main asset is to have four former prime ministers and nineteen former ministers: that is, 23 of the 28 Commissioners come directly from governments, come directly from the Council to the Commission. We already knew that the Council had colonised the European institutions, but it is regrettable that, by its hand, the Council is making a hostile takeover of the European Commission. Mr Juncker, in the economic portfolios you promise nothing but the continuation of the disastrous policy for the peripheries of the euro zone. Mr. Juncker, your Triple A Social Commission has a new brand, but the brand does not match the product, it is just misleading advertising.

name: Claude TURMES
text: Mr. President! Jean-Claude, if we Greens vote 'no' to your Commission today, then that should also make you think. Between July – when many of us voted for you – and October, there was a breach of trust on four points: your U-turn on TTIP. The fact that in your European Semester there is no environmental at all. The fact that Frans Timmermans is ridiculing himself about vacuum cleaners without knowing that eco-design is the most unbureaucratic directive that promotes the internal market the most and has the greatest efficiency mass that we have in Europe. Fourthly, where should I, where should we, take the confidence that your Commission will go beyond this ridiculously low 27% efficiency and 7% renewable energy, which the Heads of State will unfortunately decide on under the veto pressure of Cameron and Poland? I would be pleased if this breach of trust could be a little tickled in your response.

name: Laura AGEA
text: Mr Juncker, do you realise which Europe is being handed over to you today? A Europe on its knees! A Europe with seven and a half million unemployed young people, where thousands of companies have been forced to close down and where those who have been left without certainty have even taken their own lives. These are the results of disastrous austerity policies that your predecessor pursued for a decade. This should already be enough to put an stop to these criminal policies, and instead you who have made us sick also claim to cure us. But the disease is you! I appeal to you Italian colleagues, with what courage you dare to give your confidence to those who want to insist on these failed therapies! You know the situation in our country and I wonder how you can look the citizens in the eye to whom they have taken everything away: health, pensions, work, social benefits and dignity. I appeal to your conscience. I know, you do not really want such a Europe either, and so, like me, say it loud and clear: no more no! here and now!

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: Mr President, you built the prison in which we are. For 25 years, you, with the highest offices, have collaborated in the economic disaster in which we are and someone gives you a statesman.
