I have one minute to represent millions of European citizens who are damaged by this European Union, which is making the wrong wars, which has the wrong currency, which does not defend Made in Italy, which responds to the interests of Freemasonry, banking and finance, and every day we realise this. It seems to me that this Commission will bring to an end what is a wrong experiment: an obsebrious, a monster, a suicide. I therefore wish you to work as well as you have done over the last 25 years in the roles you have held and quickly, because the more you and your Commission work well and quickly, the more the peoples of Europe will regain their freedom, identity, future, currency, pride and hope that we can look to tomorrow without there being 28 strangers deciding for them.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to remind you that the vote on 25 May sent a clear message and that the challenges facing us, which await the European Union and its Member States, are indeed crucial, and you, Mr President, will have the task of leading a legislature that cannot be routine. But in your words I have always felt that you were fully aware of this, because you immediately made the subject of growth and employment a priority of your programme and you spoke of the social dimension of Europe, and that is why we have given you our confidence from the outset and today we are once again focusing on this courage. , which you have once again stated today that you have and want to have. You have also given the sense that the times are not a minor variable, and that is why you said and reiterated that you will present the investment programme together with Vice-President Katainen before Christmas, and that is also why we will be with you to push the times as well.  You have spoken about many issues, but I would like to dwell for a moment on immigration. As an Italian and as an Italian, you can imagine how much we share your desire to make immigration one of the key points and among the priorities. Tragedies such as those in Pozzallo, tragedies such as those in Lampedusa cannot and must not be repeated. But it must be a European story, it cannot be a regional story. Please, your Commission will return to look to the Mediterranean more forcefully. He said: can we bring our citizens closer to Europe? Can we drastically reduce unemployment, give young people prospects, deal with the major issues? We have to do it or it will be a failure. Europe deserves all this. Our citizens deserve it, our people deserve it. Let us return to having a Europe proud of its historical identity, of our unmistakable cultural heritage, of our model of integration, of a community based on the rule of law, of a social market economy. In the name of all this, Mr President, I wish you well in your work.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: Mr President, today Europe is at a crossroads and in our hands is the way out. The decisions that have been taken in recent years to get out of the crisis have not solved the problems and added unjust suffering to millions of men and women. It would be unforgivable not to change; would be an unacceptable mistake. You, Mr Juncker, you and your College of Commissioners today have a historic responsibility to lead a project that changes things: a Europe whose only work programme is not austerity, but bets on smart growth, which invests time and resources to meet fundamental challenges. We are talking about job creation because in countries like mine millions of people who have stopped believing in this project have been desperately desperated. We are talking about a sustainable Europe, compatible with an industrial policy that supports entrepreneurs in Europe. We are talking about a Europe that does not accept both speeds, inequalities or imbalances, that does not allow the unprotection of workers and those who have been unfairly expelled from the system. You are going to have the confidence of this House today — to be honest, not my vote — but what your Commission has to gain is the trust of the public, of those outside this Parliament, and for that, Mr Juncker, you must change policies and you must return social Europe to citizens.

name: Jørn DOHRMANN
text: Mr President! We recognise that the President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, has done in many of his speeches and speeches a great deal to meet the eurosceptic parties in this House and to underline the need for less EU and less bureaucracy, but unfortunately we do not see these intentions reflected sufficiently in the task description and composition of the new Commission. In May's elections, the People of Europe sent a strong message calling for change, demands for a much more decentralised and easier European Union. But where do we see this actually reflected in the division in the new Commission of new portfolios and work plans? All we are seeing is new steps in a federal direction, whether we are talking about the new banking union or about the new centralisation of the competence of countries in economic, labour market or asylum policy. That is why we, as the Danish People's Party, have to vote against the new Commission.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: Mr President, we will give you our confidence. It will be demanding and impatient because Europeans are waiting for concrete results. But you have assets: a great experience, a European conviction that has never wavered and real political legitimacy. However, it will also take character and courage to make Europe a space for political will to form. That is what is at stake. This requires a vision that heads of state or government too often lack. The vision of a Europe that finally deals with the big issues and decides to weigh in the world, to defend its interests and to act for its economic and social development. It will also require, as you have mentioned, a new institutional practice, a return to the Community method, with a Commission which, I hope and I am sure, will finally take over all its right of initiative. Mr President, like you, we want Europe to succeed. That is the whole sense of trust that we will give you.

name: João FERREIRA
text: Mr President, despite the scarcity of rhetoric about a supposed new cycle, a truth emerges as crystal clear and transparent: this Commission is the daughter of the same political families who formed and supported the Barroso Commission. There is no change here, if not face - and even there, not all. There's only continuity. Continuity in policies that violate fundamental human rights, in never-before-seen unemployment, in intolerable levels of poverty, in growing inequalities. Continuity in structural reforms aimed at levelling down living and working conditions in Europe. Continuity in favourof large economic groups – those whose representative organisations always anticipate in their strategic documents what will become the legislative production of the European Commission. Continuity in the attack on democracy and the will of the peoples.  This Commission is associated with all the worst we have experienced in recent years. This Commission is past, not future. Only the will, mobilization and struggle of workers and peoples can break with this continuity and force real change.

name: José BOVÉ
text: Mr President, today I am surprised. You spoke for almost 46 minutes and you did not say a word about the future of agriculture or the future of farmers. This is a real problem: agriculture is the first budget of the European Union and today it is no longer part of the discourse on the future of Europe. Farmers are threatened by free trade treaties and the end of milk quotas; the most serious crisis is likely to be experienced in the coming months. At the same time, food is threatened. It is true that in July you talked about GMOs. I believe that a clear policy is needed in this area as well. At the same time, we are trying to impose on consumers new products, nanotechnologies in the diet, titanium in yoghurts to make them whiter. Do we need that? I believe that Europe must be strong and that the aim of the European Commission, if it wants to reconnect with citizens, must be to defend both their daily lives, through food, but also the future of our territories, with the peasants.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the 5-star Movement does not intend to give this Commission any kind of blank confidence in broad agreements. You have managed to keep some Commissioners in their place despite a negative opinion of the relevant parliamentary committees. I am referring to Navracsics, to whom you have changed your portfolio by maquillage and left it in its place. We expected at least a new Commissioner and a new hearing.  What is more, all this has happened in institutional silence and the choice was taken behind closed doors very quickly and even now it is not well for whom. That is unacceptable! The citizens of Europe must know this. The Commissioners' hearings must not be merely a bridge to give a semblance of democracy to choices already made elsewhere. This detracts from the role of this Parliament and of democracy as a whole. The Commissioner for Culture, Education and Youth cannot be a person who has been the inspiration for illiberal reforms in his country.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, we will shortly be called on to ratify the election of the Commissioners of the European Union. We all know that the role of the Commissioner is very important, because he is called upon to implement the European Union's programme and its policy on the subject in which he is headed and the issues of which he coordinates. However, the way in which the Commissioner is selected and elected is not at all flattering to the MEP. What is true: MEPs are simply participating in a formal procedure in which the Commissioner has been chosen by the country in cooperation with the President of the European Commission and then we are simply asked to vote for him or not. We are therefore taking part in a formal procedure which we cannot influence and which we cannot intervene in. This would be done if there were at least two candidates for each post. That is what we are suggesting and until that is done, we will simply have the illusion that we are participating in a process in which we cannot exert any influence.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: Mr President, Mr Juncker, Europe is at a crossroads. It has to be idealistic, but pragmatic at the same time. It has to be austere, but boost growth at the same time. It has to fight climate change, but re-industrialize at the same time. It has to open up to the world, but protect yourself at the same time. It has to compete with emerging economies, but defend the welfare state at the same time. Europe must remain Europe in a universe that is no longer European.  Today you are committed to Parliament to try to resolve this equation and you will have a large majority. Only right-wing and left-wing extremists, those who want to leave the European Union before five years pass, and those who come to Europe will continue to do national politics. In short, they're going to stay out the ones who always want to stay out. You will chair a strong Commission, a Commission voted by the citizens, a centre Commission, a moderate Commission. And it will be up to you to solve that equation: how to continue to comply with stability pacts and how to grow at the same time. From Spain, many Members will support you, but we will ask you as representatives of the Spaniards to create jobs, especially for young people; don't forget the farmers, who are now paying for a foreign policy that they have not done as a result of the Russian veto; that there is a common immigration policy, because irregular immigration is a common problem; and that there are energy interconnections to save citizens from expensive energy and that it might not come. You will count on the collaboration of Miguel Arias Cañete, who knows very well the Spanish problems, who is a great defender of Spain and who, if he ever has any doubts, can ask him. Mr Juncker, the alternatives are not to continue to dream about Europe or to wake up scared. Waking up scared is not the alternative to the European dream. Dreaming Europe is the only way, it is the only opportunity, it is the only way out. I come from a land called Valencia and there we tell those who start a navigation: "Good wind and new boat!". Your luck is everyone's luck.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: Mr President, on behalf of Labour’s MEPs, I would like to congratulate Mr Juncker on his efforts in putting together his Commission team. Mr Juncker, I have to say, however, that I thought your initial decision to move medicines and medical devices to the industry portfolio was completely unacceptable. People’s health must come first, so I am delighted that you have listened to our concerns and reversed your decision. Mr Juncker, I am sure you are aware of the magnitude of the job facing your Commission: with a Europe still struggling to create jobs and growth; a Europe still faced with the consequences of climate change; a Europe where people are turning their backs on mainstream politics in favour of the extremes. It is easy to see why many people say the EU is in crisis. This Commission has the opportunity to turn the tide – to take a different approach – so here are a few suggestions. Revise the Posting of Workers Directive and stop the exploitation of migrant workers and the undercutting of local pay and conditions. Take action to protect people from the scourge of precarious employment practices such as zero-hours contracts. Tackle excessively high energy prices across the EU. And get our young people into work. Mr Juncker, this Commission cannot just defend the status quo. Europe is a force for good in the world but it could be so much better. It will need leadership and courage to make the change we need. That is the challenge. Mr Juncker, are you up for it?

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: President Juncker, we will not support your Commission because it simply has a federalist agenda that is contrary to our agenda.  You want a European prosecutor, you want harmonisation of corporate taxes, you want a tax on financial transactions, you want the redistribution of migrants and other things that we simply cannot accept, and I think it shows what a mistake it was when the governments of the Member States had the European Parliament steal the right to nominate the President of the European Commission and accede to the Spitzenkandidaten system, because then it always turns out that European political parties choose someone from their centre , some old structure like you, which leans on a comfortable majority of European people and European socialists, and nothing changes, no reform will come.  I have every reason to be pessimistic, and I am afraid that your Commission will unfortunately be worse than the Barroso Commission, and therefore we cannot support it.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: Mr President, Mr Juncker, your College of Commissioners is a provocation. Perhaps because he already knew that popular and socialists would put his chair before the interests of citizenship. Environment and energy will be treated by those who in the past have favoured, even in their private businesses, polluting industries and climate deterioration. Economics will be the fiercest supporters of austerity, job precariousness and the commodization of the public. And as in Spain, this agenda will prevail against democracy itself, rewarding authoritarianism with portfolios of civil liberties. Debating with their candidates I have noted their fidelity to the neoliberal framework they impose on us, accusing us of being out of the system — of their system, Mr Juncker — for defending alternatives for the people and for the needs of the people. For you, economics comes down to competitiveness, and political, governance. His language is corrosive and misleading. It cannot be the market that says whether there will be employment or peace or justice: it will be up to the people to decide. That is why we defend the interests of the majority, so we will vote 'no' on this Commission.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: The citizens want peace and prosperity, but what does this Commission want? Take away citizens' pensions and tax savings. There must be no more European integration, but less. The citizens want peace and prosperity, but what does this Commission want? The EU's imperialism has no borders at the expense of our security. There should be no more countries in the EU, but from the EU. The citizens want peace and prosperity, but what does this Commission want? EU travel agencies in North Africa to bring in even more money seekers with their barbaric Islamic culture. Murder, rape and violence have become normal in our cities thanks to open borders. We do not need external borders, but national borders, as is also required by United Nations Resolution 2178. The European Union has failed, but this Commission is continuing on the path of salvation. I ask you: step up and make way for people who start dismantling.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: Mr President, I was pleased to see this morning the presentation of a very strong Commission with a new approach, reinventing a new way of working efficiently. I particularly welcome the appointment of the Vice-President responsible for better regulation, because we badly need a cross-sectoral evaluation of the impact of our policies on EU competitiveness.  This is a critical moment for Europe, we all know that, and I would like to say to Commission President Mr Juncker that with his ambitious programme – which I wholeheartedly support – he has raised very high expectations and hope for us and for our citizens. I am glad to see, Mr Juncker, that your ambitions for Europe match the challenges we are facing. You and your team will be holding tremendous responsibilities to carry Europe back onto the path of growth and to win the trust of our citizens in the common European project.  The jobs, growth and investment package which you said you will present shows that we are on the right path. I have long advocated the wider use of financial instruments to stimulate private investment in the real economy. With the current public financing capacities we need to be more focused and more efficient. We need a change of paradigm in financing. Only this will allow us to raise the necessary investment.  A word on one priority announced, and there is no need to say how important the digital single market is for stimulating growth and creating employment in our economy. However, infrastructure is not the main challenge in this area. The challenge is to find the right incentives for companies to invest in their infrastructure and this depends on the regulatory framework, which is now outdated and has to be modernised to find the right balance between players and the right incentives.  I wish you good luck in the next five years.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Juncker Commission and Commissioners, I would like to tell you that you will soon receive support from our group for your Commission. However, I can also inform you that this has not been an easy exercise. We have had a lot of discussion and a lot of thought has been given to it. But you have redrawn your Commission a little and you have also said important things this morning that give us confidence, confidence in your team. As you know, for our group, another Europe is important, a Europe where we can invest back in people, in jobs, in our economy. But I would also like to inform you that not just every investment and not just any progress is enough for us. That is why it was so important to put sustainable development at the highest level, among one of the most important Commissioners – with your own, of course. Sustainable development that has to do with investing in the right place, at the right time. In other words, the 2030 energy package, in other words, the Lisbon Strategy; these are important tools for investing in sustainability. Secondly, Mr Juncker, sustainability is not only about ecology, but also about people. It is not just every job that is important to us, but jobs that provide workers with an income at the end of the month. We want a Europe where people are not played off against each other, but together we want to ensure social prosperity. That is sustainable development for us. As far as we are concerned, this is included in the core of the policy of the next Commission. Good luck, you're on your own!

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, this new Commission certainly has some positive aspects. I am thinking of the Brussels regulatory burden, which is tired of many citizens and businesses. Mr Juncker is responding well to this by giving his First Vice-President the task of using the knife. It is also true, Mr President, that the Minister, who for many years has been violating the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact, is being restricted by two colleagues. Yes, I am referring here to the French Commissioner. And in the Juncker team, I meet a few star players such as Mr Timmermans, such as the Commissioner for Agriculture and, like the English Commissioner. Those are positives. Nevertheless, Mr President, I cannot support the Juncker team and I will abstain because Mr Juncker's programme is 'more Europe, more monetary union and a rigid commitment to the euro'. Moreover, Mr President, a number of commissioners in the team are simply too weak. I have already mentioned the French Commissioner, but I also think that the matter concerning the Transport Commissioner has gone unwisely. Therefore, an abstention from the Dutch delegation in the ECR Group.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: Mr President, Mr Juncker, there are phrases left for history. Mr Barroso's yesterday was: "We have emerged from the crisis", a phrase typical of the theatre of absurdity. His phrase for the story has been: "I can't change sex in the short term." I would recommend that you do not joke about these things, and if not, ask your friend Cañete about the consequences. But I'm going to pick up the joke to convey an impression: I see you lazy in feminist readings, Mr Juncker. If you had read Simone de Beauvoir, you would know that gender is a cultural construct; if you had read Judith Butler, you would know that gender is a problem of performativity. I make you a performance proposal, Mr Juncker: come dressed as a woman next time to the European Parliament and convince Mr Cañete to do the same! It is the most radical thing you will be able to do because, in the light of your speech and in the light of your document, expecting something from your Commission is like waiting for Godot.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the new European Commission will continue, like the previous one, with unrelenting intensity the attack on the people. The European Union is a union of capital, so its institutions, their mission and functioning, regardless of persons, mark labour rights and serve business groups and their greater profitability each time. The appointment of the new Commission was also made through haggling and competition that has nothing to do with labour interests. The programme declarations, like the hearings of the Commissioners, are monuments to the promotion of the anti-labour policy of the European Union's memorandums of understanding.  The Communist Party of Greece is voting against the new European Commission and is calling on the people, without any delay, to organise the fight for immediate recovery of losses, to set out a path of development that serves their interests in conflict with the European Union and monopolies.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Mr President, Mr Juncker, in the title of your programme you have focused on democratic change. I believe that we can already congratulate you on the great step forward that we have taken for European democracy with the procedure that led to your election. But more democratic legitimacy for the Commission implies more expectations on the part of the citizens and I would like to emphasise four challenges for the future college. First of all, yes to a more political and effective Commission, but yes, above all, to a more coherent Commission. That each Commissioner no longer works in his corner implies greater coherence between the internal and external policies of the Union. Common policies, better coordination and solidarity between the Member States: all this is valid to meet the challenge of the Energy Union as well as that of our foreign policy. Secondly, a comprehensive approach to migration, as you put it forward, involves genuine migration diplomacy, as well as a migration policy based on increased dialogue and cooperation with countries of origin and transit, particularly with the countries of the southern Mediterranean. Because we need to anticipate and tackle fundamental issues, such as insecurity or youth unemployment. It also means strengthening a smart visa policy that can serve our economic objectives. Thirdly, there is an urgent need to remove the feeling that there are different categories of European citizens. In this regard, Mr Juncker, I would ask you to confirm your support for the entry of Bulgaria and Romania into the Schengen area, and to defend relentlessly the principle of the free movement of people. Finally, there is the issue of equality between men and women. Bulgaria has nominated a woman, Kristalina Georgieva, for the post of Commissioner and we are proud of her ability to work and her qualities. But today we are talking about economic growth and it will not happen without the economic potential of women. We are therefore counting on you and your college to finally encourage and enable the realization of this economic potential of women.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: Mr President, you are coming with a very strong legitimacy, so we can come with a powerful idea for Europe. I believe that we need a European new deal to relaunch growth and sustainable development. Europe remains indeed the best promise of sustainable development, democracy and citizenship, but we must recognise that we are confronted with important divergences now. So I believe that we really need to have an inspiring vision for the next phase of the Europe 2020 Strategy for growth and jobs, paving the way for the future – for more and better jobs. But we need to make sure that all Member States do have the conditions to implement such a strategy, and that is why we need this new deal. Fiscal discipline certainly; but the top priority should now be growth. We should have reforms, but above all we need to have investments for the future, and for this we need to have stronger instruments: not only the EIB and structural funds, but fiscal capacity and banking union. We need to complete the economic and monetary union.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: Mr President, what Europe needed in a new Commission was a change in direction; certainly across the Member States the people demanded that change in last May’s elections. The people of Europe, I would say to Mr Juncker, want and deserve an end to the austerity agenda, an end to the conservative, regressive and undemocratic policies that underpin the EU today. They want a social Europe that protects public services, that invests in sustainable jobs for our young people and reinvigorates the regions and rural communities.  What is on offer today instead is more of the same. Forget about the personalities involved, this Commission is representative of the old boys’ club that is intent on continuing the socially regressive, undemocratic Europe that has become disengaged from the communities and the citizens it claims to serve. Sinn Fein MEPs will be voting against the College because we want a fair Europe in which Member States work together on matters of mutual interest, rather than the two-tier, unequal Europe that is represented by this Commission.

name: Iveta GRIGULE-PĒTERSE
text: The Commission will be approved today. This will not be the best nor the worst Commission in the history of the European Union. We will confirm both bright candidates and less brilliant ones. Bright from countries such as Estonia, Lithuania, Poland, Italy – and also less skilled.  It is important for me, as a representative of Latvia, that the Commission be approved, because in two months' time the Latvian Presidency of the European Union will begin, and our government needs a partner with all the powers in Brussels to speak to.  And only for the two new Commissioners, I would like to say the way of saying that the Commissioner for Agriculture would want to want to put an end to the discriminatory policy towards the new Member States after 5 years, including the Baltic farmers, who receive 3 to 4 times less direct payments than the old Member States, and the Commissioner for Regional Development, who herself comes from Romania and perfectly understands that reducing inequalities between European regions is the most important task of these five years. I will vote in favour of the Commission.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Katharina von Siena has already said: it is not the beginning that is rewarded, but only perseverance. Nevertheless, the start of this Commission is a sign of hope. We have the most democratically legitimate President of the Commission and therefore the most independent. He presents us with a structure of the Commission, which offers the chance that the Commission will become a government, it will become more efficient, it will take political responsibility and that the projects will be put before national interests. We in Parliament, as political groups, and the Council, have to adapt to this working methodology of projects and cooperation and also to initiate reforms. We are faced with a President of the Commission who wants to make policy and is prepared to take responsibility with his Commission. His message is clear. I would ask you to listen and read and not to insinuate negative things at the beginning. This Commission is a Commission of the eco-social market economy. It is one that supports investment that the EU wants to make a global player, reduces energy dependency, reduces IT dependency, develops the internal market and sees growth and competitiveness as an activity of social cohesion. However, I would also ask you not to forget one thing: communication and information. Citizens need to know what we are doing and when and why. Therefore, this project must be above everything else. Best wishes!

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Mr President, we shall be voting for a Commission that fully assumes its political responsibility as a government, that lives on more democracy, because the choice you mentioned to listen to the voters' vote for us is only the beginning of a popular investiture process, which must be the option for completing the European project.  The relationship with Parliament will be crucial: here the Commission will have to work together on its programmes, it will have to be accountable and accountable and listen to the voice of the Europeans who speak here. We ask you to reverse the relationship between politics and technocracy in comparison with the past: politics decides, chooses and points a way. Technocracy is no longer used to say that it cannot be done, but is used to explain how it should be possible to do it. You know our priorities: the investment plan with fresh resources, a smart and reassuring use of flexibility. In short, growth and employment.  Really show us that you have understood the lesson, which comes from these years of political incapacity, lack of ambition, of strength that Europe has had in the face of the crisis, in the face of 18 million unemployed, of short-sightedness and stubborn rigour. I can say, even leaving the ECB alone to have courage. Your programme must say that change can be made. In Italy, we won the European elections with a project of change: that change can be made, that inequalities must grow, that inequalities must be combated and eliminated because democracy is made up of rights, fairness and solidarity. Our vote, Mr President, was not a foregone conclusion and is not obligatory. But it is a thoughtful and conscious choice, as you know, it is an investment to realise that vision of Europe that has been lacking, it is a fair and inflexible challenge.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Mr. President, I want to congratulate you, Mr Juncker, for the composition of the Commission, I want to congratulate you on the ambitious Commission, on the vision you have. I also see that you should have made a number of compromises, but I also see that you will lead the Commission uncompromisingly. You will rebuild bridges after the crisis, as you said, and restore trust to European citizens.  You also said that you would not develop the European Union at the expense of countries, national Member States. I like that approach a lot. You also mentioned Mr. Barroso's Commission as a success, during whose tenure 13 countries entered the European Union. Among them is Croatia, my country and I am very glad that in relation to enlargement you have set up so that Mr. Hahn who is very experienced will be commissioner for enlargement. Also Mrs Mogherini, this is very important to us and we are very interested in the attitude towards traffic, towards the Adriatic-Ionian corridor and also towards the Trans-Adriatic pipeline. These are very important topics when it comes to Southeast Europe.  I also applaud this part when you talk about gender equality. You said and I quote, "This is not a luxury, but an obligation of all European politicians." So not only in your Commission, but at all levels, administrative and political in the Commission, we expect more women, I believe you will deliver. I would like to tell you that this Commission should make the citizens of Europe live better. Let your investment program succeed. I am convinced that you will increase the number of jobs and that you will reduce youth unemployment, which I think is a key topic of the European Union.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: Thank you very much. Dear President Juncker, future Commissioners and Commissioners, the new European Commission is composed. The combination was complex, grue-lymous, unpredictable. In the end, it is also very stressful because of the Slovenian candidate, for which I am sorry. However, I believe that this was an in-house lesson, both for my country and for the European Commission, and a clear signal that the choice of commissioner requires wisdom. The European Commissioner is not only a politician, he is not only an expert, he is not only a visionary, he is a combination of all of this. True value gives him viability, judgment and determination. The Commission before us is not ideal. It reflects the compromise that we are capable of at the moment. Nevertheless, I hope that it has the majority of Commissioners being personally and socially accountable and that they are willing to work hard to create a home for Europeans in which we feel valued, safe and desirable.  For this was also the basic message of the European electorate. We remain committed to parliamentarians, so we will be working well with the commission. You are the team that plans our future and the future of our children, and never forget it. We do not want just likeable words from you, Mr Juncker, and we do not want to ask the team. We want proposals that we will support with a peaceful conscience and an awareness that we are once again propelling the European train to the hill of success. I wish you the best of luck. Thank you very much.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: Mr President, dear Mr Juncker, both in your speech on 15 July and today you have shown that you have great ambitions. I agree and fully endorse. To this end, we will support you personally and the Commission with all our might. We want a more and better Europe. We want to enlarge and deepen our democratic institutions.  Mr President, the European Union is an incomplete organisation, both economic and political. If the United States has gone through the global crisis at the lowest possible cost, it is because it has a federal budget six times larger than that of the European Union. They may print at the time of the crisis even a little inflationary money. They have the federal bonds, we have nothing. We do not even have a policy of printing a bill of one and two euros.  But also at the political level, what is our effectiveness in the ukraine issue? What is the effectiveness for Kobani in the Syrian and Iraqi crisis? What is our effectiveness in the aggression of Turkey's violation of the Exclusive Economic Zone of Cyprus? Is it or is it not the Exclusive Economic Zone of the Member States Exclusive Economic Zone of the European Union? For all these challenges, for all these difficulties we stand by you and will help you with all our strength.

name: Paul TANG
text: Mr President, I would like to welcome Mr Juncker and his team. I have one minute and will only make one point. The new Commission, the team Juncker, can push Europe in the right direction, towards the hearts and minds of Europeans – our voters – by making Europe more social, green and transparent. But to do that and push in the right direction Europe must get out of the muddling-through scenario of low growth and high unemployment. To do that, we need to get the European economy back on track. Increasing private and public investment is key – raising demand in the short term and improving the supply side in the longer term. That is why so many Social Democrats find the investment plan of EUR 300 billion crucial for the economy and for Europe. We do not doubt the good intentions of the Commission, but we are really disappointed by the lack of detail thus far. Only if the investment plans turn out to be real and substantial can the Commission continue to count on our cooperation. Good luck!

name: Esther de LANGE
text: Mr President, "la commission de la dernière chance" sounds a bit melodramatic, but I think the analysis is correct. Europe suffers from a lack of trust among many citizens. And it is up to this European Commission, together with the Council and the European Parliament, to restore that confidence by delivering and focusing on core tasks. The CDA in the European Parliament also wholeheartedly supports the First Vice-President whose task is to oversee this focus. As far as we are concerned, these core tasks are: a fair internal market, energize raw materials, food and energy, and that in a sustainable way, migration and much stronger speaking more one voice in the world. But the real core challenge ... Now I quote Jean-Luc Dehaene, in a free way, but I quote him and I want to honour him here, because unfortunately he lost us earlier this year. Jean-Luc Dehaene used to say, "The big question for Europe is: will it become a Buck kingdom, will it become an open-air museum, or do we succeed in maintaining the competitiveness of our economy?" If you know that European hands are never going to be as cheap as Chinese hands, Europe will have to be the continent that keeps reinventing itself through smart and sustainable solutions that keep those European hands at work. Growth and jobs, therefore, through smart and sustainable solutions, and – I say to Mr Tang – not by saddled future generations with sky-high debts. I do not want to be part of the generation of politicians who are now struggling to break down what the generation of my grandparents, my parents' parents, built in Europe. At a time when things are getting tough, Europe is worth fighting for. That's what I'm going to do for the next five years. And I don't expect you to be any different. I wish you every success.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: Mr President, Mr Juncker, the new Commission is born under the sign of change, it is also born under the sign of hope, of a new cycle of prosperity for the European Union. But it is also born in a very frustrating social and economic context. It is not clear that we can grow in the near future. It is clear today: the impoverished political model of the peoples of the south has a boomerang effect and is bringing stagnation to other European peoples.      That's why words aren't enough anymore. It takes concrete acts, something has to change. We need to put our man on the moon. We need to be a laboratory of the future and not a museum of the past.  You said you were going to mobilise €300 billion for the investment. You said where you were going to invest: broadband networks, energy networks, transport networks, education, research, innovation, renewable energy and energy efficiency.    Mr. Juncker, that's right, that's exactly what we have to do. We must position the European Union as a precursor to a new human face economy, capable of combining energy and information and capable of creating dignity and happiness for those who live in it.

name: Seán KELLY
text: A Uachtaráin, comhghairdeas don Choimisinéir agus do choláiste na gCoimisinéirí. Go n-éirí go geal libh sa dúshlán mór atá romhaibh agus romhainn amach.  Mr President, I would like to congratulate President Juncker on the way he has divided what could be an unwieldy bunch of 28 independent-minded Commissioners into an effective team. I think that is a good idea and, as a sportsman, I also welcome the fact that he has made sport a specific responsibility for Commissioner Navracsics. I would like to congratulate the Irish Commissioner, Phil Hogan, on being given the heavy responsibility of the agriculture portfolio, and I would ask President Juncker maybe to help him to reverse the decision of recent days to raid the emergency funds for farmers, as a result of the pressure put on them due to Russian sanctions, taking EUR 451 million and reducing it to a little over EUR 80 million. That is not acceptable. I also welcome your commitment, President Juncker, in relation to the EUR 300 billion and especially the involvement of the private sector, because it is private-sector entrepreneurs, rather than bureaucrats, who create jobs. With regard to trade, I would urge you particularly to place great emphasis on liquefied natural gas (LNG) terminals in Europe, in order to improve security and diversity of supply, and also on electricity interconnectors, which can be very effective, particularly using intermittent renewables. Lastly, I want to welcome your commitment to the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP). I would also ask you to ensure that the Comprehensive Trade and Economic Agreement (CETA) with Canada and the Singapore deal are brought to fruition as soon as possible. Mr Juncker, you have a very ambitious plan. Please make the plan a reality from the word go.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Mr Juncker, i would like to thank you for your comments. You have said with great grace that you are limiting your powers to other members of the Commission, but let me point out that this does not limit your responsibility. If anything goes wrong, you will probably be held accountable here. You have also made it clear that you are not a servant of Parliament, but I hope that you are a servant of society. This Parliament is an emanation of society. We therefore hope that Parliament will play a very important role in cooperation.  You have said that the world is not safe, that it is downright dangerous – and here we agree. You mentioned the Islamic Republic, you mentioned Ebola, and what do you think of our eastern border, because you have not said anything about it? Is what is happening behind the Eastern Border of the Union a safe world?  The third very important point is eur 300 billion. I am pleased that you are confirming this, but I would like to know more about the sources from? What about the financial transaction tax, what about the idea of project bonds, because we know more or less their purpose. I am pleased, however, that this will not become a method of increasing public debt. We will vote for you. Good luck.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: Mr President, dear President Jean-Claude Juncker, dear Commissioners designated, it is up to me to make the last scheduled speech this morning, and to that extent I will speak here, not as a Portuguese citizen, but as a European citizen. And what I would like to remind in this final speech to our President-designate, who will now see his College of Commissioners subject to a vote, is that he rests on the President and rests on all the Commissioners the responsibility of being for the first time a truly democratically entitled executive who has been subjected to an electoral act in which the presidential candidate appeared with a face and a partisan ID. , and that is such a responsibility at this point in which a new European cycle is starting that I would like you to be here to keep your responsibility recorded here.  I'm not asking you for anything else. I ask you to honor the vote of the European voters. Not the voters of Portugal, not the voters of Slovenia, not the voters of the Netherlands, not the voters of each country, but the voters who voted as Europeans and as European citizens in this act of 25 May so that you have government responsibilities.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: Mr President, on behalf of the PPE it is with great respect that I salute the new Commission and I hope that all of us here in the plenary will afterwards vote for this Commission. It has been a long road map since we started this. This is an elected Commission; this is different and many of us believe that we will now have a political future and that we are going to respond to the citizens.  This is the Commission we want. We will support you in your initiatives, in all the priorities that we all share here. I know that some of you do not, but you will feel how this is going to change the future and the unity of this European Union. This is starting today and I feel proud from the PPE family, from all my colleagues and also for those who are going to vote in favour of this new Commission and this new era under Jean-Claude Juncker.

name: Ana GOMES
text: Mr President, Mr Juncker, I will give you the benefit of the doubt, despite strong reservations about some of your Commissioners. We'll keep the Commission under surveillance.  In addition to the strategic investment plan for growth and jobs, we want to see the European Semester implemented with smart flexibility and solidarity, which requires surplus Member States such as Germany to cease ostrich policy and move towards mutualised debt management.  You come from a country that works, unfortunately, as an almost tax haven. That is why it has a special obligation to strive for an end to banking and shareholder secrecy and schemes such as Freeport Luxembourg, and to put its Commission to work against the tax jungle that today weakens Europe and encourages tax crime, money laundering, corruption and governance globally.  Good luck, Mr. Juncker!

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, I will vote against Mr Juncker and his Commission. The Commission that has just presented to us is a Commission in which the old political world of Europe is represented. Four former prime ministers, several former ministers, all those who are politically responsible for the poverty of Europe, for socialising the losses of the banks, for creating a huge army of unemployed people, for the Chineseisation of wages, for overcharging Greece with a huge shameful debt, so those who have failed now promise to save Europe, but have literally broken it up. We are strongly opposed to the Commission's programme, because it condemns the European south at second speed, strengthens German Europe, strengthens the Europe of lenders who support the troika and the memoranda in Greece, and does not oppose Mercely policy.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: Mr President, the decision of the Committee on Culture not to accept the Commissioner you sent and your insistence on accepting him is a sign not of democracy, but of dictatorship. Everything I hear about democracy 'from one ear comes in and from the other comes out'. As a human being I'm sad to see people expressing these things, but 'Plato's friend, friend the truth'. In all constitutions, of all countries, it is recorded that popular sovereignty is the foundational pedestal. But where is democracy and its implementation when it is constantly violated by everyone? The problem of democracy is the biggest of all. History is knocking on our door. The Greek people are running to open it to show you how to apply the power of the people.

name: Jörg LEICHTFRIED
text: Mr. President! Mr Juncker, I was recently in the United States – in Washington – because of TTIP. I have also spoken to American trade unionists. One of them said: TTIP, this is not an agreement between two states. This is an agreement where large corporations on both sides of the Atlantic are trying to impose their rules on everyone else. That would mean less democracy, less freedom, less rule of law for Europe. I know you mentioned it, but I would like to ask you once again: be very careful here! Be very vigilant here! Free trade is important, but the altar of free trade must not sacrifice the rest of what constitutes Europe, namely our rule of law, our democracy and our freedom. (Applause)

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Mr Juncker, we have certainly all listened very carefully to your speech today, and probably the majority of this House will give you its support today, and I will certainly be among them, not only because you have chosen a very experienced Commissioner, Mr Šefčovič, who also represents my country, as one of your closest associates and vice-presidents, but because you have presented a rather interesting programme. I would just ask you to really give a great deal of scope to social policy in your programme and that, even today, 10 years after my country became a Member State of the European Union, the average wage in Slovakia is still lower than the minimum wage in Luxembourg, in your country. So I hope that all those measures that you are going to take will be mainly for the benefit of citizens, because we have helped financial institutions and large corporations sufficiently in those previous periods. Thank you very much and I keep my fingers crossed for your Commission.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. - Congratulations to Mr J.-C. Juncker, after lengthy hearings from commissioners-designate and intensive negotiations, presented us with the new Commission in the European Parliament. It is very important that the Commission starts working from 1 November this year, because Europe cannot wait. Millions of people who are still suffering from unemployment today cannot wait. Young people, whose unemployment figures are still beating records in some Member States today, cannot wait. Finally, people trapped in poverty as a result of the financial and economic crisis can also no longer wait. So let's start acting. We Social Democrats believe in your promise to maintain the social direction of Europe's economic recovery. We believe that the economic recovery will be sustainable and that the new jobs being created will be safe. That we will fight poverty, especially for children and the elderly. That we will not allow in-work poverty to prevail, even people with jobs in our countries cannot survive. That we will fight energy poverty by increasing energy independence from unpredictable big neighbours. This is particularly true for the Baltic states. I particularly welcome your promise to treat all Member States equally and fairly. I hope that this promise will also find resonance in the agricultural policy, where the Baltic states are still discriminated against today, because they receive the lowest direct payments throughout the European Union. The commission's opening term will certainly be full of challenges, so I wish you the best of luck and look forward to starting our cooperation.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. At the beginning of a new period, I congratulate the members of the College of Commissioners nominated for election and President Juncker. In order for today's moment to come, we have held marathon hearings in our commissions, assessing the professional and political preparedness of the candidates. I welcome the end of eight months of uncertainty in the EU with today's vote. However, the Commission's formation was preceded by a number of anomalies and oddity that need to be addressed in the future. The most obvious would be for the President of the Commission, after the selection and vote of the President of the Commission, to start consultations with the Member States, to offer portfolios to them, and only then to request personal proposals from the Governments of the Member States. The current system is reversed, and Member States designate comissars in such a way that they have no idea at the moment of marking which areas they will be responsible for.  The shortcomings of the current process have given way to politically chargeable and unfounded attacks, which ultimately mean a loss of prestige not only for the country but also for the Union. Despite the fact that the composition of the Juncker Commission is not ideal – for example, there is a commissioner who would be particularly involved in the protection of the rights of historical national minorities – I certainly see a chance for the new Commission to give new energy to the Union. We expect it to be a worthy 100-year-old and help to revive citizens' faith in the Union through its actions and proposals.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Writing. Jean-Claude Juncker is the new President of the European Commission. To be sure, a Commission president without a cabinet is like an emperor without clothes. With one difference: the emperor can - in general - choose his own clothes, Juncker was - to stay in the picture - clothed by the European heads of government. He must wear what the prime ministers sent him to Brussels. But even the dressing was not left to him alone. Parliament measured carefully whether sleeve length, waistband and step actually fit, occasionally changes were made. In the end, no, enough of the parallels, in the end a candidate was sent home for poor performance, with some other future Commissioners there were one or two caveats. So now comes Jean-Claude Juncker with his new team. In his speech before the vote, he said a lot of the right things: the EU's often-quoted 300 billion investment programme "is very close to his heart" - so he will present it in his details not only in three months, but before Christmas. "This Commission is the Commission of the last chance - either we succeed in bringing Europe closer to the people, or we are finally failing." As parliamentarians, we will be looking closely at him from now on.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. –  President Juncker, we, the citizens of Europe are expecting:  A Commission with a new way of doing things: more dynamic, more efficient, better cooperating with the European Parliament, A Commission oriented towards the European citizens’ aims and goals, A Commission that will focus on new investments, investments in Europe’s critical infrastructure, investments to fuel sustainable growth, A Commission that will develop new programmes and allocate more money for job creation, especially for young people, A Commission which will work thoroughly on improving solidarity between the member countries of the EU, especially the development of less developed regions within EU countries, A Commission that will find the right balance between support for the private sector and for financial institutions and an effective social security for EU citizens, A Commission which will work hard to implement and further develop a real Common Security and Defence Policy, an EU with the necessary military capabilities to face old and new challenges and threats to our common security, A Commission which will work hard for a more influential EU in international affairs. We wish the New Commission lots of success, because together with the European Parliament and the Council, our success is going to be Europe’s success!

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the election of the new EU Commission. I did not take this decision lightly. The main reason for my 'yes' was that both Jean-Claude Juncker personally and the responsible Social Commissioner Marianne Thyssen promised me to support my commitment to a generally more family-friendly EU policy and a non-legislative 'European Family Strategy' as the basis for this policy. That is what I will judge them to do over the next five years. I expect family friendliness as the basic principle of Europe! I was also convinced in today's speech that Juncker's clear rejection of secret arbitration tribunals for the settlement of investor-state disputes (ISDS) in the TTIP agreement was also convincing. This 'no' is elementary! I expect quick, concrete steps. Mr Juncker, you promise a new Commission without drawer thinking, a political commission alongside the citizens, a new movement for Europe. You have my trust - don't disappoint me! Give Europe gas! Give Europe a new direction! Let's make it better! And family-friendly!

name: Eduard-Raul HELLVIG
text: in writing. – The choice of the new European Commission marks a new, key stage in the process of institutional reconfiguration at EU level. By appointing Mr Juncker to head the future Commission and approving its members, following hearings in the European Parliament, this forum, an exponent of the will of the citizens of the 28 Member States, validates the option expressed in the European Parliament elections and confers unprecedented democratic legitimacy on the Commission. This is an important step to overcome the crisis of confidence that the Community institutions are experiencing in the wake of the years of recession. It is the new Commission's mission to launch, now, a courageous process of economic growth and combating unemployment. I am confident that the experience of Mr Juncker and other members of his team in stabilising the EU in the wake of the financial and economic crisis is a solid basis for the ambitious agenda I propose to Europe over the next five years. The EU needs further efforts to improve the budget, strengthen progress, and a sustainable boost to economic competitiveness and job creation. At the same time, the European integration process must continue, by removing the last barriers to free movement and active solidarity with a view to closing the gap between the old and new Member States of the Union.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Writing. " Anyone who knows the postcard, "The Perfect European Should Be..." this caricature may also be flashed in connection with the new committee.  According to this, The Perfect European cooks like a Brit, humorous as a German, sober as an Irishman, organized as a Greek, and modest as a Spaniard. President Juncker seems to have allocated portfolios in the new Commission on this basis. Thus, Spain's Cañete, which has significant oil interests, will be responsible for making European climate and energy policy sufficiently ambitious and for the Union to play a leading role at the Paris climate summit at the end of next year, where an international system capable of preventing catastrophic climate change consequences should be agreed. In recent years, the statue of budgetary discipline has not been patterned after Paris, yet Moscovici will be commissioner for economic and financial and tax matters. Will he be able to overcome the EU's economic difficulties? And then there is Tibor Navracsics, responsible for education, culture and youth affairs. He is the only Commissioner-designate who has not received support in the industry even from the coalition that would otherwise support the Commission. And who will perhaps represent the terrifyingly retrograde education policy that the Hungarian Government has implemented in recent years. As a responsible Member, I cannot support this Commission by my vote.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing – Mr Juncker, I agree that the mid-term evaluation of the multiannual financial framework scheduled for the end of 2016 should be an opportunity to further channel the EU budget towards employment, growth and competitiveness. I believe that your actions will be directed to areas that can create hundreds of billions of euros in additional growth. Only the Digital Agenda has the potential for the emergence of a dynamic knowledge society and hundreds of thousands of new jobs, especially for younger jobseekers. The same potential is the completion of the single market or the Transatlantic Agreement with the US. However, it is necessary to look in full seriousness at the unsustainable deficit in payments for projects already implemented, which the EU has not paid its creditors. I agree with the view that economies in which it is not invested are not growing. And if economies don't grow, they don't create employment. But if the economy is invested, but then there is no one to pay for those investments, that is the worst-case scenario that we cannot allow in the EU. The Council's deferral approach has already crossed all borders. This is also the first homework task for you, which we must solve together.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. – As someone who knows the Commission intimately, I must say I admire the courage of its President, Mr Juncker, to try ending its unfortunate ʽsiloʼ culture. Another positive ingredient of the Juncker vision is delegation to the Vice-Presidents, which should create space for the President to provide more vision and leadership than was the case in the past. The personal qualities of the President also seem to foretell the right balance between charm and firmness, a long leash and swift retribution. The new arrangements, however, also leave some questions unanswered. At the top, the presidentialism of previous years was accompanied by an ʽambush cultureʼ, which essentially meant sacrificing collegiality for the sake of presidential power, underpinned by a super-strong Secretariat-General (in itself a normal thing). In time, every Commissioner learnt to use the system to clear his or her files, and the habit became second-nature. I am also afraid the old-fashioned career and motivation system for officials will not help the Juncker approach. Finally, a more political Commission is a good thing, provided ʽpoliticalʼ is opposed to superficial posturing, spinning and opportunistic surfing. I hope the President has the right answers for all these problems and I wish him luck.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written.- I supported President Juncker's work programme. As the holder of the HDZ list in the European elections in the Republic of Croatia, I am glad that by winning we contributed to the EPP's "spitzenkandidat" becoming President of the Commission. The innovative electoral process strengthened the democratic legitimacy of the EU institutions, with the EP playing a prominent role.  Juncker has put together a quality team of Commissioners who have proven competent at the hearings. The work programme focuses on jobs, growth, fairness and democratic change. Given the problems encountered by the Member States of the Union, and in particular with unemployment, I expect that the main priority of the work of the future Commission will be to strengthen the European economy with a positive impact on the standard of citizens.  The European Union needs smarter investments, fewer rules and more flexibility. It is important to build better infrastructure, strengthen industry, create a solid energy union and lead an active climate policy. I emphasise the need to dynamism of the internal and digital markets, to strengthen EMU as a basis for the Union's economic growth.  I expect further strong engagement on illegal migration, the fight against cross-border crime and terrorism. Globally, it is essential to strengthen the EU's foreign policy activity with partners in tackling crises in Ukraine, Syria and Iraq, and to prioritise neighbourhood policy. I am pleased that the Commission will work on an EU enlargement policy, especially towards Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. The Commission, led by Mr Juncker, does not meet the expectations of European citizens in many respects. On the one hand, it is characterised by Commissioners who stand for the continuation and deepening of European policy to date and, on the other hand, they are staffed by numerous Commissioners who are not technically up to the task. Mr Moscovici, Mr Kataini and Mr Dombrovsky s shall be mentioned in particular. In the hearings held before Parliament, these gentlemen were not able to convince a majority of parliamentarians, either politically or technically. They owe their election only to an unworthy behind-the-scenes chatter in this House, an indisputable process from a democratic point of view that once again confirms and exacerbates the worst fears and reservations of many citizens against the EU and its institutions. According to Mr Juncker, he has also persuaded six governments to nominate a woman instead of a male candidate. I would have preferred him to have influenced as many governments to nominate more qualified candidates.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: , in writing.– I believe and hope that the team you have formed will help the European Union emerge from the current crisis. Your plans and promises and the Commissioners-designate are ambitious, whether in terms of supporting investment, regularising emigration, creating jobs among young people, combating illegalities and, above all, reducing red tape at European level. The latter is also one of the priorities of the Commissioner-designate for Agriculture, Phil Hogan, which I fully share. European agriculture needs simple procedures to simplify the lives of European farmers. I welcome all the ambitions of the new committee. But please remember, in the conduct of the mandate, the promises you have made. As far as the Vice-Presidents are concerned, I hope that this new formula will not lead to internal bottlenecks within the Commission, which is why I want you to intervene firmly in their coordination. The European Union must not enter into any procedural, bureaucratic, etc. deadlock, etc. I believe that the Credibility of the Commission will only be demonstrated if it succeeds in reducing unemployment, increasing investment, supporting farmers in difficult times such as the current one caused by the Russian embargo and cooperating more closely than in the past with the European Parliament.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: , in writing. – Today I voted for the Framework Programme and the composition of the new European Commission, headed by Jean Claude Juncker, in the plenary of the European Parliament. The new European Commission was elected by a majority vote of MEPs, with 423 votes in favour. As a Member of the European Parliament I have high expectations from the new European Commission. I look forward to the continuation of social public policies, I expect public policies targeted at the needs of young people, I expect sustainable investment in infrastructure and in bridging the gaps between East and West. Last but not least, I expect a positive attitude towards the European course of the Republic of Moldova from the new European Commission. I wish success in the work of all European Commissioners and wish them to work effectively and transparently for the benefit of European citizens, both members of the European Parliament and the relevant ministers of the Member States. I believe that the European institutions, the European Parliament and the European Commission must approach and communicate directly and transparently with citizens. I would like every European citizen to know what its direct benefits are, which derive from the European policies that we propose. I am convinced that this new beginning for the European Commission will further open the way for communication and rapprochement with European citizens.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. As the final architecture of what the Commission will look like over the next five years is about to be finalised, as the European Parliament prepares to vote on its confidence (or not) in the Juncker team, it is time to remind the President of the Commission of the promises made during the election campaign. 1/ The investment plan of 300 billion euros will have to be composed of fresh money not resulting from various recyclings. 2/ on the withdrawal of the arbitration clause (ISDS) which allows multinationals to make and undo the law, according to their profit-seeking and to the detriment of citizens. 3/ on a revision of the directive on the secondment of workers which is currently too used abusively to organise social dumping, to the detriment of small businesses and workers. 4/ on a return of drug-related materials to the DG sanco Otherwise "Words fly, the writings remain" This is the message I want to convey to you. The President of the European Commission must respect his commitments and formalise them otherwise the Belgian Socialist delegation could refuse on Wednesday to vote on the nomination of the new team proposed by Juncker.

name: Sergei STANISHEV
text: in writing. –  Today I believe we have to support the Juncker Team, because it is the responsible and democratic thing to do. Juncker received our support as President after declaring his will for real change in European priorities, the main line being his EUR 300 billion investment plan for jobs, growth and competitiveness. By saying ‘Yes’ to the new College we underscore our support for the Commissioners from the Socialist family who showed a high level of expertise and commitment at the hearings. The balance in the Commission has been improved in the course of negotiations, thanks to the efforts of the Group of Socialists and Democrats. We have better representation, with key portfolios and 3 Vice Presidents and no important decision can be taken without our approval. Yet our support is not unconditional, we will strictly monitor the implementation of Junker’s commitments and expect him to uphold his promises. And last, but not least, we should give our support because, if we want a change, we have to participate in every step of achieving it.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Writing. The new Commission has set out with a number of ambitious objectives. Last but not least, the objective of an investment package clearly shows that, after years of saving at the expense of the people of Europe, it is time to finally ensure that Europe's economy and society are shaped for the future. The focus must be on the fact that Europe is no longer a purely economic Europe, but that the Commission finally takes responsibility for social Europe. We call for a social investment pact, clear and targeted measures against unemployment, wage and social dumping and poverty. We want to set these objectives and regularly measure the Commission and the Member States against them. Just as we are reviewing compliance with economic indicators in the context of the European Semester, we must in future introduce ambitious targets for combating poverty, combating youth unemployment and creating good, sustainable and in no way precarious jobs. The new Commission must clearly show its colours in favour of the people of Europe and must no longer put free competition before the interests of the people.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. This Juncker Commission in no way represents the democratic will of the citizens, who have expressed a desire for change. In the economic area, the rigour with the disputed fiscal policies imposed on states will still be too strict. In this historic moment of crisis, after 5 years of austerity, which has generated only impoverishment in the eurozone, there is no longer any valid excuse and motivation supported by studies, to continue with these policies imposed by a single Member State that is Germany.  We must quickly review the parameters of the Six Pack and Two Pack, call on the Council to abolish the Fiscal Compact and amend the ECB Statute, so that the institution can have all the means to finance the real economy more effectively by contributing to the objectives set out in Article 3 TEU.  If we do not do this, Europe will continue to become impoverished and the States will be justified in wanting to regain sovereignty instead of surrendering it. Juncker's $300 billion plan is unlikely to give the economy the stimulus it needs.  The private resources that are to be called into question come from market speculators, who are forcing member states to create the conditions necessary to speculate through reforms in our countries, and blackmail in these terms is not acceptable."

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the election of the Commission. I would point out that there will be a round of speakers from the group chairmen before the vote.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the We have now had a great time to discuss the new Commission, to weigh up the pros and cons. I would like to begin by taking up the idea that many have once again defended their individual positions. I have heard terms such as neoliberal, austerity, flexibility. I would now be campaigning for us to apply the thinking in compromises, for us to get out of political views, and instead to reach the compromise. Because we will only achieve solutions for the citizens of Europe through compromises. I would therefore once again ask all Colleagues to be aware of their responsibilities. Anyone who does not support and reject the Commission today, if there is no majority for it, risks a bit of crisis and instability in Europe. I would like to appeal once again to Mrs Harms, to the Greens: i would answer the counter-argument that we are voting against for certain substantive reasons that everyone can understand: Europe will certainly not be better off in the forthcoming climate talks if we do not have a functioning Commission. This argument can also be brought along, and it should perhaps be weighed up again. That is why I would argue that everyone in this House today should argue, not just from a party point of view, that anyone who presses a button now is not just arguing from their personal national glasses or party or factional goggles, but is aware of their overall responsibility. I am glad to say that the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats will be united in supporting the new Commission. (Applause)

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: On behalf of the Group of the Progressive Democrats in the European Parliament , Mr Juncker, I confirm the favourable vote of the Group of the Party of European Socialists and Democrats, for your attention to Parliament, for the positive new institutional architecture that you have chosen for the Commission, for your call for a rebalancing of austerity policies – I would add that those who have committed themselves to courageous structural reforms and are in a situation of low growth , must take advantage of all the flexibility provided for in the Treaties – for its attention to social dumping: the expression, the social triple A, will judge us to be the weakest citizens. Our rating agency is the citizens. It has also confirmed its focus on investment: this point is decisive for us; It has listened to the speeches made by my colleagues in my group. When you spoke about the investment plan, you said that it is also the private sector that has a great responsibility, and you are right. However, I remain convinced that the recovery of the economy cannot be exclusively contracted out to private individuals, and in its investment plan there must be a clear commitment to public resources and public investment.  On the single market, we agree with you that structural reforms are needed to reduce barriers to growth. However, beware of the rhetoric of structural reforms, many states have been making bold structural reforms for many years. We cannot continue to say that this is not enough, that they must always do more! Perhaps if, despite these reforms, growth does not start again, the problem is that structural reforms alone are not enough, but we also need a revival of domestic demand. The main problem with the European economy is the weakness of domestic demand. One last word that I have heard little about: solidarity, which is the basis of the European project. Between European states, between European citizens, but also beyond Europe. You rightly mentioned the Ebola tragedy. Well, this must be the test to show that Europe is there. There is wherever he is in the world, whatever his nationality, he will leave no one behind. There is a beautiful phrase by Don Luigi Ciotti, which says: it is not so important to be believers as to be believed. This is the challenge of politics, this is your challenge, this is our challenge.

name: Ryszard Antoni LEGUTKO
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, President Juncker, the ECR Group will abstain. You start, so to speak, with a clean slate. We heard your words, we heard the words of the Commissioners, but words are like smoke – they tend to blur in peoples’ memory. We will wait for your performance. We count on your success, not on your failure. The future is in your hands. Your team is far from the dream team, but there are some good people there, so there is some hope. I must admit we were slightly dismayed by your excessive support of the Community method when you have the alternative – subsidiarity. The ECR is definitely on the side of subsidiarity, so do not promise goods that you cannot deliver. There are some limitations. You just cannot deliver certain goods. You cannot reduce youth unemployment – much as you would like to – because you do not have the instruments to do so. You did not mention innovation (which I think is to your credit), because the European Commission or European Parliament do not have the instruments to boost innovation. If they had the instruments, we would have been thriving, and all the Nobel Prizes would go to Europe. They are not going to Europe, and there must be some reason for it. So, contrary to what a lot of my colleagues have said, I urge you to practise the virtue of self-restraint. Do not be over-active. The subsidiarity principle is to be treated seriously, and please do not jump on the federalist bandwagon. My last point is about so-called ‘European’ values. You are a representative of Christian democracy: a noble political tradition, long dead but worth reviving. So my request is: do not kow-tow to the political Left that dominates the European Union. Act like a good Christian Democrat. Do not think that you can appease them. Believe me, they do not take prisoners. Take my advice, because this is friendly advice made in a good spirit. Good luck.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
