text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, let me be clear, after the spokesman of the Abstentionist Party of Europe, the ECR – this could be a new name for Mr Kamallʼs troops – that our Group is very clear; we shall support this new Commission as part, Mr Juncker, of this broad – I hope for you – pro-European majority and coalition in this House.  That said, I think that this debate has been useful because it has made it clear that there are two visions of Europe: there are those in the majority, the Socialists, PPE, ourselves, ALDE, who think that we have to move forward on European integration, and those like Mr Farage who has made his classic intervention for the British public – he is already in the British elections, he is not in the European elections but he is in the British elections for the moment. We shall see ʽMarianneʼ Le Pen in a few minutes. Deux minutes de patriotisme français à l'intérieur du Parlement européen. Elle n'a pas participé au débat mais elle fera un petit show tout à l'heure, en deux minutes. C'est à cela que nous allons assister. (Applaudissements) M. Lucke est intervenu. Mr Legutko intervened, and I think he was also against the Commission – more clearly than Mr Kamall – saying that the problem is that we are growing everywhere in the world, but not in Europe. That is the problem. His recipe for that is: let us give up the euro and let us give up the European Union, like the Americans gave up the dollar, the Chinese the renminbi or the Japanese the yen. I have not heard the Americans saying: oh, we have to tackle the crisis: let’s go back to the 50 states and the 50 markets in the United States. What they are saying is: more unity, common action. That is their response to the crisis, and that has to be our response to the crisis now. So things are very clear now. There are those who are saying to public opinion that we shall create jobs by going back to the past. Well, I believe in the future and, for that reason, the ALDE Group will vote in favour of the Commission.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Mr Juncker, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which he has been a member of the European Parliament. The decision we are taking today is a political decision. It is not a decision whether we think you, Mr Juncker, are wise enough to lead this Commission, or whether we consider Mr Timmermans to be the born communicator. The real question is: is the Commission political enough to bring about the necessary change that is just around the corner?  You yourself have described the drama of the task. You described it very well. But what you have initiated is not, in our view, sufficiently gripping. It is incomprehensible enough whether this European Union will actually make a massive start in the coming weeks, months and years in order to become a democratic, sustainable, solidarity-based Union. By this yardstick, you did not convince us. Too many members of your Commission are provoking doubts that they are willing and able to do exactly what the citizens have said with the election and what has also led to this leak between the citizens and the European institutions, that you want to introduce precisely these course corrections, that you are against an austerity policy, that you will actually work for more democracy, for a different EU migration policy, that puts an end to us pursuing migration policy with joint police actions or with Frontex, but creates the legal way to get people here and also be protected by us. Criticism of Mr Navracsics' nomination shows that no one is taking away his transformation into a champion of more democracy, cultural openness or even media freedom. Does anyone really believe that the new Commission will push forward the fight for the protection of animals, humans, the environment and the climate as massively as it should be? Even when asked at the hearings, we were not able to see how the triple-A that you so invoked for a social union is to be enforced. If, at the hearings, even the Commissioners questioned were not even able to state clearly that austerity policy is not in line with the European Charter of Fundamental Rights, with the granting of human rights, how can this change succeed? How is this turnaround to succeed? However, our criticism is not only directed at you and the Commission. I honestly admit that we are also disappointed by some of the Members here in Parliament. Unfortunately, some groups have become hostages to the grand coalition, have allowed themselves to be turned into a game, and that has begun with the nomination and election of you, Mr Juncker, as President of the Commission. What has been declared a historic gain for Parliament's rights has now become a bargaining deal between some groups to allow candidates through. This price is too high for us!

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Mr Juncker, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work he has done. I still find it remarkable that we are at a point that is already marking a break. If the future President of the Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, is the man who has come into this position as a candidate for the European Parliament. This should really be further recognised as a major step in the development of European democracy. It is a pity – and I must say this explicitly at this point – that the opportunity to make this Commission, Team Juncker, the team of the European Parliament, on the basis of the hearings has been missed. In fact, the package between the Member States' governments and the political groups in this House and the three parties behind it was too tightly laced in terms of power politics. This is a missed opportunity for a further departure into European democracy. We will have to talk in this House about how we can turn the appearance of hearings back into the existence of hearings and actually strengthen the power of the European Parliament in the future. But let me say one thing: my group has found a number of Commissioners to be positive and have also assessed them in this way. We are a pro-European group in this House. We know that the very great challenges, that is to say the fight against the deregulation of the financial markets, which is still not won, can only win the fight for a more social Europe, the fight for climate protection and energy security together at European level. That is why today, despite our 'no' vote, marks the start of optimistic and European cooperation with Jean-Claude Juncker's Commission.

name: David BORRELLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr Junker, Europe is facing an epochal moment: we are well aware of the challenges before us and what a heavy responsibility we have taken on in representing the concerns and hopes of European citizens in Europe. Today you are asking us to give confidence to your idea of Europe and you are asking us to approve your strategy, based on austerity and rigour, asking us to confirm the people you have chosen. Now, over and above the individual value of the people he proposes to us as members of his team, we wonder whether this strategy is time-appropriate, whether it meets the immediate needs of European citizens in difficulty. If this strategy is able to recover, modernise and make the values of solidarity, subsidiarity and the responsibility of the common European future more incisive in today's day. What we believe is that there is a dangerous ups and going on in Europe. We believe that we are moving away from fundamental values and principles and replacing them with state reason. Your Commission was in fact born in complete disrespect to the principle of collegiality, with a strange concentration of powers and providing for figures and places that had never been introduced before, all endorsed by a European Parliament that is not even able to respect within it, the democratic principles of proportionality and representativeness. A European Parliament that applies proportional methods only when they are in favour of the majority and tramples them underfoot when they benefit minorities, even if the minorities represent millions of European citizens. All this under the eyes of a European Council, representing the States, capable of endorsing, for example, the situation in Greece, where people are being taken away from health care, only at the same time to give billions of euros to banks and financial structures. We have a heavy responsibility to defend the weakest, the citizens, from the merciless war that is taking place in Europe between major interests. In this stormy sea we do not see valiant commanders, but only a dangerous attempt to centralise strategic decisions in the hands of a few men and a few countries. For these reasons, we shall not vote in favour of this Commission. We are voting against it because we want more, more respect for the citizens, for small businesses, the heart of our economy, more respect for the environment, the only real common heritage, and above all more solidarity because the poor cannot wait. We are voting against it because we want a more true, more democratic Europe that is closer to the people.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Thank you very much. (Some members hold up banners.) We have seen that. I have no objection to you standing still. But I assume that Mrs Le Pen, who is about to speak, will not be so pleased about it. You now have your photos, please sit down again.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: Mr President, Mr Barroso has left a European Union without a project, a European continent adrift, in a deplorable state. To save the euro, he applied austerity plans to the people of southern Europe with unprecedented harshness with catastrophic results on unemployment, debt and impoverishment. Mr Juncker, let us now talk about your Commission, an institution which is not based on any popular legitimacy. To moralize and regulate the financial sector, you have appointed Lord Hill, a close friend of the City, who has spent half his career as a lobbyist, working for hedge funds or big banks. To deal with the issue of the euro and social dialogue, you chose Valdis Dombrovskis, a former Latvian prime minister who led the most serious austerity plan in his country, which resulted in a mass exodus of his population. You have appointed Miguel Arias Caete to the climate and energy portfolio, and this man has very close ties with two oil companies, which he himself founded and which his family continues to control. By lacking such ethics in politics, independence from lobbies, you humiliate and insult all Europeans. Your new Commission's roadmap is terrifying: a new kind of total free trade agreements are planned with Canada and the United States; competition with the very powerful American agriculture risks bringing our farmers to their knees, survivors will have to take an even more productive approach at the expense of product quality and respect for nature. This agreement will align all the standards, the collective preferences of the French, with the American standards. Finally, shame on the European Commission! It is in the process of imposing private justice for multinationals against states in these free trade treaties. Thus, you will have completely destroyed our old democracies, at the mercy of the attacks of transnational firms. But the work isn't finished, is it? You need to dismantle public services a little more, they will have to be competitive and competitive or disappear. That is the role of the TISA Treaty, which the Commission is currently negotiating. These treaties will unfortunately enshrine the takeover of multinationals on democracy in Europe. Finally, your 300 billion euro bank loan programme will have an indigent effect on the economy since, once again, it will only act indirectly on the real economy and employment. What can I say, in conclusion, about your desire to bring Turkey into the European Union? Oh what a visionary you are, Mr Juncker! The people of Kobane are blown away! Mr Juncker, we will vote against your Commission because, contrary to the French adage, with you the worst is always safe.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: We shall now proceed to the vote on the Commission. (The President explained the voting procedure and the subsequent steps) (The election will be conducted by roll call) Votes cast 699 in favour 423 against 209 abstentions 67 So I note that the Commission has been elected. (Sustained applause) I have sent Mr Juncker the communication on the majority of the European Parliament's approval of the election of the Commission. I congratulate you, Mr Juncker, now officially on behalf of the whole House. However, I also congratulate all the elected members of the European Commission, their Vice-Presidents, the Commissioners, and i wish you every success, on behalf of all Members, good luck in your difficult task for the benefit of the citizens of the European Union! (Applause)

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the Council, I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate Mr Juncker and the entire Commission on the approval vote they have just received from this House. It really is a sign of support and confidence on the part of Members of this House. This vote paves the way for the necessary final step, the appointment by the European Council, which must be completed by the end of this week. In the coming months and years, the Commission will have to play a key role in meeting the challenges we face. These are formidable challenges, including increasing Europe's competitiveness and creating jobs, developing a coherent European energy and climate policy and the problem of insecurity in our neighbourhood, and there are many others. Of course, the Commission cannot face all these challenges on its own, it also needs the cooperation of this Parliament and the Council. I would therefore like to take this opportunity, Mr Juncker, to underline the Council's commitment to cooperate with you over the next five years. We will have to work closely with each other, as well as with this Parliament, if we are to implement the Agenda agreed by the European Council from the beginning of this year. The measures we implement and the policies we adopt will be the basis on which we will all be judged by our citizens, and this is more difficult today than ever. I am therefore pleased that you recognise that the citizens of Europe not only expect things to be done, but to a large extent they want them to be done differently from the past. The way in which you have organised the Commission is a clear sign of your willingness to operate differently, and we welcome that.  At the same time, Mr Juncker, you showed in your speech that you are a staunch supporter of the European ideal. Every time he works in the interests of Europe, he will have our support and encouragement. We welcome the prospect of working with you and your team in the years to come.

name: Damian DRĂGHICI
text: in writing. – I am convinced that the new European Commission team is a strong one with extensive experience, which will directly support the interests of EU citizens. I am referring here to the development of the investment sector - so important for creating new jobs and reducing youth unemployment - and to taking measures to combat illegal migration or to continuing EU enlargement negotiations. I am pleased that Romania will have an extremely important portfolio, and in this way I would like to congratulate and wish success to my colleague Corina Crețu in the performance of her duties as Commissioner for Regional Policy.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the Juncker Commission in the context of a broad agreement between the EPP, S&D and the Liberals. This is a much more political and much more potential Commission than the previous ones, so it would have been irresponsible on The part of Parliament to weaken it before its mandate began, since weakening the Commission only means strengthening the role of States. The College of Commissioners has emerged stronger from the hearings, where they have demonstrated their independence and was in office in an exercise of democratic and transparent control. The great political pact between the EPP, S&D and the Liberals is very positive and hopeful, given that the European Parliament has been shaped in a way that neither the EPP nor S&D can articulate alternative majorities in the House. This shows that the two major parties must be able to reach agreements on matters of general interest to the EU. I am convinced that taking the path of dialogue and agreement will be very positive for the legislature that has just begun and that it can lay the cross-cutting bases on which to project the European Union of the future.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I welcome the outcome of today's vote, which appoints the composition of the new European Commission. For more than two weeks, Parliament has been checking the competences of the 27 Commissioners-designate proposed by the new Commission Head Jean-Claude Juncker. I have already participated three times in the questioning of Commissioners-designate, during the two terms of the Barroso Commission and the current one, and I believe that we have chosen a good team with a good work programme. Although most candidates were positive in their hearings, I believe that they had too little time to get to know their portfolio in depth and prepare for a new role. An example would be the Sowed candidate Alenka Bratušek, who was appointed Vice-President of the EC for the Energy Union, which Parliament did not accept. A new candidate from Slovenia, Violeta Bulc, who is to be responsible for transport, received a positive assessment, while Slovakian Maroš Šefčovič became Vice-President of the EC Energy Union. Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker and his more experienced team are now ready to face the both economic and geopolitical challenges facing Europe.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item is voting time. I hear that not all Members are yet equipped with voting lists. But I think the respective chief whips have at least one list. That is why I think it is right to start. Until everyone has taken their seats, and because not all the new Members have heard that, I would like to say a few words about the voting system: at the last vote in one day, when you leave before the vote is closed, you must not draw your voting card, otherwise your vote will not remain in the system. You should therefore not draw the voting card until a vote is closed.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: Mr President, as every year, due to the complexity of the procedure, there are some technical adjustments to be put to the vote.  Concerning pilot project ‘Cohesion policy and synergies with the research and development funds: “the stairways to excellence”’ in line 13 03 77 13, Plenary Amendment 9500 replaces Amendment 1167 (ex-BUDG 3570). This is to delete a duplicated paragraph, leaving only the modification as adopted.  On ‘Financial support for encouraging the economic development of the Turkish Cypriot community’ in line 22 03 01, Plenary Amendment 9501 replaces Amendment 1235 (ex-BUDG 3638). This is to correct omissions in a modified paragraph and to delete a duplicate paragraph.

name: Michael CRAMER
text: Mr. President! We in the Committee on Transport and Transport, with the support of all the Members, decided that we wanted to invest 0.5% of the money for the Committee on Transport in the 14 EuroVelo routes. This was not taken into account in the Committee on Budgets. I have then been instructed by all the coordinators to make this request so that 0.5% of the transport budget is made available for the EuroVelo routes. I would ask you to agree to this here too, because we did not like the Committee on Budgets interfering in the internal affairs of the Committee on Transport and The Committee on Transport and The Committee on Budgets and taking a different decision from the committee. I would therefore ask, on behalf of all the coordinators of the Committee on Transport, to vote in favour of 472 and later also 473.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: Mr President, a point of order on the order of points. Rule 174, paragraph 2: ‘If two or more mutually-exclusive amendments have been tabled to the same part of a text, the amendment that departs the furthest from the original text shall have priority and shall be put to the vote first’. Here, the first amendment merely moves money from one pot of money to another, moving it to the European External Action Service, but it does not make a penny piece difference to the original budget. Our amendment would save taxpayers EUR 15 million in commitments and 7 million in payments. It would be a terrible shame if the first amendment were to pass and the second, therefore, were to fall, because the real cost-saving measure would not be heard. So I would respectfully submit that the order of vote should be reversed and that 547 should be taken before 157.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, Mr Arnott. The Committee on Budgets has a special role to play in the budget procedure. That is why the committee's proposals are put forward first. We shall therefore put Amendment No 157 to the vote first. - After the vote:

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I note how the European Parliament has just adopted amendments to the Council's position on the draft budget for the financial year 2015, taking into account, at this point, the different positions, there was already a wide-ranging debate yesterday. As President-in-Office of the Council, in agreement with the President of the European Parliament, I would like to say that the Conciliation Committee will then be convened in accordance with Article 314(4)(c) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, just to say that the Council takes note of the fact that parliament's amendments to the Council's position have also been adopted in respect of amending budget No 2 for the financial year 2014, and therefore also with regard to this amending budget, in agreement with the President of the European Parliament, the Council will ask for the conciliation committee to be set up, as provided for in Article 314(4). , point (c) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Mr. President, the dilemmas surrounding Mr. Juncker's election have renewed the debate on which direction the European Union should be developed 60 years after its founding. Did the latest crisis prove that the European project should be limited to developing the single market, or is the only response to the crisis the European Union as an in-depth integrated political community.  Jacques Delors argued that the European economic model must be based on three principles: stimulating competitiveness, strengthening cooperation and solidarity uniting. And the five most recent European problems to be addressed immediately are: unemployment, social inequalities, member states' public debt, climate change and an ageing population.  I also voted for this European Union because its President promised in a speech to Parliament to be president of the European Social Dialogue. He should be given the opportunity as a competent man, as one of the designers of a system that has worked well for a long time, and which now needs to be seriously improved.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioners, my opinion of the Commission is negative. There are many critical issues that have emerged in the hearings, ranging from potential conflicts of interest to lack of experience, or even incompetence in areas that are key to the life of the Union, so as not to remain silent at last about its political line, with which I wish to express open dissent. I will give two examples in particular. Commissioner Jourová: no clear and satisfactory response has been received from you regarding the embarrassing coverage of conflicts of interest, the use of funds in the European Union by the Czech Finance Minister and head of your party, Andrey Babiš. On the other hand, we know that my question has caused a great deal of hype in the press in his country, as well as unjustified nervous and offensive reactions to me from Babiš himself. None of this is in favour of its transparency and independence. Mr Avramopoulos, you are now famous in Europe for praising the barbed wire barrier on greece's border with Turkey, stressing the need to protect our society and our borders from irregular immigration. This image is also for us a metaphor for the Juncker Commission's programme on immigration, a policy that does not specifically provide for the solution of the humanitarian tragedy taking place in the Mediterranean. This response will affect the conscience of those who refuse to face reality, which is made up of despair and death and which we intend to share with those who will vote for confidence in this Commission.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Mr President, I am part of a generation that has been fortunate enough to be born and raised in Europe. However, that plan has been stuck in half in recent years and perhaps the courage on the part of the Member States has been lacking, and so there is a great responsibility to this new Commission. And I fully understand my group's choice and the great work that has been done with hearings in recent weeks. Yet there is something missing, and yet some of the choices made by Mr Juncker did not find me perfectly convinced: I am talking about the number of women on whom perhaps it was precisely with the States, with the governments, that we could have insisted more. I am talking about the choice that has been made, perhaps failing to listen fully to the warning issued by the Committee on Culture. For these reasons and for some others, I have not felt able to give this vote here today, but with the hope that in future the many promises that have been made by President Juncker and other excellent elements of the Commission, including Federica Mogherini, Frans Timmermans, will also be carried out with our help towards that Europe project, which is a half-promise for the time being.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: Mr President, the Europe of democracy and transparency has just suffered a serious setback. By accepting the appointment of Mr Miguel Arias Caete, whose family has very important direct interests in the oil sector, to the post of Commissioner for Climate and Energy, this Parliament is dishonouring what is the very foundation of democracy and which should constitute the greatness of this Assembly: the defence of the European general interest. Respect for transparency and independence, as well as the fight against conflicts of interest and corruption, are not optional in a democracy, they are the condition. These principles should never be abandoned in the name of a grand coalition and efficiency with blurred and completely opaque contours. Today, therefore, I reject the Commission presented by Mr Juncker and I do so as a pro-European. I want this Europe to fulfil its primary function, that of defending the european general interest.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Mr President, I voted for Mr Juncker's Commission. I loved his performance today. He has confirmed that he is an experienced politician and it is very good that he will lead this institution as the representative of the winner of the European elections. As a newcomer to the European Parliament, I have closely followed the various hearings, the individual statements and the demeanors of future Commissioners, and I must say that I was very impressed that this was not just a formal protocol introduction of these future Members of the European Commission, but that it was a matter-of-fact debate that could examine their political considerations, their direction, and how they would like to conduct their departments.  It is very good that the future European Commission is an institution of politicians, not officials, that there are many more experienced top politicians, there are four prime ministers, etc. This will lead to her being better positioned and, in my opinion, to greater respect for the European Council.  And the last thing is the program. I very much respect the programme that regulates investment issues, 300 billion euros is, I think, a good plan for investment for the economy as a whole.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I acknowledge the merit of Mr Juncker for having wanted a political Commission, with an innovative structure that encourages the Community method and with the challenge of bringing the European Union closer to its citizens and also with some very good Commissioners. I regret, however, as chairman of the Committee on Culture, Youth, Education, the Common Security and Consumer Policy, that our clear indication has not been sufficiently taken into account, confining itself to a small variation which does not affect the substantive competences on culture and education. Although I hope that Mr Juncker will take on the invitation of the chairman of my group, Mr Pittella, to invest in culture as a pillar of sustainable development. Commissioner Navracsics knows, however, that we appreciated in the Commission his strong statements about his independence and fidelity to the values and principles of the EU. We see this as a commitment, to which we will call it back and on the basis of which we can cooperate loyally without prejudice but without discounts. That is why my abstention is a sign of political coherence but also of positive expectation.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: Mr President, as Mark Twain once observed, there is no distinctly American criminal class, except Congress. I think the proper institution to deal with the Commission will be the European Prosecution Office, not the European Parliament, and that is exactly why that institution does not exist. Moreover, I think that the European Union should be destroyed.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this Commission is not perfect. I am concerned about the issues relating to Commissioners Navracsics, Hill and Cañete, and I do not think they are closed at all, and we will continue to be vigilant and scrupulous. However, there are also some excellences in this Commission, mrs Georgieva's choice as Vice-President demonstrates her desire to restore a central role to the budget and as a driver of growth, so that we can once again invest in research, development, work, agriculture and the environment. Frans Timmermans and Federica Mogherini are also personalities of extraordinary depth. They are both committed to LGBT rights. That, of course, gives me hope. I hope that Mr Juncker will do the same. I have had mixed feelings in recent months and I fully take full notice of the political importance of the vote we have taken today. I voted in favour, because I decided to trust the programme presented, for that reason only. In this sense, my vote is a real vote of confidence.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: Mr President, not for the first time I feel that I am trapped in some kind of time loop here – one of those wormholes out of science fiction. The rest of Europe has moved on, but the European Commission remains resolutely trapped in the mid-1950s with Mr Juncker’s paleo-federalism, his plans for a pan-European minimum wage, a European army and police force, European taxation. What has to happen to convince European Federalists that there might be a better way? The rest of Europe has moved on but still the Eurocrats carry on chanting their ancient shamanistic incantations.  It is too much integration that created the democratic crisis; it is too much integration that created the financial crisis. And yet our only response is to accelerate, to keep redoubling all of the things that led to the problems in the first place. As my countryman Oliver Cromwell once put it ‘I beseech you in the bowels of Christ, think it possible you may be mistaken.’

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: Mr President, I abstained from supporting the Commission because I was not convinced that this Commission can deliver the change which the voters expect from this Parliament and this Commission. The doubts proceed both from the policy statements, which were not clear enough in the realisation that jobs and growth should take first place on the agenda – there was no mention of cohesion policy when, as we all realise, inequalities in present day Europe are the most severe challenge to the future of the Union – and from the composition of the Commission, as Mr Juncker entrusts his investment package to Mr Katainen. I believe that forsakes the option of major public investments.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. - (IT) Today the Grand Coalition, S&D, PPE and ALDE all united in a correspondence of loving senses, has given the Juncker Commission confidence. This has happened almost covertly by citizens who know little or nothing about both the mechanism for appointing the Commission and the new Commissioners. Perhaps this is no accident given that a financial lobbyist, Hill, has been appointed to financial services, the troika's son Katainen, as vice-president for work, growth and competitiveness, an oil tanker, Cañete, energy and climate change, and an illiberal, Navracsics, to education, culture and youth. That's just to name a few. The Five Star Movement has therefore not given its support to the Commission and will always remain vigilant in scrutinising the Commission's work. European citizens deserved better, and if they had known these names before the elections, the turnout would have been less than 42.5% (the lowest for an EP election!) and the election results would have changed. The Five Star Movement has also fought for more transparency in the cumbersome process of appointing Commissioners, especially with regard to the work carried out by parliamentary committees. Citizens need to know how their elected representatives decide and vote for them.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. I support Jean-Claude Juncker's new European Commission.  In his speech, Juncker rightly referred to the 'Commission of last chance'. One thing is clear: Europe has no time to lose. The EU must act now and redefine its priorities. Europe must help solve social problems, invest in research and development and provide jobs and growth. Because Europe is more than a crisis manager. The hearings of recent weeks have shown that the European Parliament has been critical of the Commissioners-designate and their ideas on the future of Europe. Some Commissioners did not stand up to this in-depth examination and, at our insistence, were replaced or their areas of competence changed. Such control would certainly also make sense for the identification of national members of the government.  Juncker speaks of a "new start for Europe" – a new start that is desperately needed in the eyes of many citizens. We now need to put Juncker's agenda into practice. In this sense, my agreement with the new Juncker Commission is not to be seen as a blank cheque. It is bound by the implementation of the aforementioned content. If Europe does not change course now, the European project will not be enhanced in the eyes of the citizens.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. - As a Socialist Portuguese/Portuguese Member, in line with the voting orientation of the Socialists and Democrats group, I decided to vote in favour of the investiture of the Juncker Commission, giving it the benefit of the doubt in the face of the political commitments of change made before the European Parliament. This vote, despite the reservations expressed, takes into account the serious inconveniences that would result from a political impasse in the European Union and is linked to a demanding attitude towards the new Commission, which will continue in its political review. Throughout this process, in which the democratic functioning of the European Union has been strengthened, the demanding attitude of the Socialists has made it possible to achieve improvements in the proposed Commission, such as the allocation to Socialist Commissioners of the folders of the Coordination of Sustainable Development and Energy, in addition to new commitments on the economic agenda. The appointments of commissioners with the profile of Navracsics and Katainen justify reservations. And the uncertainty in skills, budgetary flexibility and investment requires a surveillance attitude. The Portuguese Socialists will continue to demand from the new Commission full compliance with the change programme announced by Juncker, with emphasis on the €300 billion investment plan promised for early 2015.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. - After conducting the last hours of final negotiations on several fronts, we have obtained from President Juncker several commitments which we believed were indispensable in the defence of the interests of the citizen. The casting of the Commissioners is certainly not entirely what we would have liked, and the programme is currently only a set of promises that will have to be made, but we have decided to give this Last Chance Commission a chance. The $300 billion: we have been assured that it would not be recycled funds. We will ensure that the Commission is used to finance public investments that are essential for recovery and useful to citizens.  The arbitration clause (ISDS) in TTIP-CETA: we will never accept a company dictating laws for its commercial ambitions or expected profits, at the expense of the citizen.  Drugs: We have obtained that the drugs are not a commodity, nor the patients of the clients. This is an important victory for us, which concerns the health of all citizens.  Social dumping: revising the Detachment of Workers Directive, currently too used to organise social dumping to the detriment of small businesses and workers, is essential.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. - President Juncker, the greatest gift we can give Eurosceptics and critics is that this Commission does not get off the ground and floats aimlessly on the open sea. They do not want Europe to prove that it can take the bull by the horns and to create cooperation in areas where it really adds value. This Commission has a historic opportunity to regain the lost trust of many Europeans in the European project. There is only one remedy for this: action. The 28 Commissioners know perfectly what they have to do: fly right in, rise above themselves and do everything to give our economy a vital injection that translates into jobs and faith in the future. We are counting on each Commissioner to develop some very concrete measures in his own field that directly translate into more growth and jobs. Parliament will enthusiastically support such action. President Juncker, we don't have a minute left to lose. Let us immediately work on those renewable energy networks, of an ambitious digital new deal, of a substantial injection of oxygen into innovative industry so that people re-associate Europe with a hopeful future. Good luck!

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. N-has not been legitimate than the Barroso Commission, the Juncker Commission. Contrary to what we are led to believe, the European Parliament does not decide and the major European parties have quietly negotiated the allocation of Commissioners' posts.  The new Commission will, of course, continue the disastrous policy pursued by the previous one and will further lock the peoples of Europe into a cycle of austerity, mass unemployment and impoverishment.  It will remain subject to multinationals, lobbies and banks. As proof, its Commissioner for Financial Services, John Hill, is British (and will therefore take care of the City...); its Energy Commissioner, Miguel Canete, is a shareholder in two oil companies or Finland's Katainen, the Employment Commissioner, who now wants a 300 billion euro stimulus package even though he was before the austerity drive and wanted to mortgage the Parthenon in exchange for financial aid to Greece.  Europe will therefore continue its ultra-liberal policy of opening borders, destroying public services and enlargement. By the very admission of the Commissioner for Neighbourhood, Johannes Hahn, Turkey must be put on the list of priority countries.  For all these reasons, I voted against this Commission.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. - (IT) My vote in support of the Commission led by President Junker is dictated by the important commitments made in the economic field, which are also the basis of the support of the S&D Group. The environment in which we live, a weak, fragmented and economically proven Europe, needs concrete answers and clear horizons. The EU must once again be an instrument of growth for its citizens and not just define budgetary constraints and parameters to be respected. The investment plan of EUR 300 billion can be a signal that there is also a change of attitude in Europe. A credible Europe for its citizens is an authoritative Europe in the international arena, and in this respect I very much welcome the appointment of Federica Mogherini. We must be able to speak with one voice, both on the current crises and on the crucial dossiers, strong in the founding values of the Union and aware of the global scope of the current social and economic challenges.  The new parliamentary term is now beginning effectively. We have before us the important task of working with the Commission, urging it to take effective action and bringing the demands of the citizens we represent into the debate. We are all called upon to ensure that this opportunity for recovery is se caught.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. - The new European Commission has the greatest burden of pulling the EU out of the crisis and restoring faith in the European project. For the last five years of the Barroso Commission we will not remember for the good, the main associations that bind to it are painful cuts and a protracted crisis. Mr Juncker's Commission will inherit this burden, but I hope that 2019 will be the year of the euthan European citizens live significantly better. This is crucial for the survival of the European Union and the long-term stability of our continent.  Some commissioners such as Mr Canete and Navracics are a bitter pill to swallow, but if we want excellent commissioners such as Timmermans, Andirukaitis and Mimica to take up their duties, we must vote for the Commission's proposal in full.  I expect President Juncker to deliver on his €300 billion investment cycle pledge to focus on growth and employment projects within a reasonable timeframe. Furthermore, it pledged that the security and rights of European consumers would not be compromised during the free trade negotiations (TTIP and CETA).  I welcome the announcement that Mr Juncker will abandon his intention to move medicines and medical devices into the Portfolio of the Commissioner for Market and Industry. This means that he has listened to the voice of the European Parliament and I hope that the announcement is how he will work for the next five years.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. We denounce the composition of this Commission, which could have been hoped to bring a renewal to a continent driven by Mr Barroso's drift and its catastrophic record. This Commission exudes, without the slightest popular legitimacy, a bad smell, that of lobbies that cannibalize the living resources of nations for the benefit of stateless multinationals.  The presence of Lord Hill, so close to the City, does not reassure us. Valdis Dombrovskis's is terrifying, driving some of his people away with a sinister austerity plan.  What else can you say about Miguel Arias Caete, potentate of an oil managed with his family. To these garish moral faults is added a calamitous roadmap where it is clear that Europe's alignment with American standards will reach a scale never before known, with its predictable procession of bankruptcies and unemployment for European workers.  No, I do not accept these men of decadence and decline who want to have the justice of our countries controlled by private justice tomorrow.  So in rejecting this college, I say no to the double humiliation of addiction and decline.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted against the new Commission. Commissioners not up to the job and insufficient programme to solve the economic crisis and the problems of the citizens. This new Commission will continue to give priority to the interests of banks and financial groups to the detriment of citizens.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. - For the first time in the history of the Union, the President of the European Commission was appointed following the results of the elections to the European Parliament last May. With the European People's Party winning the most votes and the most seats, its candidate, Jean-Claude Juncker, was appointed President. This is one more step towards a political Europe closer to the citizens. I voted for the new Commission because I consider it to be balanced and made up of competent personalities. I also support Jean-Claude Juncker's programme for growth, jobs and competitiveness in Europe. The new Commission will now go to work for a five-year term.

name: David CAMPBELL BANNERMAN
text: in writing. - It is a sad reality that any EU Commission and its Commissioners are at heart federalist, wishing to advance ‘more Europe’ at every opportunity, in working towards ‘ever closer union’ within a political European super-state, and not the democratic interests of national citizens. I abstained in the vote on the Commission as it does not make much difference which Commission is in force, though clearly some individuals are better than others in terms of merit and attitude. The EU needs root and branch reform, not token opposition within its broken and unsuitable framework.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - (IT) Today I voted in favour of the new Commission, in the hope that it will act differently from the Barroso Commission, on which I have many reservations. I expect an ambitious Commission with a strategic vision that will lead us out of the crisis. Juncker has signed a contract with Parliament and I hope he will respect it. Your team must propose a credible strategy on investment and growth. It is essential that this Commission looks more at people than at figures, more at citizens and their needs than at the numbers of the Stability Pact. The new European Commission is the last chance for the EU: either it manages to bring its citizens closer to the European institutions or Europe will fail. On the social aspects of European policy, Juncker announced that the ambitious €300 billion investment plan, promised in July, will be presented by Christmas. Its credibility and that of the Commission will be assessed in terms of investment, which should make it possible to strengthen the European economy and boost employment and growth.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - (IT) The 5-Star Movement stands against Jean Claude Juncker's Commission, both for its composition and for its repeated desire to remain on the path of austerity and austerity. It will not be the poor compliance with budgetary rules that will save millions of families who have become poor or are about to be poor, and the events of past years fully demonstrate this. We cannot believe that the college of Commissioners so composed can act fairly by ensuring the impartiality of the measures taken, just look at the curriculum of some members such as Lord Jonathan Hill or Miguel Arias Canete.  The regulations on transparency and the absence of conflicts of interest within the European institutions do not seem to apply to the body that most of all determines the content of legislative acts that have a serious impact on the lives of more than 500 million people. We cannot believe in the total impartiality of people who have built their careers in the financial or oil industry, they will always be inclined to meet the needs and demands of those who have worked with them for so many years.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. - While some Commissioners-designate demonstrated competence, commitment and a progressive outlook, Mr Junker was dealt a very bad hand by the European Council of Member State governments. Many governments nominated candidates who were obviously picked for the job as thanks for their pedigrees as loyal, party-political servants. We saw serious instances of conflicts of interest and candidates with very questionable commitment to fundamental European values. Unfortunately, some of the logical outcomes that should have been drawn at the end of the hearings process were marred by paralysis, as the main conservative group decided to hold some candidates hostage in order to force its most unsavoury candidates through. Gender equality also fell victim to the Member Statesʼ choice to reward political allies over ability. Mr Juncker himself recognised as much in his speech this morning, describing the appointment of nine women out of 28 as ‘ridiculousʼ. We must rethink the hearings process to prevent it from becoming a rubber-stamping exercise where candidates are frozen in by a threat of mutually assured rejection across party lines. Our electorates sent a clear message for change at the European elections. We ignore it at the European project’s peril.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. - (IT) I am well aware of how difficult it is to define a team and a government programme, and this is all the more true at European level, where we need to find an 'intersection' between the will of the Council, inevitably conditioned by the proposals reserved for the individual Member States, and the will of Parliament, or rather of the various political groups, in the light of their electoral weight. Although there is no shortage of reasons for concern, I supported the Commission for the reasons of confidence arising from the programme, and in particular for some of the priorities indicated on 15 July and resumed today, and for the value of many Commissioners, some of whom are in decisive positions precisely for the implementation of those points of the programme that are closest to my heart: the fight against unemployment. , especially the youth sector; the development of the area of justice, judicial cooperation and the fight against organised crime; and a new and greater focus on immigration, through the construction of a sound European policy on legal immigration and asylum. I therefore hope that a stronger common foreign policy will be implemented that lives up to the Union's responsibilities. For these reasons, I have decided today to give my confidence to this Commission.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted with confidence in favour of the composition of the new Commission. My confidence is first and foremost placed in the hands of Mr Juncker, who has already shown that he knows the European machine very well and knows where to get his hands on improving what is wrong. I am not entirely satisfied with the hearings of all the Commissioners, but overall the College far exceeds the sufficiency and it will be my job to punish those Commissioners who are less in line with my expectations. The confidence granted today is not and will not be blind, but I will ensure that the interests of European citizens are protected in practice.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Commission chaired by Jean-Claude Juncker because I think he has a good President, a good composition and a good Commissioner Portuguese. In the case of hearings held in the European Parliament, all these elements have been well established and the amendments that have been imposed have been made. I hope that the commission now elected will be able to honour its oath to preserve the common interest and contribute to strengthening the European ideal, the experience of European citizenship and the increase in investment and job creation.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. - Today we witnessed a historical exercise of European democracy. It was citizens who, by their vote in May, decided who leads Europe. But we also made a crucial political choice, one binding us for the next five years. Commission President-elect Juncker was not my candidate during the election campaign and is not my candidate today. Yes, the majority of EU citizens voted for him. Their votes must be respected. But he did not win an absolute majority in this House.  My vote, that of S&D, was one based on precise demands to Mr Juncker and his new Commission College. EU citizens want a new direction for Europe; they gave a mandate for change. Our red lines as a political family were clear: the end of austerity-only policies; investment for sustainable growth and decent jobs; a vigorous fight against the drama of youth unemployment; safeguarding freedom of movement. We secured an agenda which included our key priorities. This is the Juncker Commissionʼs commitment. This is why I voted yes. Today the EU is more democratic, transparent and accountable than ever before. We will remain vigilant to ensure that citizensʼ voices are heard and so will our College Members, including Romanian Commissioner Corina Creƫu.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the new Commission led by Juncker since this is a Commission that will be led by a President in a way that reflects also the vote of the people. Furthermore, the Commission´s work plan places social development high on its agenda, whereby economic growth is expected to be sought without excluding the social aspects. The Commission is also expected to bring about investment in infrastructures related to education and employment.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - (IT) As has been the case for twenty years in Italy, we in the European Parliament too are witnessing the ridiculous farce of the grand coalition between the People's Party, the Social Democrats and the Liberal Democrats. Today I declare, with an immense sense of dignity, that among the votes against the Junker Committee there is also mine, in addition to that of the entire M5S. This committee, which will decide the fate of hundreds of millions of European citizens, is the result of the tried and tested and clear inciucio between European lobbyists, bankers and Freemasons. It must be communicated to the citizens of Europe that, following the economic and social disasters perpetrated by the Commissions chaired by Mr Barroso over the last ten years, they have today been condemned to another 5 years of austerity, increased poverty, new taxes and a famine of social rights. Without hesitation, commissioners were appointed as Cañete, a shareholder in two oil companies, or as Katainen, a ruthless rigorist who wanted to mortgage the Partion in exchange for financial aid to Greece. And like them, so many other unpresentables who will govern this Europe in the midst of a social and economic crisis. This fool could only see me against it. I have expressed my doubts in the relevant committees and I did so today with my vote!

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - I voted outright against this new college of Commissioners by Mr Juncker, since it is nothing more than a change of faces for the continued policy of the Barroso Commission. Neoliberal policies that violate the most fundamental human rights, which have taken us to levels of unemployment never known in EU history, to intolerable levels of poverty and social exclusion. This Commission ensures that the path of structural reforms that seek to level down living and working conditions in the EU will be followed. Reforms that will continue to favour large economic groups, at the cost of dismantling and privatizing the small public sector that remains in EU countries. For all these reasons I voted against this Juncker Commission.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - The birth of the new team to be led by Juncker represented a turning point for the European institutional system. In spite of what has been said, the candidate of the party that was victorious in the European elections in May has been nominated as President and, from this, a team of political government has resulted, which has, at its base, a political majority in the European Parliament, with which he will have to contend and with which he will also have to deal. Starting with what has been heralded as the union's main action plan since the beginning of the crisis. It is potentially an extraordinary instrument for reviving the European economy, but at the same time it can turn into yet another wasted opportunity. I believe that the only way is to invest fresh resources - not just a relocation of those already allocated under cohesion policy - which will be able to activate the necessary private investment. I can't see any other way. This will be the first real test on which we will assess the real will of the new Commission to make the change of pace that the citizens of Europe have demanded by their vote.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. – Today we witnessed an historic exercise of European democracy. It was for the citizens, with their May vote, to decide on who leads Europe. But we also made a crucial political choice, one binding us for the next five years. Commission President-elect Juncker was not my candidate during the election campaign and is not my candidate today. Yes, the majority of European citizens voted for him. Their votes must be respected. But he didn’t win an absolute majority in this House.  My vote, that of S&D, was one based on precise demands to Mr Juncker and his new Commission College. European citizens want a new direction for Europe; they gave a mandate for change. Our red lines as a political family were clear: the end of austerity-only policies; investments for sustainable growth and decent jobs; a vigorous fight against the drama of youth unemployment; safeguarding freedom of movement. We secured an agenda including our key priorities. This is the Juncker Commission’s commitment. This is why I voted yes. Today the EU is more democratic, transparent and accountable than ever before. We will remain vigilant to ensure that citizens’ voice are heard, and so will our College Members, including Romanian Commissioner Corina Cretu.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the Juncker Commission as along with my political group, S&D, I believe that this Commission can make a difference. This Commission has also committed itself to support our agenda in addressing youth unemployment, enhancing competitiveness and focusing on energy and industry. We will hold this Commission to this commitment. Now it is time for the Juncker Commission to start delivering on what we have agreed upon including the EU 300 billion investment plan.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. - (IT) Some considerations allow me today to vote in favour of the Juncker Commission. The EUR 300 billion investment plan represents a decisive change of strategy compared with the previous Commission and can become an extraordinary driver for economic growth. Only a growth programme can lead to a significant reduction in the unemployment rate, a major European scourge and an improvement in the accounts of individual states. I was convinced by President Juncker's idea of aiming for a Europe that gets the 'Triple A' not on economic parameters, but on social parameters. Europe's greater attention to the essential issue of immigration: Europe will only be Europe if it is able to take on a programme of reception and cooperation towards the countries on the southern shore of the Mediterranean. Of course, not everything convinces us in the composition of the College: alongside extraordinary personalities, including Federica Mogherini and Franz Timmermans, we record the presence of commissioners who are not up to the task, as well as the low presence of women and the sub-representation of our political area. However, as Mr Juncker said, this is the last opportunity to relaunch the European project, to base it on a new basis, starting with greater democracy and a stronger role for Parliament.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. - In conscience and in line with the commitments made to my constituents, I voted against the new European Commission. I voted and campaigned for Jean-Claude Juncker. But I did not find, during their hearings, in the words of the Commissioners-designate, the flagship proposals on which we were elected in France. How, in particular, to give a blank-seing to a Commission in which the Commissioner for Migration and Home Affairs not only supports the entry of Romania and Bulgaria into Schengen, but also does not seem at all inclined to carry out the urgent reform of Schengen that the people expect? The Commissioner-designate for accession negotiations, for his part, has shown no desire to pause the enlargement process, supporting the continuation of negotiations with the candidate countries, including Turkey. And how can we approve Pierre Moscovici's candidacy for the post of Commissioner for Economic and Financial Affairs when we know his disastrous record in France?  In this context, I decided to be faithful to my constituents and my commitments by voting against it.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. I voted confidence in the new European Commission proposed by Jean-Claude Juncker. This confidence will be demanding and impatient because Europeans expect concrete results. And Jean-Claude Juncker has assets: great experience, a European conviction that has never wavered and real political legitimacy. It will also need character and courage to make Europe a space for political will to form. That is what is at stake. This requires a vision that heads of state and government too often lack. The vision of a Europe that finally deals with the big issues, that decides to weigh in the world, to defend its interests and to act for its economic and social development. It will also require a new institutional practice, a return to the Community method with a Commission which will finally take over all its right of initiative. We want Europe to succeed. That is the whole sense of trust that we have placed in it.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. - I voted for the European Commission and the College of Commissioners as proposed by its President Jean-Claude Juncker after the hearings carried out by the European Parliament. The composition of the college is a reflection of the results of the European elections and it is normal for democracy to be expressed, but I will remain very attentive to the proposals that the various Commissioners can make and will not hesitate to oppose the ideas that I will not share.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Written. - Ladies and gentlemen, the N-VA delegation chooses a Europe that does not deal with details, but focuses on what really matters, including by focusing on growth, competitiveness and jobs through fewer but better rules. The European Commission must therefore resolutely commit itself to a reform agenda. We want to be constructive and work with the new Commission on priorities such as the completion of monetary union, the deepening of the internal market, the increase in energy security and the creation of jobs. The most important thing, however, is the commitment of the new team to reform. During the hearings, many candidates acknowledged the urgent need for change, efficient governance at the most appropriate level and less regulatory drive. The clear powers of Juncker's right-hand man Timmermans, whose core task is to ensure more subsidiarity and less regulatory drive, are cautiously positive; the need for change also seems to have penetrated the Berlaymont building. As a reform party, we embrace this development. We will take a critically constructive attitude to assess whether the Commission is keeping its word and is putting its promises into practice. That is our task for the next five years.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I have given my confidence without hesitation to the new European Commission, but I have a demanding and impatient confidence because the Europeans are waiting for concrete results. I welcome the commission's new internal organisation, designed by Jean-Claude Juncker, because I have confidence in the talents and conviction of 'Prime Minister' Timmermans, the most brilliant Commissioner I have heard at the hearings. Furthermore, I am delighted to have learned that the Commission will present before Christmas its proposal to mobilise EUR 300 billion to boost the growth of the European economy. Finally, I took note with pleasure of the social accents of the new Commission's programme. Good luck Jean-Claude!

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. - Mr Jean-Claude Juncker has not yet shown he is able to deliver real change. I will endorse his Commission when I see that change.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. - WE CAN voted against the new Juncker Commission. We vote against substance and forms; we voted against the way in which this European institutionality works, the arrangements and the composed of the grand coalition and the Council, the irresponsible follow-up with the Troika's guidelines, the political and ideological framework that continues to impose austericide, generating unbearable amounts of social suffering in the southern countries, and undermining the very foundations of the European project. We voted against a Commission plagued by conflicts of interest, complicit and promoter of austericide, complacent in the face of failed, unfair and unworkable policies on employment, immigration or energy. We voted against a programme that continues to impose the dangerous dogma of the Stability Pact and a programme that aims to boost competitiveness by lowering wages.  In southern Europe we know what is behind this Commission: imposition of public spending cuts; increase in indirect taxes; loss of rights, greater inequality and job precariousness; inadequacy in wage income; degradation and vulnerability of the working situation; and, as a result, the overall worsening of the living conditions of the popular classes.

name: Elisa FERREIRA
text: in writing. - As a Portuguese Socialist MEMBER, in line with the voting direction of the Group of Socialists and Democrats, I decided to vote in favour of the investiture of the Juncker Commission, giving it the benefit of the doubt in the face of the political commitments of change made before the European Parliament. This vote, despite the reservations expressed, takes into account the serious inconveniences that would result from a political impasse in the European Union and is linked to a demanding attitude towards the new Commission, which will continue in its political review. Throughout this process, in which the democratic functioning of the European Union has been strengthened, the demanding attitude of the Socialists has made improvements in the proposed Commission, such as the allocation to Socialist Commissioners of the folders of the Coordination of Sustainable Development and Energy, in addition to new commitments on the economic agenda. The appointments of Commissioners with the profile of Navracsics and Katainen justify reservations. And the uncertainty in skills, budgetary flexibility and investment requires a surveillance attitude. The Portuguese Socialists will continue to demand from the new Commission full compliance with the change programme announced by Juncker, with emphasis on the €300 billion investment plan promised for early 2015.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - As we said in the debate, all the rhetoric about a supposed new cycle, common to the right and social democracy, does not hide a crystal line: this is a Continuity Commission. There is no change here, but of faces – and even there, not all of them. There's only continuity. Continuity in so-called adjustment policies that violate fundamental human rights; unemployment, intolerable levels of poverty, growing inequalities. Continuity in structural reforms aimed at levelling down living and working conditions in Europe. Continuity in the attack on public services and the social functions of states. Continuity in favour of large economic groups – those whose representative organisations anticipate in their strategic documents what will be the legislative production of the European Commission. Continuity in the attack on democracy and the sovereign will of peoples, through instruments such as the Budgetary Treaty and the European Semester. This is a Commission associated with all the worst we have experienced in recent years. This Commission is past, not future. Significantly, it was supported here by PS, PSD and CDS – the supporters and performers, at the time, of right-wing politics. Only the will, mobilization and struggle of workers and peoples can break with this continuity and force real change.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in total disagreement with the election of Juncker and his college of Commissioners. As has been denounced several times, this committee represents, in my view, the continuation of a European policy that is not only wrong, but absolutely harmful to the vast majority of European citizens.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - I do not agree with the election of the new Commission, because none of the Commissioners meets our expectations for the Europe of the future. That is why I am voting against the election of the Commission.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. - Despite reservations on certain individual Commissioners, I voted for the Juncker Commission. Because there is a great urgency to implement actions that address the concerns and needs of EU citizens, we need change and a coordinated approach. Therefore, I believe it is in the interest of my constituents that the new Commission makes swift progress in drawing up a plan for jobs and growth that establishes how the EUR 300 billion promised by Mr Juncker will be deployed to increase economic investment into our regions. One of the top priorities has to be to skill up our young people and urgently review certain detrimental policies implemented by the outgoing Commission.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. - Last week I voted in favour of the new European Commission. Although the British Prime Minister David Cameron originally opposed Mr Juncker becoming the new President of the Commission, the UK is pleased with his commitments, hitherto, to work with Member States to ensure the EU focuses its efforts where it is best placed to do so. Avoiding needless bureaucracy and interference in areas best dealt with at home must be a cornerstone of a new, reformed EU. Given Mr Juncker’s commitments to better regulation and recognition of Member State subsidiarity, I was happy to support the election of the Commission, for the period 2014-2019.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: In writing. The new President of the Commission said this morning that the team he will chair will be the last chance. At the end of five years, we will know whether he will have had the wealth to meet the great challenges of restoring the institution's authority, getting out of the crisis, building a solid foundation for future generations and preserving Europe as a community of values.  My positive vote for the Commission is in line with a logic that started with the appointment of the Spitzenkandidaten and was achieved with full respect for the will expressed by the majority of European citizens in the last European elections.  Finally, I make no secret of my emotion at seeing Jean-Claude Juncker become President of the Commission. After Gaston Thorn and Jacques Santer, here is again one of my compatriots called to chair the European executive.

name: Ana GOMES
text: in writing. - As a Socialist Portuguese/Portuguese Member, in line with the voting orientation of the Socialists and Democrats group, I decided to vote in favour of the investiture of the Juncker Commission, giving it the benefit of the doubt in the face of the political commitments of change made before the European Parliament. This vote, despite the reservations expressed, takes into account the serious inconveniences that would result from a political impasse in the European Union and is linked to a demanding attitude towards the new Commission, which will continue in its political review. Throughout this process, in which the democratic functioning of the European Union has been strengthened, the demanding attitude of the Socialists has made it possible to achieve improvements in the proposed Commission, such as the allocation to Socialist Commissioners of the folders of the Coordination of Sustainable Development and Energy, in addition to new commitments on the economic agenda. The appointments of commissioners with the profile of Navracsics and Katainen justify reservations. And the uncertainty in skills, budgetary flexibility and investment requires a surveillance attitude. The Portuguese Socialists will continue to demand from the new Commission full compliance with the change programme announced by Juncker, with emphasis on the €300 billion investment plan promised for early 2015.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - WE CAN voted against the new Juncker Commission. We vote against substance and forms; we voted against the way in which this European institutionality works, the arrangements and the composed of the grand coalition and the Council, the irresponsible follow-up with the Troika's guidelines, the political and ideological framework that continues to impose austericide, generating unbearable amounts of social suffering in the southern countries, and undermining the very foundations of the European project. We voted against a Commission full of names tainted by conflicts of interest, for its complicity and collusion with austerity policies, for its complacency in the face of failed, unfair and unviable policies on employment, immigration and energy. We voted against a programme that continues to impose the dangerous dogma of the Stability and Growth Pact, a programme that aims to boost competitiveness by lowering prices and therefore also wages.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this Commission, but that does not necessarily mean I am fully in favour of every member in every portfolio. However, the European Unionʼs model is based on compromise and I support the Commission as a whole while retaining some reservations about particular members.  In particular I, along with my colleagues in the S&D Group, had serious concerns about the suitability of Mr Cañete for the position of Commissioner responsible for climate action and energy. During the hearing, we heavily questioned him on his links to oil companies and his ability to remain impartial.  Mr Juncker put forward a number of concessions to ease these concerns. He agreed to our Groupʼs request to add responsibility for sustainable development to the portfolio of the First Vice-President, Mr Timmermans. It was made clear that this includes responsibility for coordinating policy on climate action and energy.  In light of these concessions and supervision, we felt we could support the candidacy of Mr Cañete.  Nonetheless, Labour MEPs have made it abundantly clear that we will continue to assess, not just Mr Cañeteʼs performance, but the performance of the Commission as a whole to make sure it is working in the interests of EU citizens.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Commission because I believe that we share the same values and will work closely together towards greater European Union. This Commission is crucial for the Union. It is important that every Commissioner works hard to ensure the best results and to lead Europe out of crisis.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. - We had the opportunity to get an idea of the suitability of the individual candidates. There were convincing people, such as Mr Hill and Mr Oettinger. However, in addition to Mr Juncker, there are two other candidates that I consider unsuitable. Mr Juncker has been particularly committed to the communitarisation of public debt through the so-called 'Eurobonds', particularly in the south of Europe; in Germany, he liked to keep this secret. Mr Juncker is responsible for demolishing the firewall between German taxpayers and spending-loving politicians in southern Europe and France by helping to tear down the no-bail-out clause. In France, Mr Moscovici has not bothered for years about the Maastricht criteria or the fulfilment of the Fiscal Compact. Although Mr Katainen repeatedly pointed out in his hearing the beneficial effects of a three hundred billion investment project, he was guilty of answering Mr Lucke's question as to where he intends to take the money for it. If Members had had the opportunity to vote individually on the candidates, I would have liked to have voted for Mr Oettinger and Mr Hill. But both are not so good that it would be worth accepting Juncker, Moscovici and Katainen as well. That is why I am voting in favour of the Commission.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. - I welcome the establishment of Jean-Claude Juncker's new Commission.  Finally, we will have real interlocutors, most of them former ministers, who, through their governmental experience, measure their responsibility for the political choices that will engage Europe. However, if I am pleased that a team is being formed and the political balance respected, I will be particularly attentive to the immediate decisions that will be taken, especially with regard to the French budget. Similarly, I expect the new Commissioner for Migration, whose portfolio has been supplemented, and this is very regrettable, by that of Citizenship, that he should not confine himself to symbolic speeches on respect for fundamental rights but to make realistic choices on migration policy, choices as close as possible to the sometimes difficult and dramatic realities such as those in Lampedusa and Calais.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We can vote against the new Juncker Commission. We vote against substance and forms; we voted against the way in which this European institutionality works, the arrangements and the composed of the grand coalition and the Council, the irresponsible follow-up with the Troika's guidelines, the political and ideological framework that continues to impose austericide, generating unbearable amounts of social suffering in the southern countries, and undermining the very foundations of the European project.
