We voted against a Commission full of names tainted by conflicts of interest, for its complicity and collusion with austerity policies, for its complacency in the face of failed, unfair and unviable policies on employment, immigration and energy. We voted against a programme that continues to impose the dangerous dogma of the Stability and Growth Pact, a programme that aims to boost competitiveness by lowering prices and therefore also wages.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - I voted for the new European Commission as mr Juncker's election of the President of the European Commission expresses the will of the European Parliament, expressed by the majority of citizens in may's EU elections. The Commission is politically strong with several former Prime Ministers occupying prominent roles and balanced as regards the division of portfolios with regard to the countries from which commissioners come. Although I believe that people such as The Hungarian Representative Tibor Navracsis, who has shown himself to be an opponent of fundamental European democratic values in his political work so far, have no place in the European Commission - I voted YES because I have convinced myself that the Commissioners of the European Commission reflect an indispensable political compromise, but more importantly, I believe that this composition of the European Commission provides a good basis for the successful conduct of the European Union over the next 5 years.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. - This week, Commission President-elect Mr Juncker presented his college of commissioners and their programme to the Members of the European Parliament. After having assessed each commissioner, Parliament decided, by a majority of votes cast, to approve the new Commission. My support for this new college is far from unconditional, and our group (ALDE) has made that very clear from the outset. We need a Commission of ambitious reforms and better regulation to help boost competitiveness and economic growth. The first priority should be to get the European economy back on track. I believe that President Juncker, first Vice-President Timmermans and their colleagues will form a strong and independent Commission.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Commission proposed by Jean-Claude Juncker following the european Parliament's hearing of the various candidate Commissioners. These auditions allowed to control the knowledge and European commitment of each of the candidates.  He would not have been responsible for further delaying the establishment of this new European Commission, at a time when many Europeans are still largely suffering from the economic crisis. The Commission was approved by a majority of 423 votes in the second place, 209 against and 67 abstentions. I welcome this vote which will allow us to get back to work quickly to get Europe out of the crisis.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of the new European Commission chaired by Jean-Claude Juncker. In these difficult times, the new EU executive will have to get to work quickly, and rise to the challenges that lie ahead. Indeed, the results of the European elections on 25 May were a testimony to a profound disavowal of Europe, as well as a demonstration of the European Union's inability to make itself audible to European citizens. Thus, if the Union wishes to regain their trust, it will have to give itself the means to be a real power: an economic, commercial, energy, social, cultural and political power. It should be where it is expected, choosing to focus on the essentials, stopping drowning in unnecessary texts and providing concrete solutions. Finally, it should foster the europeans' sense of adherence to a common destiny. This can be done by cultivating the pride of being European, not partly through the education, from school, of our common history.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: in writing. - I welcome the positive outcome of the vote on the next European Commission. The Commission now consists of a strong pro-European coalition and I applaud our liberal Commissioners, amongst whom Andrus Ansip and Margrethe Vestager, who will hold important portfolios. We will, however, closely monitor that European values are respected by Tibor Navracsis, as well as the relationship between Valdis Dombrovskis and Pierre Moscovici who have similar competences in economic affairs.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. - The appointment of a new European Commission represents an important opportunity for reform in Europe and our Group has given a strong input. The two most challenging political priorities for the next Commission are to change the direction of Europe and to finally take action to boost growth, encourage development and create new jobs. We can proudly say that we have contributed to shaping a new and different Commission which is much closer to our values.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. - Why did I vote against the current composition of the Commission? The answer is not simple. It must be said in advance that my negative opinion does not apply to individual members of Mr Juncker's cabinet, as I consider some future Commissioners, such as Mrs Jourová, Mr Šefčovič or Mr Andriukaitis, to be competent to perform their duties. The way I voted justifies several facts, in particular the inappropriate institutional framework and the absolutely illogical and confusing division of powers between the commissioners. Portfolios that have no relationship with each other or are only marginally related have been linked, which has also affected my area of interest, where fishing has been inexplicably linked to the environment. It must be clear that, while at first glance related areas, each of them deserves separate care due to its complexity. However, I have an even bigger problem with the number of last-minute changes being made, e.g. the transfer of powers both between the various portfolios of Commissioners and even between the sub-directorates that Mr Juncker made only on the day of the commission vote itself, in fact, up to 30 days after the EP committees were alerted to 'lost' portfolios, such as space or the issue of political refugees. Furthermore, I cannot agree with the programme presented by the future Commission, which continues the dysfunctional policy of budget cuts, the reduction of social assistance and the cutting of the traditional European concept of the welfare state to the marrow.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the new Commission chaired by Jean-Claude Juncker because I am sure that this new government team will be able to respond to the challenges of the international context. From the outset, the new President characterized the action of the new Commission with rapid responses, and reiterated that on some issues Europe is lagging behind - think of youth unemployment, the current Ebola crisis, the major issues of climate change or energy supply. In addition, Juncker has announced that €300 billion investment plans will be ready by Christmas. I am therefore sure that the new European Commission is moving in the right direction and I believe that it will be able to make the right contribution to the relaunch of European action.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Writing. - The FDP in the EP welcomes the progress made in European policy in the composition of the new EU Commission. For the first time in the European elections, citizens had the opportunity to choose between different leading candidates. Although the procedure is not yet perfect, it is an important step towards strengthening European democracy. Juncker's Commission reform, with strong vice-presidents, creates leaner structures and, hopefully, less bureaucracy. So there are a lot of positives in Terms of European policy. A strong Commission is needed right now, as Chancellor Merkel and President Hollande set out to circumvent the rules for stable finances and sustainable economic reforms in France. However, we lack confidence that this Commission will be resolute enough in its approach to pushing through the Treaty – on the contrary, it is to be feared that the Commissioner responsible could even support them. The economic slowdown in Germany, the high level of unemployment in France and the increasingly desperate measures of the ECB show that this is the wrong way to go. Market economy reforms, not pension gifts or new debts, are a prerequisite for growth, jobs and new opportunities for millions of people across the EU who want to return to productive activity. Unfortunately, the Commission is so misplaced in this central field that the FDP could not agree to it.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - I voted in favour of the new European Commission chaired by Jean-Claude Juncker. I am aware that not all of the S&D Group's demands have been met, but much has been achieved. The composition of the EC is always the result of a compromise. As I emphasised in the debate, I look forward to the good and systematic cooperation between the EC and the EP. The President of the EC reaffirmed all the main priorities in his speech. In this situation, the new EC should work without delay from 1 November, and indeed from 3 November, the first working day.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - I voted outright against this new college of Commissioners by Mr Juncker, since it is nothing more than a change of faces for the continued policy of the Barroso Commission. Neoliberal policies that violate the most fundamental human rights, which have taken us to levels of unemployment never known in EU history, to intolerable levels of poverty and social exclusion. This Commission ensures that the path of structural reforms that seek to level down living and working conditions in the EU will be followed. Reforms that will continue to favour large economic groups, at the cost of dismantling and privatizing the small public sector that remains in EU countries. For all these reasons I voted against this Juncker Commission.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - I abstained from voting on the establishment of a new College of Commissioners. It is unacceptable for me not to take into account the Opinion of the European Parliament on the Hungarian Commissioner Tibor Navracsics. The CULT Committee rejected Mr Navracsics' candidature by a majority in terms of the portfolio allocated to him. However, its remit has only minimally been changed and he remains commissioner responsible for education, culture and youth. This situation is unacceptable by the members of the Committee on Culture and Education (CULT), who have negatively assessed Mr Navracsics' candidacy in these areas. As a member of the CULT Committee, I cannot agree that Tibor Navracsics, whose not only political past but above all his substantive preparation for the duties of Commissioner responsible for education, culture, youth and citizenship, has not been approved by cult. The failure to take into account the opinion of the committee responsible for hearing Mr Navracsics and the lack of response to the incorrect preparation and qualification of this candidate for the post of Commissioner responsible for education, culture and youth did not allow me to fully support the new European Commission.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. - By a majority of 423 votes in favour, the European Parliament has just appointed the new European Commission. The Juncker Commission team will start work from 1 November 2014.  The next five years will be a mandate for the european institutions' conscious difficulties and a clear litmus for the way the European Union is evolving – close to its citizens and responding to today's challenges or remote and increasingly criticised. For me personally, of all the debates and programmes proposed, the only clear conclusion is that reforms are the only alternative for all Member States! The majority of political groups agree that without structural reforms in a number of key sectors, our European family will not be able to develop its potential and advantages as the richest, free and peaceful community in the world. I sincerely hope that the new European Commission will play an important role as a driver for change in Europe and will be able to work fruitfully with all national governments in the coming years. You have my support. Success!

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - The European Commission's team is very mixed and professionalism is side by side with incompetence. Voting on the entire commission, rather than on the basis of each Commissioner-designate, also opens the way for politicians whose previous performance is completely at different to those they have to perform in the new Commission.  Valdis Dombrovskis is proposed to be vice-president of the European Commission, who will be responsible for the euro and social dialogue.  As Prime Minister of Latvia, Mr. Dombrovskis implemented a ruthless social policy. As a result, thousands of Latvians left Latvia, about 40 percent of its population lives in poverty, while social stiflement is huge.  In my opinion, guillotine - not the best tool against headaches. I therefore categorically oppose the coordination of social dialogue in the European Union by Valdis Dombrovskis. That is why I voted against the new composition of the commission.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. - On 22 October I voted for the Junker Commission and the portfolio assigned to Romania. The new Commission must carry forward the reforms undertaken by the Barroso Commission and face the great challenges facing Europe today. Among them, I want to bring to the fore the issue of unemployment in the EU, which remains at a very high level, despite all efforts, and the issue of Russian gas, on which many states are dependent. The Junker Commission must enter into operation very quickly and move beyond the proposals stage on paper. Immediately applicable solutions are needed, which also come with tangible results. I believe and hope I made the right choice. The european Commission's new team has a strong political profile. Three former prime ministers, two former foreign ministers, two former economy ministers are among its members. The Junker Commission must fulfil the trust it has been placed in. Increased attention must also be directed towards how public investment is spent. For example, Romania has more than 3 billion euros at its disposal this year, which needs to be invested in the economy efficiently so as to generate development and progress.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. - On the part of the JURI Parliamentary Committee, immediately after hearing the candidate for Commissioner for Justice, Consumer Policy and Gender Equality, Vera Jourová, I expressed my support for this candidate. Unfortunately, during the hearings of the other candidates, the structure of the Commission has changed, the portfolios have been redistributed, which seems to me to be unclear and confusing at this point, including the competences of the Vice-Presidents. Some basic sectors do not have commissioners (space portfolio), data protection and the Energy Union are not defined at all. I voted against the Commission for these reasons and not for reasons of adversity towards individual candidates.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted with conviction in favour of the European Commission led by my Luxembourg colleague Jean-Claude Juncker. Once the Council formally confirms our vote in this House, the new Commission will be able to take up its work from 1 November. I have great hope in the newly elected Commission for the complex challenges facing the European Union in the coming years. Only with determination and a spirit of union will it be possible to find a solution to problems such as youth employment, immigration, terrorism and economic recovery.  The team of Commissioners led by Juncker demonstrated during the hearings in the European Parliament that they are able to confront many and have the right skills.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. - Since the Commissioners-designate are neither up to their remit in terms of content nor democratically legitimised by the European citizen, I could only vote against it in this election.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the adoption of this College of Commissioners, because I believe that it is a balanced team, and that it will be able to implement the necessary policies in the most important areas that will lead to a new phase of eu growth and expansion. I would like to wish the President of the Commission, Jean Claude Junker and his Commissioners, all the best and success in implementing their policies.

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. - (IT) In today's vote, I wanted to express a strong disagreement with the Juncker Commission because I reject this governance that protects neither the citizens nor their interests. I reject a government that continues to pursue austerity policies undaunted and that does not aim for growth, development, which does not give oxygen to a battered social and economic fabric. I reject this team of Commissioners who are in complete continuity with the past, with those technocrats who have been pushing us to the abyss for ten years.  I will only vote 'yes' to a Commission when it stops looking at the interests of the usual well-known, big business, business banks, and puts SMEs and small social realities at the centre, the historic backbone of this continent. I shall vote 'yes' only when there is a Commission which puts resources into the agricultural production circuit for the protection of kilometer 0, production excellence and genuineness of products.  The Commission to which I will say yes cannot be Juncker's, that of euro bureaucrats with interests opposed to our own.  I shall vote 'yes' to a Commission which, in five years' time, will wipe out you and the dark interests of which you are the ists. That day will come.  In the meantime, listen to our thunderous no to this team.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. - The election of Mr Juncker as head of the European Commission is full of symbols. First, because the President of the Commission is elected for the first time. However, MEPs have no choice, since Mr Juncker was the only candidate! Then, while the European elections in May showed a strong will for change, is elected a candidate of the serail, the result of behind-the-scenes negotiations where transparency is not invited. The illusion of European democracy is total: the word of the peoples receives only a distant echo here. Finally, Prime Minister for 18 years of one of the founding countries of the Union, Mr Juncker bears responsibility for the policies that led to the current situation: ultraliberalism, austerity plans, mass unemployment, growth at half-mast, lack of competitiveness, rescue mechanisms of the euro and ruinous banks, public over-indebtedness etc. It embodies the continuity of a Europe that refuses to question its failures. The proof of this is its commitment to the transatlantic treaty, a real time bomb for our businesses and our market. Over the next five years, Eurorealist MEPs in Parliament will therefore put the new European Commission under enhanced surveillance.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Barroso leaves an EU in a total slump, with austerity plans implemented for the sole purpose of saving the single currency. Austerity plans that have only increased the debt of the member states and ruined the people. The new Juncker Commission will, of course, be the acceleration of the processes of dislocation of nation states and the submission of peoples. This Commission, which has no popular legitimacy, will thus intensify the mechanisms of globalisation. The free trade agreement with the United States and Canada will result in our standards being aligned with U.S. standards. In the agricultural sector, this will lead to even more productivity at the expense of product quality, the environment and consumer health. With the new Juncker Commission, public services will have to be ever more competitive and competitive or risk disappearing outright. For the new Juncker Commission, the process of Turkey's entry into the EU will also be a priority... Finally, the new Juncker Commission is sorely lacking, by its very composition, of independence from the lobbies. For all these reasons, I voted against the Juncker Commission.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. It was after much hesitation and thoughtful thought that I decided to vote in favour of the Commission.  The Commissioners' hearings showed us that the portfolios allocated to certain commissioners were not sound.  I take as proof the catastrophic hearing of Pierre Moscovici which will remain engraved in the annals as the trial of France because of the poor economic results of which the Commissioner is an accountant. As soon as François Hollande had nominated him as a candidate, it would have been wiser to entrust him with a responsibility other than economic affairs where he had seriously failed in his own country. However, since Pierre Moscovici by dishonouring France found himself under the tutelage of two vice-presidents, and other Commissioners had really demonstrated their competence, I chose not to penalise the Commission for a few who did not seem to me to be up to the task. Furthermore, I have chosen to respect the democratic legitimacy of Jean-Claude Juncker appointed President in accordance with the election result. Finally, rejecting the Commission would have delayed our work while the people expect us to have concrete results. My vote is not a blank cheque but a vigilant and demanding support.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. - (IT) Mr Juncker has given answers to many of our doubts, touching on several points that lead me to give my confidence to him and to this Commission. A political Commission, to begin with, which marks the primacy of policy over bureaucracy, where, in his own words, it will be the Directors-General who will follow the commissioners' instructions, not the other way round. The new organisation with seven Vice-Presidents is positive, forcing the College to act as such, not compartmentalised. Above all, I was convinced by Juncker's great pro-European strength, which, more than anything else, unites us. In his words, he has shown that he is fully aware of the crucial moment in which we find ourselves, at that crossroads for which we either become something not only more but profoundly different from the union of states alone or the EU will collapse on itself. I believe that the only hope, the only horizon for all, is Europe, to invest in it, to build a solid alliance politically, fiscally and socially; finding common answers to problems that affect us all, from youth unemployment to climate change, to the implementation of sustainable development. If the Commission really does act to achieve these objectives in full, we will certainly work together.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this new European Commission which reflects the political balance that resulted from last May's elections. Jean-Claude Juncker has a real European stature and if I regret part of the cast of his new team, it is up to the states, some of which have had rather risky choices. This Commission will take office on 1 November and I am delighted that we can finally get to work.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. - I supported the Juncker Commission with my vote. This is despite the fact that some of its members do not converse with my views, and I could imagine another division of responsibilities. The reasons for my support for the Commission are essentially two. I believe that the commissioners-designate has been through a tough but fair hearing. And those supported by the EP, despite their different quality, can hold the position of Commissioner. More fundamentally, however, in today's setting of powers between the EU institutions and the Member States, the composition of the Commission must be a considerable compromise taking into account the results of the elections. And that's the way it is.  I believe that the composition of the Commission and the compromises included in it will not be a source of problems, but can, on the contrary, be an impetus for finding the best solutions. The Commission's support in the EP does not end there, but begins. And I, as a Member, want to contribute in my measure to the Commission's success in the difficult work.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - I have always been firmly opposed to the Commission's ever-increasing agglomeration of power. With the new Commission under Juncker, however, the European Union is once again taking another major step towards centralisation, opacity and lobbying. Since, in my view, no member of this new Commission has sufficient democratic legitimacy and I also call for a reduction in the number of Members of the Commission, I voted against the motion.

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: Written. I voted for Juncker's Commission. Would I have chosen the same 27 Commissioners if I could choose freely on all shelves? No. In that case, there would have been more radical Commissioners and even higher ambitions in the green field. But instead of wearing the 'no' hat, I will then work hard to get concrete results. Our job must be to keep the commission on the promises made and work concrete results. In the Radical Liberals and ALDE, we work with those who want to. Because only through cooperation can you have real influence and actually make a difference to the climate. Compromises need to be made and perhaps we will not get everything we want. But the best must never be the enemy of the good. That's best done in the engine room. Not on the sidelines.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - The new process of electing the President of the European Commission strengthened the democratic legitimacy of the Institutions of the European Union, with the European Parliament playing a prominent role. In the process of hearing candidates for Commissioners of the European Commission, the competent committees of the European Parliament also played an important role in examining and confirming commissioners-designate. Following today's presentation by the President-elect of the Commission on the College of Commissioners and the Work Programme, I voted for the new European Commission, as I believe that Jean-Claude Juncker has put together a quality team of Commissioners. It is an experienced team of several former prime ministers, former ministers and commissioners, and former colleagues of the European Parliament. I am glad that Croatia has received one of the most important portfolios, international cooperation and development, and I would also like to congratulate Croatian Commissioner Neven Mimica and wish him successful work in the new mandate.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - The European Commission chaired by Jean-Claude Juncker is made up of good leadership that can effectively implement the development and employment policies necessary to revive growth in Europe. We could not afford to wait any longer, the necessary reforms must be carried out as soon as possible, targeted investments must be made and a considered use of flexibility must be made. Good and immediate answers must be given to the EU citizens who voted for us and given their confidence.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Writing. - He voted in favour of the establishment of the College of Commissioners and I am using this opportunity for the first time to explain my vote. I have had a number of discussions with my PPE colleagues, my movement and my friends about my final decision. I see the problem in the composition of the Commission, in particular, in the post of High Representative for Foreign Affairs, to be carried out by Mrs Federica Mogherini. I am a member of a generation in my country that lived through its childhood and early youth in the totalitarianism of communism. My family has always been an opponent of communism, some have even been locked up in prison for years. Mrs Mogherini has had a secret period – at some point in her CV – when she has a significant inclination towards communism and ties to the current undemocratic Russia. Normally, I could not support such a high representative. Of course, she may have changed her past views, but even her past experience in foreign policy does not convince me that she should support the entire EU's foreign policy. Finally, I decided to support the Commission as a whole. The explanation is simple. But Russia's autocratic forces would be most happy about its non-establishment. I wish Mr Juncker and his team every success, I am aware that he did not choose Mrs Mogherini and we MEPs will closely monitor and scrutiny her actions. That is why it would be doubtful on my part to sink an otherwise very competent team, which would certainly be a fundamental mistake in terms of the need to move Europe further, which could backfire enormously on our continent. Despite my serious reservations about Mrs Mogherini, I did not want to take this risk.

name: Soraya POST
text: in writing. - Through the EU Treaty, we have committed to ensuring gender equality and equal rights. This is clear from Article 23 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights and Article 8 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It should therefore be an obvious starting point that the EU institutions have an equal representation of men and women. The European Commission should set an example for the Member States and represent the EU’s fundamental values before the rest of the world. This is particularly important in times when fascism and anti-democratic forces are growing in Europe. The President-elect of the Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, has ahead of today’s vote proposed a college of commissioners where only 9 of 28 members are women. This composition does not live up to the commitment to ensure gender equality and equal rights. It does not live up to the definition of gender equality that the Commission itself has set out. For this reason I have chosen to vote against the current proposal. I think it would be a betrayal of the EU’s fundamental values to accept a new college of Commissioners that is as unequal as the previous one.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. - Like more than 200 other Members, I voted against this Commission. Rightly, Jean-Claude Juncker called this Commission the Commission of last chance. A Commission of the last chance to bury democracy and the rule of law once and for all within Europe. But, Mr Juncker, do not underestimate the citizens of Europe! These citizens are increasingly recognizing where your course and the course of your accomplices should lead us: towards a planned economy and a rigid state economy. Towards an exuberant state that monitors the citizen, makes him more and more numerous rules and regulations for his life and curtails his freedom. But more than 200 years of enlightenment have not passed without a trace on our society. We citizens will know how to defend ourselves. This Commission will be left without a chance in its quest to equalise a democratic, constitutional, liberal and diverse society in Europe.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. - A new European Commission is in place, headed by Jean-Claude Juncker. This is a great victory for our political family, the EPP. We are the first force in the European Parliament, it made sense for us to take the lead in the Commission. Now I hope that the projects and policies set out by President Juncker will not go unheeded and will be implemented by the Commissioners: investments, administrative simplification, ambitious policies for industry and energy, deficit reduction, trade policy focused on the growth of our companies. I will remain vigilant for the commitments made before Parliament to be made in strong action.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: in writing. - I believe that the positive vote given by the European Parliament to the new European Commission is an important democratic action that reflects the parliamentary elections. The reticans to certain Commissioners were exceeded by 423 votes in favour of the entire team. After a period of political negotiations and tough hearings in the European Parliament, President Juncker and his Commissioners will take over the leadership of the European Executive on 1 November 2014. This Commission, if it works more closely with the European Parliament than in the past, will succeed in achieving the results it has set itself.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. - I saw in Juncker the possibility of Hope for Europe. I have seen the possibility of compliance with parity and political balance. Democracy would be fulfilled. But I do not understand how Europe can be governed by those who demand guarantees from those who have almost nothing. I do not understand a European government that advocates equality and in which one of its members has made women smaller and where that member, through business gymnastics, thinks that he can buy what is the fundamental value of politics: ethics. A European government where its commissioner, Portuguese like me, has launched my land, an OR-Madeira, into misery. Education and Culture were left in the hands of those who gaoured press freedom and inquined student mobility. I do not understand a European identity, united by its culture, left in the hands of those who do not believe in it. Taking only Citizenship from Commissioner Navracsics is an insult to the Culture and Education itself which are the basis of the whole European project. Navracsics is not worthy of representing European culture. President Juncker did not respect the decision of the Committee on Culture and what he gave me in Hope was subtracted by the lack of courage.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: in writing. - As a Portuguese Socialist MEMBER, in line with the voting direction of the Group of Socialists and Democrats, I decided to vote in favour of the investiture of the Juncker Commission, giving it the benefit of the doubt in the face of the political commitments of change made before the European Parliament. This vote, despite the reservations expressed, takes into account the serious inconveniences that would result from a political impasse in the European Union and is linked to a demanding attitude towards the new Commission, which will continue in its political review. Throughout this process, in which the democratic functioning of the European Union has been strengthened, the demanding attitude of the Socialists has made improvements in the proposed Commission, such as the allocation to Socialist Commissioners of the folders of the Coordination of Sustainable Development and Energy, in addition to new commitments on the economic agenda. The appointments of Commissioners with the profile of Navracsics and Katainen justify reservations. And the uncertainty in skills, budgetary flexibility and investment requires a surveillance attitude. The Portuguese Socialists will continue to demand from the new Commission full compliance with the change programme announced by Juncker, with emphasis on the €300 billion investment plan promised for early 2015.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. – I voted against because the European Commission was not set up in accordance with all the principles of democracy and optimal selection. It should be noted that there are a number of Commissioners who have managed to convince Parliament of its knowledge and competences. Candidates from Lithuania, Ireland and Romania were welcomed. It is also commendable for J.-C. Juncker's decision to revamp the structure of the European Commission. Juncker heard the concerns of MEPs and referred pharmaceutical questions to the Health Commissioner. He also expressed the position that, in order to maintain competitiveness in agriculture across Europe, he would seek to review the common agricultural policy framework. We hope that this will happen. However, there are Commissioners who may have conflicts of interest. Some of them are appointed to certain posts only because of political affiliation. Decisions based on party agreements rather than competences can cast a shadow on the Commission as a whole and weaken it in the future. Today, meanwhile, Europe needs an effective and strong European Commission that is ready to respond today to the daily challenges and to take the necessary decisions.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. - With 423 votes in and 209 in against and 67 abstentions, the European Parliament has approved Jean-Claude Juncker's new European Commission, which will take office on 1 November.  I have supported the future European Commission and its political direction for the next five years.  Jean-Claude Juncker's programme is ambitious and coincides with the current political, economic and financial situation in the European Union. The rapid implementation of a 300 billion euro investment plan will enable the Eu to boost growth and jobs. On international trade, Jean-Claude Juncker said that future free trade agreements would not be concluded at any price and affirmed his goal of securing a fair and balanced agreement on the current trade negotiations between the European Union and the United States. This vote symbolizes an important step in the construction of an ever more democratic European Union. European citizens, in the European elections on 25 May, were able to vote on the election of the future President of the European Commission and on the political direction of the EU. This is another step towards greater transparency and democracy in Europe.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the new Commission led by Jean-Claude Juncker, who presented the Commissioners and their programme, pointing out that they had taken on board the requests of the parliamentary committees following the hearings with the Commissioners-designate. The election of the Commission was an important step towards greater transparency and democracy in Europe. For the GROUP of the European People's Party, the Commission's priority must be to find concrete solutions to the demands of European citizens, particularly on the issues of stability, growth and work, but also on security, immigration and foreign policy.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - I voted against the new Commission, I vote against the substance and forms; I vote against the way in which this European institution works, the arrangements and the composed of the grand coalition and the Council, the irresponsible follow-up to the Troika's guidelines, the political and ideological framework that continues to impose austericide, generating unbearable amounts of social suffering in the southern countries, and undermining the very foundations of the European project. According to Eurostat data, the poverty rate in our country has increased from 24.5% in 2008 to 28.2% in 2012, and the number of poor workers has risen from 10.1% in 2006 to 12.3% in 2012. The new Commission represents the continuity of economic policies that have led our country to a social emergency as we had not known in decades. I voted against this new Commission and endorsed my commitment to combating the dangerous ideological and political drift of a Union which should be dedicated to defending and guaranteeing the rights of its citizens, and not to closing them to serve the interests of a few that no one has chosen and which lead us at a firm pace towards disaster.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: in writing. - My vote is contrary to the election of this Commission where parity is far away and where Commissioners such as Cañete or Hill are listed who until recently held interests with private groups which for me are morally incompatible with the defence of the public interests of European citizenship. Neither the fight against austericide nor the pressing need to restore lost social justice to Europeans nor the determined commitment to an energy and productive model towards sustainability are among the priorities of this Commission, and therefore we do not share its project and cannot vote on it.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted against Mr Juncker's college of commissioners because, judging by people's profiles and auditions, it will mean continuity and tightening of neoliberal policies that violate human rights, which have generated the highest level of unemployment, poverty and social exclusion in the EU. Structural reforms will continue to reduce living and working conditions. It will continue with dire agricultural and food policies for peasantism, which will provide unsafe food and encourage aggressive modes of production for the environment. It will continue to favour large economic groups, at the cost of dismantling and privatizing the public sector. He will continue to look the other way with repression of the trade union movement and social movements fighting to maintain social rights and conquests. Nor will it promote the necessary directives to advance women's equal rights and the fight against sexist violence. Nor does a Commission show respect for the right to decide on the peoples that make up the multinational reality of some States. President Juncker has made no ruling on the Spanish government's decision to prevent Catalonia from contesting a referendum.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: in writing. - As a Socialist Portuguese, in line with the voting direction of the Group of Socialists and Democrats, I decided to vote in favour of the investiture of the Juncker Commission, giving it the benefit of the doubt in the face of the political commitments made before the European Parliament. This vote, despite the reservations expressed, takes into account the serious inconveniences that would result from a political impasse in the European Union and is linked to a demanding attitude towards the new Commission, which will continue in its political review. Throughout this process, in which the democratic functioning of the European Union has been strengthened, the demanding attitude of the Socialists has made it possible to achieve improvements in the proposed Commission, such as the allocation to Socialist Commissioners of the folders of the Coordination of Sustainable Development and Energy, in addition to new commitments on the economic agenda. The appointments of commissioners with the profile of Navracsics and Katainen justify reservations. And the uncertainty in skills, budgetary flexibility and investment requires a surveillance attitude. The Portuguese Socialists will continue to demand from the new Commission full compliance with the change programme announced by Juncker, with emphasis on the €300 billion investment plan promised for early 2015.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. - I would like to congratulate Mr Šefčovič on obtaining an important post as Vice-President of the EC. However, the composition of the EC is more the result of politics and dating with individual portfolios than the result of seeking appropriate expertise. Candidates do not have a direct mandate from citizens, and their choices are increasingly moving away from democratic practices. That's why I'm staying.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. - Since I am the only Croatian MEMBER of the European Parliament who voted against the new composition of the European Commission, I decided to justify my opinion. Despite warnings from several political groups, the proposed Commissioners have proven to be or are in a conflict of interest, have publicly expressed gender animosity and supported civil rights and democratic values violations, which is inadmissible for future public office holders.  One of the main reasons for my disagreement is the future president's clearly stated position on curbing enlargement policy. Therefore, supporting the Juncker Commission means turning its back on candidate countries and potential candidate countries and is not politically wise or long-term beneficial for the stability of the European neighbourhood, including Croatia. Also, by merging general administrations for climate change and energy and for the environment and fisheries, the Commission will significantly weaken sectoral climate change and environmental policies. Low-set targets in achieving a higher share of renewables and energy efficiency based only on declarative emphasis on sustainable development will make the Union economy globally uncompetitive. The new Commission's notional energy policies do not attract private capital with their risks and put Europe at energy uncertainty. My vote and that of my colleagues in the Greens/ESS Club does not mean that we are against all the commissioners and commissioners proposed, but some of the more important guidelines towards prosperity and trust have been misplaced.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - I supported the Commission because I believe that the composition of the Commission gives guarantees to address the problems we have in the EU. During the hinges, the individual Commissioners convinced themselves that, although their nominations are political, they can nevertheless guarantee the professional functioning of their Commissions, and that they know what challenges are ahead of us in order to reduce unemployment and poverty rates, kick-start the growth of the economy, ensure energy security and self-sufficiency, protect the uniqueness of Europe's natural resources, fauna and flora, but also eliminate war conflicts in Europe and the world. I also consider the divisions of competences of the individual Vice-Presidents to be very positive, because they will have to coordinate more the activities of the various commissions and there will be more cooperation between Commissioners than has been the case so far, which will certainly be positively reflected in the regulations submitted to the EP. I also consider positive the promise made by both the President of the Commission and the individual Commissioners that, in future, they want to go to committees more often among Members, but also to informal meetings and discuss with them solutions to the problems that are plaguing the populations of the whole EU. I also supported the Commission because I have a guarantee that the Vice-President of the Commission for Slovakia, p. With his knowledge, experience, expertise and diplomacy, Maroš Ševčovič will contribute to good decisions made by the Commission.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. – I backed the election of the Commission due to commitments including a EUR 300 billion investment plan by February 2015, a relaunch for European industry, a strengthened European Youth Guarantee, a Europe-wide minimum wage, a continued focus on public services, a more democratic structure to replace the Troika, the fight against tax evasion and the introduction of a financial transaction tax – all of which are important to our citizens.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. - It must be acknowledged that Jean-Claude Juncker surprised the Commissioners with his proposals. His proposals from the Commissioners show that he set up the European Commission himself and was not dictated to him by the heads of government of strong states. The really uncomfortable news is Pierre Moscovici, the French socialist who is to become Commissioner for the Economy, Currency and Finance. France's finance minister has failed to reduce France's deficit, has sought to introduce a 70% income tax in his capacity and has flagrantly breached EU budget rules. It's called making a capa gardener. This nomination is all the more dangerous because the ECB's boss is Italian Mario Draghi and the Head of the Eurogroup is to be a Spaniard. All these countries are pushing for the relaxation of EU financial rules, which is the way to hell. The last thing the EU needs today is more socialism and budgetary irresponsibility. Without Moscovici, I might have voted in favour, that's how I abstained.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing. - I supported jean-Claude Juncker's European Commission in today's vote because I believe that the current situation in the European Union and around the world requires a Commission with a strong mandate and a Commission that will work team-up to comprehensively solve all the problems for the benefit of the citizens of the European Union. I welcome the fact that the Commission has already received support at the October plenary of the European Parliament. Of course, like many other Members, I had reservations about some commissioners-designate. In the end, however, these reservations did not outweigh the need to start this institutional engine of European integration in a timely way, as the Commission has been dubbed. Early approval will allow the Commission to take up its tasks as early as 1 November. The situation in Europe is serious and every day of delay in the deployment of new Commissioners would be a great loss for all.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. - I am voting against the composition of the Commission, because it is made up of Presidents and members who do not have the will and the capacity to lead the European Union down a path that is in favour of its citizens, its nations, security and stability. This Commission does not live up to the expectations of the Europe of the future.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of the election of the European Commission, because the democratic legitimacy of the Juncker-led Commission is stronger than before, thanks to the Treaty of Lisbon, which ensured better transparency of political processes, including the role of the European Parliament and the increased participation of European citizens. In the framework of this democratic process, the President of the Commission was elected directly following a wide-ranging European campaign, and its members were accepted or rejected by EP commissions on the basis of thorough and critical hearings. The new Commission can launch with a programme focusing on effective, pro-growth Crisis Management in Europe, restructuring with a focus on job creation, increased mainstreaming of European solidarity and fundamental rights and values, and a strong political mandate. Perhaps the most important areas for the future (external relations, sustainable development, energy, fundamental rights) within the new, more targeted structure of the Juncker-led Commission are overseen by vice-presidents of the left as a way of enforcing left-wing values. It is regrettable that, because of the Hungarian Government's negative Europe policy and unfortunate action, Hungary did not get involved in the democratic process that led to the formation of the Juncker-led Commission, but instead became further marginalised and took on political burdens. In the wake of today's decision, the new European Commission (albeit in a modest position) will be up to Tibor Navracsics, whose position is severely strained by the fact that, because of its political past, the relevant EP commission did not consider it suitable for its post.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing - I applaud Mr Juncker's efforts to date in the constitutionality of the new European Commission, as well as his efforts to reallocate portfolios to individual Commissioners as effectively as possible. I firmly believe that, thanks to the hearings held in the European Parliament, the competences of the candidates have been thoroughly examined and the clearance of the entire college in the PLENARY of the EP is proof of their qualities and the beginning of a new successful phase of cooperation between the EC and the EP.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. - After conducting the last hours of final negotiations on several fronts, we have obtained from President Juncker several commitments which we believed were indispensable in the defence of the interests of the citizen. The casting of the Commissioners is certainly not entirely what we would have liked, and the programme is currently only a set of promises that will have to be made, but we have decided to give this Last Chance Commission a chance. The $300 billion: we have been assured that it would not be recycled funds. We will ensure that the Commission is used to finance public investments that are essential for recovery and useful to citizens.  The arbitration clause (ISDS) in TTIP-CETA: we will never accept a company dictating laws for its commercial ambitions or expected profits, at the expense of the citizen.  Drugs: we have obtained that medicines are not a commodity, nor are the patients of customers, an important victory for us and which concerns the health of all citizens.  Social dumping: revising the Detachment of Workers Directive, currently too used to organise social dumping to the detriment of small businesses and workers, is essential.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. - Today I abstained in the vote on this new Commission and Mr Juncker for the following reasons: 1. I was not convinced by some Commissioner candidates in the hearings; in particular I was not convinced by the Commissioner candidates of Spain, France and the UK; 2. This European Commission seems to be the same as the previous one of Mr Barroso, and it will submit to the Council and its Member States; 3. This European Commission seems to be the secretary of the Council. This is not what we need. We need a real European and federalist government of Europe, clearly committed to democratic principles and to respecting the will of the people.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - I voted outright against this new college of Commissioners by Mr Juncker, since it is nothing more than a change of faces for the continued policy of the Barroso Commission. Neoliberal policies that violate the most fundamental human rights, which have taken us to levels of unemployment never known in EU history, to intolerable levels of poverty and social exclusion. This Commission ensures that the path of structural reforms that seek to level down living and working conditions in the EU will be followed. Reforms that will continue to favour large economic groups, at the cost of dismantling and privatizing the small public sector that remains in EU countries. For all these reasons I voted against this Juncker Commission.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: in writing. - The European Commission is the engine of European integration. Its new President, Mr Juncker, is an unreformed Euro-federalist. He restated today his commitment to the ‘Community method’ rather than an inter-governmental approach. There is no commitment to fundamental reform, to change, in the way that I and our citizens clearly demand. I cannot therefore support this Commission or what it stands for. However, I am optimistic that Lord Hill, the nominee of the United Kingdom, will prove his worth. On this basis, and in keeping with my Group whip, I abstained.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favour of the new Commission led by Jean-Claude Juncker. The Commission received backing from a very large majority of the Parliament, and Mr Junkerʼs own nomination is the direct result of the outcome of the European Parliament elections.  Never before has a Commission had more democratic legitimacy and been more accountable. The Commission has promised to lead a coordinated policy approach leading to stability, growth and unity for its citizens and Member States and we have insisted it cooperates closely with this Parliament.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. - Together with my colleagues from the GUE/NGL and 200 other MePs, I voted without any mood against the Commission proposed by Jean-Claude Juncker. The majority of the European Parliament approved it by 423 votes in person, 209 against and 67 abstentions, far less than the Commission chaired by Manuel Barroso in 2004 and 2009. However, this is only an extension of the same dogmatisms, far removed from the message of the citizens in the European elections.  This new Commission is therefore not up to the current democratic and social challenges. Its architecture puts the market in almost every commissioner's portfolio; the few requests made during the cartoons of hearings of the candidate Commissioners before the European Parliament were not taken into account. While the actual evaluation of nominations before parliamentary committees quickly gave way to blackmail between the main political groups, EPP, S and D and ALDE, the majority of the European Parliament has therefore finished making a fool of itself and will bear a heavy responsibility in the situation to come.  The continued existence of Mr. Navracsics and Mr. Canete are two sad caricatures of what should not have been done. Let those who have supported her not come and teach us lessons.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - Beyond the feigned social concerns with the most disadvantaged, jobs and economic growth, what remains of this Commission is the certainty of the continuation of the neoliberal orientation of the policies that have dragged the EU into the current recession. In addition to the attempt to present a renewed, cohesive European Commission, anchored in ten priority projects, in shared and supportive management, what remains is complete uncertainty around a confusing new organisation chart, with numerous areas of overlap, to which is added a vertical hierarchy that does not bode well, with commissioners of first, second and even third. Not only the deep link between each of the Commissioners and the neoliberal agendas of the European Commission, but also the direct links to the great European capital, emerges from the hearings.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. - With the new Commission under Juncker, the EU is once again taking another major step towards centralism, opacity and lobbying. Since, in my view, none of the new Commissioners has sufficient democratic legitimacy and I am in favour of halving the Commission, I voted against it in this election.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. - I have refused to approve the appointment of the President, the EU Foreign Minister and the other members of the Commission as a college for the term of office until 31 October 2019. As an EU government (executive), the EU Commission is also the initiator of EU legislation (legislative). This is a fundamental violation of the principle of the separation of powers, which is inherent in the rule of law. I stand for a reduction in THE EU's competences and more sovereign rights for the Member States. Jean-Claude Juncker and his Commission with him stand for the opposite. The mere appointment of the failed French Finance Minister as Commissioner for Economic Affairs makes the entire Commission unelectable in itself.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. - I have been very concerned about the nomination of several Commissioners-designate whose hearings did not convince me or who did not fully meet the criteria of independence, absence of conflicts of interest and commitment to EU values. In particular, as a member of the Committee on Culture and Education (CULT), I was very unsatisfied that the Committeeʼs vote rejecting the portfolio for culture, education, youth and citizenship to Mr Navracsics was insufficiently taken into account by Mr Juncker. I have also been concerned by the lack of effort to reach gender equality in the new Commission. Nevertheless, I believe that having a functioning Commission in place as soon as possible for the EU to work in the best interests of the citizens is crucial. In addition, Member States are responsible for nominating their candidates for Commissioners and the composition of the new Commission reflects the political reality across the EU. My political group has had a strong input into this new Commission and we will continue to insist on the close cooperation with Parliament that Mr Juncker has committed himself to. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of the approbation of the new European Commission proposed by Mr Juncker.

name: Hermann WINKLER
text: Writing. - I could not agree to the appointment of the new EU Commission under the leadership of Jean-Claude Juncker.  I call on EU institutions to comply with their own laws. According to the Lisbon Treaty, the size of the European Commission from this year will be only two thirds of the number of Member States, i.e. only 19 Commissioners. Now that there have been 28 heads named by the Member States, all the EU institutions are not following their own rules and are also deliberately missing the opportunity to streamline and set priorities. The new Commission lacks the will to urgently change and renew the European Union. I also take a critical view of individual personnel decisions by Juncker. Anyone who, with Pierre Moscovici, is one of the main culprits for France's disastrous financial situation as the EU's top monetary watchdog, will make the buck a gardener. Let me stress that my vote is not directed at Günther Oettinger or many other capable colleagues. However, as the procedure does not allow individual votes, which must change in the future, I felt compelled to vote against the new EU Commission.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. - I voted with great hope for the Commission presented today in plenary by Jean-Claude Juncker. It is a natural vote that follows the vote in the EPP Congress in Dublin for Jean-Claude Juncker's candidacy for the head of the EC, the one given in the EP plenary to appoint him as President of the Commission, and the vote on 25 May, from the European elections, in which the UDMR supported this candidacy.  I hope that the new Commission will know how to avoid the dangers it is exposed to in the very first days after it comes into operation. I agree with the principle of flexibility and the stimulation of teamwork on which Jean-Claude Juncker built the new EC. However, we will have to see this principle put into practice, we will have to see the EC's new role in its relationship with the Member States, that of guidance, support and synergy, not just that of control and coercion. How the new Commission starts its work and achieves the balance between the Vice-Presidents and the teams of Commissioners it coordinates will be essential. The new EC must become the true partner of the Member States! I wish the new Commission good and good luck!

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. - (IT) I believe that today's vote has guaranteed us another five long years of austerity, rigour and economic recession. Unfortunately, this is a sad observation, because the 'new' Juncker Commission is nothing more than a clear continuation, perhaps with even worse aspects, of barroso's ten years. Moreover, it was difficult to expect anything other than an agreement born out of the traditional European political families of the people, socialists and liberals, who are among the main culprits of the current dramatic situation. My Italian colleagues from the Democratic Party and Forza Italia today strongly supported all this, in the face of the radical change that they demanded every day during the election campaign. Moreover, it is quite simple to understand that the person who ruled the Eurogroup until recently and who has been at the top of his country for almost twenty years will hardly be able to represent change. And the team that will support him is in some ways even worse, with an oil tanker dealing with the climate, a financial lobbyist to regulate the banks and a minister who has brought his country to financial disreseabey will guide us into the economy: certainly a nice representation of what this European Union is becoming.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. - As a Socialist Portuguese, in line with the voting direction of the Group of Socialists and Democrats, I decided to vote in favour of the investiture of the Juncker Commission, giving it the benefit of the doubt in the face of the political commitments made before the European Parliament. This vote, despite the reservations expressed, takes into account the serious inconveniences that would result from a political impasse in the European Union and is linked to a demanding attitude towards the new Commission, which will continue in its political review. Throughout this process, in which the democratic functioning of the European Union has been strengthened, the demanding attitude of the Socialists has made improvements in the proposed Commission, such as the allocation to Socialist Commissioners of the folders of the Coordination of Sustainable Development and Energy, in addition to new commitments on the economic agenda. The appointments of Commissioners with the profile of Navracsics and Katainen justify reservations. And the uncertainty in skills, budgetary flexibility and investment requires a surveillance attitude. The Portuguese Socialists will continue to demand from the new Commission full compliance with the change programme announced by Juncker, with emphasis on the €300 billion investment plan promised for early 2015.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr. President! Since today, we have, in fact, a European government, and I would like to hope that the new impetus will also spread to the budget. Budgetary truth and budgetary clarity should be introduced. Budget is, after all, the policy cast in figures. We still have the phenomenon that, depending on how one calculates, we have between 25 and 33 billion outstanding bills that cannot be paid. They cannot be paid because the Member States do not want to re-transfer their membership fees. I believe that this would be the Commission's first most important task, together with Parliament, for the budget to restore budgetary truth and clarity. That is why I was able to vote for the Commission today, because I hope that the Commission can take a decisive step forward here.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. - This Draft Amending Budget will save substantial money, but this money is not going back to taxpayers.  Instead it is being spent to part-finance DAB3 and DAB4. So whilst I support the principle of cuts, these are not true cuts to the EU budget. For that reason I have abstained on this motion.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. - In view of the difficulties encountered in means of payment, it is proposed to allocate the surplus appropriations of the 2013 budget to payment appropriations in the 2014 financial year. This perspective must be supported on the one hand in view of the size of the outstanding payments and, on the other hand, of the sectors mainly affected by this outstanding (humanitarian sector, youth, structural funds,...).

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This draft 2014 amending budget on the surplus resulting from the execution of the 2013 financial year aims to register more than EUR 1 billion in surplus for the 2013 financial year. EUR 771 million from positive revenues (including fines and late interest) and EUR 276 million from under-employment.  I would like to point out that the 2014-2020 multi-year framework does not take into account the outstanding payments, which at the end of 2013 amounted to EUR 23.4 billion. There is, therefore, the growing gap between commitments and payments, the emergence of a European debt even as Brussels sends letters to member states on their budgets.  It is also interesting to note that European competition policy is not so perfect, as evidenced by the high level of fines and interest (an additional 1.331 billion for 2013 but surely more than 3 billion in 2014...).  Finally, this draft amending budget does not change the budgetary and political guidelines decided, and I have spoken out against.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this technical measure that moves budget surpluses from 2013 to 2014 for a total amount of € 1,005 million.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour.  The surplus will partly compensate for member states' contribution to the financing of amending budget 3/2014.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - In view of the strong pressure on payments for 2014 and the strengthening requested by the Commission in draft amending budget (PBR) No 3/2014, it has been proposed that the amount of the surplus for the financial year 2013 be used to finance the newly created budget line "Reserve for additional payment needs" on the expenditure side of the budget.  Bearing in mind that the funds requested by the Commission in the form of draft budget amending measures will be used to be able to make payments to local authorities, small businesses and other beneficiaries in 2014, I believe that it is essential to reach agreement on draft amending budgets before negotiations begin with the Council. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution today.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - The Financial Regulations stipulate that the Commission is obliged to submit each year a draft amending budget which accounts for the result of the previous year.  In this case, the current reporting applies to the year 2013. If there has been a surplus of around EUR 1 005 million, it would appear that EUR 30 billion of invoices are still unpaid, so the payment appropriations are not sufficient to cover everything that has already been spent. The Council has asked the Member States to pay their bills within thirty days, so if we continue with this type of practice, it will mean, for example, that Erasmus students will not be able to receive emoluments for their grants, some of the beneficiaries of the Structural Funds will not be paid and many examples of disruption to citizens could be made.  The 2015 budget is already under discussion but we want guarantees to close the 2014 budget.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - With amending budget number two for 2014, the Commission has accounted for the surplus from the 2013 budget, the balances of which are in line with previous years.  These surplus amounts are repaid to the Member States by offsetting the contributions that the Member States pay monthly to the European Union. For our country this sum will amount to about 110 million euros. I voted in favour of this draft amending budget, as the measure essentially involves the return of funds from the EU treasury to the Member States.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the second amending budget for the financial year 2014. I share, however, the criticisms made by Mr José Manuel Fernandes. The Council is systematically violating the Treaty on European Union, which clearly provides that there can be no deficit in the Union's fiscal year. If the commitments made with the authorisation of the budgetary authority (therefore also of the Council) are faced with a lack of funds for their payment, this only proves that Parliament was right when it complained about the difference between commitment appropriations and payment appropriations. And they also prove that the Council lied when it promised to provide the missing funds if they were to prove necessary.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this purely technical budget, which forms part of a specific procedure codified in the Financial Regulation, which, once the result of the previous year's financial year has been established, requires that the budgetary changes noted be adopted and incorporated into the current financial year. The current situation, which is entirely positive, is that a surplus of EUR 1 005 million from the implementation of the 2013 financial year will be accounted for in 2014, which means that the EU will have at its disposal an additional sum of own resources to reduce the need for any additional contributions from the Member States.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Written. - (SV) The Moderates in the European Parliament voted today on the EU budget for 2015. When the budget was increased compared to last year, we were very sceptical that the European Parliament wanted to increase the budget further, especially given that many EU countries suffer from deficits and high public debt. It is therefore important that the EU budget is used properly, and that politicians take responsibility for both Sweden's and the EU's economy. For this reason, we chose to support the European Parliament's call for higher funding for research, innovation and to complete the internal market, because this is what adds value to both Sweden and the EU. In addition, it was important for us to support the EU's asylum and migration programmes in order to create safe and legal routes into the EU, including by strengthening Frontex. On the other hand, we cannot accept that more taxpayers' money is spent on agricultural subsidies and huge subsidy schemes to support archaic and climate-damaging industries.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of this measure, which represents an amending budget and refers to a surplus for the EU 2013 budget of around EUR 1 billion, largely the result of higher revenues for fines and default interest. As a rule, this figure should be returned to the Member States, but in view of a number of problems and a continuing lack of funds, especially for payments, the European Parliament's Committee on Budgets has proposed linking the adoption of this amending budget No 2 to the following 3 and 4, so as to compensate for unforeseen revenue and expenditure and thus have a neutral impact. This, together with additional amending budgets, should even lead to a final surplus for the EU coffers. It is therefore essential to consider this amending budget as linked to subsequent budgets, and as a priority over the discussions and adoption of the budget for next year 2015. All this because it is considered absolutely necessary to regulate the previous situations as soon as possible, before dealing with everything else.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - Draft amending budget 2/2014 intends to record in the 2014 budget a surplus of the 2013 budget, worth EUR 1005 million of positive differences resulting from its implementation: 276 million derived from the sub-execution and 42 million negative changing variations. As I agree with the principle of transferring surpluses from one financial year to the next, I voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. - This report intended to introduce the surplus to the budget, resulting from the implementation of the budget year 2013. Due to the payment crisis, a historically low surplus of EUR 1 005 million is to be entered in the 2014 EU budget. Normally the surplus reduces the contribution of the Members States to the EU budget by the same amount. I consider that this budget amendment is positive as it is taken in the best interest of the programmes in question that could have been negatively affected due to the lack of funds. That is why I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. - I welcome the good budget management efforts that have resulted in a surplus of around EUR 1 billion in the implementation of the 2013 budget. Given the very significant pressure on the EU budget, this surplus will be included in the 2014 budget. In a context of fiscal difficulties, it is essential to ensure that surpluses are allocated correctly.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The EU Financial Regulation provides for the Commission to present an annual draft amending budget to budget the surplus resulting from the previous year's budgetary year, in this case the 2013 budget year. Year after year, the payments situation becomes critical. At the end of 2013, for example, there were more than 23 billion unpaid debts and they would now be approaching 30 billion. This is of course a cause for concern because the European budget is 75% funded by national contributions. Even though the Treaty gives the Council and Parliament the same power over expenditure, in fact the States have the final say on payments. An agreement on the 2014 amending budget is therefore both an urgent necessity and a prerequisite for the final adoption of the 2015 budget. We will be vigilant, as Europe needs a consolidated budget to invest in growth. More profoundly, the repeated crises are a reminder of the urgent need for a substantive debate on the EU's resources so that it gains fiscal autonomy.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the amendment to paragraph 46 European Parliament Resolution of 22 October 2014 on the Council position on the draft amending budget No 2/2014 of the European Union for the 2014 financial year, section III, as we consider that CAP appropriations and any other budget appropriations should not be used to finance bullfighting activities involving the death of the bull. Such financing also constitutes a breach of the European Convention for the Protection of Animals on Livestock (Council Directive 98/58/EC).

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - It is urgent, and of extreme importance for the credibility of the European Union, to ensure the correction of budgetary imbalances, due to insufficient allocation to deliver payments for commitments made. These are imbalances caused by the Council's repeated stance on increasing budget cuts, especially in terms of payment appropriations. The Council's position in this and other amending budgets will serve to demonstrate whether or not it is in good faith in this process, whether it is reliable and assumes its institutional loyalty. These amending budgets are intended to pay for investments, programmes, projects already carried out and duly authorised, often by the Council itself, for SMEs, young people, scientists, local authorities, NGOs. It is unacceptable for the Council to refuse - and in particular the Council - to pay what it has requested and authorised. It should also be stressed that the Council has signed, annually, in the context of conciliation with Parliament, statements which assume that it approves amending budgets necessary for payments that are to be confirmed. The commitments are to be fulfilled and I am hopeful that the commitments between the institutions and with the citizens will be respected.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - Draft amending budget No 2/2014 aims to include in the 2014 budget a surplus for the financial year 2013, in the amount of EUR 1005 million, which is mainly the result of a surplus of EUR 771 million of positive differences resulting from the implementation of revenue, EUR 276 million for under-implementation of expenditure and EUR 42 million from negative exchange variations. We agree with the principle of transferring surpluses from a given financial year to the budget of the following year, provided that this corresponds to additional revenue! We regret that this budget surplus serves to reduce the proportion of the GNI-based contribution of the Member States to the EU budget, rather than being an extraordinary revenue that is so lacking, in order to bridge the gap of a budget determined by a Multiannual Financial Framework of indigence. Furthermore, in the current framework, marked by the accumulation of debt resulting from expenditure authorised by the EU and the lack of payments by some of the Member States that contribute the most (and even more should contribute, taking into account the need to realise the redistributive function of the budget...) to the EU budget.
