Hence our abstention.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - I supported the proposal as such, because without it it would be very difficult to deal with the areas it covers. However, I regret that the amendments that I supported, the main objective of which was to reduce expenditure for Members, be it their salaries, travel allowances or distance allowances, have not been pass. In the difficult economic and social situation in which the EU is currently in, this would be a good signal to citizens that we are ready to make savings on our own.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the draft amending budget. This surplus will partly compensate for member states' contribution to the financing of amending budget 3/2014.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - I am voting against draft amending budget No 1/2004. 2/2014, because the surplus money is not allocated as it should in the following year, but is lost in various budgets for its own benefit.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the amendment to paragraph 46 European Parliament Resolution of 22 October 2014 on the Council position on the draft amending budget No 2/2014 of the European Union for the 2014 financial year, section III, as we consider that CAP appropriations and any other budget appropriations should not be used to finance bullfighting activities involving the death of the bull. Such financing also constitutes a breach of the European Convention for the Protection of Animals on Livestock (Council Directive 98/58/EC).

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the amendment to paragraph 46 European Parliament Resolution of 22 October 2014 on the Council position on the draft amending budget No 2/2014 of the European Union for the 2014 financial year, section III, as we consider that CAP appropriations and any other budget appropriations should not be used to finance bullfighting activities involving the death of the bull. Such financing also constitutes a breach of the European Convention for the Protection of Animals on Livestock (Council Directive 98/58/EC).

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - I voted for this motion for a resolution because the adoption of the amendment to budget No. 2 for the 2014 financial year reduced member states' gross national income contribution to the EU budget by entering a 2013 surplus of 1.005 million into the 2014 budget. Taking into account the scale of the financial crisis affecting European countries and the structure of the European Union, these amendments represent a coherent and balanced approach to the EU financial framework.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. - The draft amending budget is only intended to budget for the surplus for the 2013 financial year. However, again this year we are seeing a deficit in payment credits.  We must find a lasting solution to the recurring problem of unpaid debts, and stop this snowball effect at the risk of remaining paralyzed in a budget crisis. The credibility of the European Union is at stake.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. - I supported the decision, as it only introduces the surplus to the budget resulting from the implementation of the budget year 2013.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Gérard Deprez that the appropriations provided for therein will be used to cover the need for additional payment appropriations identified by the Commission in draft amending budget No 3. Unfortunately, the implementation of the annual budgets and the gap between commitment appropriations and payments clearly show that current budgetary policy cannot remain unchanged. We need to move strongly towards a reform of the own resources system, in order to free the EU budget from the needs of individual Member States.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - Draft amending budget 2/2014 intends to record in the 2014 budget a surplus of the 2013 budget, worth EUR 1005 million of positive differences resulting from its implementation: 276 million derived from the sub-execution and 42 million negative changing variations. As I agree with the principle of transferring surpluses from one financial year to the next, I voted in favour.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - In its draft amendment to budget No 2 for 2014, the European Commission included a budget surplus of €1 billion resulting from an increase in revenues (+€771 million), lower expenditure than planned (+€276 million) and negative exchange rate differences (-€42 million). This would mean reducing Member States' contributions to the European budget by €1 billion.  As the draft amendment to budget number 2 was adopted in parallel with the draft amendment to budget number 3 (mobilisation of additional payment funds) and 4 (revision in the forecast of traditional own resources) additional payments of EUR 106 million to the budget (payments made by Member States to the GNI budget) are needed, thus securing funds for additional payments.  I supported this Report because it is important to meet existing budgetary commitments.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. - I supported this proposal for Draft amending budget No 2/2014, which aims to enter in the 2014 budget the surplus from the 2013 financial year, amounting to EUR 1 005 million.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the report by Mr De Clercq on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and Industrial Policy. Deprez on the technical measure that shifts budget surpluses from 2013 to 2014 for a amort of around 1 billion Euros, to compensate for unexpected revenues and expenditures, and to have a final surplus for the EU coffers

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report endorses the EU's 2nd amending budget for 2014. It aims to include in the 2014 budget the "surplus" of EUR 1,005,000,000 in the 2013 budget. A sign of the EU's chaotic management: the budget shows an excess while at the same time all existing indicators show a shortage of payment appropriations, both in the 2012 budget and in the 2013 budget. The report proposes to allocate this "surplus" to the financing of a new budget line, numbered 40 04 01, entitled "Reserve for Additional Payment Needs". A cat will not find her little ones! A surplus to pay a non-payment of the same budget. I abstain on this text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this amending budget in order to accommodate the surpluses resulting from the implementation of the 2013 financial year.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. - I have voted in favour of this report as it proposes effective ways to allocate the surplus amount for the year 2013. This report also changes the breakdown of contributions between Member States on the basis of the latest updated macroeconomic data.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. It is welcome to note that the draft amending budget No. 2/2014, which allows unused appropriations to be deferred to 2014 in 2013, has been adopted.  I particularly welcome the decision of rapporteur Gérard Deprez to carry out parallel to this, the negotiations on amending budgets 3 and 4, in order to give the Union the necessary means to act. The amending budget 3 includes the need for additional payment appropriations. If all three projects are adopted, the net budgetary impact for Member States will be EUR 105,700,000. This is little compared to what they could actually give if they had the political will.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. - I support the Draft Amending Budget (DAB) No 2/2014, which is intended to introduce the surplus to the budget resulting from the implementation of the budget year 2013.  In order to align the procedural calendar, the BUDG Committee decided to keep the DABs of 2014 as a package. By keeping the three DABs as a package there are no additional costs for Member States.

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 2/2014 because it aims only to enter in the budget the surplus resulting from the implementation of the previous year. At the end of the 2013 financial year, in fact, there was a surplus of about 1,005 million Euros. This sum, according to the Financial Regulation, results in a refund to the Member States made, as a rule, by offsetting the contributions paid monthly by member states to the EU. For Italy, the amount of the refund is around EUR 110 million. The surplus will therefore compensate, in part, for the member states' contribution to the financing of amending budget No 3.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This draft amending budget No. 2/2014 does not solve the serious underlying problem of unpaid debts. As of 31/12/2013, the latter amounted to more than 23 million euros and given the expected snowball effect, unpaid bills will exceed 27 million euros by the end of 2014. Worse, the EU has 220 billion RAL (commitment authorizations that are not covered by payment credits). Clearly, the EU has made commitments that it cannot honour and is therefore unable to apply to itself the budgetary rigour it requires of member states. Today, it finds itself concretely on the verge of default. Finally, in such a context, what credibility can be given to Mr Juncker, who is announcing a major multi-year programme of additional investments of 300 billion euros. Who's going to pay? Member States? Or should we expect the creation of a direct European tax which will further affect the purchasing power of the European peoples, already crushed by the austerity measures imposed by Brussels... This draft amending budget is therefore only a small sheet applied to contain a haemorrhage. For all these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of this draft budget which aims to set aside the 2013 budget surplus. Indeed, as part of its competition policy, the European Commission has raised more than one billion euros through various fines. The payments go directly to the general budget of the European Union in deduction of national contributions. However, we already know that the 2014 budget will be out of balance, due to a lack of willingness on the part of the Council to pay for the closure of the various programmes. I therefore supported the idea of setting aside the 2013 surplus until a solution could be found to balance the 2014 budget.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I supported amending budget No. 2/2014 of the European Union for the financial year 2014, Part III - Commission, aimed at entering EUR 1 005 million as a surplus from the 2013 financial year into the 2014 budget. It is clear that such amendments do not solve the real problem of unpaid bills reaching €25 billion, so I think it is important to highlight the fact that the EU's credibility is again being questioned. Delaying the adoption of as many decisions as possible, as proposed by the Council, is also not a solution. We must fulfil the commitments we have made in the past years and primarily during the negotiation process of the new Multiannual Financial Framework. Otherwise, it is clear that it will not be possible to properly implement the agreed Multiannual Financial Framework if we do not respect the agreed one already in the first year of its implementation.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - With draft amending budget No 2/2014, the European Commission has accounted for the result of the previous year, namely the surplus from the 2013 budget. At the end of the year, there was a surplus of around EUR 1005 million at the end of the year. The Financial Regulation provides for a refund of the sums to the Member States, with compensation for the contributions paid monthly by them to the EU. With this draft amending budget there will be a refund of the sums whose amounts vary from Member State to Member State.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Deprez report amending the amending budget for the 2014 financial year, because it deals urgently with the issue of the 23 billion euros in budget deficit. The bulk treatment of all the amending budget projects introduced for 2014 seems to me to be a good strategy. This should avoid any refusal of additional funds on the part of the Council in the context of filling this imbalance. The beneficiaries of European programmes, as well as Europe itself, deserve the commitments to be honoured. I also agree on the principle of not starting negotiations on the 2015 budget until the 2014 amending budget is amended.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report to demand that the Council urgently resolve the alarming payment crisis already amounting to more than EUR 26 billion in unpaid invoices. The EU must be a good payer and meet its commitments. This is depended on by public institutions, private institutions, NGOs, SMEs, students, researchers, universities, which have participated in European programmes and which continue to expect eu-committed funding. The EU must pay what it owes. The situation of defaults cannot continue to be delayed.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported this European Parliament resolution on the amending budget for 2014. In order to honour payments from local authorities, small businesses and other beneficiaries of EU funds in 2014, the European Commission had to apply for additional funds.  Reaching agreement between the political groups on the 2014 amending budget was fundamental in order to be able to start negotiations on the 2015 budget with the Council.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 2/2014, relating to the surplus resulting from the implementation of the 2013 financial year, which provides for a surplus, to be entered in the Union budget for the financial year 2014, amounting to EUR 1 005 million, thereby reducing member states' contributions by the same amount. The main components of this surplus are a positive result on the revenue side of EUR 771 million, an under-implementation of expenditure of EUR 276 million and a negative exchange rate difference of EUR 42 million. There are currently three draft amending budgets proposed by the Commission for the 2014 budget. Taking into account the 3 draft amending budgets in total, the net impact on the budget would be only EUR 106 million.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the amendment to paragraph 46 European Parliament Resolution of 22 October 2014 on the Council position on the draft amending budget No 2/2014 of the European Union for the 2014 financial year, section III, as we consider that CAP appropriations and any other budget appropriations should not be used to finance bullfighting activities involving the death of the bull. Such financing also constitutes a breach of the European Convention for the Protection of Animals on Livestock (Council Directive 98/58/EC).

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - Draft amending budget 2/2014 intends to record in the 2014 budget a surplus of the 2013 budget, worth EUR 1005 million of positive differences resulting from its implementation: 276 million derived from the sub-execution and 42 million negative changing variations. As I agree with the principle of transferring surpluses from one financial year to the next, I voted in favour.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. - I welcome today’s vote in favour of the Draft Amending Budget No 2/2014 on the surplus of the implementation of budget year 2013. A surplus of EUR 1 005 million will be entered in the EU budget for 2014, thus reducing by the same amount the contributions of the Member States. The surplus comes mostly from fines and interest on late payments.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. - This is a budget adjustment from the previous period. The budget is developing more positively than originally foreseen. This is a €9.5bn cut in EU own resources requirements. This is also good news for Slovakia and for other EU Member States, which should pay less in the EU budget (eur 53 million less for Slovakia). I'm voting FOR.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. - Draft budget amendment No. 2/2014 is dedicated solely to bringing a surplus of EUR 1.005 million from 2013 into the budget. By adopting this amendment to budget No. 2 would reduce member states' GNI contribution share to the EU budget by EUR 1.005 million, partially replacing their contribution to amending Budget No 1.005 million. 3 (EUR 3 170 million of additional own resources required).  I therefore underline the need to implement the process of adopting draft amendments to budget No 1000/2013. 2 in parallel with the negotiations on draft amending budget No 2. 3 relating to the mobilisation of additional payment appropriations and draft amendments to budget No 1000/2013. 4 relating to the review of traditional own resources estimates, other revenues and the final determination of some penalties, allowing for an additional EUR 2 059 million of own resources which could further reduce the need for additional appropriations from draft amendments to budget No 2 059 million. 3. I consider it important to maintain a political and procedural link between draft amending budget No 3000/2013. 2, 3 and 4, and based on that, I support this report.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. - I supported this as there are no additional costs for Member States.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I support amending budget No. 2/2014 of the European Union for the financial year 2014, Part III - Commission (12300/2014 - C8 -0160/2014 - 2014/2035(BUD)). I believe the changes were made in draft budget No. 2/2014 of high quality and that the entry of EUR 1.005 million as a surplus from the 2013 financial year into the 2014 budget will help in certain financial sectors within the European Union.  On the revenue side, the increase mainly stems from penalties and default interest, which means that if we add this to the 2014 budget, the contribution that must be paid by the Member States themselves of the European Union will be reduced. By faciliting contribution payments, Member States will be able to use these funds to improve market and economic conditions in their countries. And therefore, the European Union will also progress in a positive direction. Improving the quality of life of every citizen within european union countries is what needs to be pursued, and amending this budget is another step in that direction.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. - I am voting against this plan because the transfer of the surplus for 2013 to the 2014 budget is not taking place in targeted areas where there are real needs and will help the Member States of the European Union, but as a reserve for the need for additional payments which means that this money will be managed for the benefit of those in power.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. - Given the very significant pressure on 2014 payments and the consolidation requested by the Commission in PBR 3/2014, it is proposed that the 2013 surplus be allocated to the financing of a new budget line, numbered 40 04 01, entitled "Reserve for Additional Payment Needs" and contained in the expenditure component of the budget, rather than reducing own resources based on GNI. If PBR 3/2014 is adopted by the Council without amendment, this amendment will be withdrawn.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. I want to denounce the insincerity of the European States which, last November, agreed, in dialogue with Parliament, to create a reserve for unforeseen events in the 2014-2020 financial framework. And today the Council refuses to apply it. Instead, he proposes to make the budget cavalry and asks us to let the project owners and local authorities bear the brunt of their inadequacy. Without these elements of flexibility, the Council would not have had an agreement. And today the Council tramples him, at the same time as our assembly. Everyone knows that the Union needs a boost for growth and jobs. Everyone knows that it will not be done without fresh money. As the Council emerges from its schizophrenia. Let them respect the citizens of Europe. Let him start by paying his debts and keeping his commitments.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. - I voted against the proposal for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the Council's position on draft amendments to budget No 1009/2013. 2/2014 of the European Union for the financial year 2014, Part III- Commission, as the rapporteur proposes instead of reducing the GDP contribution of the Member States to replace member states' contribution to amending budget No 1.005 million. 3., and therefore proposes that the process of adopting the draft amendment to budget No 3 2 in parallel with the negotiations on draft amending budget No 2. 3, relating to the mobilisation of additional payment appropriations and draft amendments to budget No 3. 4 concerning the review of traditional own resources assessments, other revenues and the final determination of some penalties.  In my view, such a recommendation is unacceptable because it constitutes a breach of the Financial Regulation and its Article 18(1) according to which 'the balance of each budget year shall be entered in the budget of the following budget year as revenue in the event of a surplus or as a means of payment in the event of loss.'

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - Draft amending budget 2/2014 intends to record in the 2014 budget a surplus of the 2013 budget, worth EUR 1005 million of positive differences resulting from its implementation: 276 million derived from the sub-execution and 42 million negative changing variations. As I agree with the principle of transferring surpluses from one financial year to the next, I voted in favour.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - Draft amending budget No 2/2014 aims to include in the 2014 budget a surplus for the financial year 2013, in the amount of EUR 1005 million, which is mainly the result of a surplus of EUR 771 million of positive differences resulting from the implementation of revenue, EUR 276 million for under-implementation of expenditure and EUR 42 million from negative exchange variations. We regret that this budget surplus serves to reduce the proportion of the GNI-based contribution of the Member States to the EU budget, rather than being an extraordinary revenue that is so lacking at a time when debts resulting from EU expenditure are accumulating.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. - The draft amending budget is incompatible with the accounting hocus-pocus and article 18(1) of the EU Financial Regulation, which this Parliament itself has adopted. The EU Financial Regulation stipulates that surpluses on the credit side must be recorded in the following financial year. Accordingly, Member States' payments to the EU should be reduced. However, this is not possible now. Instead of complying with the Financial Regulation, the EP is illegally creating a new reserve budget line for an additional need for payments – a war chest for bad times – instead of reducing GNI own resources. In accordance with Article 18(1) of the Financial Regulation, the balance of each financial year, depending on whether the surplus or a shortfall is concerned, shall be entered in the budget for the following financial year by means of an amending budget as revenue or as expenditure. This regulation is obviously being circumvented here, and that is why I am voting against the amending budget.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: Mr President, whilst the budget is not ideal, I voted in favour of amendment 906 supporting the peace process and financial assistance for Palestine and for UNRWA. As the people of Gaza are emerging from the most recent onslaught, their needs are greater than ever and UNRWA needs financial support to carry out its work. UNRWA is dealing with thousands of families who are homeless and without livelihood. Even those with homes find themselves in neighbourhoods where water, sewage and electricity systems are demolished. The future of Gaza must not be defined by the instability and poverty imposed by the blockade. The international community will need to move forward and do more, to make sure that it is doing more than just humanitarian action and to address the underlying causes of the crisis, hence ending Israel’s occupation in Palestine. As we wait for that to happen, UNRWA is playing a leading role in addressing the devastation caused by the recent conflict and the pervasive effect of the Israeli-imposed blockade. UNRWA is seeking USD 1.6 billion for emergency relief, early recovery and reconstruction priorities in the Gaza Strip, and hence the EU must increase UNRWA’s budget.

name: Anne SANDER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this resolution on the 2015 budget because Europe must have the means to work for growth and jobs. However, I strongly oppose the paragraph, which concerns a so-called roadmap for a single seat of Parliament. Behind this formulation lies a targeted attack on Strasbourg. Such an attack is legally false and politically unacceptable. Should I, once again, point out that there is already a single seat? It's Strasbourg! So, yes, Mr President, I am for a single seat but for the single seat in Strasbourg!

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr. President! I would like to draw the attention of the House to a technical problem in the field of agriculture or agricultural policy in the context of the budget discussions. We are currently experiencing a sales crisis in agriculture as a a response to the European embargo policy on the part of Russia. We have a fall in the price of fruit and vegetables, now for dairy products, and in the pig sector there is a similar evidence. I would like to draw attention to the fact that, of course, we want to deal with the crisis. We will support farmers. We also have a crisis fund, and that is right, but we will also have to use some of the so-called cash reflux funds for this purpose. That is not yet the case. There are still heated discussions. However, I hope that together with the Committee on Agriculture and the Committee on Budgets and the Commission, we will also find a solution to this problem.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: Mr President, here is a really extraordinary statistic. Over the past four years the United Kingdom has created more jobs than the other 27 members of the European Union combined. There are various ingredients that went into that formula.  There were changes to the welfare system, there was the removal of a number of low-paid workers from income tax altogether, but one of the things that did not go into it was trying to create jobs by spending money, as this budget proposes. Even if you or I were directly to say ʽI am going to create a job by employing someone in my officeʼ, I think we both understand that this would be taking more money out of the private sector than goes into the job. There is always a net loss, which is why the European Union is falling behind, why we are on the only continent on the planet that is not growing.  One specific point in my remaining time on this budget: it is impossible on the amendment to do with subsidising fighting bulls to distinguish between the ones that might be raised for the plaza and the ones which are not, because almost all of the camada brava end up in the food chain anyway. This was therefore a declamatory, rather than practical, amendment. It would have had absolutely no impact, and if you are against subsidising fighting bulls the only solution is to withdraw from the common agricultural policy.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. - Many amendments to the budget were proposed, both by the EFDD Group and some of the other political groups, which would have saved substantial amounts of money for taxpayers. These amendments were voted down time and time again, and even the request to stop EU subsidies for bullfighting did not achieve a qualified majority.  The European Union has failed once again to put its own house in order, failed to take a lead with cuts, and failed to show that it understands that taxpayers’ cash belongs to them not to the European Union.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This draft general budget for 2015 reveals all the hypocrisy of the European Union. On the one hand, it asks states like France to review its budget because of excessive deficit; on the other hand, it is facing recurrent payment delays that reach impressive levels: nearly 30 billion euros of unpaid bills at the end of 2014!  Faced with this situation and the impossibility of demanding ever more credits from member states already heavily indebted and affected by the economic crisis, the European Union will soon have no choice but to take its idea of a European tax out of the drawers. Whether it is Juncker or Barroso, the EPP or the PES, the same ultraliberal and technocratic policies will be applied.  I have therefore spoken out against this general budget, which is part of too many years of forfeiture of the sovereignty of nation states.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - (IT) Having blamed the Member States for the crisis, after imposing austerity measures that cost its citizens tears and blood, Europe is presenting its accounts today. Faced with 25 million unemployed Europeans and 3 million Italians who, despite having a job, live in hardship, without being able to afford a decent meal or a roof over their heads, Europe is demanding more money. At a time when citizens need support and services and businesses are looking for new funds to promote their competitiveness, the EU should be the first to set a good example. The total unwillingness to make cuts in the efficiency of expenditure has therefore convinced me to vote against the text.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. - I've voted against the budget. The budget is too large and comprehensive.  There should be substantial cuts.  Agricultural policy is just one example. It results in overproduction and negative effects on the environment, climate and animal husbandry. Another example is the incalculable regional and structural funds, where there is widespread fraud, as confirmed by the Commission itself.  I am opposed to the efforts of Frontex, which means the continued construction of Fortress Europe, which forces people fleeing war and oppression to risk their lives to get to sanctuary. This and initiatives to increase the militarisation of the EU are completely the wrong way for a Union that claims to defend human rights and is a peace project. In principle, I also think it wrong that the European Parliament has power over the budget. The Member States that pay the EU budget should have full decision-making power over Union expenditure. It is more democratic for the governments of the Member States, and the national parliaments, to decide on the long-term budget. It is the taxpayers in the Member States who pay and therefore it is their directly elected representatives in each country who should be in power.  These are some of the reasons why I choose to vote against the budget.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Amendment 232, tabled by Mr Bas Eickhout, which calls for the abolition of direct CAP aid for bull farms for bullfighting. While thousands of small-scale farmers are not sufficiently supported by CAP funds, they should not be allocated to bullfighting farms.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - The draft budget for 2015 maintains a tendency to increase expenditure and payment commitments. The contribution of states to the functioning of the institutions is a flow of money that should be used according to strict criteria of necessity, especially in times of serious structural crisis throughout the continent. However, we can see that not only are administrative expenditure increasing, but contributions to European political foundations and parties are also increasing, while the taxpayers of the nations that have set up the institutions themselves are deprived of economic security which should result precisely from widespread action by the latter.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. - (Amendments Nos 553-554-555-556-557) The issue of the costs of politics – which is linked to the broader issue of the costs of democracy – is a sensitive and complex issue, in reference to which, especially in times of economic crisis, there is no lack of controversy and, sometimes, exploitation. Having said that, I believe that, being officially called upon to take a position, as Parliamentarians, on aspects relating to our economic treatment, it is appropriate – precisely because the decision directly affects 'our pockets' (and, indirectly, those of all citizens) – to set aside not only their own private interests, but also any possible reservations of principle on the 'details' and possible contingent aims of the individual initiatives. , and instead maintain a clear and transparent position. Not in order to indulge populist, 'anti-political' or anti-European tendencies, but simply because – faced with the possibility of choosing between maintaining the current treatment and instead exploiting a certain margin of reduction that it allows (without affecting the functionality, decorum and dignity of our institution) to release market resources to other more pressing needs, first and then the fight against unemployment and crime – conscience and reason lead , in my opinion, to prefer the second option. For purely "objective" reasons, before they are symbolic. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the draft general budget of the European Union for 2015, but I am rather critical on two items: funds for natural disasters and the reserve for crises in agriculture. I hope that the funds for flood-affected areas in recent weeks will be requested in good time and allocated as soon as possible, but I believe that, over and above competences, we must also establish a solidarity mechanism that will lead to an increase in the appropriations. With regard to the reserve for agricultural crises, I would like our farms that are making up for it as a result of the Russian embargo to be compensated with funds made available by those same authorities that triggered the embargo as a reaction. My attention to these issues remains high.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015, although I criticise the limited financial resources put at the service of the European Union. At a time when we are calling for more investment, economic recovery and job creation, we need more Europe and not less Europe. A budget of not 1% of GNI is an insufficient budget. Especially if we take into account that 94 % of the Union budget (withdrawals from administrative expenditure) is funds that return to the Member States to help public and private investment. The basic and interest-making accounts of so-called net taxpayers call on us to urgently rethink the EU's own resources system which is not largely dependent on member states' payments.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the resolution as a whole. In so doing, however, I voted in favour of an amendment that prohibits the use of EU funds to finance lethal bullfighting; and I abstained on an amendment that proposes a roadmap towards the EP having one seat, since I believe that before we conclude whether there is to be one seat or not other measures could be considered to establish that political, historical and economic balance that the seat in Strasbourg seeks to provide.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - I voted against the EU budget for 2015 because once again it is the budget of austericide and poverty. These are budgets made with their backs to the reality of social emergency that popular classes are experiencing in all EU countries. This budget remains in the neoliberal logic of memorandums, cuts, public privatisations and remains not budgets for job creation and living conditions for EU citizens.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - (IT) Once again, we are faced with choices by the Council which, in defiance of all economic and social considerations, and in the name of mere accounting assessments, is making indiscriminate cuts to the Commission's proposal which, in itself, was the bare minimum in order to achieve, although partially, the objectives of the Union. It is our duty as Parliamentarians, directly elected representatives of the citizens of Europe, to make it clear that without these objectives the Union itself cannot exist, turning itself into a monetary group - more or less two-speed - devoid of soul and added value, which alienates the citizens and which is pushing them more and more towards forms of Euroscepticism that degenerate into a 'Euro-project'. In addition to the risk of seeing the level of the price increase again, given the gap between commitments and payments; It is very worrying that for heading 1b the Council has not taken adequate account of the fact that, as payment requests will soar at the end of the 2007-2013 programming period, there will be a surge in payment requests in 2015. The lack of appropriations puts the survival of hundreds of European companies, and with it those of thousands of workers, at risk. Like S&D, this is the austerity we don't want and will continue to fight against.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – In this complex vote I supported the move to restore the Commission’s draft budget (thus rejecting the linear cuts to the administrative expenditure for the institutions made by the Council), with some adjustments to take into account specific needs of the institutions.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. - I regret that the cuts proposed by the Council in relation to certain lines for administrative and support expenditure granting funding to the implementation of key Union programmes could be detrimental to the successful launch of the new programmes and which pose a major risk of hindering the implementation of Union policies.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. - Well aware of the challenges facing the sugar sector, I strongly defended the latter, particularly during the negotiations on the common organisation of markets which I was rapporteur on the framework of the CAP reform, where I was able to obtain a postponement of the end date of quotas. However, in the budgetary context that we are experiencing, particularly in view of the urgent need for aid financing in connection with the Russian embargo, I think it is important to have a more detailed discussion in the Agriculture Committee in order to work on the best ways to support the sugar sector in the context of the end of quotas.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. - Despite having voted in favour of the resolution on the 2015 budget as a whole in order to support growth and jobs in Europe, I opposed the paragraph proposing a single seat. Indeed, it is stipulated in the European texts that the European Parliament has one and only one Strasbourg seat, so this paragraph is legally wrong and is only intended to attack Strasbourg. If some want to question the seats of the institutions, then we must put everything on the table: all the institutions and agencies across the European Union.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Written. - The budgetary challenges are immense. The N-VA advocates a healthy fiscal framework that does not pass on debt and primarily focuses on competitiveness, growth and jobs.  To this end, everyone is asked to make an effort. Not only the Member States, but also the EU itself, must make a move. In this sense, the N-VA supports the Council's position on the 2015 budget.  The EU institutions can also take concrete action. For example, the N-VA supports the request for a single seat for the European Parliament and the strengthening of transparency, control and accountability in the administrative expense severance for Members of the European Parliament. The reorientation of initiatives that do not achieve their objectives (such as EuroparlTV) or which are strictly not part of Parliament's remit (risk of duplication, House of European History) should also be negotiable.  However, a majority in the European Parliament is calling for the European Commission's proposals to be stuck and sometimes going further. Although we understand commitments made, we are committed to a strict European budget that remains within the agreed margins. All these considerations have led to our choice of abstention.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The European Union must have a credible, supportive budget that contributes to growth and jobs. The Treaties, financial regulations, the European Union 2020 strategy and the multiannual financial framework 2014-2020 must be respected. It is a compromise between the institutions, but it is also a commitment to the citizens. The Europe 2020 strategy, which guides the multiannual financial framework, must see its objectives achieved, but to do so we need to ensure the necessary means for these same objectives to be achieved. The means must be up to the height of ambition. Therefore, for the EU budget for 2015, the cuts proposed by the Council by more than 500 million in commitments and 2 100 million in payments are unacceptable. I call for the strengthening of programmes for SMEs, youth, research and innovation, as well as the programme to support the most disadvantaged. External solidarity is another concern, which underpins the increases that Parliament proposes for humanitarian aid, support for refugees and neighbourhood policy. The multiannual financial framework, its programmes, funds and priorities are required to be rapidly implementing it.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - We have tabled more than half a hundred amendments to the draft EU budget for 2015, in a work that began in mid-April, with the development of pilot projects. In reaction to the European Commission's initial proposal, we have proposed a considerable set of amendments to be included in the opinions of parliamentary committees. We highlight the approval of three pilot projects on: 1. traditional trade support measures, 2. support for small-scale fishing and 3. support for the study of the consequences of reducing social benefits in increasing poverty and inequalities between men and women. In addition to these, the set of proposals that we have advanced covers several areas, with a special focus on social and economic (in defense of national production) and environmental. Among many others: defense of public services; strengthening of amounts for the Youth Employment Initiative; support for micro, small and medium-sized enterprises; promoting equality between men and women; strengthening of funds for the prevention of natural disasters; increase in appropriations for the LIFE programme and natura 2000; increase in appropriations for R&D; public education; strengthening fruit and milk distribution schemes in schools; increase in funding for Culture; the principle of multilingualism in the European institutions.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - I am voting against the European Union's draft general budget, the financial year 2015, because it shifts its centre of gravity more towards numbers and power than towards the citizens themselves.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing. - I supported this report because I believe that all cuts introduced by the Council should be restored and it proposes using all the flexibility instruments of the Multiannual Financial Framework in the 2015 budget, leading to an additional amount of more than EUR 4 billion in payments in order to effectively address the situation. We need to promote growth and jobs with a credible and solidary budget that strengthens scientific research, Erasmus+, the CEF and SMEs. It therefore does not accept the Council’s position, presenting cuts and deepening the payments problem.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. - I do not believe that EU funds should be used to subsidise the farming of bulls used in bullfights. Taxpayersʼ money should not be used to fund any practice which causes animals unnecessary pain, suffering or distress. Given the UK Conservative delegation’s opposition to coupled payments under the CAP, it is imperative that these animals are identifiable in order to stop any payments of this kind. For this reason I supported Amendment 12 of the vote on the resolution and Amendment 232 of the vote on the budget lines. Animals used for lethal bullfighting activities should not be eligible to receive any direct CAP appropriations nor any other appropriations from the budget.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament abstained as we point out our full dissatisf with the budget defined from its origin by the European Commission in its draft. Moreover, with the additional cuts proposed by the Council and the lack of consideration of basic agreements in budgetary and multi-year development, insisting on its obsession with austerity which jeopardizes the basic functioning of important programmes and continues to bet on abandoning public initiative to rescue European society. The European Parliament's position only restores the level of expenditure, we note that it does not seek to go beyond accepting its freezing and weight loss in the European economy, that its main concern is the delays and difficulties of paying overdue bills, and that it has not had the audacity to set a more ambitious budget.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament abstained as we point out our full dissatisf with the budget defined from its origin by the European Commission in its draft. Moreover, with the additional cuts proposed by the Council and the lack of consideration of basic agreements in budgetary and multi-year development, insisting on its obsession with austerity which jeopardizes the basic functioning of important programmes and continues to bet on abandoning public initiative to rescue European society. The European Parliament's position only restores the level of expenditure, we note that it does not seek to go beyond accepting its freezing and weight loss in the European economy, that its main concern is the delays and difficulties of paying overdue bills, and that it has not had the audacity to set a more ambitious budget.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - I voted for the draft amendments to the draft general budget for 2015, as they represent a balanced and coherent approach to the parts of the budget in question for 2015. The amendments are aimed at further strengthening and defining the revenues and expenditure of the European Union, and it is necessary to take into account the effects of the global economic crisis, which has strongly affected EU growth and investment, thus contributing to the definition of the budget for the coming year.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. - We have worked to restore a reasonable and measured budget to participate in innovation, growth and social justice. In particular, we are committed to the preservation of substantial and appropriate funding for the creation of SMEs, Erasmus scholarships, scientific research and food aid for the poorest.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. - In order for the EU to honour its commitments and avoid a cessation of payment for several European programmes, Parliament is calling for the eu's 2 billion cuts to be abandoned in the draft 2015 budget. I welcome the fact that, on the occasion of this vote, the EPP increased funding for job creation for SMEs (EUR 26.5 million), Erasmus scholarships (EUR 24 million), scientific research (EUR 90 million) and food aid for the poorest (EUR 16.7 million).

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. - I voted against a number of measures which would have seen the overall EU budget increase and against proposed rises in agricultural subsidies, including bullfighting subsidies, and administration. I voted instead to focus the EU budget more heavily upon investment for growth and jobs, and voted for regional funding that goes directly to communities that are best able to determine how to deliver for people locally. I want to see a real budget reform in the EU, with areas that do not bring any real benefits to our constituents cut.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. - The 2015 Eu budget internalizes the gradual cuts to the multi-year framework of the European budget, which is to reduce EU funds by 10%. However, it is an expanding European budget that should be adopted in these times of crisis to ensure European solidarity with countries and territories in difficulty, as well as to revive economic activity through an ambitious investment in the infrastructure and human capital of the European Union. I would add that in return for the acceptance of this multi-year austerity framework, Parliament had been promised to move forward with the reflection on own resources, but it has not yet begun. However, Parliament's amendments to the Council's proposal bring some improvements. Starting with the attempt to solve the accumulation of unpaid bills: it is unthinkable that a shrinking European budget will also have to cover the unpaid debts of the previous budgetary framework.  That is why I supported the changes made to the 2015 budget proposal by Parliament.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - I voted against the EU budget for 2015 because once again it is the budget of austericide and poverty. These are budgets made with their backs to the reality of social emergency that popular classes are experiencing in all EU countries. This budget remains in the neoliberal logic of memorandums, cuts, public privatisations and remains not budgets for job creation and living conditions for EU citizens.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - I supported this decision by voting in favour because the majority of the EP managed to get rid of the populism of the EFDD political group and their offers to cut off a more point, thus supposedly saving EU funds. There was no real offer behind it. The budget as a whole is balanced and good.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. – I could not support the draft budget for 2015 because it proposes an increase in the budget beyond inflation.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - I agree with the document adopted here today in which parliament reiterates its position on the EU budget for next year. We must be firm in rejecting the cuts made by the Council to the draft budget. We must find solutions to increase appropriations in areas as important as growth, employment, research, education and humanitarian aid. I also agree that €4 billion should be added to avoid serious payment failures to local authorities, SMEs and other beneficiaries of European funds. This new budget must serve to help the EU find the path to growth and development. I have changed my intention to vote on Amendment No 12 by Mep Bas Eickhout, voting against, because I believe that our cultural heritage should be respected and the importance of maintaining single bovine breeds, including brave bullies. This amendment reflects what I consider to be strict compliance with the law.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. - I have voted in favour of this report because it focuses on reinforcing those programmes that are at the heart of the Europe 2020 strategy that aim to foster growth, employment and competitiveness (namely Horizon 2020, COSME, Erasmus+, the Digital Agenda, Progress and the Social Agenda, including EURES and the Microfinance Facility). This will enable the EU to further contribute to a more innovative and prosperous economy throughout the Union.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. - I fully support the  budget of the European Union for 2015, as we successfully managed to negotiated a package deal agreeing on targeted increases above Commission’s 2015 Draft Budget, especially for initiatives that will boost competitiveness, growth and jobs and will support initiatives in favour of reinforcements for asylum, migration and security. I also voted in favour of any amendments forbidding the use of any funds for breeders of bulls reared for bullfighting. The EU funds should not be used to finance the exploitation of animals and their agony.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. - The vote on the 2015 budget saw once again the exorbitant amount of unfunded commitments, which constitute a form of debt for the Union.  Taken together, they would represent nearly 30 billion euros of unpaid invoices at the end of 2014 and about 220 billion euros of commitment authorizations not covered by payment credits. So what is the legitimacy of the Commission, which is initiating sanctions proceedings this month for excessive deficits against France and Italy, while it is accumulating these debts itself? What is the credibility of Mr Juncker, who is announcing a multi-year programme of additional investments of 300 billion euros, without specifying how it will be financed? In the long run, it is still the Member States that will be put to work, unless a European tax, which European leaders dream of, finds its justification. National Front MPs voted against the 2015 budget, with the exception of certain appropriations such as the CAP, which they approved, and budgets for growth and innovation, for which they abstained.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of this draft budget. The draft, presented by the European Parliament, essentially echoes the European Commission's proposal. The Council, for its part, wanted to reduce the European budget for 2015. As we begin a new financial program (2014-2020), we must have the funds to meet our previous programming claims (2007-2013). With the budget that the Member States want today, we are going to put the European Union in a debt situation even though the treaties forbid us. I am in for compliance with treaties and state commitments. This reduction demanded by the Member States is also unjustified as it covers all sectors that are levers for growth and jobs such as research, re-industrialisation and innovation. I therefore call for the European budget to be restored. Indeed, 95% of the budget is an investment budget and therefore indirectly goes to the states and citizens. Of the 5% of operating costs, all the European institutions have taken savings measures in order to participate in the European effort. For example, institutions have committed to reducing the wage bill by 2017.

name: Alessandra MORETTI
text: in writing. - (IT) I would like to express great satisfaction with today's vote on the European Union budget for 2015 on the European Parliament's negotiating position with a view to conciliation. The Socialist rapporteur, Eider Gardiazabal, has done an excellent job in reaching an agreement with the People's Party, the ALDE and the Greens in order to re-establish the Commission's original proposal by opposing the cuts desired by the Council.  We are particularly pleased that the agreement includes strengthening certain political priorities, which are central to our group, in support of growth, competitiveness, employment, the strengthening of the Culture, Media programme, the Frontex agency and the adoption of increases to reduce the impact of Russian sanctions on the import of certain agricultural products and the fishing industry. We must realise that today a whole series of regional programmes and initiatives, the work of many NGOs and university programmes such as Erasmus are at risk; It is our duty to take on these problems by doing everything in our power to ensure that they continue to be financed.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the 2015 budget because the European Union must have the means to implement all the policies necessary to promote growth and create the jobs that are sorely lacking in our societies, especially among young people and women. However, I strongly opposed the paragraph on the roadmap on a so-called single seat of the European Parliament, because there is an attack on Strasbourg behind this wording. Especially since it is politically dangerous and legally wrong because the Treaties confirm it, the European Parliament has only one seat: Strasbourg.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - The vote concerned the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015. The budget has increased again compared to the previous year. The additional funds required are justified by a further increase in effort. This reasoning does not seem to me to be sufficient, since for the most part concrete figures are not provided. Furthermore, as Austrian sovereignty should be an exception because of the principle of subsidiarity, it should be an exception to the basic rule and european regulation, I was also unable to agree to an increase in funding for the decentralised agencies (recital 6). In this respect, I would also like to draw particular attention to the enormous administrative costs of these agencies (up to 71% of the total budget). I therefore did not vote in favour of the motion.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. - For the vote on the Community budget for 2015, I felt it appropriate to stick to the positions of my group.

name: Marit PAULSEN
text: Written. - (C) The EU needs a modern budget that responds to today's real needs and tomorrow's major challenges, such as youth unemployment, refugee flows and climate change. We cannot therefore accept the Council's general approach, which involves cuts in those aimed at creating jobs and growth - such as research and small businesses - and in important areas such as humanitarian aid, emergency aid and aid to countries in our eastern partnership such as Ukraine. Furthermore, the Council's position, once again, betrays its own commitments, which is unethical and unfair to individual beneficiaries and project owners across Europe. Of course, there is money to be saved in the EU budget today, but it should be more strategic and targeted. We have therefore voted in favour of the proposals calling for an end to aid for, for example, tobacco growing, bullfighting and export refunds for live animals. In other areas, too, there is room for cuts. However, as a 'negotiating bid' in the further process, we chose - for the reasons set out above - to support the proposal of the Committee on Budgets (including, for example, support for the Roma minority), even though the voting procedure with so-called 'blocs' did not allow us to vote in detail against everything that we would have liked. Marit Paulsen, Cecilia Wikström and Fredrick Federley (ALDE)

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - Europe must have funds that benefit growth and jobs. This year's budget focuses on strengthening those programmes at the heart of the Europe 2020 strategy, which aims to boost growth, jobs and competitiveness - such as Horizon 2020, COSME, Erasmus+, the Digital Agenda, Progress and the Social Agenda (including EURES and the Microfinance Facility). These programmes are an example of the Union's contribution to an innovative and thriving economy across Europe. Therefore, I supported the draft general budget of the European Union - financial year 2015.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the draft general budget for the financial year 2015 that the Council approved last month because, thanks to Parliament's intervention, it was possible to increase the commitment appropriations to EUR 146.3809 billion and an increase in payment appropriations to EUR 146.4165 billion was obtained. Among parliament's demands, I think it is important to highlight the demand for additional appropriations to stimulate growth and employment, the possibility of setting up more funds for small and medium-sized enterprises experiencing serious difficulties, increased funding for research and development programmes as a result of the crisis, and increased funding to meet international obligations. With regard to heading 3 of the draft budget, I am delighted that Parliament has asked the Commission and the Council to step up their political and financial efforts in the coming years. This heading includes essential Eu ropean Union policies, such as asylum and immigration and internal security policies. I very much hope that an agreement will be reached with the Council as soon as possible, so that the budget can be approved at the next plenary session in November.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I am pleased that the budgetary amendment calling for the removal of aid for fighting bulls on has not been accepted by my colleagues. I am proud to have been active with the bullfighting clubs from an early age. The European Greens have made the fight against bullfighting a fad. But I say that this amendment does not in any way respect the principle of subsidiarity. Because yes, our regional traditions are not the responsibility of Europe. And I intend to continue my fight to keep this going.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. - The European Parliament spoke on the 2015 general budget, sending a message to the other institutions to define what the Political Priorities of the European Union should be. While it is essential to be fiscally serious and not to squander public resources, it is also not conceivable to sacrifice the investments needed for growth and jobs in Europe, and MEPs remain vigilant to maintain a sufficient level of funding to be effective. That is why I voted in favour of Amendment 472, which would increase transport funding to EUR 465 million instead of EUR 402, an increase of 15%, specifically to eliminate bottlenecks, facilitate rail interoperability, complete missing links and improve border crossings. In short, this money would greatly improve European mobility, which is not a luxury for a space that seeks to emerge sustainably from the crisis and return to the path of jobs and prosperity!  The ball is now in the Council's court, which will have to show whether it too is ready to move towards an ambitious budget.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this draft budget to restore the Commission's draft budget in most areas cut by the Council, rejecting the Council's proposal to cut EUR 522 million in commitments and EUR 2 100 in payments. Austerity policies have been a failure, they have brought nothing but suffering and not only have they not taken us out of the crisis, but they are leading us to the brink of a third recession. The current situation calls for a change in the direction of economic policy and the European budget should serve to activate public investment by complementing national budgets and boosting growth and employment. The draft Council budget does not reflect the needs and priorities of the Union. That is why I supported this Resolution which requires increases for key budget lines for growth, competitiveness and employment such as Horizon 2020, Erasmus + or COSME, and is committed to a budget that fights inequalities and serves our most suffering citizens, increasing the European Aid Fund for the Most Needy, and a budget that does not cut neighbourhood policy , development cooperation and humanitarian aid.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted against the EU budget for 2015 because once again it is the budget of austericide and poverty. These are budgets made with their backs to the reality of social emergency that popular classes are experiencing in all EU countries. This budget remains in the neoliberal logic of memorandums, cuts, public privatisations and remains not budgets for job creation and living conditions for EU citizens.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. - I and my fellow UK Labour MEPs voted against a number of measures which would have seen the overall EU budget increase. Labour MEPs voted to focus the EU budget more heavily upon investment for growth and jobs and against proposed rises for agricultural subsidies and administration.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. - I cannot support the European Commission's draft Budget of the European Union. I've got two compelling arguments for that. In my opinion, it is uneasy towards taxpayers, it does not support the consolidation of the public finances of the Member States of the European Union. And in the chapter 'European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights', it explicitly supports organisations promoting LGBTI people. However, more than €255 million is available in the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights (EIDHR) budget chapter in 2015. I cannot support a budget prepared in this way.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. - The Union budget must in no way be perceived and assessed only as a financial item burdening national budgets but, on the contrary, should be seen as an opportunity to stimulate initiatives and investments that are of importance and added value for the Union as a whole. I agree with Parliament's note that the EU budget needs to be created to reflect the current difficult economic situation faced by citizens across the EU on a daily basis.   Also, due to the difficult economic situation, many Member States are still grappling with the consequences of the recession and the global crisis, which is why it is necessary to proceed with agreed reforms, without jeopardising legislative excellence or disrupting the national parliament's relationship with the European Parliament, in order to achieve the desired EU-wide economic recovery.  I therefore support the European Parliament's decision that the budget provided for 2015 should be set on a realistic basis and in agreement with financial management, and that the budget should cover the planned legal obligations and expenditures for 2015.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. - I am voting against this project because it shifts the centre of gravity of the European Union more towards numbers and economic power than towards its own citizens and their needs.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of Amendment No 232 because I firmly believe in the need to eliminate public funding of any kind, direct and indirect, towards cruel practices against any kind of animal. The European Convention for the Protection of Animals on Farms is clear: animals must not feel pain, fear, distress or being injured. In this case, it is not acceptable for the CAP to finance the possibility of showing that employs bulls for pure popular amusement. I will continue to support battles, like this one, aimed at animal protection.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. - The resolution we voted on today represents a financial package of EUR 142.1 billion in payments appropriations and EUR 145.6 billion in commitments appropriations. Although a modest budget, the Council took the approach of making further cuts in payments, representing a reduction of -0.18% in comparison to 2014.  These cuts were reversed by the EP, which also called on the use of the flexibility mechanism to generate an additional EUR 4 billion for the 2015 budget. These funds are essential for investment in programmes such as Horizon 2020, Erasmus and COSME, which help to promote job creation and growth. But a discussion on the 2015 budget cannot take place without addressing the shortage in payments for 2014. Even if the draft amending budgets for 2014 are successfully adopted, we are still facing a roll-over of bills from 2014 into 2015 of EUR 18 billion EUR. This situation is unacceptable.  This resolution, which I voted in favour of, reminds the Council that the EU budget is an investment, not a burden. The longer the Council takes to address the shortage in payments, the longer it continues to make further cuts to what is already perceived as a limited-size budget, the longer it delays Europe’s economic recovery and growth.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. - We voted in favour of the EU's draft general budget, as well as the general budget 2015 in general.  It is important to point out, however, that we have rejected the amendments: 1/ on the EU subsidy for bullfighting; 2/ on tobacco subsidies; 3/ on the history museum. On the other hand, we are in favour of a single seat roadmap.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - I voted against the EU budget for 2015 because once again it is the budget of austericide and poverty. These are budgets made with their backs to the reality of social emergency that popular classes are experiencing in all EU countries. This budget remains in the neoliberal logic of memorandums, cuts, public privatisations and remains not budgets for job creation and living conditions for EU citizens.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - Our position on the budget and in the face of this proposal reflects our position on this EU, with its neoliberal, federalist and militarist matrix. The EU budget is the concrete expression of a policy line aimed at promoting the dismantling of public services, the loss of social and labour rights and public-private partnerships. This is the budget that supports austerity, the European Semester and all the agencies that monitor and condition member states' policies and punish bad pupils. It is the budget that supports increasingly aggressive interference in various parts of the globe. That builds a Europe Fortress less and less in solidarity with its neighbors. This farce or this pseudo-dispute between the Commission and the Council cannot deviate from the essentials, which is the condemnation of the neoliberal policies of this EU supported by this budget.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. - The EU's general budget for the financial year 2015 is not only facing cuts, but is yet another example of gross misinvestment. On the one hand, there will be an increase in programmes and projects that are saved in times of economic crisis, such as various agencies or support for civil societies. On the other hand, important components for economic growth, especially those of SMEs, are neglected. Furthermore, there is no serious debate on a single seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg. For these and other reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. - There are some inconsistencies in the resolution on the general budget. The EP disagrees with all the savings proposals put forward by the Council. The text emphasises the need for decentralised agencies, although it has always been stressed that 'agencyitis' should be combated. Some agencies could even be completely dissolved, for example the European Gender Institute or the Fundamental Rights Agency. The institutions of the European Financial Supervisory System are also to receive €6.1 million more, although there is always talk of saving. I have the impression that this annual budget is not coherent. The savings potential is not used intelligently. My proposal is to rethink spending policy and only pay for the programmes where the EU really offers added value without performing national tasks. As a first concrete measure of fiscal consolidation, the Commission should be banned from accounting tricks consisting of simply transferring unpaid invoices into the next financial year in order to service payment commitments entered into. As a result, a mountain of debt or deficit of EUR 23 billion has accumulated over the years. The EU does not comply with the principle of "honorable merchant".

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. - (IT) Today's vote on the budget is a clear demonstration that European politicians are also capable of demanding sacrifices from others alone. We had tabled a number of amendments to reduce certain administrative expenditure, thus freeing up funds for priority lines of action: a large part of this House, namely the People's-Socialist-Liberal Bloc, rejected this. We wanted to see the salaries of us parliamentarians, our allowances and also some privileges so dear to the bureaucrats in Brussels reduced in the first place. Less than two hundred Members, out of more than seven hundred, wanted to endorse our proposal: all this is scandalous, and it once again demonstrates the hypocrisy of traditional politics. Public contributions to European political parties and foundations have, of course, remained very much present, indeed even increased: is this a European priority, something on which to invest several million euros? I do not think so, but the majority wants to secure public subsidies for their apparatuses and thus carry on their disastrous policies which have reduced us to the dramatic situation in which we find ourselves today. If we want to be credible, especially towards our citizens, we must be the first to set an example, and we have certainly not done so today.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The budget for 2015 is as unpopular as the previous ones, but also the next ones to be drawn up under the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020. Whether the funds are reduced, as proposed by the Council, or increased, according to the Proposal of the European Parliament, they are intended to finance programmes, projects, actions and investments solely to enhance the profitability of monopolistic groups, to the detriment of popular needs. The increase in the budget proposed by the European Parliament concerns the financing of research programmes in the service of capital, monopoly subsidies for investments in new profitable sectors, such as energy and the digital market. Strengthening the EU's repressive mechanisms and its anti-immigration policy. Increasing the funds for the diverse civil-military instruments for the EU's imperialist interventions around the world.  That is why the European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the draft budget and the amendments proposed by the political staff of monopolies and the forces of urban management moving in the same strategic direction of promoting capitalist development by strengthening business groups. It advocated a drastic reduction in the privileges and all kinds of high financial benefits for MEPs, which are a challenge for workers suffering from the unpopular policy in which the European Parliament is a leader.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - I am expressing fundamental doubts about the planned EU budget for 2015. Eur 145 billion is planned to be spent across the European Union. It must be made clear that this will be eur 2 billion less than the budget made in 2014, and in addition, the 2015 budget will be debited with bills not paid by the EU in the current year, amounting to at least EUR 24 billion. This worrying situation in practice will mean a scarcity of resources for infrastructure investment strategies, for supporting modern technologies and for creating new jobs. It is clear that further savings will be needed in the EU budget. In my opinion, as an MEP, they cannot be evenly distributed. There needs to be a concentration of resources to solve europe's number one social problem, the scourge of unemployment. I therefore propose that, in this respect, review the planned expenditure in 2015 in order to support more strongly all those areas, investments and research that create new jobs.

name: Clare MOODY
text: Mr President, today my Labour colleagues and I have voted for the EU to do more of what it is good at: working collectively to deliver real benefits – developments in technology like the Composites Centre in Bristol, where cutting-edge research is delivering for industry. Projects like this keep the UK and Europe as world leaders in science and technology. We voted for investment for growth: projects like the Hub in Lockleaze, where businesses have benefited from funding that would not have happened without the EU, and voted for regional funding that goes directly to communities – communities like Cornwall, communities that are best able to determine how to deliver for people locally. We also voted for the EU to fulfil the global demands that national governments have put on it, whether in Ukraine, in Gaza or on Ebola. These are areas where we are more than the sum of our parts, where the EU makes a real difference. I am proud that Labour MEPs have stood up for constituents in these areas.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to express my satisfaction at the ok given to Amendment No 12, which was widely shared within this Parliament. This means that the topic has been shared by many people, who have created a real movement of thought. I firmly believe that lethal pro-bullfighting funding should not be used at all, not least because this is a real violation of the European Convention on the Protection of Animals and we know how much more and more attention there is, fortunately, to animal welfare issues. I am also pleased with the consensus reached on the Road Map, which would lead to a single seat for the European Parliament. This is also a subject that is strongly felt by the citizens of Europe.  Unfortunately, the amendment concerning sugar-producing companies was not adopted, and this will have a great many negative economic repercussions.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: A Uachtaráin, chaith mé vóta i gcoinne an bhuiséid seo. Dúirt an Chomhairle go raibh siad chun infheistíocht a dhéanamh i ndaoine ach is léir nach bhfuil siad sásta sin a dhéanamh agus táim an-bhuartha faoi sin. Tá a fhios ag gach duine go bhfuil gnáthdhaoine faoi bhrú mar gheall ar na polasaithe déine atá ag teacht ón Aontas Eorpach. Caithfear bogadh ó na beartais déine agus bogadh i dtreo infheistíocht agus fás atá inbhuanaithe. Caithfear poist a chruthú agus sos a thabhairt dóibh siúd atá ag streachailt. Tá dualgas agus freagracht ar an gComisiúin a ngealltanais a choimeád.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! In recent days, the Greens, especially in Germany, have launched an impressive, above all Internet-based campaign against the support of bullfighting by EU funds. The German Social Democrats support this. With all due respect to the cultural life in Spain, the citizens do not want their taxpayers' money to be used for this purpose. The Greens, however, have given the impression that this is ultimately decided today, and that is wrong. The Greens propose adding a restrictive sentence in the commentary on the budget line on the single single payment, quote: "This cannot stop the EU subsidies for bullfighting, as the Greens are calling for on the Internet. Because no administration in the world can control today whether a bull standing on a meadow somewhere in the EU today will be led into a bullring tomorrow." This motion by the Greens is therefore either naive or has a different objective. This is also available on the website. Because with the roll-call vote, the Greens are pursuing the objective, quote: "that we will know exactly who supports us and who does not". We German Social Democrats will not be slurred. We are against public money for bullfighting, but we know that the rules of EU agricultural support cannot be changed through budget figures. It is a pity that the Greens are mislead tens of thousands of committed animal rights activists politically.
