name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the ITER programme is intended for the construction of the largest thermonuclear reactor in the world. This project consists of a total cost of EUR 15 billion. The ITRE Commission, with Amendment No 59 to the budget, intends to increase the funding of the project once again. We understand the reasons and hopes of many researchers working in this area of basic research, especially when we refer to the objective of reducing the production of nuclear waste as the ITER project promises to do. However, I personally voted against Amendment No 59 because at such an acute time of economic crisis, these additional resources should have been allocated to more pressing social issues. I believe that the ITER project should not be abandoned, but to date it is at least necessary to focus exclusively on the primary target of 500 MW of power from the 50 MW of inbound departure scheduled for 2028. Only the key scientific priorities that have already been identified in the project review must therefore be safeguarded without further delays that are unacceptable for the future.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Mr President, we voted today on the EU budget for 2015 and I would like to comment on amendments that mean sensible investment. I voted in favour of these proposals because we need to focus the EU budget on investment in the future, and these include proposals relating to Erasmus+, the main instrument for promoting the quality of education, and we have managed to raise this programme to a level that will be able to meet the Objectives of the European Commission as well as the objectives of the 2020 Agenda.  I would just like to mention briefly that I supported the resolution on the single seat of the European Parliament. While Strasbourg is a beautiful city, the European Parliament should also be an example of efficiency, if we are talking about savings and efficiency, then the European Parliament should also set an example for citizens and Member States in its work.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr. President! I will not overuse your patience. Of course, it is important that we do more for research and employment. Of course, we need to invest more, better spending more money, as they say. However, this too is not in the voting text, so I would like to explain my voting behaviour once again. We should look again at the programmes to see if they really work, because the best programme is of no use to us if it is not reliable for use, if it does not work, one could also say if it is not tamper-proof. We have, of course, examples, particularly in the agricultural sector in rural areas: if some programmes have error rates of up to 25% in some Member States, there is little point in making even more money available through these programmes. That includes taking a proper inventory, doing a proper evaluation, and making the programs – I always assume the good – user-friendly, so that such things don't happen again.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: Mr President, we voted against the budget. Robbing the people and giving great amounts of money to some abstract projects is a criminal act. Throwing billions away to fight global warming is a criminal act. Moreover, I think the European Union should be destroyed.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: Mr President, hundreds of my constituents have written to me asking me to vote against EU subsidies for bullfighting and I was more than happy to oblige. Most British taxpayers would be appalled to know that their money is being used for this purpose.  However, they also need to know that while the vote on the budget itself achieved a majority, it was not allowed because it did not achieve a qualified majority. The subsequent vote on the report also had a majority but the report was purely a commentary on the budget and it also has no effect. British taxpayers’ money will continue to be spent and used to subsidise the breeding of bulls for ritual slaughter. If the British people do not like it, then the only thing that they can do is vote for the UK Independence Party and bring forward the day when Britain leaves the European Union.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. - Today I voted on the EU budget for 2015. It is important that the EU budget is used properly, and that politicians assume their responsibility for the economies of the EU and the Member States. At a time of large deficits and soaring public debt in many Member States, a majority of MEPs voted in favour of increased funding for the EU. It wanted more taxpayers' money spent on agricultural subsidies, regional subsidies and huge subsidy schemes to support archaic industries. I could not support this. However, I supported the European Parliament's call for higher funding for research, investment in transport, innovation and the completion of the internal market, as this is what adds value to both Sweden and the EU.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. – "We expect Europe to [...] not teachings, but the 300 billion in investments". "Prosperity can only be maintained if we are willing to invest in new things". "Au Conseil européen, je réaffirmerai que la priorité c'est la croissance, c'est l'emploi, c'est l'investissement". These demands and statements do not come from me. These are statements by Matteo Renzi, Angela Merkel and Francois Hollande. All three Heads of Government are represented in the Council and could have ensured that the EU draft budget is not cut. What do we learn from this?  When it becomes concrete, the Heads of Government will get cold feet. The blame is simply conveniently deported to Europe afterwards. The example of the appropriations earmarked for research and development in the budget is particularly striking.  The reduction of almost EUR 1 billion in actual expenditure for Horizon 2020 is completely incomprehensible. If we want to prepare our economy for the future and secure jobs, we must invest in innovation. In other parts of the world, this has long been understood.  That is why we need more than just lip service right now, honourable Heads of Government! The budget must be renegotiated accordingly.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. The European Parliament is taking completely the wrong position on this matter. It should be safeguarding public money, and trying to provide value for money for citizens. Instead, it is empire-building. It is trying to carve out as much money as possible for the EU to spend, usually on projects which fail to respect the subsidiarity principle. It is supporting the Gentleman’s Agreement between Council, Commission and Parliament which keeps costs high and transparency low.   For these reasons I could not vote in favour of such a report.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. - The 2015 budget must move away from austerity policies and the Union must promote recovery, economic growth and job creation to help the most vulnerable citizens. This includes support for research, the creation of activities promoting youth employment and regional cohesion policies. It is also necessary, in payment appropriations, to fulfil our commitments to the humanitarian aid sector, structural funds and youth programmes.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. - This draft general budget, which is presented to us here as an opportunity to prepare "initiatives and investments that are of interest and add value to the Union", fits perfectly in line with previous budgets which have only brought europeans austerity and increasing precariousness.  According to the report, we should not see this budget as "an additional burden on national budgets". However, it is clear that this is the case. Let me remind you, for example, that France contributes more than EUR 21 billion a year to the EU budget, whereas we receive only EUR 13 billion in return. Moreover, where is the logic when we are asked to vote on additional appropriations when, since 2010, the Union has experienced recurring payment problems and for cohesion policy alone, arrears have reached a record level of EUR 23 billion at the end of 2013.  For these reasons, I voted against this draft budget for 2015.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - (IT) Having blamed the Member States for the crisis, after imposing austerity measures that cost its citizens tears and blood, Europe is presenting its accounts today. Faced with 25 million unemployed people, especially young people, 3 million Italians who, despite having a job, live in hardship, without being able to afford a decent meal or a roof over Europe's head, are asking for more money. At a time when citizens need support and services and businesses are looking for new funds to promote their competitiveness, the EU should be the first to set a good example. The total unwillingness to make cuts in spending efficiency convinced me to vote against the text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - The general EU budget approved by Parliament corrects the cuts imposed by the Council on the Commission's draft, the only way to meet the actual payment needs envisaged and which is going in the right direction. The EU payment crisis reaches alarming tinges in multiple areas, which threaten to prevent the proper development of EU-funded programmes, from Erasmus to the Cohesion Funds, with unpaid bills of EUR 26 billion in 2014, adding difficulties and uncertainties to combating the crisis. In fisheries matters, consideration is given to the amendment adopted to increase the budget of the European Fisheries Control Agency, although we regret that fisheries policy has not been spared from the overall cut.  Europe needs a shift in its economic policy that will stop the austerity measures that are taking the EU into its third recession. The increase in funds for growth and employment should not be reversed, and should be complemented by the investment plan announced by the new President of the Commission, Jean Claude Juncker. The Council must not thwart the exit from the crisis.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. - The cuts envisaged by the Council to the Commission's proposal on the level of payments for 2015 are not sustainable in the period of crisis we are going through: competitiveness, growth and work must be adequately financed and the €2.1 billion cut would be a negative sign. That is why I voted in favour of the budg committee's amendments to restore the Commission's proposals, which provided for full use to be made of the available resources.  With a view to financial commitment to economic and social development, action should also be taken in favour of a more targeted and responsible use of EU resources. The additional cost of parliament's dual seat - estimated at between EUR 156 million and EUR 204 million per year - is particularly onerous. That is why I voted in favour of Amendment No 86, which reaffirms the Assembly's position on the establishment of a single seat.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. Reviving the debate on the situation at the European Parliament's headquarters in Strasbourg is like opening the Pandora's box. Indeed, the location of institutions is the result of subtle and sometimes difficult compromises.  Requiring a single seat for the European Parliament in Brussels is contrary to the letter and spirit of the treaties.  The economic and even ecological arguments appear to be greatly exaggerated.  I therefore voted against Amendment 563 in paragraph 86 in favour of a roadmap for a single seat of the European Parliament. The European Structural Funds must enable EU member states to remain competitive in the global economy. It is regrettable that these structural funds are sometimes diverted in order to allow relocations, in fact motivated by stateless economic interests. I believe that the Structural Funds, the second item in the Community budget, should not be diverted from their purpose by direct or indirect support for relocations. I can only support Amendment 43 bis tabled by Rina Ronja Kari, which "reminds us that structural funds cannot be used in a way that directly or indirectly supports the relocation of services or production to other Member States".

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. - I abstained on this resolution as, although it contains some good elements, and we have reversed some of the damaging decreases in some budget lines, there are still many problems with the EU Budget and its application.  Damaging delays and misplaced focus mean that once again we have a budget that mostly benefits the elite.  There are some important increases which, although I welcome their presence, do not go far enough. Also, I am disappointed that money continues to be committed to areas which are simply not valuable to Europeʼs citizens. The role of the VPRH is just one of these areas where the EU is simply out of touch with what citizens want.  On the other hand I am pleased to see that Parliament has decided to increase the funding to UNRWA, this is clearly an example of the citizensʼ concerns coming to the fore. However on the whole, many items in the budget are simply not what the people need and therefore I abstained.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. - The 2015 Union budget is intended to respond to future challenges, to promote initiatives on growth, jobs, investments of general interest, but not least to strengthen areas of deficit or priority interest. Unfortunately, the proposal to reduce the commitment appropriations of operational funds for producer organisations contributes to widening the development gaps. I recall that in some Member States the level of organisation of producer groups is at a very low level. I would also point out that the application of the 'financial discipline' mechanism may create difficulties for farmers with regard to direct payments of an amount exceeding EUR 2000. The abolition of milk quotas in April 2015 and sugar in 2017 will create major imbalances in the internal market. It is therefore necessary, as a priority, to create a fund to identify new outlets in third countries.  The Commission recently allocated EUR 30 million for the prospecting of new markets under temporary emergency aid with the application of the Russian embargo. We still need concrete action plans supported by a robust budget to reduce the surplus of dairy products and sugar.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - I voted against. In the face of very strong cuts that Member States and local authorities are making, almost always to the detriment of the citizens, we do not see in this budget the awareness of doing the same at the level of the EU institutions.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. - The EU does not allocate any specific aid to bullfighting, but supports 'agricultural activity'. That is, the cultivation of agricultural products and the rearing and maintenance of dairy or meat animals, as well as the maintenance of land in good agricultural and environmental conditions. Amendment No 232 concerns Budget Line 05 03 0101, which covers direct PAYMENTS from the CAP. For the reasons already set out above, we consider that this amendment lacks technical support, nor could its approval have any direct consequence on the abolition of bullfighting.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the European Parliament's draft budget for 2015. The European Union adopted its Multi-Year Financial Framework for the next six years last year. We must now meet our commitments so that the investments financed by the European budget can be made. However, I do not agree with paragraph 86 of this resolution. The latter mentions the establishment of a roadmap for a single seat of the European Parliament. The treaties are clear: Parliament has only one official seat, in Strasbourg. We have to respect the treaties.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - (IT) Today I voted in favour of the resolution on the European Union budget, the most important political document, but which continues to be perceived by the Member States as a burden, as an additional burden on national budgets and not as it should actually be, that is, as an opportunity to strengthen initiatives and investments that have added value for the Union. It would have been desirable that, at a time of crisis as important as the one we are experiencing, we had discussed a somewhat more ambitious draft budget for Europe that included, for example, the strengthening of the programmes that are at the heart of the Europe 2020 strategy, aimed at promoting growth, competitiveness and employment.  I also believe that unnecessary expenditure and waste must be reduced absolutely. I therefore supported the amendments proposing a 10% reduction in Members' wages, a 15% reduction in travel expenses, a 15% reduction in general allowance costs, a 50% reduction in transitional allowances and a 15% reduction in Members' pensions. I also voted in favour of the amendment to achieve a single seat for the European Parliament (Brussels) which I hope will lead to the removal of the Strasbourg seat.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - (IT) Faced with a crisis situation which has been going on for seven years now, Parliament's response is to increase expenditure commitments, thus causing problems with backpaying. Over the years, administrative expenditure has increased, but what appears most serious is the increase in contributions to European political parties and foundations. Let us remember that the distinction between these two subjects is one of the many tricks for having more public funds and confusing those who are not in charge of the work by making them believe in the need for such substantial contributions. When people are forced to face an economic reality that is getting worse by the day, it is more than necessary to spend public contributions in order to help those in need, instead of reserving those funds for high-level politicians and bureaucrats.

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: Written. We are categorically opposed to eu funds being used for the relocation of jobs, against subsidies for tobacco production and against the granting of aid in any way for long journeys of live animals causing suffering to animals. We are in favour of greater transparency in terms of transparency. Union expenditure and the European Parliament's use of money, as well as increased levels of investment in Europe for the benefit of growth and jobs in all Member States. That is why we are actively fighting for these matters in our respective committees and for this to be included in relevant legislative texts. On the other hand, we are clearly opposed to empty talk, increased bureaucracy and genuinely ineffective measures, as the proposals of the two outer groups of parliament unfortunately are reflected. Many of the proposals from this are not part of a vote on the budget and will have no effect outside the walls of this Parliament. That is why we have voted against these amendments from end to end. Finally, we recognise that the European Parliament's proposals have good and progressive ideas about supporting growth and job-creating initiatives, as well as necessary research and development. Overall, however, it is our position that the European Union must show financial responsibility at this time and, as far as possible, prioritise these efforts within an existing framework. We therefore abstain from voting in favour of the budget.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the report on the Draft Budget of the European Union for 2015 as I agree with the line taken in this regard by Parliament, especially with regard to increasing strategic investments in interventions with a European added value aimed at contributing to the recovery of the European economy and promoting competitiveness, sustainable growth and employment, especially among young people.   Payment appropriations for competitiveness for growth and employment are essential to overcome the crisis and to boost economic growth.  I therefore agree that Parliament wants to focus the increase in appropriations on the programmes at the heart of the Europe 2020 strategy, including Horizon 2020 to promote research and innovation, COSME to help businesses and SMEs, Erasmus+, to support training, education, youth and sport, and so on.  It is now essential that a balanced agreement be reached with the Council and that the joint project that will result from it is for the benefit of the citizens of Europe and aimed at overcoming the crisis.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Hohlmeier report, although I criticise the scant financial resources put at the service of the European Union. At a time when we are calling for more investment, economic recovery and job creation we need more Europe and not less Europe. A budget of not 1% of GNI is an insufficient budget. Especially if we take into account that 94 % of the Union budget (withdrawals from administrative expenditure) are funds that return to the Member States to contribute to public and private investment. The basic and interest-making accounts of so-called net taxpayers call on us to urgently rethink the EU's own resources system which is not largely dependent on member states' payments.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) It is obvious that economic growth and employment cannot be stimulated without the necessary appropriations. However, the right balance must be struck between rigour and development and between commitment and payment appropriations. The credibility of the European Union must not be weakened by a continuous delay in payments, to the detriment of SMEs and young people, and by the unnecessary waste of economic resources. I therefore voted in favour because it is our responsibility to implement the new multiannual programmes and to honour the commitments made, guaranteeing more funds to SMEs, young people through the Erasmus Programme, supporting research and innovation with Horizon 2020 as well as agricultural policy and also what is provided for in Heading 3, namely strengthening the European response to the humanitarian and social crisis in relation to the management of migratory flows.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - Today I could only vote against the EU general budget for the year 2015. The budget proposed by the Commission in June provided for a total of EUR 145.599 billion in commitments and EUR 142.137 billion in payments. The Council presented its proposal in July, which provides for around EUR 500 million less as commitments and more than EUR 2 billion in payments compared with the figures presented by the Commission. This reduction was the result of across-the-board cuts, without taking into account the priorities repeatedly expressed by the various European institutions. The European Parliament has therefore reacted to these cuts by proposing a basic strategy aimed at restoring the figures originally proposed by the European Commission, and going even further for different budget lines. The result after Parliament's amendments is therefore 146.348 billion in commitments and 146.416 billion in payments. The approach taken by the M5S in committee was to table more than 100 amendments, highlighting some priorities where we felt it was necessary to increase appropriations, such as immigration issues, agricultural crises, support for SMEs and youth employment, humanitarian aid, and, on the other hand, to indicate certain lines that could be reduced, such as the pre-accession instrument and communication expenditure.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - I voted against the EU budget for 2015 because once again it is the budget of austericide and poverty. These are budgets made with their backs to the reality of social emergency that popular classes are experiencing in all EU countries. This budget remains in the neoliberal logic of memerándums, cuts, public privatisations and remains not budgets for job creation and living conditions for EU citizens.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – In this complex vote I supported to restore the Commission's draft budget (thus rejecting the linear cuts to the administrative expenditure for the institutions made by the Council), with some adjustments to take into account specific needs of the institutions.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. - I believe that additional support is needed to mitigate the impact of the Russian ban on the import of certain agricultural and fishery products from the Union and with the emergency support measures taken by the European Commission in response to this crisis.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. - Through this vote, the European Parliament has demonstrated its willingness to negotiate a coherent budget for 2015 that reflects our political priorities. We were keen to highlight our concerns in the wake of the major budget cuts proposed by the Council, particularly in the section on competitiveness, growth and employment. It is crucial, in particular, to ensure strong financial support for SMEs in Europe. That is why we want to increase the commitment to SMEs and the creation of businesses by 26.5 million euros compared to the draft budget. In addition, I welcome the initiative to increase the envelope of the European Fund for Aid to the Most Deprived (FEAD). Solidarity is a European commitment. I fought, like many of my colleagues, during the last mandate for the sustainability of this fund.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The European Union must prepare for the future and safeguard education programmes, such as Erasmus and Erasmus Mundus, research and development programmes. It must also support economic development with business assistance programmes. That is the meaning of the draft budget that we have adopted. The European Parliament and Council now have three weeks of so-called "conciliation" before the final budget for 2015 is signed at the end of November. Our vigilance must not weaken because we need a consolidated budget that will enable us to respond to the concerns of European citizens.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. - Despite having voted in favour of the resolution on the 2015 budget as a whole, in order to support growth and jobs in Europe, I opposed the paragraph proposing a single seat. Indeed, it is stipulated in the European texts that the European Parliament has one and only one seat Strasbourg, so this paragraph is legally wrong and is only intended to attack Strasbourg. If some want to question the seats of the institutions, then we must put everything on the table: all the institutions and agencies across the European Union.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. - The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament abstained as we point out our full dissatisf with the budget defined from its origin by the European Commission in its draft. Moreover, with the additional cuts proposed by the Council and the lack of consideration for basic agreements in budgetary and multi-year preparation, insisting on its obsession with austerity which jeopardizes the basic functioning of important programmes and continues to bet on abandoning public initiative to rescue European society. However, the European Parliament's position only restores the level of expenditure, we note that they do not seek to go beyond accepting their freezing and weight loss in the European economy, that their main concern is the delays and difficulties of paying overdue bills, and that it has not had the audacity to set a more ambitious budget.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: in writing. - (IT) I would like to express my reasons for voting in favour of the amendments which provide for a significant increase in EU support for UNRWA, the United Nations Agency providing assistance to 5 million Palestinian refugees, to cover the immediate needs of the population affected again this year by a conflict that is all the more abhorrent the more it affects innocent civilian populations and children on both sides. The vote in favour, however, should not be separated from the following considerations: all those involved in the region must ensure that humanitarian aid actually reaches without waste and without giving rise to suspicions of diverted funds either directly or indirectly, in favour of activities that are even remotely comparable to pro-terrorist propaganda, or to forage bureaucratic clientele mechanisms aimed at rewarding those who wish to exploit the suffering of a region in crisis. We will ensure that this does not happen and we will take account of how every single euro donated by european citizens will be spent.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. - When negotiating the EU budget, the objectives of returning from the crisis and creating jobs should be taken into account in particular. Cohesion and agricultural subsidies, which are the engine of development and job creation, should therefore be increased in the first place. Those who want to reduce these resources are ignoring the European Union's main objectives, which the new Commission has flagned: economic growth and job creation. It is sad that, with a view to next year's budget, the Council has finally adopted a position that goes against our stated objectives openly. I therefore voted in favour of the report proposed by the Committee on Budgets, taking full account of the position of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. We will not allow next year's rural development resources, advance recognition and operating aid to producer organisations, and beekeeping and oenological aid to be reduced by up to a penny. Furthermore, it is a great success that our amendments, tabled jointly with my fellow Member Tamás Deutsch, have been included in Parliament's proposal. This would provide EUR 7 million more for school fruit programmes and EUR 4 million more for school milk programmes. In addition to helping our dairy and fruit and vegetable sectors, this step serves the health and well-being of our children, which is in the interest of all well-feeling Europeans.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this amendment on the Budget 2015, which was tabled to stop Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) payments being made to farmers who are breeding bulls for bullfighting. CAP funding, which is so important for Welsh agriculture, should not be used to support bullfighting. Despite most MEPs voting in favour of this amendment, a qualified majority was not reached, and so it did not pass. As a Member of the European Parliament, I have given animal welfare a high priority and will continue to do so. I recently presented a petition to the new European Commission President, Jean-Claude Juncker, calling for a commissioner with clear responsibility for animal welfare, but it was unfortunately unsuccessful. However, I remain very positive that in the vote on next year's Budget, we will finally put a stop to European taxpayers’ money being used to support the bullfighting industry

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The European Union must have a credible, supportive budget that contributes to growth and jobs. The Treaties, financial regulations, the European Union 2020 strategy and the multiannual financial framework 2014-2020 must be respected. It is a compromise between the institutions, but it is also a commitment to the citizens. The Europe 2020 strategy, which guides the multiannual financial framework, must see its objectives achieved, but to do so we need to ensure the necessary means for these same objectives to be achieved. The means must be up to the height of ambition. Therefore, for the EU Budget for 2015, the cuts proposed by the Council by more than 500 million in commitments and 2 100 million in payments are unacceptable. I call for the strengthening of programmes for SMEs, youth, research and innovation, as well as the programme to support the most disadvantaged. External solidarity is another concern, which underpins the increases that Parliament proposes for humanitarian aid in support for refugees and in the Neighbourhood Policy. The multiannual financial framework, its programmes, funds and priorities are required to be rapidly implementing it.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - This report analyses the Council's proposal for a Budget made by the Council on the commission's initial proposal. This is another year in which there is the usual dance between the Commission (the good policeman), the Council (the bad cop) and Parliament. Through the cuts proposed by the Council, Parliament proposes to repay the amounts cut, even in some cases, in addition to this refund. But it is never enough, in the case of a trilogue, to negotiate a strengthened budget.  In June, the draft EU general budget for 2015 proposed by the European Commission was already at birth condemned to be limited compared to what the European Union itself had decided in the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 (MFF). After all, the proposal put forward by the Commission withdraws EUR 480 million in commitments and EUR 3360 million in payments – about 3 % less than would be foreseen in the MFF. It also prioritises the objectives for the EU 2020 strategy, among other policies used to attack labour rights, and continues to be channelled into militaristic and neoliberal objectives, to which we oppose it. The report has positive aspects, which are critical of the Council's position. But it does not call into question fundamental issues, such as the political objectives served by this budget. We voted against it.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Written. - (C) We have today voted against the proposals to further increase the budget for the EU. It is of the utmost importance that not only the Member States but also the European Union act with rigour with regard to all budgetary treatment. We are opposed to parliament's majority calling for a substantial increase in the budget in virtually all areas, while there have been deficits since previous years. On the other hand, we have chosen to vote in favour of a budgetary approach that means higher funding for research, innovation and the completion of the internal market, as this is crucial for growth and job creation. In addition, it was important for us to support the EU's asylum and migration programmes in order to create safe routes into the EU. On the other hand, we cannot accept that more taxpayers' money is spent on agricultural subsidies and huge subsidy schemes to support archaic and climate-damaging industries.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - The budget for other sections covers the administrative budgets of the European institutions, including the European Parliament, with the exception, however, of the European Commission. The European Parliament's budget for 2015 was set at EUR 1 794 929 112, representing an increase of 2.24% compared to the 2014 budget. The budget of the Court of Justice of the European Union should also be increased in view of the significant increase in the number of cases and the creation of an additional 12 posts to ensure that judgments are delivered in a timely manner and without undue delay. Implementation of the cooperation agreement between the European Parliament and the Committee of the Regions and the European Economic and Social Committee, where there will be a gradual transfer of 80 staff from advisory committees to the European Parliament. It will also be necessary to increase the budget of the European External Action Service, which will be linked to the opening of a new representation in the Persian Gulf, in which the European Union is underrepresented.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted against, strongly criticising the EU for its budget. In the face of very strong cuts and sacrifices that Member States and local authorities are making, almost always to the detriment of the citizens, we do not see in this budget the awareness of doing the same at European level.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - I am voting against the Draft General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015, all sections, because it shifts its centre of gravity more towards numbers and economic power than towards the citizens themselves.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. - I voted against the General Budget of the EU for the financial year 2015 because it restores the draft budget proposed by the Commission and even increases certain lines above the Commission proposal. I am not prepared to give the EU any more taxpayersʼ money. The budget also leaves no margin under the ceiling, which means the Commission will be unable to deal with any unforeseen pressures that will inevitably arise.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - As the author of the JURI opinion on the 2015 budget, I welcome today's vote. The EP reinstated the expenditure and commitments (€142.1 billion and €145.6 billion) proposed by the European Commission in June, rejecting the Council's proposal to reduce the level of proposed payments by more than EUR 2 billion, which would mean a decrease of -0.18% compared to the 2014 budget.  I welcome the fact that we have managed to reach agreement on the use of the flexibility mechanisms set out in the MFF 2014-2020 Regulation, including the reference to the contingency margin. This is an increase of around €4 billion in the 2015 payment ceiling. These funds should be allocated to economic growth and employment policies, education and population support in conflict regions. Additional resources are also needed to support farmers who have suffered losses as a result of the Russian food embargo from the EU. The Council's position is worrying, as it could lead to an increase in deficits carried over from one financial year to another, which will result in a loss of credibility vis-ing towards partner countries and the blocking of key projects under Horizon 2020, ERASMUS+ and the Neighbourhood Policy. Already at the end of 2013, the accumulated backlog since 2010 amounted to around €23 billion.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. - I voted against the resolution on the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 because I believe the fact that we have not reformed the EU budget significantly to address the pressing needs of our citizens is a missed opportunity. I find it appalling that we are going to increase by 2.24 % over the 2014 budget, which will benefit the agricultural sector disproportionately. It is hard to justify in the current economic context how we can subsidise bullfighting and the tobacco industry.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. - I do not believe that EU funds should be used to subsidise the farming of bulls used in bullfights. Taxpayersʼ money should not be used to fund any practice which causes animals unnecessary pain, suffering or distress. Given the UK Conservative delegation’s opposition to coupled payments under the CAP, it is imperative that these animals are identifiable in order to stop any payments of this kind. For this reason I supported Amendment 12 of the vote on the resolution and Amendment 232 of the vote on the budget lines. Animals used for lethal bullfighting activities should not be eligible to receive any direct CAP appropriations nor any other appropriations from the budget.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: In writing. I voted for this report by which the European Parliament adopted its position on the European Union budget for 2015.  In the face of the drastic cuts proposed by the Council, our Parliament wanted to restore the amounts originally proposed by the European Commission, so that the European Union could pursue an ambitious policy, in terms of competitiveness and growth, to create jobs, fight unemployment, support research and innovation, help SMEs: these are Parliament's priorities. Last but not surprisingly, I once again supported the seat of Strasbourg, which, not to the displeasure of some, is the official seat of the European Parliament. I also welcome the vote on an amendment on the financial and human resources of the EU Institutions Translation Centre. We must respect the fundamental principle of multilingualism.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. - Europeans expect strong action from the European Union to meet the challenges of growth and jobs. I have thereby approved this report on the 2015 budget, which reminds member states of their commitments on the European budget. With this vote, the European Parliament expresses very clearly its determination for an ambitious And respectful European budget to the decision taken at the end of 2013 on the multi-year budget.  I supported this report because it reminds the Council that the European Union has a seven-year budget with specific budget commitments. The European Parliament rejects the budget cuts proposed by the Council even though there is a consensus in Europe on the need to revive growth and jobs. On the other hand, I welcome the broad consensus in the European Parliament to resolve the payments crisis which is tarnishing the credibility of the European Union. With six billion euros more than the Council's proposal on payments, the European Parliament is giving the Union the means to pay its debts to associations, businesses and communities that have applied for European structural funds.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. - I voted against the EU budget for 2015 because it is not future-proof. There is no investment in animals, nature and the environment. The EU has only one goal: Growth! Economic growth!  Almost half of the budget is earmarked for agricultural subsidies, regardless of the impact on animals, people, nature or the environment. There is hardly any investment in biodiversity. Instead of investing in sustainable agriculture that focuses on the production of plant-based food, the EU subsidizes intensive livestock farming and maintains long-term transports of live animals. The European Parliament approves this in no way; election promises seem forgotten and citizens are ignored. Take bullfights, for example. A vast majority of Europeans do not want bullfights to be sponsored with their tax money. However, there was no qualified majority in Parliament who actually wanted to abolish subsidies for bullfighting, while the political will appeared to be there a little later (Amendment 12, report on the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015). These differences cannot be explained and further fuel citizens' distrust of the European Union.

name: Eduard-Raul HELLVIG
text: in writing. - The Council's position on the 2015 budget is contrary to the European Parliament resolution of 13 March 2014 and the conclusions of June and August 2014 of the European Council. It is worrying, in particular, to reduce payment appropriations under the Competitiveness and Growth Funds, which violates the Council's commitments to act to overcome the crisis and its effects.  Instead of a strategic investment programme to increase competitiveness and sustainable jobs in key areas such as transport infrastructure, telecommunications and energy, the Council presented a proposal that ignores the EU's role in coordinating and supporting growth initiatives through its own financing instruments.  I am referring in particular to the programmes contained in the Europe 2020 strategy, such as EURES, aimed at promoting cross-border labour mobility. In this respect, I consider it appropriate to launch the pilot project to introduce the European worker's e-card, including workers' professional and social security data – a card distinct from the European health insurance framework.  I also support the call for increased subsidies for SMEs and cooperatives in order to support them in the face of increasing production costs, continued technological progress and the dominant market positions of large companies.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. - Irrespective of the fact that I cannot agree to the general budget because it is pushing ahead with a multi-billion-dollar debt mountain by postponing payment commitments that have already been entered into, I would like to point out that, even within the plan, great contradictions with the Commission's statements are evident. There is a regular mention of the importance of research and development for Europe's future competitiveness, and then it is in this area that we are cut back. I would also like to point out that the disproportionate reduction in research funding for educational research is diametrically opposed to the statements made by European politicians about the importance of education. No, the EU rightly does not have competence for education, and the individual countries can do that much better. In my country, this is even the competence of the individual Länder, but if there were anything to do together in the field of education on a European basis, it would probably be in education research. Now many will ask themselves: where do they take the money from? Let me give you an example: instead of wanting to buy billions of dollars to eliminate youth unemployment, which is not possible anyway, a different Europolicy could have ensured that the south of Europe, including France, would not lose its growth, its industry and its jobs, also because of too high a euro exchange rate.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. - With regard to the 2015 EU budget, I understand the Council's desire to reduce it and am certain that some expenditure can be reduced.  Given the budgetary situation of the Member States, I am convinced that we can 'do more with less' for a limited period of time. However, I do not believe that the Council's solution is the right one. By proposing a sharp cut of two billion euros in the 2015 budget, states are in fact only denouncing their contractual obligations and penalising the citizens who are the main beneficiaries of popular programmes such as food aid to the poorest, the Erasmus programme and cohesion policy. While I am pleased that the European Parliament has called for the restoration of the most necessary aid, I would argue that cuts must be made in order to avoid the asphyxiation of states and therefore of taxpayers who remain the main contributors to the EU budget. It is a difficult exercise to reduce the budget while guaranteeing payment of commitments made to citizens through the CAP, regional policy and all spending that is supposed to support growth.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - I voted in, because I support the increase in funding for programmes that represent the priorities of the Europe 2020 strategy, namely the programme of growth, employment and competitiveness, information and communication technologies, energy security and the environment and climate action. This is added to foreign policy programmes, such as European neighbourhood policy and support for countries in the Union's south-eastern neighbourhood, which are in the phase of democratic growth and unification.  I also support additional support to mitigate the consequences of the Russian ban on imports of European agricultural and fishing products. It should also be noted that the draft budget for 2015 represents a growth of 1.4% compared to the budget in 2014, as regards the agreed payment appropriations, but also the €2 billion shortfall, in terms of implementation, compared to 2013.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the European Parliament’s position on the EU budget for 2015. It is very important that the EU has the means available to fulfil all the contracts it has entered into. It would be unacceptable to have a lack of funds available to pay Member States for work done under cohesion policy and structural funds. Therefore, I support Parliament’s increase of the payments level in its reading of the budget. There is one particular point I am keen to emphasise: Parliament has voted for an increase of the funds available for humanitarian aid and disaster prevention. We are facing some deeply troubling situations. I am primarily concerned by the malnourishment crisis in South Sudan, which could cause the deaths of more than 50 000 children in the next year. It is estimated that over 1 million children under the age of 5 in the country will require treatment for malnutrition in 2014. It is important in this context that European Union humanitarian aid programmes have money available to them to make a real difference.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. - We have worked to restore a reasonable and measured budget to participate in innovation, growth and social justice. In particular, we are committed to the preservation of substantial and appropriate funding for the creation of SMEs, Erasmus scholarships, scientific research and food aid for the poorest.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I supported the European Parliament's position on the European Union's draft 2015 budget, which calls on Member States to honour their budgetary commitments and increase funding for growth, employment, scientific research and humanitarian aid. However, I objected to a proposal by this project to establish a roadmap for a single seat of the European Parliament. Indeed, it is stated in the Treaties that the seat of the Union's institutions can only be changed by a unanimous decision of the Heads of State and Government. Moreover, to question the Strasbourg siege would be to undermine a strong symbol of reconciliation between France and Germany, and thus to the European project itself. This proposal was supported by a majority of MePs, so I chose to abstain on the final vote.

name: Eva KAILI
text: Writing. - After long and largely unjustified delays, the EU budget is moving, although with many objections, in one direction of development policy. However, in practice this could be more substantial in terms of the adequacy of the resources available to meet social priority. In addition, the 2015 budget is quite limited in terms of the adequacy of resources to finance sectors of the economy such as entrepreneurship, support for small and medium-sized enterprises, innovation, and above all sufficient resources to support youth employment programmes.  In addition, for countries with strong energy activity it would be appropriate to place more emphasis on the second category of expenditure (Natural Resources). The emphasis at the moment is not important and this holds back programmes and actions that would help the country take significant steps in infrastructure. Finally, it would be potentially useful if at this stage there had been transfers of resources from the fourth and fifth categories of expenditure (Europe as a global partner and administrative expenditure) in order to further strengthen the first, second and third categories of expenditure.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. - Labour argued against the proposed increase in EU spending in 2012, and voted for a real-terms cut in the EU budget then. We have argued for reform of the EU budget, including a greater focus on generating growth and jobs, and for the EU to undertake a zero-based review of all spending by EU agencies.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: Written. We are categorically opposed to eu funds being used for the relocation of jobs, against subsidies for tobacco production and against the granting of aid in any way for long journeys of live animals causing suffering to animals. We are in favour of greater transparency in terms of transparency. Union expenditure and the European Parliament's use of money, as well as increased levels of investment in Europe for the benefit of growth and jobs in all Member States. That is why we are actively fighting for these matters in our respective committees and for this to be included in relevant legislative texts. On the other hand, we are clearly opposed to empty talk, increased bureaucracy and genuinely ineffective measures, as the proposals of the two outer groups of parliament unfortunately are reflected. Many of the proposals from this are not part of a vote on the budget and will have no effect outside the walls of this Parliament. That is why we have voted against these amendments from end to end. Finally, we recognise that the European Parliament's proposals have good and progressive ideas about supporting growth and job-creating initiatives, as well as necessary research and development. Overall, however, it is our position that the European Union must show financial responsibility at this time and, as far as possible, prioritise these efforts within an existing framework. We therefore abstain from voting in favour of the budget.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - First of all, I would like to thank Mrs Gardiazabal and Mrs Hohlmeier for the work they have done so far in the 2015 budget procedure. In recent years, we, as a Parliament, have fought hard to ensure that the European budget has the necessary funds to enable all European policies to be properly implemented, and we have done so responsibly. We have done so again today, focusing our priorities on supporting employment, business, education and research. Unfortunately, the difficulties of the forthcoming negotiations continue to be evident, especially in terms of payments, but we trust that the Council will be able to meet the needs of its citizens by guaranteeing the investments necessary for the development of the EU.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Writing. – I supported this document, which, on the part of the European Parliament, decides to increase the amounts allocated most to the most important europe 2020 programmes, investment in innovation and research, the aim of promoting growth, competitiveness and employment, horizon 2020, Erasmus+ and others. The EU contributes to the creation of an innovative and prosperous economy across the continent and continues to increase support for programmes such as neighbourhood policy, development and humanitarian aid programmes, which ensure the implementation of the Union's external policy agenda. I fully agree with the need to ensure continued support for eastern neighbourhood states under pressure from undemocratic forces and seeking stable democratic governance. I therefore agree that the Council must restore the reduced amounts of support lines by leaving the amounts provided for in the draft budget, because a secure, stable, democratic neighbourhood of the EU, especially the Eastern Neighbourhood, is of strategic importance to us.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - I voted in favour of the budget. The Position of the European Parliament is justified and moderate. A higher amount is needed. In 2015, we will have increased payments for the period from 2007 to 2013 in accordance with the n+2 rule. A new financial perspective begins. We cannot abandon the objective of reviving the economy. We need an increase in payments, not commitments. I expect the Council to change its position.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - The European Parliament today voted on a budget for the EU which has been very marked by the Strategy of the Governments of the Member States based on very aggressive fiscal consolidation policies which have brought more suffering to families and which threaten to lead the EU into a third economic recession in five years. Since the Eurochamber we have tried to adapt the Community budget to the need to implement growth and employment policies, activating demand through the public sector with the aim of creating a benchmark in the welfare society again. We want to change the trend of policies to be implemented from the Council so that we can respond in the most efficient way to the urgent needs of the continent's citizens today.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - I voted against the EU budget for 2015 because once again it is the budget of austericide and poverty. These are budgets made with their backs to the reality of social emergency that popular classes are experiencing in all EU countries. This budget remains in the neoliberal logic of memerándums, cuts, public privatisations and remains not budgets for job creation and living conditions for EU citizens.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - With regard to the 2015 Union budget, I draw attention to the alarming situation regarding payments that the Union urgently has to deal with. The lack of payment appropriations m.in the continuity of key EU programmes, including Erasmus+, for which €100 million is already missing for payments in the 2014 budget. A particularly alarming situation also exists in the area of research and development, where the gap between political declarations and actual actions is greatest. Horizon 2020, the EU's largest research and development programme, aims to provide an impeaching to the EU economy, provide a scientific and technical basis for industry and improve the quality of life of Europeans, while the programme is structurally underfunded.  2015 is the first year of the new financial perspective, so new programmes that take some time to start will not feel a lack of resources. However, in the years to come, if we do not solve the problem of managing payments and reducing the structural deficit of the budget, the lack of payment appropriations will increase. It is therefore crucial to monitor in detail the payments triggered by the Commission. It will also be necessary to review the Multiannual Financial Framework in 2016 in terms of increasing payment appropriations and actually planning commitments to increase the Union's innovation and competitiveness.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - While delays in disbursements from the European budget have become a major problem for Member States, the Council has proposed a small increase in the 2015 budget for payments. The total proposed amount for payments in 2015 was €140 billion, up only 3.3% from the payment limit in 2014.  Given the significant transferred and overdue and unpaid commitments, Parliament increased the projected payment amount to €146.4 billion, an increase of 8.1% compared to 2014. As regards the permissible creation of commitments, the Council proposed a level of €145 billion and Parliament proposed an increase to €146.4 billion with a view to enhanced investment in development projects in science, research and development and job creation and tackling high unemployment, especially for young people. Budget cuts in payment appropriations lead to disruptions in disbursements. For example, in Horizon 2020, which aims to foster innovation and competitiveness, end-users have not received funding for projects already realised. This attitude towards the budget creates illiquidity in the Member States and loses citizens' trust in the European budget and thus in the EU institutions.    I supported this report on the draft general budget of the European Union for 2015, as the increases achieved are necessary for the implementation of budgetary commitments.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. – I welcome the paragraph in the report calling on the EU to end all subsidies for bullfighting.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - With my vote I strongly supported the Position of the European Parliament on the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015, as I believe it is right to focus the increase in appropriations on programmes at the heart of the Europe 2020 strategy, such as Cosme, Horizon 2020, Progress and Erasmus+. Indeed, I believe that it is only by focusing member states' efforts on the Europe 2020 strategy that the objectives set out in the Multiannual Financial Framework - such as growth, employment and competitiveness - that Europe needs to emerge from the crisis can be achieved.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. - I rejected the resolution because, contrary to the Council's position, the European Parliament is opposed to a reduction in the budget. The additional funds required are justified by an ever-increasing effort. This justification is not sufficient for me, as for the most part concrete figures are not provided. Furthermore, as Austrian sovereignty should be an exception because of the principle of subsidiarity, it should be an exception to the basic rule and european regulation, I was also unable to agree to an increase in funding for the decentralised agencies (recital 6). In this respect, I would like to draw attention to the enormous administrative costs of these agencies (up to 71% of the total budget).

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report rejects the Council's position on the 2015 European budget. After a sharp drop in the budget in 2014, the EU's financial situation is critical: it is neither able to pay off the 26 billion unpaid debts accumulated at the end of 2013, nor to finance any new priority. The Commission's proposal for 2015 was already indigent. It is made disastrous by the additional restrictions demanded by the Council. Unimaginable cuts are planned in the growth and employment appropriations, which are seen as its top priorities by the same Council. Equally intolerable cuts are amplified in research, SMEs and infrastructure. This report therefore rightly describes the Council's proposal as "arbitrary, inconsistent and catastrophic" in its consequences. However, the budget proposed by this report remains very insufficient, with only 2 billion more than the 2013 budget. This would not even solve the unpaid debts, let alone fund new priorities. I abstain because I share the strong condemnation of the Council's austere delusions, but I cannot endorse a counter-proposal that is as insufficient as it is velleitarian.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - I agree with the document adopted here today in which Parliament reiterates its position on the EU budget for next year. We must be firm in rejecting the cuts made by the Council to the draft budget. We must find solutions to increase appropriations in areas as important as growth, employment, research, education and humanitarian aid. I also agree that €4 billion should be added to avoid serious payment failures to local authorities, SMEs and other beneficiaries of European funds. This new budget must serve to help the EU find the path to growth and development. I have changed my intention to vote on Amendment No 12 by Mep Bas Eickhout, voting against, because I believe that our cultural heritage should be respected and the importance of maintaining single bovine breeds, including brave bullies.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. - I have voted in favour of this report because it focuses on reinforcing those programmes that are at the heart of the Europe 2020 strategy that aim to foster growth, employment and competitiveness (namely Horizon 2020, COSME, Erasmus+, the Digital Agenda, Progress and the Social Agenda, including EURES and the Microfinance Facility). This will lead the EU to further contribute to a more innovative and prosperous economy all throughout the Union.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. - I fully support the budget of the European Union for 2015, as we successfully managed to negotiated a package deal agreeing on targeted increases above the Commission’s 2015 Draft Budget, especially for initiatives that will boost competitiveness, growth and jobs and will support initiatives in favour of reinforcements for asylum, migration and security. I also voted in favour of any amendments forbidding the use of any funds for breeders of bulls reared for bullfighting. The E.U funds should not be used to finance the exploitation of animals and their agony.

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. - My final vote on the European Union budget for 2015 was negative.  However, I would like to point out that I voted in favour of some important amendments, which called for: - to make unemployment and the fight against poverty the EU's priorities;  - transparency measures for parliamentary allowances; - a single seat for a single seat of the European Parliament. I also voted in favour of the amendment calling for the cap appropriations not to be used to finance lethal bullfights, listening to the voices of thousands of citizens who, like me, consider this practice unacceptable, as well as a clear violation of the European Convention on the Protection of Animals in Livestock Farming (Council Directive 98/58/EC);

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of this text which completes the vote on the draft general budget 2015. It takes back in literary form all the concerns expressed in the previous vote.  However, I denounce the unacceptable attempt to hijack the budgetary power of the European Parliament into an anti-Strasbourg weapon. Indeed, an amendment, against which I voted, was tabled calling for the establishment of a single seat of the European Parliament. The history of European construction and the city of Strasbourg are closely linked. France, the founding country of the Union, must retain the seat of Parliament in Strasbourg in accordance with the Treaty.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. - I voted for this budget on which the EPP has obtained the following appropriations: an envelope plus 26.5 million euros for the creation of jobs for SMEs, more than 24 million additional appropriations for Erasmus , and 90 million euros more on scientific research compared to the Commission's proposal. In these times of crisis, the EPP has also successfully campaigned for an increase of an additional EUR 16.7 million for food aid to the poorest. However, I am concerned about the ever-increasing debt resulting from unfuled commitments by states. Of course, the economic situation is not favourable, but it is the States that have set their contributions and then denounce them.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. - I voted for the draft general budget of the European Union because, through the effort of the Committee on Budgets of the European Parliament, of which I am a member, we have managed to achieve a budgetary architecture that focuses on the needs of young people, innovation, SMEs and social policies. The draft budget also provides for the pilot project that we have initiated on increasing access to healthcare services in rural areas.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. - I voted for the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015. The Union budget plays an important role in achieving political objectives such as: investments in transport, energy and telecommunications infrastructure at Union scale (including the completion of the Digital Single Market by 2015), energy efficiency, innovation and research. Unemployment is the most pressing concern for the EU, and for the recovery of Member States' economies and the creation of new jobs it is necessary to re-apply the EU's austerity policies, allowing Member States to apply the most appropriate policy options for their specific situations. The EU budget should therefore focus in particular on creating decent jobs and sustainable economic growth. Instruments such as the ESF, the European Regional Development Fund, the Cohesion Fund or the Youth Employment Initiative are also particularly important in times of crisis. Given that 2015 will be the second year of implementation of the new cycle of the European Structural and Investment Funds, we stress the need to allocate sufficient commitment and payment appropriations to ensure that the programmes reach the desired number of beneficiaries and thus produce the expected impact.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. - I did not support another of the EP's steps towards resolving the migration between Brussels and Strasbourg. I have two reasons. The first is that the seat of the EP is determined by the Treaties and it is not in the EP's power to change them. Moreover, some countries will still not support this change. Therefore, this is not a real effort to change the situation. If there is a positive signal from the Council to change this situation, I will seriously consider it, because the economical and efficient use of resources is very important to me.  The second reason is that the European Union, like similar projects or states, stands on a number of symbols. There are few of them: commissioners for each country, presidency rotations and the like. And Strasbourg is one of the very important symbols – historically, geographically and culturally. I am not saying that "old symbols" must not change, but it is always necessary to weigh what change will bring and what it will take away. By the way, if someone in my country had suggested that we demolish Prague Castle, an ancient symbol of our statehood and history, they would surely have failed and may have ended up in the care of a medical facility. And yet, economically, it might be advantageous to build concrete skyscrapers instead.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - The EU's general budget for the financial year 2015 faces fewer cuts than gross misinvestment. On the one hand, there are more programmes and projects whose meaning is difficult to convey to the citizen in times of a financial crisis that is still unresolved, such as various agencies or the promotion of certain civil societies. On the other hand, important components for economic growth, especially those of small and medium-sized enterprises, are neglected. Furthermore, there is no serious debate on a single seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg. For these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. - (IT) After carefully examining the document in question, I voted in favour.

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: Written. I voted in favour of calling on the Council to stop having more seats in parliament. Today, the EU spends €114 million (about DKK 850 million) on moving MEPs to Strassbourg. In addition, the travel circus means an additional CO2 emissions of 20,000 tons! It is simply not okay to waste taxpayers' money and damage the environment in this way. It has to be stopped and I will do everything I can to stop the travelling circus. However, this requires the member states to agree and, in particular, France and Luxembourg are adamant about keeping Strassbourg. Too bad.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - This year's draft general EU budget was drafted to balance the allocation of money to commitments and payments to which the EU has committed itself to its programmes. I support the increase in funding directed towards the programmes at the heart of the Europe 2020 strategy, such as Horizon 2020, COSME, Erasmus+, as well as further enhancing programmes that are essential for the implementation of the Union's foreign policy programmes – The Enshlamation Policy and Development and Humanitarian Aid.  As SMEs are the main driver of economic growth in the EU, it is also essential to increase financial support, which will greatly contribute to the fight against unemployment. I also support the additional support granted to mitigate the effects of the Russian ban on imports of certain Union agricultural and fishing products. At the same time, I am pleased that the EU has recognised the importance of energy independence and synergies between all member states, and the importance of promoting renewable energy sources and energy efficiency in order to achieve energy security, especially in the Member States most dependent on Russian gas.  The crisis in Ukraine has imposed the need for stronger co-operation on all energy, not just gas. Consequently, I am of the belief that this draft budget proposal is the right way forward for the EU, so I supported it.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - (IT) I gave my assent to the General Budget of the European Union because, at a difficult time such as the one we are experiencing, of economic crisis and low growth, it is necessary to strike the right balance between rigour and development, clearly and transparently identifying the political priorities and objectives to be achieved most importantly, through the effective use and allocation of available resources. I am delighted that the Plenary has agreed to Amendment No 86 on the road map to a single seat for the European Parliament. I believe that it can lead to major savings in the EU budget, especially at a time like this of scarce resources, and it also meets the demands of European citizens. On the other hand, I regret that Amendment No 34, on the need to create a restructuring fund for the sugar sector, has been rejected; European companies in this sector, which are suffering particularly from a serious structural crisis, would have needed targeted aid to cope with the necessary restructuring which would relaunch their competitiveness.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. - I supported the report on the adoption of the European Union budget for 2015. My support was based, inter alia, on the fact that the priorities of the budget include support for erasmus+. I have run for the European Parliament with a programme for the further development of student exchanges and stays, and i therefore welcome the increase in the budget for the Erasmus+ chapter.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which allocates a balanced budget and takes into account the current European situation. As regards the proposed amendment on the non-allocation of CAP funds to death bullfighting, it is characterised by a high lack of technical quality. It does not take into account cap support allocation mechanisms, and is also unaware that there is no direct support for the breeding of death bulls. The authors were obliged to submit a proposal whose meaning of vote could result in an effective change. Having not done so, I believe that the vote in favour could elude voters, since in practice nothing would change. So and as this is a non-amendment, the content of which is absolutely empty, I abstained.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I approved the European Parliament's resolution on the Council's position on the European Union's general draft for the 2015 financial year. I am in favour of restoring the amounts that have been cut by the Council because it is essential that the lines at the heart of the Europe 2020 strategy be strengthened in favour of growth, competitiveness, employment and creation. Moreover, stabilizing our debt is a priority, and I have therefore voted to add EUR 4 billion in order to settle the programmes at the end of the journey and avoid any serious default, which Europe certainly cannot afford.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this draft budget to restore the Commission's draft budget in most areas cut by the Council, rejecting the Council's proposal to cut EUR 522 million in commitments and EUR 2 100 in payments. Austerity policies have been a failure, they have brought nothing but suffering and not only have they not taken us out of the crisis, but they are leading us to the brink of a third recession. The current situation calls for a change in the direction of economic policy and the European budget should serve to activate public investment by complementing national budgets and boosting growth and employment. The draft Council budget does not reflect the needs and priorities of the Union. That is why I supported this Resolution which requires increases for key budget lines for growth, competitiveness and employment such as Horizon 2020, Erasmus + or COSME, and is committed to a budget that fights inequalities and serves our most suffering citizens, increasing the European Aid Fund for the Most Needy, and a budget that does not cut neighbourhood policy , development cooperation and humanitarian aid.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - The EPP advocates a credible, supportive budget that contributes to growth and jobs by promoting investment in scientific research in Erasmus+, SMEs and CEF. On the other hand, the European Union had around 23.4 billion in unpaid commitments at the end of 2013. These are the two main reasons why I voted for today's report, which demonstrated the EP's displeasure at the Council's position to cut more than 500 million in commitments and 2 100 million in payments for 2015. In the case of late payments, it seems clear to me that further budget cuts would mean extending these non-payments by the Union for longer, which in addition to underscinst their credibility, weakens the financial health of the entities that depend on them. A small word on Amendment No 12 on which I abstained, as a way of providing a broader and more consequential debate on this matter, within the framework of the Multiannual Financial Framework and the CAP itself. The conciliation procedures with the Council are now beginning, which I hope will be able to meet the positions we have put forward in today's report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. - I supported the draft budget for 2015 which raises the commitment appropriations to 146,380.9 million euros and payment appropriations to 146,416.5 million euros.  Parliament has cancelled all the cuts planned by Member States in the Commission's original proposal and has called for additional funding to boost growth and employment in the European Union.  SMEs and research and education programmes, including Erasmus, are expected to receive an additional EUR 190 million. With regard to the EU's international responsibilities, Parliament supported the allocation of an additional EUR 400 million.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the draft budget (DB) for 2015 proposed by the Commission, which amounts to EUR 145 599.3 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 142,137.3 million in payment appropriations. The total volume of payment appropriations in the DB represents a moderate increase of 1.4% over the budget and is still EUR 2 billion lower than in the implementation of the 2013 budget. The BUDG Committee voted for a total of 1 500 amendments and the result of the vote fully satisfies the PPE Group. All the cuts adopted by the Council have been reintroduced at the level of the draft budget. The GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats wants to promote growth and work through a budget that strengthens scientific research, the Erasmus+ programme, the CEF and SMEs. It does not accept the cuts proposed by the Council, which accentuate the problem of payments. The GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats considered that all the cuts made by the Council should be reviewed and proposed that all available flexibility instruments be used to deal effectively with the situation.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - My final vote on the European Union budget is negative because in the face of very strong cuts that Member States and local authorities are making, almost always to the detriment of the citizens, we do not see in this budget the awareness of doing the same at the level of the European institutions.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament abstained as we point out our full dissatisf with the budget defined from its origin by the European Commission in its draft.
