Moreover, with the additional cuts proposed by the Council and the lack of consideration for basic agreements in budgetary and multi-year preparation, insisting on its obsession with austerity which jeopardizes the basic functioning of important programmes and continues to bet on abandoning public initiative to rescue European society. However, the European Parliament's position only restores the level of expenditure, we note that they do not seek to go beyond accepting their freezing and weight loss in the European economy, that their main concern is the delays and difficulties of paying overdue bills, and that it has not had the audacity to set a more ambitious budget.

name: Alfred SANT
text: bil-miktub. - Nixtieq nirreġistra li l-vot tiegħi favur il-mozzjoni qed isir b'riżervi kbar. Fit-tħaddim tal-fondi ssettjati taħt il-baġit annwali, bil-maqlub ta' dak li jingħad, l-Unjoni qiegħda timplimenta proħeduri ta' one size fits all - l-istesss kejl qed jiġi applikat għal kulħadd.  Insemmi żewġ eżempji mill-esperjenza ta' Malta, l-i大ken membru tal-Unjoni, kollu kemm hu gżira. Wara Malta, daħlu pajjiżi oħra bħala membri. Dan kellu l-effett statistic li baxxa l-medja fl-Unjoni tal-prodott gross domestiku ras imb'ras. B'hedge Malta tilfet l-a大大ess għal ikeerti fund strutturali. Minflok, il-gvern innegozja u kiseb finanzi addizzjonali taħt il-perspettiva baġitarja attwali. Madankollu l-istennija hi li azjendi privati ta' daqs zgħir u medju mhux se jibbenefikaw minn dawn il-fondi minħabba r-regoli tal-Unjoni dwar għajniet tal-istat. Is-sens komun jgħidlek li l-istess regoli m'għandhomx jiġu applikati għal dawn il-fondi. It-tieni, għandna l-każ ta' Għawdex, gżira i大ken minn Malta bl-identità u l-karatteristii spe大jali tagħha. Waqgħet lura minħabba insularità doppja. Teħtieġ tmexxija reġjonali biex tiżviluppa. F'paragun assurd, il-Gumsjoni Ewropea dde大idiet kontra li Għawdex jitqies b'dan il-mod billi qabblitha ma' gzejjer Skandinavi. Fit-twettiq tal-baġit Ewropew u fl-użu tal-fondi qed jintesa prin大ipju essenzjali ta' x'jagħmel l-Ewropa dak li hi -- jiġifieri, Ewropa tan-nazzjiejonit. Għalhekk il-vot tiegħi hu kondizzjonat bl-akbar riżervi.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: In writing. Paragraph 86 of the draft resolution of Mrs Gardiazabal Rubial (S-D-ES) and Hohlmeier (EPP-ED) calls on Parliament and the Council to set out a roadmap for a single seat of the European Parliament.  I voted against this amendment as did the FN MEPs. I would like to point out that the treaties specifically indicate that 'the seat of the Union's institutions is set by the common agreement of the governments of the Member States' and that 'the European Parliament is based in Strasbourg'. So there is only one seat of the European Parliament and that is the seat of Strasbourg. To question the Strasbourg seat of the parliamentary institution would be to call into question the whole balance of the geography of the institutions. I will defend this clear position on a consistent basis. Thank you.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. I am categorically opposed to EU funds being used for the relocation of jobs, against support for tobacco production and against any aid being granted for the long journey of live animals causing animal suffering. I am in favour of increased transparency in terms of transparency. The Union's expenditure and the European Parliament's use of money, and for an increased level of investment in Europe for the benefit of growth and jobs in all Member States. That is why I am actively campaigning for these matters in my committees and for this to be included in relevant legislative texts. I am also opposed to increased bureaucracy and genuinely ineffective measures. Some of the proposals that have been made create bureaucracy or are ineffective. Many of the proposals have no place in a vote on the budget and will have no effect outside the walls of this Parliament. That is why, in certain areas, I have voted against proposals which, on the surface, may sound good. Finally, I recognise that the European Parliament's proposals have good and progressive ideas about supporting growth and job-creating initiatives, as well as necessary research and development. Overall, however, I believe that the European Union must show financial responsibility at this time and, as far as possible, prioritise these efforts within an existing framework. I am therefore abstaining from voting in favour of the budget.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted against the EU budget for 2015 because once again it is the budget of austericide and poverty. These are budgets made with their backs to the reality of social emergency that popular classes are experiencing in all EU countries. This budget remains in the neoliberal logic of memerándums, cuts, public privatisations and remains not budgets for job creation and living conditions for EU citizens.  These budgets remain the instrument for further deterioration of public services, while they are the support for implementing laws enshrining the transfer of public money, which should be used in the public, to private companies to which public management will be handed over.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. - Labour MEPs voted today for the EU to do more of what it is good at, working collectively to deliver real benefits and developments in technology, such as funding for the Low Carbon Vehicle Technology Project at the University of Warwick and European Bioenergy Research Institute at Aston University – delivering cutting edge research to local industry. Labour MEPs voted for investment for growth and voted for regional funding that goes directly to communities in the West Midlands and the rest of the UK, as it is local communities that are best able to determine how to deliver for people locally. These are areas where we are more than the sum of our parts, where the EU makes a real difference, and I am proud that Labour MEPs have stood up for the constituents of the West Midlands and the UK in these areas today.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. - In my judgment, the EU budget for 2015 will be without the additional EUR 4 billion that the Committee on Budgets wants to increase it. It is time to efficiently dispose of every euro. If states want to achieve balanced management, we must support them. I support the ER's position to make the budget more taxpayer-friendly. I'm voting NO.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. - I believe it is important to align the Union budget with the state budgets of the Member States with a view to emphasising its role in promoting growth and employment. However, due to the current economic situation in which appropriate measures and programmes need to be responded to, I support the decision to increase funding in the 2015 EU budget for programmes promoting growth, competitiveness and employment, such as Erasmus+, the Social Agenda or Horizon 2020.  In order to combat inequalities, it is necessary to increase funding for programmes and initiatives such as Europe for Citizens, the Fund for European Aid for the Neediest and similar programmes. I also support the call for the approval of €203.3 million to the European Neighbourhood Instrument, so that the EU can fulfil its commitments to its eastern and southern neighbourhoods, which face challenges in terms of economic and social development, immigration and stability.  In order to reduce dependence on Russian gas, it is important to invest in renewable energy sources in order to achieve energy security, and to harmonise horizon 2020 energy consumption targets.  I support the decision to increase the funding earmarked for SMEs, as it is their innovation that can contribute to the EU's desired economic recovery in the form of reducing the number of unemployed and boosting economic growth.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. – Overall I could not support this resolution as it is not the time for a rise in the EU budget. Many areas need reform and the EU should do more of what it is good at, investing in research, in SMEs and creating real jobs and real growth. What my Labour colleagues and I voted for is to work collectively to deliver real benefits, such as developments in technology. We voted for investment and for growth and voted for regional funding that goes directly to communities that are best able to determine how to deliver for people locally.  We also voted for the EU to fulfil the global demands that national governments have put on it – whether in Ukraine, Gaza or on Ebola.   These are areas where we are more than the sum of our parts, where the EU makes a real difference, and I am proud that Labour MEPs have stood up for our constituents in these areas. I also voted against amendments to subsidise bullfighting and to subsidise the tobacco industry, which I do not feel are an appropriate use of EU funds (Amendments 232 and 231).

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing. – Although I support the proposal to establish only one seat of the European Parliament, in today's vote on the proposed paragraph 86 (paragraph 87 in the adopted text), which includes a call for a timetable for the establishment of a single seat of the European Parliament, I abstained, as I believe that this matter must be dealt with in the form of a separate resolution of the European Parliament confirming the European Parliament's position on this particular matter. , not in the form of a sticker on the material concerned by the Budget of the European Union.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. - I am voting against this report because it shifts the centre of gravity of the European Union more towards numbers and economic power than towards its own citizens and their needs.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - The draft budget proposed by the Commission is 2.24% higher than the 2014 budget. This position is in line with the fact that a solution to the periodic lack of payments affecting the EU budget needs to be found. According to the BUDG Committee decision, payments should be increased by EUR 4 billion compared to the 2015 ceiling and commitments should also be increased, in particular for programmes such as COSME, Horzion 2020, Erasmus+.  I believe that the EU budget complements national budgets and provides a good incentive to create growth and jobs. For this reason, it should not be arbitrarily reduced, but certain areas should even be reinforced. It is wrong to view the budget only as a financial item added as a burden on the national budget, but as an opportunity to boost initiatives and investments that create added value in the EU as a whole. For all of the above, I support the Committee's proposal and voted for the 2015 budget.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing - I did not support the draft budget of the European Union, because it is above all about redistributing the money it takes from those who create values. Much of the budget will be swallowed up by the common agricultural policy, which should not have existed for a long time. Similarly, a large part goes to Eu funds, which are looting and distorting the business environment. The European Union needs a fundamental change in the budget: to save more on its administration, to reduce the amount of regulation, to abolish agricultural subsidies, etc.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. - We voted in favour of the EU's draft general budget, as well as the general budget 2015 in general.  It is important to point out, however, that we have rejected the amendments: 1/ on the EU subsidy for bullfighting; 2/ on tobacco subsidies; 3/ on the history museum. On the other hand, we are in favour of a single seat roadmap.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. - With this vote on the budget of the European Union (EU), the Parliament adopted a strong position and expressed support to growth and jobs in the EU. Among other reasons, I voted in favour of this proposal to support our SMEs, but also research, innovation and education. EU needs ambition. I nevertheless disagree with some of the measures proposed. I voted for example against funding for breeding of bulls for bull-fighting. I also voted to put an end to export funds. I believe this is a distortion of the market and that these funds prevent some countries to develop their own production.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. - I voted against the proposal for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 because of two points of particular concern to me. In fact, I oppose the recommendation expressed in the chapter 'Addressing repeated payment crises', in which the rapporteur supports the Commission's proposal to make full use of the available funds under the 2015 payment ceiling, leaving no difference up to the 2015 cap on payments.  In this way, the 2015 budget will not be able to adapt to the unforeseen pressures that will inevitably arise, and therefore I firmly oppose such a recommendation from the rapporteur and the proposal of the European Commission. On the other hand, I am concerned that all draft changes to the budget should be adopted before an agreement is reached on the draft budget for 2015, and therefore I have decided to vote against this proposal.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this Budget but I want to stress that the budget has to be spent in order to provide answers to the priorities agreed: to fully support the EU’s recovery, to strengthen the single market and to follow the EU guidelines to achieve the 2020 Strategy. In my view, giving public subsidies to raise bulls to be sent to bullfights is not a priority that the EU should support or promote, as it goes against my principal values of respecting the well-being of animals. I also voted in favour of the amendment to paragraph 86 which ‘Stresses that the Parliament and the Council, in order to create long term savings in the Union budget, must address the need for a roadmap to a single seat, as stated by the Parliament in several previous resolutions;’. I strongly support a single seat for this House in order to save waste and money, and also in order to be more environmentally-friendly in our work.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of Parliament's proposal for its demand for a significant increase in various essential headings which the Council wants to cut.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted against the draft budget for the financial year 2015 because there are considerable resources in items that should be reduced and reallocated in key areas that respond concretely to the real needs of the Member States most in difficulty.  The M5S has proposed numerous cuts in the Committee on Budgets as part of all the administrative waste present in the various European institutions and has at the same time tried to reallocate part of these cuts into items to support the real needs of citizens, such as appropriations for employment, the fight against fraud and corruption, SMEs, policies for managing and controlling migratory flows and instruments for facilitating access to credit.  It is necessary to assess the performance of each European programme in order to understand whether the appropriations envisaged are really capable of contributing to the well-being of citizens. European funds must, in the first place, be efficient and able to create added value for taxpayers.  I therefore voted against this proposal because, for the umpteenth time, the EU would have seen its money spent on unnecessary items, such as funding for political foundations, communication and pre-accession processes, without focusing spending on key priorities at a time of such difficult economic crisis.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - I voted against the EU budget for 2015 because once again it is the budget of austericide and poverty. These are budgets made with their backs to the reality of social emergency that popular classes are experiencing in all EU countries. This budget remains in the neoliberal logic of memerándums, cuts, public privatisations and remains not budgets for job creation and living conditions for EU citizens.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - Our position on the budget and in the face of this proposal reflects our position on this EU, with its neoliberal, federalist and militarist matrix. The EU budget is the concrete expression of a policy line aimed at promoting the dismantling of public services, the loss of social and labour rights and public-private partnerships. This is the budget that supports austerity, the European Semester and all the agencies that monitor and condition member states' policies and punish bad pupils. It is the budget that supports increasingly aggressive interference in various parts of the globe. That builds a Europe Fortress less and less in solidarity with its neighbors. This farce or this pseudo-dispute between the Commission and the Council cannot deviate from the essentials, which is the condemnation of the neoliberal policies of this EU supported by this budget.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. - The European Parliament allocates around 40% of its budget to agricultural development and the common agricultural policy. The agricultural appropriations for the current year amounted to approximately EUR 58 billion. It does not matter where the appropriations from the EU budget are directed. Agricultural subsidies must respect sustainable principles - the aim is to guarantee a functioning internal market for agricultural products, to reduce harmful and market-distorting aid and to guarantee producers an adequate income and clean food for consumers. Support policy must also be ethically sustainable. I do not agree with the use of the common agricultural budget for the growing of tobacco products. It is also completely unjustified that the suckler cow allowance received by producers growing bullfights is also completely unjustified. It is also a question of the legitimacy of the common budget among the citizens of the Member States. For example, money common to support tobacco products or bullfighting should not be used.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - Amendment 232 to the draft EU general budget states that financial support for bull farming used for fighting should not be covered by the European Union budget. Corrida, in the course of which these bulls are used, is a Spanish tradition, so the EU should not interfere in this, much less finance, humanitarianly questionable ventures. In accordance with the European Convention for the Protection of Farmed Animals, animals should not suffer and be exposed to injury and fear. During the vote, I voted in favour of the amendment, namely against the European Union's support for the breeding of bulls used for fighting.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. - First of all, it is logical that Member States are coming up with proposals for significant cuts in the draft budget for 2015 in an effort to save budgets and reduce deficits. On closer inspection, however, we can see that many of these proposals mainly concern key areas such as innovation, research, infrastructure, support for small and medium-sized enterprises and energy. In particular, energy security is not achievable without increasing investment in energy infrastructure, energy efficiency, interconnections and renewable energy production. The 2015 budget already lacks the funds approved by the Council when discussing the multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020. I therefore support Parliament's position, which calls for a return to the Commission's proposal in order to avoid delays in payments to research, universities and the development of the business sector.  At the same time, I consider it populism if the Heads of State or Government at each summit talk about the importance of growth and job creation, while at the same time the same politicians are proposing cuts to the EU budget precisely in these areas.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted against the budget proposal for 2015 because I believe that not enough effort has been made to cut unnecessary and inappropriate expenditure and instead support virtuous initiatives. In particular, I regret the failure to reach a quorum for the amendment which sought to exclude fighting bull farms from funding provided within the CAP. It is shameful that such brutal practices involving the killing of animals for entertainment should be supported through public money, which could instead be used for nobler purposes. Civil society has mobilised in this regard, collecting 10 000 signatures in Italy alone in support of this amendment: an important testimony to the widespread awareness of the need to protect animals as sentient beings. We parliamentarians have a duty to represent these demands and to be the spokesman for this sensitivity. Like many of my colleagues, I felt this sensitivity, first by signing this amendment and then by voting in favour. Our efforts this time have not been enough, but I hope that more and more Members will be able to join this battle for civilisation in the future.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. - On the occasion of the accession of the Republic of Croatia as the 28th Member State to the EU, it is also necessary to ratify the Additional Protocol to the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Korea, on the other, in order to ensure that the Republic of Croatia continues to participate fully in the eu-Korea Free Trade Agreement, which remains in force. Although this Additional Agreement has been in force since 1 July 2013, the approval of the EU Parliament is a binding component in the completion of the process of ratifying this Additional Protocol. This report has been complied with by the European Parliament.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. - I have abstained on this motion, because although I disagree with the principle of the EU rather than nation states conducting free trade agreements, this is merely a technical change to an existing agreement.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. - The EU-South Korea Free Trade Agreement adopted in 2011 aims to integrate the European and Korean economies, and to remove trade barriers between the two partners. EU exports to Korea amounted to EUR 37.8 billion in 2012 and Korea's exports to the EU amounted to EUR 37.9 billion in 2012. The EU's exports that have grown the most thanks to the FTA are North Sea oil, machinery, motor vehicles and spare parts.  I think it was therefore important that Croatia could also be part of this agreement.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. On 1 July 2013, Croatia became the 28th member state of the European Union and an additional Memorandum of Understanding to the 2009 EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement was signed.  This decision, which we are asked to approve, must ensure that Croatia continues to participate fully in this free trade agreement. Parliamentary approval for this type of decision is mandatory.  I have spoken out against this protocol because I believe that the European Union must stop this gradual liberalisation of trade and the total elimination of existing tariffs and barriers, and even if this is a technical change, I do not wish to endorse the past free trade agreement.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - (IT) I did not support with my vote the Zahradil report on the additional trade protocol between the EU and the Republic of Korea. The measure is poorly balanced and does not take account of the disparities between these economic realities. While companies in the Asian country are moving in an extremely dynamic and competitive market, European companies are still going through a very strong crisis, and I believe that this agreement would risk further damaging them.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. - I've abstained. The Left Party and the GUE/NGL opposed the original agreement between the EU and the Republic of Korea, partly on the basis of environmental and consumer interests.  The fundamental opposition remains. However, since this vote is about a change of impact, with Croatia as the new Member State of the European Union, I choose to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this Recommendation so that the Republic of Croatia can participate fully as a member of the European Union in the EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement, signed in 2009.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it supported the amendments to the Free Trade Agreement between the EU and Korea necessary to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union. In particular, this part of the agreement, which was also approved today by the European Parliament, concerns the labelling of the origin of goods. The provisions of the Agreement will apply to goods exported from Korea to Croatia or from Croatia to Korea which comply with the provisions of the Protocol on The Rules of Origin of the Agreement and which were en route or were temporarily stored in a Korean or Croatian customs warehouse or free zone on 1 July 2013.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - I voted against. The measure is harmful, South Korea is a country with much more dynamic industries in a very competitive industrial sector. We should protect ourselves with ad hoc duties rather than opening up the EU's marked treaty to them.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. - The European Union and South Korea are two very important trading partners. It has already been three years since the EU and the Republic of Korea put in place a free trade agreement. This agreement works very well and both sides benefit from it. With Croatia's accession to the EU in 2013, all international agreements, trade or other, must be extended to this new Member State. I voted in favour of this report, which stresses the importance of adapting the European legislative framework to the structural changes taking place within the Union.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - On 6 March 2014, the Council of the EU concluded, on behalf of the European Union (EU) and its Member States, the Additional Protocol to the Free Trade Agreement signed on 15 October 2009 with the Republic of Korea. On 17 February 2011, the European Parliament adopted a legislative resolution approving this agreement by 465 votes in favour, 128 against and 19 abstentions.  On 1 July 2013, the Republic of Croatia joined the EU and became the 28th Member State. The Additional Protocol to the EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement, which takes account of Croatia's accession, was signed and also entered into force on 1 July 2013. The current Council decision therefore aims to ensure that Croatia continues to participate fully in the EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement that remains in force.  I voted in favour of the protocol, bearing in mind that the European Parliament's approval of this Council decision is a mandatory element for the completion of the ratification process and helps to protect the integrity of the Union's internal market.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - The Additional Protocol to the Free Trade Agreement between the EU and Korea aims to consider the accession of the Republic of Croatia on 1 July 2013 to the European Union. As a result, Mr Syod's recommendation is that the Commission should be able to take account of parliament's Jan Zahradil only legally frames this situation. The European Parliament's approval of this Council decision is a mandatory element in the completion of the ratification process.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the Protocol to the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Korea, on the other, the aim of which is to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union. In fact, following croatia's accession to the European Union, a review of all existing trade agreements has become mandatory, so that they can be extended, with their benefits and obligations, to Croatia. This is usually done through an accession protocol, as in this particular case with South Korea.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote in favour of the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of an additional protocol to the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Korea, of the other part, which began on 15 October 2009, to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU. I believe it is necessary for Croatia to be guaranteed the opportunity to participate in the EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement currently in force. I also maintain that we must vote in favour in order to protect the integrity of the European Union's internal market, as well as to complete the process of ratifying the agreement with the South Korean State.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – This vote reflects the accession of Croatia to the EU, which as a Member State is to enjoy participation in the Free Trade Agreement already in force between the EU and its Member States of the one part and the Republic of Korea of the other. For this reason I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of concluding an additional protocol to the FREE TRADE Agreement between the EU and Korea. I will soon be supporting the completion of the ratification process and thus contributing to protecting the integrity of the Union's internal market, also considering the fact that on 1 July 2013 the Republic of Croatia joined the EU and became the 28th Member State. By voting in favour, I intend to ensure that this Member State continues to participate fully in the EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - This is not the first time I have positioned against free trade agreements as trade deregulation is yet another way for strong economies to enter new markets at the expense of the progressive dismantling of weaker production systems, the growth of inequalities and asymmetry between countries and by putting workers from different geographical areas into competition. Although this report is purely technical, being a component of the process of ratification of Croatia's additional protocol of accession to the EU, I did not vote in favour of it because of the above.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – The European Union and the Republic of Korea adopted a mutual understanding on Trade, known as the EU-Korea FTA, in 2011, with an majority of elected representatives from Member States voting in favour of the agreement. Trade agreements such as the EU-Korea FTA ensure guarantees and safeguards so that both parties reap the benefits. In order to safeguard trade agreements like these, the EU must ensure that new Member States who join the EU fully participate in these forms of agreements. For this reason, I voted in favour of the reinstatement of this agreement taking into consideration Croatia’s accession to the EU last year.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. By voting on this text, the European Union wishes to give Croatia, the last state that joined it, full benefit from the advantages it is able to provide, in particular, from its commercial power. In this regard, I am in favour of this text which will not only legally secure the extension of the EU-Republic of Korea free trade agreement to Croatia, but also preserve the integrity of the Union's internal market.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. - On 1 July 2013, the Republic of Croatia joined the EU and became its 28th Member State. On the same day, an additional protocol to the EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement, taking into account Croatia's accession, entered into force on a provisional basis.  On 6 March 2014, the Council of the European Union decided to conclude, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, the Additional Protocol to the Free Trade Agreement previously signed on 15 October 2009 between the EU and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Korea, of the other part. I voted in favour of this provision because, with this decision, the aim is to ensure, in accordance with croatia's act of accession to the EU, that croatia continues to participate fully in the EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. - We voted to abstain because, despite being against the FTA, we believe that it is consistent for Croatia as an EU Member State to arm itself with the other EU States. We do not support the EU-Korea free trade agreement approved in July 2011. The agreement has significant negative consequences for the European economy and employment, especially with regard to the automotive industry and Europe's industrialisation potentials. Moreover, the treaty does not consider the environmental impact of the exchange of goods from across the planet. Korean peasant and trade union organizations also expressed a strong rejection of the treaty. However, the Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament of 22 October 2014 on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Korea, on the other hand, , in order to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union, simply addresses Croatia's accession, as the new Member State of the Union, to that agreement.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The signing of the Additional Protocol to the Free Trade Agreement signed by all Member States and the Republic of Korea has established a set of important principles for the sustained economic development of the European Union, further opening a channel for the distribution of its products. Since the Republic of Croatia has been a full Member State since July 2013 and is already covered, albeit provisionally, by this Protocol, it makes sense to continue to participate fully in this Free Trade Agreement, which is still in force.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - Our position on free trade is well known. Recalling Lacordaire: Between the rich and the poor, between the strong and the weak, it is the law that frees and the freedom that oppresses. Trade deregulation is a way for stronger economies to snare new markets at the expense of the progressive dismantling of the most deformed production systems. Asymmetries between countries grow. And in all of them a race is forced to the bottom in the plan of workers' rights and wages. By putting the workforce of different geographical backgrounds in competition, its overall devaluation is forced. Since the adoption by the European Parliament is a mandatory component of the completion of the ratification process of the Additional Protocol for Croatia's accession to the EU, this report is essentially technical, since we are not deciding either on the creation of a free trade area or croatia's accession, but rather to adapt existing legislation taking into account the consequences of such accession. As far as the adoption is concerned, our position is well known: not ignoring the profound meaning of enlargement in a process of capitalist integration, such as the European Union, we believe that the decision to join or should not be taken respecting the sovereign will of each people. Hence our abstention.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - On 6 March 2014, the European Union and its Member States concluded an Additional Protocol to the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union, of the one part, and the Republic of Korea, of the other part. The Republic of Croatia acceded to the European Union on 1 July 2013 and became its 28th Member State. As a result of Croatia's accession to the European Union, it was necessary to take account of this accession in an already existing agreement. The Council Decision therefore aims to ensure, in accordance with the Act of Accession of Croatia to the European Union, that Croatia participates fully in the agreement in question.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting against the EU-South Korea Free Trade Agreement. The text does not convince in many respects, not least the fact that companies in the Asian country are much more dynamic and develop in a much more competitive context than ours.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - Croatia's full inclusion in this agreement will also mean the problematic disposal of its products in the EU, resulting in its economic dependence and economic disaster. That is why I am voting against the Protocol to the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Korea, on the other, in order to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. - I voted for the additional Protocol to the EU-Republic of Korea Free Trade Agreement, as it clearly concerns a technicality necessary to take Croatiaʼs accession to the EU into account.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - We voted to abstain because, despite being against the FTA, we believe that it is consistent for Croatia as an EU Member State to arm itself with the other EU States. We do not support the EU-Korea free trade agreement approved in July 2011. The agreement has significant negative consequences for the European economy and employment, especially with regard to the automotive industry and Europe's industrialisation potentials. Moreover, the treaty does not consider the environmental impact of the exchange of goods from across the planet. Korean peasant and trade union organizations also expressed a strong rejection of the treaty. However, the Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament of 22 October 2014 on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Korea, on the other hand, , in order to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union, simply addresses Croatia's accession, as the new Member State of the Union, to that agreement.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We voted to abstain because, despite being against the FTA, we believe that it is consistent for Croatia as an EU Member State to arm itself with the other EU States. We do not support the EU-Korea free trade agreement approved in July 2011. The agreement has significant negative consequences for the European economy and employment, especially with regard to the automotive industry and Europe's industrialisation potentials. Moreover, the treaty does not consider the environmental impact of the exchange of goods from across the planet. Korean peasant and trade union organizations also expressed a strong rejection of the treaty. However, the Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament of 22 October 2014 on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Korea, on the other hand, , in order to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union, simply addresses Croatia's accession, as the new Member State of the Union, to that agreement.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - I voted yes, because this draft Additional Protocol with the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union (and its members) and the Republic of Korea takes into account Croatia's accession to the European Union, and allows it to participate fully in the implementation of the said Agreement. At a time of economic globalisation and the opening up of global markets, it is extremely important to ensure the sustainability and competitiveness of eu economies and trade in smaller EU countries such as Croatia.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Jan Zahradil's report on the Protocol to the EU-Republic of Korea Free Trade Agreement. The aim of this text is to take into account Croatia's accession to the European Union in this agreement with Korea. The report was adopted by a majority of 524 votes in person, 53 against and 106 abstentions, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the protocol to the EU-Republic of Korea free trade agreement to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union. Since 2010, the EU and South Korea have strengthened their ties by entering into a strategic partnership that guarantees a high level of mutual engagement. These relations are mainly based on two major agreements: the EU-South Korea framework agreement adopted in 2010 and the EU-South Korea free trade agreement adopted in 2011. This agreement is the most ambitious trade agreement ever negotiated by the European Union and the first signed with an Asian country. It provides for the removal of tariffs on almost 99% of the goods traded within five years, as well as the removal of many non-tariff barriers. It will stimulate bilateral trade, with the principle of reciprocity as a fundamental basis. It will also improve the penetration of European companies in the Korean market and, more broadly, throughout Asia.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. - I supported the report. The technical amendment will allow Croatia to fully participate and benefit from the Free Trade Agreement between the EU and the Republic of Korea.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr Beazley's recommendation. Jan Zahradil, who has allow Croatia, which became the 28th EU Member State on 1 July 2013, to enjoy the effects of the free trade agreement signed on 15 October 2009 between the EU and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Korea on the other. The Additional Protocol is a mandatory element for the completion of the ratification process and also helps to protect the integrity of the Eu ropean Union's internal market.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - Since Croatia's accession to the EU in July 2013, the EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement (dating back to 2009) has been implemented on an interim basis. In March 2014, the EU concluded the signing of the Additional Protocol to the EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement to take account of Croatia's accession and for Croatia to continue to participate fully in the EU-Korea Agreement. Parliament's adoption of this Council decision is a mandatory process for finalizing the process of ratification of the Additional Protocol. That is why I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - This is not the first time I have positioned against free trade agreements as trade deregulation is yet another way for strong economies to enter new markets at the expense of the progressive dismantling of weaker production systems, the growth of inequalities and asymmetry between countries and by putting workers from different geographical areas into competition. Although this report is purely technical, being a component of the process of ratification of Croatia's additional protocol of accession to the EU, I did not vote in favour of it because of the above.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - On 6 March 2014, the Council of the European Union decided on behalf of the European Union and its Member States to conclude an additional protocol to the Free Trade Agreement signed on 15 October 2009 between the Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Korea, on the other. The European Parliament has given its consent to the conclusion of this Treaty. On 1 July 2013. The Republic of Croatia joined the Union and became its 28th member. The Additional Protocol between the EU and the Republic of Korea was signed taking into account Croatia's entry into the EU and began to apply provisionally from 1 July 2013.  I supported this report because the current Council Decision seeks to ensure, in accordance with the Law on Croatia's Accession to the EU, that Croatia as a member will continue to participate fully in free trade between the EU and the Republic of Korea and by signing the Agreement will contribute to preserving the integrity of the Union's internal market.  The consent of the European Parliament is a mandatory component in the completion of the process of ratification of the Additional Protocol.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - It is imperative for the EU to develop relations with Asia. The issue with South Korea has long been resolved, this was a known technical vote, since Horvatija is now a full member of the EU. I voted in favour.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. – The free trade agreement with the Republic of Korea has produced a substantial increase in trade between South Korea and the EU. I welcome its extension to include Croatia.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution on customs duties on goods from Ukraine because I believe that this proposal is crucial for the peace process in Ukraine. I also believe it is crucial for the EU to extend trade partnership agreements because they are strongly needed to strengthen the EU's economic and social financial security, contributing positively to the development of a just and strong inclusive Europe

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. - (IT) It is the duty of this Parliament to act to ensure that each Member State of the European Union is guaranteed the instruments necessary to achieve its social and economic expectations, on the basis of full respect for the principle of fairness.  It is therefore essential that each of them enjoys the same prerogatives of access to a market of global inspiration, the proper functioning of which depends on the degree of efficiency of the agreements between the parties.  In this context, the conclusion of an additional protocol to the Free Trade Agreement between the EU Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Korea, on the other, which takes into account Croatia's accession to the Community, is an act of absolute responsibility, the guarantee that, at the last of the countries that have joined our European family, full participation in the economic agreement between the Union and the Asian country continues to be ensured. My decision to vote in favour of Mr Zahradil's report stems not only from previous considerations but also from a clear awareness: the reduction of trade barriers, as well as the creation of a more stable and transparent environment for trade and investment, are two essential prerequisites for achieving prosperity and growth within our countries.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. A free trade agreement was signed on 15 October 2009 between the European Union and its Member States on the one hand and the Republic of Korea on the other. On 17 February 2011, the European Parliament adopted a legislative resolution approving an additional memorandum of understanding. On 1 July 2013, the Republic of Croatia joined the European Union and became its 28th Member State. Parliament must now approve Croatia's participation in the EU-Korea free trade agreement to complete its ratification process. Being opposed to free trade treaties as well as Croatia's accession, I vote against this text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - Croatia's accession as a member of the EU, which took place on 1 July 2013, has as a consequence the need to approve a rectification of the Protocol to the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Korea. This is a pro-form to preserve the integrity of the Internal Market of the European Union.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. - I have voted in favour of this recommendation, as this Additional Protocol to the EU-Republic of Korea Free Trade Agreement will safeguard the integrity of the Union’s internal market. Moreover, this recommendation will also make sure that Croatia continues to fully participate in the EU-Republic of Korea Free Trade Agreement.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome the ratification by the European Parliament of the Council's decision adding an additional protocol to include Croatia in the free trade agreement signed on 15 October 2009 between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Korea on the other.  This free trade agreement aims at the gradual liberalisation of trade in goods and services and the elimination of tariffs and other barriers between these two economic zones. It is vital for European democracy that Parliament ratify this type of agreement which touches on the very original nature of the European Union, which is to trade with the outside world.

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. - The Additional Protocol to the EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement, which takes account of Croatia's accession, entered into force provisionally on 1 July 2013. Consequently, the current Council decision aims to ensure, in accordance with Croatia's Act of Accession to the EU, that croatia continues to participate fully in the EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement. The European Parliament's approval of this Council decision is a mandatory element for the completion of the ratification process and also helps to protect the integrity of the Union's internal market. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text. The European Union maintains trade relations with South Korea as part of a free trade agreement. The text voted today aims to include Croatia definitively in this agreement. Croatia was included in an additional protocol since negotiations on the agreement had begun before Croatia joined the European Union.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - An ever-increasing number of free trade agreements are primarily for the benefit of certain large multinationals. As the currently highly controversial example of TTIP shows, this is having an increasingly negative impact on citizens' perceptions that sufficient account is being taken of consumer protection and sustainable economic development. This does not primarily apply to the issue of Croatia's integration into the European internal market and the adaptation of appropriate framework treaties, but reflects my fundamental scepticism about extending the scope of the existing free trade agreements at this stage. That is why I voted against the motion.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. - I welcome the adaptation of the Protocol to the EU-Republic of Korea Free Trade Agreement to Croatia's accession to the Union. Although Korea is not one of the largest trading partners of the Republic of Croatia, trade exchange between these two countries has significant potential for growth through investments in ports and infrastructure, exports of Croatian products and through an increase in the number of tourists 58% more visited Croatia last year.  On this occasion, I would like to recall that this Agreement was adapted even 15 months after Croatia's accession and to point out that many other trade agreements concluded by the EU with third countries remained unadjusted, among which are agreements with some of Croatia's most important trading partners such as BiH. By joining the European Union, Croatia has taken over the contractual and trade relations that the European Union has with third countries and automatically abandoned previous trade agreements with third countries.  However, third countries have not automatically adapted their agreements to Croatia's accession to the EU, causing the Croatian economy to suffer significant damage. I hope that we will vote as soon as possible on the adjustment of the remaining trade agreements between the EU and third countries, so that Croatian businessmen can participate equally on the world market.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I would like to thank the European Commission, the Council and the European Parliament for all the efforts made to ensure that the Protocol to the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Korea, taking into account Croatia's accession to the European Union, enters into force as soon as possible. The provisional application of the Protocol allowed Croatian businessmen to be more competitive on the Market of the Republic of Korea and to use preferential customs rates.  As a recent example and confirmation of good cooperation, I can cite the Contract for the sale and distribution of Croatian beer on the Korean market that a Croatian brewery concluded on October 10th this year. I am convinced that this is just one of the steps that will help Croatia strengthen its economy and become recognised in markets outside Europe. I support the European Parliament's decision to make the application permanent.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - The vote on the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union and its Member States of an additional protocol to the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Korea, of the other part, shall be taken to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union after the date of the Agreement. The EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement, which also includes Croatia, was signed and provisionally entered into force on 1 July 2013. Giving final approval to the Council's decision is necessary to ensure that the ratification process is completed and that the European Union's internal market acts in its full integrity.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I am voting in favour of this additional protocol to take into account Croatia's accession to the free trade agreement between the Union and the Republic of Korea because the approval of the European Parliament is the prerequisite for the conclusion of such a protocol. The free trade agreement with Korea has generally been beneficial. It cannot therefore pre-exist such a blatant obstacle to this agreement.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this recommendation so that the Republic of Croatia can participate fully as a member of the European Union in the EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement, signed in 2009.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - The Council of the European Union concluded on 6 March 2014 the Additional Protocol to the Free Trade Agreement (FTA) signed on 15 October 2009 between the EU and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Korea, of the other part, which already contemplated Croatia's accession to the European Union, which took place on 1 July 2013. Since that date, the Additional Protocol to the EU-South Korea FTA has been applied provisionally. The Council's decision thus ensures that Croatia, following EU accession, can continue to participate fully in the EU-Korea FTA, which remains in force. To that extent, and because it is a mandatory component of the completion of the ratification process of the Additional Protocol, I voted in favour of this Recommendation, which contributes to the maintenance and preservation of the integrity of the European internal market.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. - When Croatia joined the European Union (1 July 2013), the additional protocol of the EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement was signed on the same day to take account of this accession and has been applied provisionally since that date.  The Council's current decision is intended to ensure that Croatia can continue to participate fully in the EU-Korea agreement.  I have therefore supported this report, which completes the process of ratifying the additional protocol.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. - Croatia's accession to the European Union obliges a review of all trade agreements by force to allow croatia to be extended, with benefits and obligations. This is generally done with an accession protocol, as in this specific case of South Korea. I voted in favour of supporting the process of accession of the Republic of Croatia to the EU and promoting trade with the Republic of Korea.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - This measure is due to the fact that Croatia was not yet part of the EU when the EU-South Korea Free Trade Agreement was approved. In line with my vote against the whole text during the last parliamentary term, I also confirm my opposition to this protocol. The EU-South Korea Free Trade Agreement, in fact, does not convince in many respects, not least the fact that companies in the Asian country are much more dynamic and develop in a much more competitive context than ours.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - I voted to abstain because, despite being against the FTA, I think it is consistent for Croatia as an EU Member State to arm itself with the other EU States. We do not support the EU-Korea free trade agreement approved in July 2011. The agreement has significant negative consequences for the European economy and employment, especially with regard to the automotive industry and Europe's industrialisation potentials. Moreover, the treaty does not consider the environmental impact of the exchange of goods from across the planet. Korean peasant and trade union organizations also expressed a strong rejection of the treaty. However, the Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament of 22 October 2014 on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Korea, on the other hand, , in order to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union, simply addresses Croatia's accession, as the new Member State of the Union, to that agreement.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - This is not the first time I have positioned against free trade agreements as trade deregulation is yet another way for strong economies to enter new markets at the cost of the progressive dismantling of weaker production systems, the growth of inequalities and asymmetry between countries and by putting workers in different geographical areas into competition and , subjecting the peasantry on both sides to unfair competition from industrial agriculture and agro-export businesses. The fact that we circulate a huge amount of goods, including food that we eat every day and which we could find in proximity, represent a very strong increase in greenhouse gas emissions, further exacerbating the climate crisis. Although this report is purely technical, being a component of the process of ratification of Croatia's additional protocol of accession to the EU, I did not vote in favour of it because of the above.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. - I welcome today’s vote on the ratification of the Additional Protocol to the EU-Korea FTA taking account of Croatia's accession to the EU.  This vote is a mandatory component in the completion of the ratification process of the Additional Protocol and contributes to safeguarding the integrity of the Union’s internal market.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. - As a Croatian MEMBER of the European Parliament, I support the conclusion of the Additional Protocol to the existing Free Trade Agreement. By concluding the Protocol, Croatia becomes a beneficiary of the benefits of the bilateral trade agreement that exists between South Korea and the EU, and its implementation should benefit market development and economic growth in both countries.  The agreement obliges EU member states and the Republic of Korea to eliminate 98.7% of customs obligations on the value of trade for industrial and agricultural products over the next 5 years. During 2012, Croatia made a profit of about $8 million through exports of radiotelephony transmitters, turbo-jet engines and debris from starch production to Korea, while in 2013 it made a profit of $12 million by exporting predominantly the same products, showing a 50% increase in exports.  On the other hand, the most imported from Korea are passenger cars and motor vehicles and electrical devices. I believe that this Protocol opens up many possibilities for Croatia given the size of the market there. I welcome this decision, as the FTA increases trade balance turnover between beneficiary countries, thereby stimulating the development of both economies. This way I would like to take the opportunity to invite countries that have a signed free trade agreement with the EU, and have not aligned it with Croatia's accession to the EU, to do so.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - After the 24th of September 2012. The Council approved the Opening of Negotiations with the Republic of Korea to conclude the Additional Protocol to the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States and the Republic of Korea, it is necessary to take into account Croatia's accession to the European Union (the "Protocol").  Parliament's consent is required to conclude the Protocol by the European Union. As a new member of the Union, Croatia is obliged to implement and comply with all laws and treaties required by EU membership, and will be happy to join the Free Trade Agreement between EU Member States and the Republic of Korea.  Free trade enables a greater flow of different goods and develops the market and opens up new business opportunities. I support this Protocol because the implementation of this agreement will certainly benefit Croatia as well as the European Union. All countries within the EU have the same status, and therefore the vote of this Protocol has a more formal nature and is also a symbolic act that demonstrates the equality of all Member States.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. - I am voting against this plan because if Croatia fully joins this agreement with Korea, the disposal of its products - in relation to the corresponding products produced in Korea - will be problematic and lead to economic difficulties.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. - On 1 July 2013, the Republic of Croatia joined the European Union and became its 28th Member State. On the same day, the additional protocol to the EU-Korea FTA was signed to take account of this accession and has been applied provisionally since that date.  The Council's current decision therefore aims to ensure, in accordance with Croatia's accession to the European Union, that Croatia will continue to participate fully in the EU-Korea FTA, which remains in force. The European Parliament's approval of this Council decision is mandatory to complete the ratification process of the additional protocol and helps to preserve the integrity of the Union's internal market.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. - I voted for the Protocol to the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Korea to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. The adoption of the protocol is necessary in order for that FTA to be permanently applied to the common market.  On the other hand, as an MP from the Republic of Croatia, I especially support this Protocol because its ratification permanently opens another market to Croatian entrepreneurs and investors. Initiatives have already been launched in this direction, such as the imminent opening of a temporary diplomatic office in South Korea, focused, inter alia, on economic diplomacy, and therefore I fully support this new step forward in strengthening economic relations between South Korea and my homeland.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. - Any agreement to facilitate business exchange is positive for European companies, and in a context of economic crisis still more, since exports are very important to maintain the growth of the European economy. Moreover, the internal market is one of the best treasures of the European Union. It has brought economic growth, prosperity and better life quality to the countries that are in it, so it is a great pleasure to welcome Croatia in it. That is why I have supported this protocol, because it contributes to safeguarding the integrity of the Union’s internal market and facilitates exports in Asia.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - This is not the first time I have positioned against free trade agreements as trade deregulation is yet another way for strong economies to enter new markets at the expense of the progressive dismantling of weaker production systems, the growth of inequalities and asymmetry between countries and by putting workers from different geographical areas into competition. Although this report is purely technical, being a component of the process of ratification of Croatia's additional protocol of accession to the EU, I did not vote in favour of it because of the above.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - Since the adoption by the European Parliament is a mandatory component of the completion of the ratification process of the Additional Protocol for Croatia's accession to the European Union, it is no less true that this moment should serve as a thorough reflection on what has been the enlargement of the EU over the last decades. Indeed, this enlargement has not contributed to the development of these countries. In fact, and despite the initial aid, they do not hide the weakening of the productive apparatus, with very serious social consequences. Even infrastructure subsidized with European funds is now at the service of the great industry in central Europe, thus proving that enlargement is mainly done on the basis of a strategy of widening markets and attracting cheap labour.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: In my opinion, the role of the European Parliament's resolutions is to draw attention to breaches of commitments, to seek to correct undesirable conditions, to appreciate, to encourage the successful achievement of objectives and commitments. The institutions of the European Union have clearly defined powers and instruments to achieve the objectives. It is therefore superfluous to take on an expressive but in reality of a low-key language. This is what is happening in the approved resolution on the European Semester. As an institution, we regret here that Europe is in danger of falling behind. We can express regret when someone dies, when a natural disaster is going to happen, when things happen that we cannot control, but not where proposals and concrete solutions are expected of us. In this way, I therefore call on Parliament, and therefore all your colleagues, to avoid such language in the future and to focus our attention on the proposal for real solutions that will move Europe forward.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: Mr President, I was glad to see that my amendment expressly pointing to the issue of Roma poverty, social marginalisation and discrimination in Europe, was accepted in the final report on the European Semester. This is proof of the fact that here in the European Parliament we are aware of and agree on the need to implement long-term targeted and integrated measures aimed at reducing the social and economic marginalisation of Roma communities.  I believe that these measures should also be included and followed through in the European Semester recommendations for all countries facing challenges in this field. Drawing the Roma into the regular labour market would provide them with social benefits. On the one hand it would alleviate the burden of social welfare systems and on the other hand would lead to increases in tax revenues. In the long term, however, I found that it is imperative that we increase school attendance by Roma children and that we take more targeted measures against early school leaving.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. - I voted against the De Backer report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination. Countries like Ireland which require progressive economic policy have instead been tied to an awful austerity agenda which has resulted in deprivation, poverty, unemployment. Entire rural communities have been left desolate, with no employment opportunities for the young, resulting in mass emigration. The only way to get the economies back up and running is to combine public investment with protection of wages of low and middle income earners. The austerity agenda is having an impact in the North, with proposed welfare cuts on top of the billions that have been deducted from the Block Grant. Families, the working poor, single parents and the disabled that actually suffered most throughout the recession are being subjected to further cuts to their benefits. Tories in London, Dublin and Brussels are all cheerleaders of this approach. The failure of austerity policies and cuts, North and South, are impacting on our most vulnerable in society, and those with the levers of power are ignoring the fact that what is needed is real investment that will reinvigorate our economies in Ireland and across Europe.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. - I welcome this own-initiative report by the European Parliament on the European Semester, as it not only highlights the most important areas that need to be reformed most, but also highlights the shortcomings that arise in its implementation. The European Semester is a cycle in which EU Member States coordinate their economic and fiscal policies. Central to this are the country-specific recommendations, which provide concrete and tailored guidance for its financial, economic and employment policies. The semester will serve to ensure sound public finances, promote economic growth and prevent excessive macroeconomic imbalances. Not only has there been a lack of consistency between European commitment and the implementation of the recommendations by the Member States, but the involvement of national and regional parliaments and the European Parliament is also low. While the recommendations of the EU Commission should leave the Member States political space for the design of the measures and specific reforms, they should also propose reforms that are credible. The joint action in the context of the semester should be seen as a partnership with a clear division of competences between the EU and the Member States. It is also necessary to ensure the early and widest possible involvement of parliaments.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. - As a UKIP MEP, this resolution goes against the fundamental principles of what I believe about economic policy, which could and should be the preserve of the Member States.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. - Some aspects of the proposal highlight the need for an ambitious initiative based on an investment plan to revive and support economic growth and, above all, job creation, and I can only welcome that. However, there are still unacceptable points in this report. First of all, the mystery remains as to the source of the 300 billion euros promised for the investment. Indeed, we still do not know whether this money will come from savings made on other policies or whether it is called "fresh money".  This text should have put more emphasis on the crucial importance of public investment. Especially when we see the reluctance of private investment. Because this public investment can allow, for example, the creation of industrial zoning, motorways but also the implementation of an energy development plan that we so lack. In other words, it is one of the key keys to economic recovery and future betting.  Social protection and workers' health also remain one of the key points of this report. Workers' rights are very little discussed, especially when they say they want to remove red tapes via REFIT.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on the European semester for economic policy coordination and priorities for 2014 perfectly captures all the 'European' thinking that currently dominates the European Union.  Even as people suffer an ever-ending economic crisis, this report proposes nothing less than to continue the policy of austerity whose evils can only be seen. It stresses the need for member states to comply with Brussels' budgetary requirements or risk legal proceedings and carries the euro, the single currency, on the altar of prosperity (even though the eurozone is worse off than the European Union itself!).  The report acknowledges an increase of 10 million people living in poverty between 2010 and 2012 but it gives us "its" solutions to revive growth: structural reform including health systems and lowering the retirement age, a "common, modern and inclusive immigration policy", stimulation of worker mobility and free movement, restoration of a "favourable environment" for businesses... In short, a descent into hell with ever more federalism and ultraliberalism, that is why I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - Considering that the European Semester is one of the instruments through which the Commission imposed the EU Commissioner on the budgets and economies of the Member States preventing the recovery of our economies, I did not support the De Backer report dealing with the implementation of the priorities of this instrument for 2014.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - Europe cannot continue on the path of austerity. Policies of austerity and internal devaluation have caused nothing more than an increase in unemployment, especially youth, to unsusable rates, labour poverty, precariousness and rising inequality. Europe needs to revive an investment cycle that encourages job creation and regains domestic demand to avoid falling into a third recession. It is urgent to implement the investment plan announced by the President of the Commission with additional funds and to urge countries with room for manoeuvre to implement expansion policies that pull the Union as a whole. And deficit control objectives must be subject to the maintenance and incentive of social cohesion, sacrificed during these years of austerity. We must also help Member States to make better use of European funds, preventing linkage between them and the principles of good governance from triggering harm to citizens of countries in difficulty. Together with Economic and Monetary Union, we must erect a social pillar that shields the European social model.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – Unemployment remains high in the European Union, especially among young people. I would therefore like to call on the Member States to implement the Youth Employment Initiative as soon as possible, which should now be one of the top priorities in all countries, in order to help young people get a job, especially their first job. In addition, the Youth Employment Initiative should be seen as an incentive for all Member States to use the European Social Fund (ESF) to finance wider projects involving young people, and in particular poverty and social inclusion.  The economic and financial crisis, as a result of the austerity measures taken in the Member States, has led to a significant increase in poverty in Europe and further increasing poverty, in particular child poverty. We also need to pay utmost attention to women's poverty, because women are currently the highest earners. Thus, the Commission and the Member States should ensure in their policy programmes, in line with the ep's recommendations, that all people are given the necessary and appropriate social protection, access to health and social services, greater inclusion of vulnerable groups in the labour market, the reduction of poverty at work and the promotion of gender equality. It is also necessary to promote health and safety at work, to strengthen the rights of workers on atypical contracts of employment and to ensure greater social protection for the self-employed.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. - High debt levels, high unemployment, especially among young people, and economic growth in the almost non-existent euro area, are some of the current challenges and also the priorities of the European Semester.  Labour recovery is hitting obstacles due to the lack of competitiveness of some sectors, which contributes to the fragmentation of the labour market at Community level.   Economic growth is closely linked to the existence of a functioning labour market, based on the exploitation of inclusive professional skills, which encourages mobility and guarantees equal treatment for all workers. The economic crisis has hit the SME sector hard, making it difficult to access finance. Consistent programmes are needed to increase competitiveness, to create new jobs, and in this respect, the European Semester can contribute effectively by coordinating budgetary policies. The particularly low level in the implementation of country-specific recommendations shows a lack of confidence in these recommendations and confirms the lack of coherence between Community commitment and the actual implementation of policies at Member State level. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the ownership by the governments of the Member States of Community commitments is an essential condition for economic growth, financial stability and employment.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - I voted against. The European Semester is a master through which the EU's commissionership on member states' budgets and economies is in fact exercised.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. - Fragmentation of the labour market is now one of the causes of unequal access to jobs, differentiated pay or unfavourable working conditions in the EU. All this translates into a high youth unemployment rate, insufficient standards for a decent life, and the increasing polarisation between low-skilled and highly skilled work. To put an end to this fragmentation, structural reforms are needed to focus on sustainable growth-friendly policies and ultimately create jobs and combat poverty. I believe that these reforms should aim in particular at increasing the capacity of labour markets to integrate young people into the workforce, or that are able to provide opportunities for vulnerable groups of the population. Another objective of structural reforms should be the medium and long-term sustainability and equity of social security, health care and pension systems.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. - The European semester is the European mechanism for economic governance. It provides an overview of the European Union's economic and financial policies and establishes a roadmap for identifying the weak points on which each country must make progress. In the wake of the serious consequences of the crisis, it was important to develop a mechanism to harmonize Member States' economic policies so that we would no longer find ourselves in a situation like the one we experienced in 2008. I voted in favour of this text, which puts into perspective the progress that each Member State must make in order to emerge definitively from this economic recession. Every state must be aware of its economic influence on the rest of Europe. We have chosen to integrate our markets to form the European single market. If one state fails, the others will also suffer the consequences.
