It is therefore essential to coordinate national fiscal policies and to implement the structural reforms necessary for the recovery of the European economy.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - (IT) Today I voted in favour of this report because I believe that greater coordination of economic policies between all the Member States is essential. The Member States must keep their commitments on economic reforms. In 2013, only 10% of recommendations per country were implemented in full, while little or no progress was made on 45% of these recommendations.  In my opinion, the Commission should submit quarterly reports to Parliament on the progress made in implementing the country-specific recommendations. But the Member States must also play their part, and in particular those which have not complied with these recommendations should explain the reasons for non-compliance with them. With regard to the content of the recommendations, it is essential that a common EU labour market and a common immigration policy be created. Simplifying tax systems and taking urgent measures to combat tax fraud and evasion are other important common objectives. Finally, I call on the Member States to invest in research and innovation, as agreed in the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - The coordination of economic policies must not be aimed solely at balancing numbers on a state budget. These numbers represent people, businesses and social realities who are seriously affected by a suicidal policy for which only statistical appearances and compliance with rules that are too strict and do not correspond to the real needs of the European population count. Investment must be made in the real economy, the speculative logic that dominates the purely financial economy bases its profit on algorithms, whereas it should be based on the expansion of jobs, on the growth of companies that make up the social fabric. This multiplicity of players should flourish with the Union's economic aid, unfortunately this is not the case and the crisis has been going on for far too long, if we continue along the path of rigour, only rubble will remain in Europe.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the Motion for a Resolution on the European Semester for the Coordination of Economic Policies on the implementation of the priorities for 2014.  In particular, I share the focus on the centrality of investment to create jobs, generate income for families and stimulate growth, thereby supporting economic recovery. The call for the new European Commission is to increase European investment by EUR 300 billion, as was also announced by Jean-Claude Juncker in his policy guidelines. Another important focus is the fight against youth unemployment, including through the exchange of useful information between Member States.  Finally, I share the concerns expressed about the risks to the growth and sustainability of SMEs and the demands made for the economic system's ability to lend to be restored and for access to programmes such as COSME and Horizon 2020 by SMEs to be facilitated.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The European Semester is now an essential tool in coordinating member states' economic and budgetary policies. Despite the encouraging signs of the last two years, in a context of global unemployment, in particular youth unemployment, persistent high levels of public debt, low nominal GDP growth, banking crisis and labour market fragmentation, this coordination is vital to support the EU's economic recovery in order to deliver more growth and jobs. I believe it is important and necessary to take an ambitious initiative to stimulate investment across the EU and relaunch the economy by strengthening European investment by EUR 300 billion as proposed by President Juncker. I believe that it is also a priority to focus efforts on strengthening competitiveness, supporting job creation, combating unemployment and monitoring reforms to improve the financing of the economy and labour markets, targets that the European Council had already outlined in March.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of Mr De Backer's resolution because the European Semester plays an essential role in the coordination of European policies, i.e. between the macroeconomic and budgetary policies of the Member States, which are necessary to achieve a correct and efficient Economic and Monetary Union (EMU). In debating priorities, we must bear in mind what is needed to improve the everyday lives of all European citizens. There are many challenges ahead, but we must identify specific objectives: first of all, to solve the problem of unemployment, especially among young people, which has reached an extremely alarming rate; promoting competitiveness and growth by increasing investment by launching the €300 billion plan announced by Juncker as soon as possible; make the most of the potential contained in the 2020 Strategy and improve better and stronger fiscal coordination to ensure a level playing field and avoid unfair competition and harmful distortions within the single market.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as it highlights the priorities where actions are needed and ties these priorities for action by the Council and Commission to the European Semester.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting against the report on the European Semester for the Coordination of Economic Policies. The European Semester represents a cycle of coordination of the EU's economic and fiscal policies. The aim of this coordination would be to ensure sound public finances, promote economic growth and prevent excessive macroeconomic imbalances. The M5S has tried to incorporate its priorities through a number of amendments, which have been rejected. The text produced by the ECON Committee has not been sustainable for us, especially as regards the strictly economic part. We are opposed to the economic and fiscal policies implemented so far, and this text does not distance itself from them at all.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - This report analyses the implementation of the European Semester in the last half and makes recommendations for the coming semester, which will begin once the European Commission publishes the Annual Growth Analysis in November. The report is littered with rhetoric of socially balanced and sustainable growth, calls for job creation and the fight against youth unemployment to make us believe that we are on the path to the new cycle. But the reality is that the European Semester confirms the austericidal policies that have destroyed millions of jobs and gives carte blanche to continue on the same path. That is why, obviously, I voted against it.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - (IT) The vote in favour was affected by the deletion of the second part of paragraph 23, which explicitly reiterated the linking of resources from the Structural Funds to compliance with the rules of economic governance. The political balance that emerged from the May elections may be the beginning of a turning point, giving a more authoritative voice to those who continue to call for a new investment policy and greater flexibility in the Stability Pact, in order to allow for greater growth aimed at creating quality jobs. However, it should be reaffirmed that the battle against a penalising instrument such as macroeconomic conditionality must not lose its vigour. This is an unfair mechanism, both because it penalises citizens - final beneficiaries of cohesion policies - and because it creates an imbalance between the depressed regions of the euro area countries (such as southern Italy) and those of the non-euro countries. This imbalance has led to a worrying slowdown in the macroeconomic values of the former in recent years. The Europe we want is the One that helps to close the gap of imbalances and contributes to cohesion that pushes up the macroeconomic values of all its regions. That is why we have reiterated our opposition to a constraint which, on the other hand, goes in the opposite direction.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. - The economic and financial crisis has made it clear to us that we are vulnerable. Economic inequality is rising between states. This is why we need to push for an integrated economic policy that will boost the economies of the Member States of the European Union. One such instrument is an extensive and integrated market with key sectors such as financial services, transport, energy and the digital market. The European Semester plays an essential role in coordinating member states' economic and budgetary policies. Maintaining jobs and creating new ones is essential for growth. Although unemployment rates have fallen and employment in Europe is improving, unemployment among young people is still critically high. Further steps are needed to eliminate discrimination against young workers. Furthermore, the European Union must ensure that its citizens are treated equally in all areas. I also supported the proposal because it draws the attention of the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights to assess the impact of the measures on fundamental rights. We must promote comprehensive, harmonious development that leads to the strengthening of economic, social and territorial cohesion. Particular attention should therefore be paid to rural areas, areas affected by industrial change and regions with natural or demographic handicaps. Many cross-border regions are also awaiting further development in order to rise up to EU level.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – With my plenary vote I supported the outcome of the ECON Committee. This report requires a new investment policy, together with more flexibility in the Stability and Growth Pact in order to allow greater focus on growth and quality employment creation in Europe.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. - The report on the European semester, the coordination cycle of economic and budgetary policies within the European Union, raises many very interesting questions in a constructive spirit. In particular, it regrets the lack of efforts by some eurozone countries to reform themselves. If France is not named, we know that it is targeted. I regret that, because of the inability of this government to carry out ambitious reforms, our country is once again lagging behind. Nevertheless, the report proposes balanced solutions: pursuing structural reforms while investing in research and development for better quality products. There are proposals that go in the right direction, hence my favourable position on this report.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. - The current European economic context needs greater coordination in macroeconomic and budgetary policies. Measures need to be pushed forward to achieve genuine economic and monetary union, and to combat unemployment, especially youth and long-term unemployment. The internal market must also be strengthened, in particular the free movement of services; getting it real and fully operational would be a stimulus for the economy. While signs of recovery have been shown, more stimuli are needed to achieve medium-term stabilization. In this regard, the important role played by the EU budget in encouragement of sustainable growth, the boost of job creation and the reduction of macroeconomic imbalances in the EU should be underlined. The EU Youth Guarantee and Youth Employment Initiative should be promoted as useful means of combating the high youth unemployment rate. Strong budgetary policy, a real free movement of services that protects consumers and benefits SMEs, and the implementation of anti-unemployment programmes are key stimulus to move towards stronger economic and monetary policy.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - In this global world, the EU must be competitive, uphold its values and social status, ensuring the necessary conditions for all resources to be able to promote sustainable growth, job creation and territorial cohesion. The economic environment in Europe is also characterised by inert GDP (increased by 0.2 % in the EU28 in the second quarter of 2014), notoriously low inflation (down 0.3 % in August 2014) and still excessively high unemployment rate (11.5 % in the euro area and 10.2 % in the EU28 in July 2014). The economic recovery in the EU has shown encouraging signs in the last two years, but still at a fragile and unequal level, and an ambitious initiative is urgently needed to stimulate investment across the EU in order to relaunch and support economic boosting. These are the cases of the expected completion of the Banking Union and urgent reforms for all Member States, where difficulties in setting up businesses are an obstacle, as well as moving forward with a European investment programme of EUR 300 billion, as proposed by Jean-Claude Juncker, in order to contribute to the short-term recovery of European growth.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. - It is not time to mourn the time lost under the ideological paradigm of austerity at the outslest, but it is time to face the future in a different way. Our group's amendments to this report allow progress in another speech for Europe. The new European Commission must be involved in the Europeanisation of economic policy in the euro area, and for Europe to have greater capacity to implement country-specific recommendations and address tensions between France, Italy and Germany. So worrying is that a country does not comply with the rules we have given ourselves as having a current account surplus of more than 7% or 8% of GDP and the European Commission does nothing. We need countries with room for manoeuvre to make expansive policies. We also welcome the elimination of the requirement of macro-conditionality for the Structural and Cohesion Funds which doubled many regions in Europe. This European Semester should be the step from the vision of the 'euro pattern' we have suffered in recent years to a genuine economic union and we believe that the new Commission must lead it with a clear commitment.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - This report comments on the implementation of the European Semester last semester and makes recommendations for the next one, which will begin with the publication of the Annual Growth Survey by the Commission at the end of November.  The report involves the scarcity of socially balanced and sustainable growth, the call to create jobs and combat youth unemployment, in short, everything that is intended to make us believe that we are starting a new cycle. Let us be excited about the promise of increasing investment by €300 billion – the solution to all evils! The truth is that the European Semester is confirmed as an attack on the interests and aspirations of workers and peoples, an undemocratic process, attentive to the rights of sovereignty. More recessive policies that destroy thousands of jobs every day is the significance of this process. On paper are the pios votes: development of SMEs, with the aim of promoting sustainable, smart and inclusive economic growth and quality employment; combating youth unemployment; and so on... This report advocates not only the maintenance of this unacceptable process, but the deepening of its fundamental characteristics. Obviously we voted against it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - This report represents an entry into the second phase of implementation and implementation of the priorities for the European Semester for economic policy coordination in 2014. The original report was totally unacceptable. Although many positive changes have been made and included, the report continues to refer to the macroeconomic conditionality introduced under the European Structural Funds. Significant achievements include the call for the rapid implementation of a new investment plan of EUR 300 billion, allowing Member States some degree of flexibility with regard to the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact, and the need to increase public investment.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. - (IT) I express my strongest opposition to the text. The EU Commissioner for Budgets and Economies of the Member States also moves on from this type of policy.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - I am voting against the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies: the implementation of the priorities for 2014, because it requires member states to comply with even more measures, it requires centrally strengthened governance for finances and therefore weakens national governments and national independence, it requires the full integration of the European labour market - which will be disastrous for countries such as Greece - it provides disproportionately many privileges for the Roma community in relation to the rest; , overall, it is contrary to the interests of my country and its people.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. - I believe that, after years spent following a model of austerity that has proven unsuccessful, leaving us in an unacceptable economic and social situation (higher percentage of unemployment, extremely low inflation rate) we have successfully pushed for the change that Europe is waiting for. Parliamentʼs report calls for a strong social pillar to be the priority of the European Semester. Parliament calls for more investment in research and development and recalls that investments should come mainly from the public sector. It highlights the importance of socially sustainable structural reforms, enhances the fight against social exclusion, against gender inequality in the labour market and the difficulties SMEs experience in accessing finance. Moreover, it enacts the use of automatic stabilisers as a way of fighting against macroeconomic unbalances and removes the concept of macroeconomic conditionality, a rule that would punish underdeveloped regions which, on the contrary, need more support from the EU financing system.  It is in my hope that with the support of Mr Junkerʼs EUR 300 billion investment plan, we can finally recover from this crisis and put an end to social suffering that threatens the cooperation and solidarity of the European Union.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing. - In my view, a way to improve the efficiency of the European Semester is to make sure that reasons and causes for unsatisfactory implementation of CSRs are properly analysed and eliminated. Another is to radically strengthen national ownership of the CSRs in individual Member States to mobilise sufficient political support in favour of reforms. I also believe that more involvement by national parliaments could help. I support this INI report because I share the Rapporteur’s position that the EP should support the European Commission in its efforts to fully use the framework of the European Semester to improve economic governance in Europe

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report as an important step in the face of the slowdowns in the EU economies, which, if they persist, can lead us to a new recession. We must deepen the process of European integration and support policies to improve competitiveness and create jobs, with an emphasis on young people.  The EU must invest in R&D&I, modern infrastructure, sustainable energy, education and social inclusion and facilitate SMEs' access to finance. Therefore, the investment committed by the President-elect of the Commission of EUR 300 billion is an appropriate measure aimed at the growth of the European economy. States should continue structural reforms with the aim of improving employment and economic growth. It is necessary to continue with a balanced long-term strategy for budgetary consolidation conducive to growth and investment, always seeking the sustainability and equity of social security systems. Concern about social obligations, the fight against increased poverty and social exclusion must be at the center of EU economic policy.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. - Despite my earlier misgivings, I did give my support to the De Backer report on the implementation of 2014 priorities for the European Semester. I am pleased that the rapporteur included a number of crucial elements that are important to my Group: urging the rapid implementation of Mr Junckerʼs EUR 300 billion investment plan, underscoring that it is imperative to raise public investment, and highlighting the importance of rooting out poverty, precarious employment and youth unemployment. Moreover, being convinced that it is in no way helpful for Member States that are suffering because of certain budgetary rules to lose structural support, a crucial element in winning my support for the report was the scrapping of an unnecessary reference to the macroeconomic conditionality introduced in the EU Structural Funds. I staunchly believe that Member States should be allowed a certain degree of flexibility in dealing with the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact. We will not come out of the crisis, create growth and create jobs for millions of unemployed young people by implementing a pure austerity agenda.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution.  This text reminds Member States of the need to implement the necessary structural reforms: they require courage but they are indispensable! I believe that stimulating growth requires the modernization of our social security systems and health care without hindering patients' access to medical innovation and, on the other hand, our pension systems taking into account the ageing of the population. We must avoid imposing too much burden on future generations. There's an emergency!  The European Commission will have to submit quarterly reports to Parliament on progress in monitoring country-specific recommendations; and the President of the Eurogroup will have to include a follow-up report in his assessment of national budget plans for 2015. It is time for some Member States to finally get to work!

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. - The reorientation of European economic and budgetary policies was to be reflected in the recommendations made in the context of the European semester. The final text of this report, which I support, incorporates important proposals from the Socialists and Democrats to reorient the Union's economic and budgetary policies. The draft automatic sanctions are finally excluded and the flexibilities of the growth and stability pact are put forward. In addition, we have secured that the report emphasises the EUR 300 billion investment plan needed to boost public and private investment in Europe, the fight against unemployment and in particular youth unemployment and finally the need to create a common unemployment insurance scheme at the euro area level.  While I regret the non-integration of energy transition issues, which are important in order to return to sustainable growth, this text is a basis on which the European Parliament can build on to support the reorientation of economic and budgetary policies.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of implementation of the 2014 priorities of the European Semester because this is a helpful tool for the EU to provide input into national economic decision-making. I especially see as a good sign the reduction of the tax wedge on labour and improving business and innovation environment. As many of these recommendations are never implemented by Member States, I strongly support the explanation of reasons for non-compliance. Finally, we have to be clear that injection of EU funding will not help Member States to exit the crisis – recovery can only be reached if we move towards future-orientated policies.

name: Eduard-Raul HELLVIG
text: in writing. - I support the draft resolution calling on the new European Commission to launch, as a matter of urgency, a European investment programme for the recovery of economic growth in the EU in the short term. It is a key support of Parliament for President Juncker's proposal to allocate EUR 300 billion to stimulate an economic recovery, which is still fragile in many Member States. The European Commission must prioritise public investment in infrastructure, research-innovation and human capital, as it committed during the hearing procedure in the European Parliamentary Forum.  I would like to draw attention, in this regard, to the need for measures to facilitate access to finance for small and medium-sized enterprises as a fundamental element of the European economy. The full implementation of the Programme for the Competitiveness of Enterprises and Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (COSME 2014-2020) must be accompanied by measures to reduce costs and simplify procedures affecting the ability of SMEs to access funds.  It is also necessary to overcome the current fragmentation of national rules on digital services so that the Single Digital Market becomes a significant driver of economic growth. In this respect, I advocate better coordination against the avoidance of tax burdens, in particular from multinational companies, in order to strengthen the conditions for fair competition.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - I voted for this proposal for a resolution because in this way I have contributed to the call for the European Commission to start a European investment programme of €300 billion as soon as possible, as the recovery from the financial crisis is still labile and uneven. That is why it is important to insist on a sustainable and smart functioning of the Economic and Monetary Union, and to strengthen the coordination of macroeconomic and budgetary policies, in addition to the policy for the euro area, led by the European Commission. I also supported reducing unemployment and strengthening the competitiveness of Member States facing an uneasy situation of European GDP. It is also worth stressing the need to make the Recommendations of the European Semester more binding and in line with the guidelines set out in the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: the implementation of the priorities for 2014, because I believe that Parliament should, for its part, call on the Member States to implement European recommendations more conscientiously. Only 10-15% of eu recommendations on national economic and budgetary policies under the so-called European Semester were implemented in full in 2013. I believe that the coordination of economic national policies stimulates economic growth and ensures the sustainability of public finances. In its report, Parliament criticised the effectiveness of the implementation of the recommendations under the European Semester and proposed its own solutions. In the report, m.in the Commission to clarify the reasons for the failure to comply with their obligations. Violations of EU fiscal rules by some Member States undermine the credibility of economic and monetary union and pose a threat to monetary union.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. - It is important that economic and fiscal policy recommendations are better implemented. We must remain vigilant in the light of the recent market crisis and not hesitate to carry out the necessary reforms.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of this report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination in 2014. It is important that the Commission seizes the opportunity offered by the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy and the revision of the integrated guidelines to strengthen the role of the single market for growth, innovation and employment. The EU's competitiveness needs to be consolidated in key areas such as the services sector, the energy sector, the transport sector and the digital single market. More determined efforts are needed to guide and coordinate national and EU-level policies, in order to complete and reap the benefits of the single market, while continuing on the path of ambitious structural reforms in the Member States. Financing the real economy, and in particular SMEs, must be a priority and targeted and strategic investments are essential, whether public or private. I therefore welcome the EUR 300 billion investment programme proposed by the President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, which is expected to be presented by the end of 2014.

name: Eva KAILI
text: Writing. - It is important that the Union realised that there must be harmonisation of Member States' budgetary policies, although belatedly, as the crisis has found Europe lacking important tools for managing economic risks and economic coordination. We welcome, of course, any effort that is being made.  However, the results of the implementation of the European Semester have so far been disappointing. We see this in practice, as in countries that are obliged to make adjustments unemployment is increasing, that of young people is increasing even faster, social inequalities are widening, and poverty is worsening. We stick to Commissioner Moscovici's statements and hope that from next year the text of the European Semester will be improved both in content and in terms of implementation. Furthermore, it should be pointed out that this "air of change" towards more rational economic governance excludes Greece and Cyprus, which are still committed to the anachronistic policy mix of the Memorandum, whose consequences in the social field are even worse than the consequences of the poor implementation of the European Semester, where it is applied. The Union must take important and brave decisions because if the European north can withstand the slow economic death, the European south can no longer afford the "enforced" rapid and painful economic extermination.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. - Following the European elections in May of this year, the political balance has changed in the EU. This will also change the nature of the economic and social debate. As this report shows, our Group will require a new investment policy together with more flexibility, including in the Stability and Growth Pact, in order to allow greater focus on the creation of growth and quality employment in Europe.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. - The legislative document, abbreviated as the European Semester, appeared for the first time within the ENVI Committee. As shadow rapporteur, I had fundamental reservations both about this Commission initiative as such and with the opinion in the ENVI. Since I deeply disagreed with the direction in which this document is moving, the amendments I tabled focused on reversing it.  In particular, to strengthen the equal access of EU citizens to healthcare during a period of Pan-European budget cuts, to strengthen social cohesion, social justice, addressing social exclusion and intergenerational solidarity, as these are areas that the proposed legislation woefully lacks. Furthermore, as part of my position, I have stressed the need to exploit the full potential of the so-called green economy and the need to create green jobs, given that I believe that the EU is wasing the potential offered by the emphasis on the green economy. Some of my amendments were part of the ENVI rapporteur's compromises, but in my opinion the substance of them was absolutely robbed and the text tabled already lacked the spirit of the original idea. For this reason, I could not participate in this compromise. The final form of the European Semester and the report on it were even worse from my point of view, so I decided not to support this document and to vote against it.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr Beazley's resolution. Philippe De Backer on the European Semester for economic policy coordination because I believe that EU countries need to do more to revive the European economy. At a time of crisis, such as the current one, austerity alone cannot be the key word. Compliance with the rules must certainly be guaranteed, but I believe that a certain degree of flexibility is needed in implementing the specific reform recommendations for those States that want to invest and revive their economies, provided that credible structural reforms have been undertaken.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Writing. – Today, we voted not only on the European Semester for economic policy coordination, but also in favour of the composition and political programme of the European Commission led by Jean-Claude Juncker. One aspect is the commitment to increase EU investment by EUR 300 billion. This is very good news from the new Commission, contributing to a faster recovery in the European economy. On the other hand, member states' economies are growing extremely disproportionately and unemployment remains high, especially among young people. The European Semester stands for the commitment of economic solidarity between Member States, and all members have a responsibility commensurate with the Member States' respective contributions to the eu's overall economic performance. I believe that greater coordination of economic policies requires favourable economic growth in the Member States, the exchange of good practices in the field of reducing youth unemployment, as some Member States have done better than others, and investment in innovation and research, especially long-term ones, need to be facilitated.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - The political balance in the European Union has changed after the European Parliament elections in May. This new balance must bring about a change in the nature of economic and social debate. As this report shows, the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament will promote a new investment policy with greater flexibility in the Stability and Growth Pact in order to increase the focus on creating quality jobs in Europe.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - Broadly speaking, rapporteur De Backer's motion for a resolution is overly focused on the need to maintain the economic policies of recent years which have led us to an unprecedented situation in Europe in terms of inequality, poverty, exclusion, unemployment - especially among young people - and which are on track to leave us on the brink of a third consecutive recession. However, socialist contributions have made it possible to highlight important aspects of our diagnosis in relation to the European Semester, especially on the essential change of course that the Community authorities must make in order to definitively boost economic growth and job creation and urgently recover the well-being of Europeans: Stimulating demand and investment in countries with the capacity as a precondition for continuing austerity; use flexibility in fiscal consolidation processes; boost automatic stabilizers; ensure the integration of social indicators and objectives into the European Semester Recommendations. Finally, despite our vote against the wording highlighting macroeconomic conditionality for access to structural and cohesion funds, weighing the positive aspects, we have decided to vote in favour of the whole of it.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - This report analyses the implementation of the European Semester in the last half and makes recommendations for the coming semester, which will begin once the European Commission publishes the Annual Growth Analysis in November. The report is fraught with rhetoric of socially balanced and sustainable growth, calls for job creation and the fight for youth unemployment to make us believe that we are on the path to the new cycle. But the reality is that the European Semester confirms the austericidal policies that have destroyed millions of jobs and gives carte blanche to continue on the same path. That is why, obviously, I voted against it.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - In the context of the vote on the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination, I highlight two points in the implementation of the priorities for 2014. Firstly, the role of innovation, research and education. Of particular importance are the recommendations to Member States to increase investment in research, development, innovation and education, which are essential to increase the competitiveness of member states' economies and the Union as a whole. In this context, I very much support President Juncker's investment plan to support the recovery of EU economic growth. I look forward to it being rapidly mobilised by the Commission and directed in particular to areas such as infrastructure, research and development, innovation and human capital. I hope that the Commission will also ensure that the implementation of the economic policy recommendations for individual Member States is properly monitored and coordinated and better linked to the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, including m.in. poverty reduction in the Union.  Secondly, I support the idea of a European legal framework introducing minimum standards for the use of the Youth Guarantee. The Youth Guarantee is a key European project to tackle youth unemployment. Monitoring the quality of its implementation is essential for the success of this initiative. Not only do young people have to be provided with jobs, but these jobs should be adequately remunerated and should allow young workers to gain work experience.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Writing. – The crisis has shown that the confidence of economic actors is of paramount importance for stability. That is why the consolidation and reform course that has been taken must be adhered to, as must the EU budgetary rules firmly agreed by the Member States. The massive additional expenditure in economically sound states, which is usually just a straw fire, does not solve financial problems in the long term. The recommended set of economic indicators for macroeconomic assessments is a useful tool for obtaining an accurate picture of the situation in the EU Member States. This also applies to employment and social indicators. However, automatisms must not be created here that free susperation efforts. I strongly oppose automatic stabilisers, such as EU unemployment insurance, in line with the position of the CDU/CSU MEPs. The EU must not become a transfer union! There is neither a European labour market nor an EU employment agency. Trade unions negotiate wages with employers at national, not European level. The own-initiative report sets out key levers for The Ambitious €300 billion Investment Plan of Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker. Priority must be given to unleashing the power of SMEs, improving access to finance and reducing red tape. Overall, the framework conditions need to be adapted so that the EU becomes a real location for SMEs, knowledge and industry.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: in writing. - With post-war poverty levels, especially on the European periphery; unemployment levels like never before, especially among young people; social inequalities that exceed those of the "belle epoque"; a colossal lack of domestic demand offset by exports that make Europe dependent on what is happening in the world; increasing economic and social divergence between member countries; a progressive abandonment of the fight against climate change; a public debt that has soared in countries subjected to suicidal austerity; une paired tax evasion and real fiscal dumping between countries to attract capital; a dwindling intra-European trade and credit and a high risk of deflation; with all this data in sight, real Europe is far from reflected in the De Baker report and, therefore, its proposals, including relatively critical ones, are but hot cloths for a symptomatology that requires strong and immediate treatment, which requires resolving the causes of the crisis, and not just its consequences, and which above all requires resolving its mis management.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. - I welcome this Report which underlines the fact that investment is important, as it works on the supply and demand side of the economy creating jobs, generating incomes for households, increasing tax revenue, helping governments consolidate and boosting growth; reiterates the need to adopt investor-friendly policies, cut red-tape and reduce administrative burden; calls on the next European Commission to enhance European investment by € 300 billion as announced in the political guidelines by Jean-Claude Juncker.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. - The european Commission and the Member States have a top priority to support the development and growth of SMEs, which, as a result of the crisis, face extremely high costs and considerable difficulties in accessing finance. It is the Commission's responsibility to promote the search for alternative sources of finance, in particular through the Structural Funds, the European Investment Bank, the European Investment Fund and public banks for the development of new jobs. We must eliminate unnecessary administrative burdens and red tape for the self-employed, micro-enterprises and SMEs and thus encourage the start-up of new businesses.  My approval of Mr De Backer's report stems from the awareness that in order to promote smart and sustainable economic growth and full employment of the Union in accordance with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, small SMEs, as the engine of our society, need our maximum support.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This text makes a fair observation on the catastrophic economic situation: even Germany is heading for recession. But it is not said that this is the direct consequence of the austerity policies that have broken the productive apparatus and popular consumption, in the name of debt repayment and the fight against inflation. It therefore proposes to strengthen the sanctions of the European semester. It is hard to believe that such a proposal is being made. This is unacceptable! Because that means the divestiture of national parliaments. And also because this semester is itself based on recessive liberal policies: liquidation of social security, pay-as-you-go retirement, public services, attacks on "the tax burden on labour", deregulation of the labour market, condemnation of protectionism. I am voting against this incondic text, a distressing symptom of the dogmatic blindness of the European Union's technostructure.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - After six years of economic crisis and negative growth rates, the economic recovery is slowly gaining ground and is expected to spread to all Member States by 2015. The Commission's forecasts for economic recovery are still weak and reforms must continue in order to meet citizens' employment and social needs, as well as to restore productivity and competitiveness. In many parts of the EU, social conditions are weak and unemployment has reached unprecedented values, so measures are needed to address this social and unemployment situation, which would improve the prospects in terms of competitiveness and growth. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. - This report supports the objective of focusing on policies that enhance competitiveness, support investment and job creation, fight unemployment and improve the functioning of the labour market, in particular in those sectors where there is a high growth potential. This report also calls on the Commission to put in place a comprehensive mechanism that promotes an effective exchange of best practices between all national actors responsible in the field of youth unemployment. I have therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. If we are to achieve the Commission's objectives and get out of the crisis, action must be taken that will lead to a thorough integration of economic and budgetary policies.  The crisis has shown Europe that it cannot continue to pursue an economic policy made up of individual trajectories. In the new post-crisis context in which Europe finds itself, we must revive growth, through the achievement of the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy on employment, research and development, sustainable energy, education and the fight against poverty. It is a question of stabilizing the economic world, as Jean-Claude Juncker has said.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: implementation of 2014 priorities, which calls for the rapid implementation of a new investment plan of 300 billion promised by Mr Juncker and focuses on policy priorities in fighting poverty, precarious employment and youth unemployment.

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. - The European Semester plays a key role in the coordination of economic and financial policies in the Member States. The M5S has tried to incorporate its priorities through amendments in the ECON Commission, some of which called for growth measures to be considered. Unfortunately, however, they were rejected. Since I am opposed to the economic and fiscal policies pursued by this Europe, I voted against it.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This resolution on the European semester for the coordination of economic policies is an opportunity for the Eurobeats to show us the usual common ground: the single currency would save national economies, structural reforms could help boost growth... However, since 2011, the European semester is supposed to harmonize the economic policies of the Member States, and the least that can be said is that the results are really not there: near-zero growth in the euro area before probably the start of recession, an explosion of unemployment, especially in France, Berlin which continues to impose its rules within the EU , 11 out of 28 countries in excessive deficit procedures, not to mention an EU budget that is close to the cessation of payment... So what do the EPP and the S -D offer us? Even more Europe, of course. Their reasoning is this: if nothing goes well it is precisely because there is not enough Euroferferralism. On the menu, the Member States will therefore have to ingest even more ultraliberalism and peoples will be fed to austerity cures! A nightmarish future for European nations and peoples... For all these reasons, I voted against this resolution.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. - (IT) With the adoption of this report, we intend to highlight the crucial role of the Community budget in stimulating sustainable growth, promoting job creation and reducing macroeconomic imbalances in the European Union. We believe that an ambitious initiative is absolutely necessary to stimulate investment across the EU in order to relaunch and support economic recovery; We therefore call on the Commission to urgently launch a Eur 300 billion European investment programme, as proposed by Jean-Claude Juncker, in order to help restore European growth in the short term. We therefore hope for the rapid adoption of innovative financial instruments, potentially capable of playing a key role in supporting both public and private investment in the Member States. We call for this new investment policy to be combined with a new flexibility of the Stability Pact so as to allow for greater growth, the restoration of the competitiveness of the Member States and a reduction in the very high levels of unemployment in Europe. Finally, we reiterate the importance of involving the European Parliament from an early stage and as much as possible, in order to avoid – given its growing importance and binding role – creating a gap in legitimacy in the process of creating political opinion.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. - I voted for the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the European Semester for the Coordination of Economic Policies: implementation of priorities for 2014. Recovery from the financial crisis, sovereign debt and competitiveness cannot only take place through a relaxed monetary policy. We stress the importance of continuing the process of thorough, balanced and socially sustainable structural reforms with the aim of achieving growth, creating jobs and combating poverty. The EU cannot once again increase competitiveness only by reducing spending, but must increase investment in research and development, industrial development, education and skills, as well as resource efficiency at both national and European level. We call on the Commission and the Member States to strengthen EU industry by implementing a more flexible competition policy to foster competitiveness and employment, and through an environmental and digital transition plan. We reiterate our call on the Commission to draw up, after consulting the social partners, a legislative proposal on informing and consulting workers on restructuring planning and management, in order to ensure an economically and socially responsible adaptation to changes in EU industry.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - The so-called European Semester should primarily harmonise the future economic development of the European Union. For me, this harmonisation is a further step towards the creation of a bureaucratic monster, which increasingly also bears the characteristics of a socialist planned economy. The European Union should confine itself to its core tasks, namely the creation of an optimally functioning internal market, rather than denying the Member States economic competences. For these reasons, I voted against the motion.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the European Semester for the Coordination of Economic Policies, on the implementation of the priorities for 2014. After six years of economic crisis and negative growth rates, the economic recovery still appears too fragile. The general increase in unemployment, in youth unemployment in particular, continues to pose a serious threat to economic and social stability and convergence in the Union. To deal with the crisis, some Member States have adopted austerity policies that have negatively affected economic growth and social aspects, increasing inequalities. Small/medium-sized enterprises and micro-enterprises face high costs and difficulties in accessing finance, which hampers their ability to grow and create jobs. Deep, balanced and socially sustainable structural reforms are needed to generate growth and jobs, as well as policies that promote competitiveness and support investment by improving the functioning of the labour market. Aware of the crucial role of the EU budget in stimulating sustainable growth, I believe that the EU needs to invest much more in research and development, education and resource efficiency.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. - (IT) In view of the importance played by the European Semester in the coordination of the economic and budgetary policies of the Member States and following a thorough analysis of the text presented, I voted in favour.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. - Having contributed to the drafting of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets on this report on the priorities of the European Semester 2014, I would particularly like to stress the importance that our budget can have in national economic policies. Indeed, I think it is important for the European Commission to take account in future of the impact of European funding on the macroeconomic dynamics of each Member State, given that these funds are nowadays almost the only public investment dedicated to development and employment. As has been said many times in this House, we cannot continue to demand austerity if, at the same time, we do not invest in creating new jobs, new opportunities, particularly for young people. I therefore very much hope that, for example, the 300 billion plan of the future President Junker, is not just a lark mirror, but on the contrary, that it represents new and fresh resources to create jobs and sustainable growth. At the same time, I hope that we will continue to support the EU budget, especially in the Council, as an investment in the future of our businesses, our students and our researchers. For Europe to once again be synonymous with opportunity and hope and not just with rigour and sanctions.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - The European Semester plays a key role in coordinateing economic and budgetary policies in the Member States. This year's Report on the European Semester of Economic Policy Coordination most encourages job creation for populations under the age of 24. It also supports the EU Youth Guarantee and the proposed Youth Employment Initiative, which are also key means in tackling the reduction of youth non-employment rates, which remains at a worrying level. It also supports highlighting policies that boost competitiveness, support investment and job creation, combat unemployment and improve the functioning of the labour market, especially in sectors with high growth potential.   The recommendations made for each Member State must not be interpreted as a criticism of the government's work but an effort to improve economic policy for the benefit of generations to come. The devastating fact, according to the Commission, is that only 10% of country-specific recommendations for 2013 have been fully implemented. It is therefore important to encourage the Commission to provide concrete recommendations to Member States and the EU as a whole, including in economic adjustment programmes, while also targeting structural reforms that will result in real, sustainable and socially balanced growth, employment and greater competitiveness. Therefore, I support a quality report by my colleague Philippe De Backer.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - (IT) My approval of the report on the European Semester for the Coordination of Economic Policies is due to the fact that Mr De Backer's report has particularly highlighted some fundamental points such as the aid that must be given to growth and employment, at a time of stagnation and an unemployment rate of 11.5% in the euro area and 10.2% throughout the European Union. It is also important, as the report points out, that attention is given to cohesion policy, which is an important part of investment to help growth (in some important areas such as innovation, research, training), to help SMEs access to finance (difficult access to FINANCE for SMEs is a major obstacle to EU growth), to build the ten-T network's priority links. Finally, in order to have an effective policy for reviving the EU economy, the Commission is asked to immediately launch a European investment programme of EUR 300 billion, as proposed by Commission President Jean-Claude-Juncker.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. - The coherence of the European Union's policies must more than ever find a common line at a time when Jean-Claude Juncker, future President of the European Commission, promises a 300 billion euro investment plan. This report setting out the priorities of the European semester thus attempts to highlight such coherence. In this sense, I am grateful to some of the guiding threads promoted by the European Parliament, such as the coherence of the European Union's investments in innovation, for access to financing for small and medium-sized enterprises. In view of international events, it is all the more urgent to establish a strong common energy policy and greater coordination of the Economic and Monetary Union. It will therefore be a matter of being vigilant towards the developments of the successive common policies of the Union and of guaranteeing the greater participation of the European Parliament in their developments.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. - The European Semester is the European Union's cycle of economic governance that allows Member States to coordinate their economic policies to boost growth and jobs and balance their budgets.  However, only 10% of the Commission's country-by-country reform recommendations for 2013 have been fully implemented, and little progress has been made for 45% of them. It is essential that the country-by-country recommendations be implemented to ensure economic coordination within the Economic and Monetary Union, and that is why I voted in favour of this report.  A genuine democratic accountability could also be put in place with the Commission submitting quarterly reports to Parliament on progress on the implementation of country-specific recommendations; Moreover, Member States that are falling behind in implementing the recommendations could come and explain their situation to the European Parliament.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote against it because the European Semester is one of the instruments through which the EU's commissionership on the budgets and economies of the Member States is exercised.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - This report analyses the implementation of the European Semester in the last half and makes recommendations for the coming semester, which will begin once the European Commission publishes the Annual Growth Analysis in November. The report is fraught with rhetoric of socially balanced and sustainable growth, calls for job creation and the fight for youth unemployment to make us believe that we are on the path to the new cycle. But the reality is that the European Semester confirms the austericidal policies that have destroyed millions of jobs and gives carte blanche to continue on the same path. That is why, obviously, I voted against it.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. - Looking forward to the next European Semester round, I think that the policy of growth-friendly fiscal consolidation should continue, but with more emphasis on growth-enhancing reforms, ‘especially by those Member States that have fiscal space to invest’. With today’s vote, the European Parliament calls on the Commission to set in motion, as a matter of urgency, the EUR 300 billion European investment programme proposed by Jean-Claude Juncker.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. - We are in a situation where member states apply only 10-15% of the Recommendations of the European Semester. This is in any case too little, given that the European Semester plays a key role in coordinating economic and budgetary policies in the Member States, but also given that enhanced coordination of Member States' macroeconomic and budgetary policies and a comprehensive policy for the euro area are necessary to achieve a stable Economic and Monetary Union. The economic and financial crisis has led to a pronounced fragility of public finances in some Member States. Also, if some of the members do not apply the semester provisions, the burden spills over to other Member States which is not correct, but we also get into a situation without clear guidelines and order. I therefore support the implementation of the 2014 priorities, as the focus is on policies that increase competitiveness, support job creation and the fight against unemployment, which is essential for achieving economic progress and the functioning of the labour market in the EU. I also support the call on Member States to ensure sufficient levels of investment in certain sectors and to start offering vocational training, which would develop a productive workforce.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the De Backer report and want us to get the balance right during the process to ensure social and environmental indicators are realised.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - With the economic recovery in the EU showing signs of slowing down for the first time in two years, it is very weak and unequal and must be maintained to lead to long-term growth and job creation, an ambitious initiative is needed to launch investments across the EU in the form of jean-Claude Juncker's €300 billion European Investment Programme. I believe that the most important objectives of economic policy are to reduce unemployment and restore the competitiveness of Member States, which themselves have undertaken structural reforms under macroeconomic adjustment programmes. It should also be noted that all this is necessary so that the EU does not fall further behind other regions when it comes to economic and investment opportunities. For all this, I support the report on the European Semester of Economic Policy Coordination: implementation of the 2014 Priorities

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. - I am voting against this report because it promotes the centrally controlled economic and social governance of the Member States by weakening the respective National Governments. It also disproportionately promotes many privileges to Roma than to other citizens.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. - I also voted in favour of this report, which has been the subject of long and difficult debates, because it makes a number of recommendations that would need to be heeded, either in the Annual Growth Survey or, for example, in various competition documents. This will be primarily the responsibility of the Commission, to whom we have sent very important signals. I gave my vote in favour of this report, together with the fact that we have clearly stated that, although the economic recovery in some places is gratifying, it does not mean that the recovery from the economic crisis has started at European level thanks to structural reforms implemented in a misguided manner. I believe that, with total disregard for social aspects, good and effective structural reform cannot be implemented. My vote in favour was also conditional on the report taking a strong position that both public and private investment is an important and necessary element if europe's engine is to be restarted. I must also underline that the report calls for further progress in preventing tax evasion and tax evasion, as well as on equal opportunities between men and women. More importantly, in this report, the European Parliament is not calling for an increase in the consumption tax, but for a much more balanced tax system, and the right to free movement of workers has been clearly highlighted, which must remain a principle of the European Union that cannot be intremed by anyone.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. - The Belgian Socialists voted against the European semester. On the one hand, the facets of administrative simplification as mentioned in the report could weaken workers' rights and the health of citizens. Let's be clear: administrative simplification, yes, but not in any way and surely not at the expense of the citizen! On the other hand, we cannot support a report that so ignores workers' rights. Finally, the text does not provide sufficient guarantees as to the major importance of public investment in the European economic recovery process.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mr De Backer's report on the economic and budgetary policy recommendations made in the context of the European semester. The withdrawal in the report of blackmail made to the states to condition the allocation of structural funds to compliance with the 3% rule was decisive in my vote. As has been the withdrawal of automatic eu economic sanctions from Member States that do not comply with this rule. We have also secured that some of our priorities, such as increasing public investment and using the flexibilities of the Stability and Growth Pact, have been adopted. I regret, however, that this report has not gone far enough. It does not include the withdrawal of the amount of the Member States' contribution to the EU budget, when this budget consists mainly of capital expenditure, nor the questioning of the austerity policy despite its blatant failure. Finally, I denounce the political positions of a right that has still not become aware of the importance of the energy transition and the potential for growth and job creation that it would represent in this context of crisis and mass unemployment.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. - I voted against the resolution on the European Semester of Economic Policy Coordination, because I believe that it contains, among other things, recommendations that go against the national interests of my country. Since the beginning of my work in the European Parliament, I have tried to draw the attention of my fellow MEPs to the disastrous consequences of EU employment policy, a policy that advocates greater mobility of workers to tackle unemployment in the common market.  Unfortunately, this time too, the Resolution on the European Semester points out that an increasing number of workers, especially young people, are leaving their country of origin and going to other Member States in search of employment, and calls on the Commission, as well as member states, to encourage labour mobility within the EU. I regret that some of my fellow MPs do not see anything alarming in such a brain drain, but it has very poor demographic consequences for my country, and therefore not only cannot support this resolution, but I would like to express my deep disappointment and my concern about such a policy.  I should note here that I support some of the recommendations of the resolution, in particular those that advocate strengthening the skills of young people in the field of entrepreneurship, for the removal of bureaucratic barriers and regulations that do not favor investment and for tax relief of work, but for the reasons already mentioned, I cannot support this resolution.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. - I have voted in favour of the European Semester report, as it is a new step forward towards efficiently coordinating the economic policies of the euro zone Member States. The origins of our current crisis are partly to be found in the great economic divergence of the first decade of the 21st century. The European Commission has the duty to continue pushing for structural reforms that will enhance growth in the medium term.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted against the report because I strongly believe that the European Semester should not be a purely political cycle of coordination, but a series of well-defined proposals, such as measures in favour of growth, labour and the real economy. It is essential to pursue active employment policies that help to reduce the social inequality exacerbated by the economic crisis. The M5S had its amendments proposing priorities and concrete measures rejected in the ECON Committee. Therefore, the text that has been voted on today does not reflect our position, which sees us as opposed to the economic and fiscal policies pursued so far: a policy based on rigour and austerity can never allow the implementation of measures in favour of the real economy and growth. For the reasons listed, I have therefore not supported the report.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - This report analyses the implementation of the European Semester in the last half and makes recommendations for the coming semester, which will begin once the European Commission publishes the Annual Growth Analysis in November. The report is littered with rhetoric of socially balanced and sustainable growth, calls for job creation and the fight against youth unemployment to make us believe that we are on the path to the new cycle. But the reality is that the European Semester confirms the austericidal policies that have destroyed millions of jobs and gives carte blanche to continue on the same path. That is why, obviously, I voted against it.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Written. - France and Italy must honour eurozone agreements! The European Union has agreed to improve the structure and functioning of the euro area. On Wednesday 22 October, we will discuss one of these agreements: the European Semester for the coordination of economic policy. At the same time, we see that some countries want to flout the agreed rules. The new budgets of France and Italy show that these countries are refusing to comply with the stability and growth pact agreements.  If France and Italy do not comply with the Stability and Growth Pact, we will be back to the situation of 2003. At that time, Germany and France ignored the rules of the SGP, laying the groundwork for the current euro crisis. It is therefore very important that the rules of the SGP are enforced. France and Italy must comply with the rules they themselves agreed to a few years ago.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. - Each year, the Commission provides each Member State with neutral advice regarding how to improve the state of their economies. This advice is often ignored. I supported today’s report because it encourages both investment from the Member States and the implementation of President Juncker’s promised EUR 300 billion investment programme. I and fellow Labour MEPs agreed to the report after it was agreed that this important funding would be given with no strings attached. The report gets jobs-based growth back on the agenda and will allow the reform that we need in order for Europeans to see real economic recovery in their everyday lives.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. - The European semester is the implementation of the EU's austere measures adopted after the 2008 financial crisis (6 packs, 2 packs).  Under the guise of European coordination of economic and budgetary policies, it aims to monitor, among other things, the implementation of so-called structural reforms, which must reduce budget deficits. We know what that means. This requires the "modernization" of public services, including social protection and health services, the flexibilization of work... These reforms are supposed to boost growth and jobs... The Commission did not wait until France's budget for 2015 was debated in the French Parliament to deem the 21 billion austerity plan insufficient and to ask the French government for more budgetary "savings" to be in line with the "structural effort" needed. Never mind the dramatic social consequences of these policies. They keep going! With the GUE/NGL we will continue to reject these austere policies and say that there are alternative policies. The European semester is the tutelage of national budgets with the sole objective, economic convergence leading to an ever-lower social levelling, the explosion of precariousness, poverty and inequality!

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - We are equally sympathetic to the Ukrainian people. That is why we have finalised the illegal coup d'état supported by the EU and the US. This aid that the EU wants to give to the people of Ukraine we also know in Portugal. In exchange for financial aid, the EU will impose the liberalisation of the economy. It will dismantle the productive apparatus of that country, which is unable to compete with the big European companies.  What the EU wants is not to help. It just wants to extend its market to new consumers and have access to raw materials from Ukraine. If the EU wants to help, demand respect for human rights from ukraine's current coup government. Stop supporting fascist militias that persecute trade unionists and other social activists. That condemn the attempt to illegalize the Communist Party of Ukraine and investigate all crimes committed, with particular emphasis on the crime of Odessa. This is the help the EU should give.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. - I voted against this resolution. The only advantage of this text is that the EP openly admits that the 'European Semester' serves the budgetary and macroeconomic surveillance of the Member States. The inclusion of a liability community is intended to make the measures provided for in the European Semester mandatory. The EP calls for the abolition of free competition: the Commission should manage macroeconomic imbalances between Member States and promote economic and budgetary surveillance. By implementing the roadmap "Towards a genuine Economic and Monetary Union" (5 December 2012), the EU is effectively abolishing the budgetary sovereignty of the Member States. In addition, a single external representation of the euro area will be established. This leads to a profound centralisation of economic policy. Subsequently, financial assistance and the Troika's ad hoc system will be integrated into an improved legal structure that would only be in line with the EU's economic governance framework and Community law. The EP is also in favour of the rapid completion of the Banking Union, the Insurance Union and the Union of Markets – it is hard to imagine a shift of competence stake in Brussels. Labour market policy and unemployment benefits will also be communitised. I reject that.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: in writing. -  The European Semester is the first phase of the EU’s annual cycle of economic policy guidance, and this report concerns the Parliament’s priorities for economic policy coordination between Member States in 2014. Labour MEPs voted for this report after our key amendments were accepted, which included more of a focus on delivering jobs and growth, and a recognition of the social impacts of austerity. I was pleased that an amendment I tabled, recognising that EU legislation on working conditions and discrimination is not red tape, but vital to protect workers and to enable disadvantaged groups into the Labour market, was accepted. My colleague Anneliese Dodds was also successful in removing references to private investment being more effective for growth than public investment.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: We see how most EU Member States are failing to deal with the financial crisis, the sovereign debt crisis or the competitiveness crisis. It is therefore necessary to pursue thorough, balanced and socially sustainable structural reforms. Without them, it is not possible to kick-start the economic growth on which employment depends. Investments in research and development, industrial development, education and skills and resource efficiency at both national and European level are particularly crucial from this point of view. However, I myself still have doubts as to whether and to what extent effective investments, which are not decided by private investors, can be motivated by an effort to make a profit, but by officials and politicians. I am therefore glad that, in this resolution, Parliament reiterated its support for structural reforms and reiterated the importance of reducing the level of public debt. Only in this way can it create the conditions for economic growth, on which jobs depend in the first place. These are the main prerequisites for success in the fight against poverty and social exclusion.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: That concludes the explanations of vote. (The sitting was suspended at 2.25 p.m. and resumed at 3 p.m.)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Kobane and the threat posed by ISIS (2014/2899(RSP)).

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is an honour for me to speak today on behalf of the High Representative Vice-President Catherine Ashton to address an issue of great concern, the situation in the besieged city of Ain al-Arab Kobane. During the debate in plenary last month on the situation in Iraq and Syria, we all recognised the complex terrorist threat that Isis poses not only to Iraq and Syria, but also to the whole region and to Europe. The intentions of the terrorists are clear, their aim is to occupy as wide a territory as possible, to achieve financial autonomy and to spread their law based on force. The despicable actions for which they are guilty go from the heinous murder of hostages and prisoners to abuse of children and women, persecution of members of religious and ethnic minorities and the vilification of sacred and cultural sites. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are here today to discuss the situation in Kobane, which has been under siege by terrorists for over a month. The fight is fierce and unequal, the terrorists have managed to transfer huge forces and a large amount of heavy and sophisticated equipment that they have taken over since the fall of Mosul. The speed of this transfer demonstrates ISIS' logistical expertise and kobane's strategic importance to the terrorist group. On the other side of the barricade there are a few hundred local fighters and volunteers, who can count only on modest weapons and with great courage continue to defend their city, street to street and house to house. Kobane has already become a symbol of resistance to the regime of terror and oppression imposed by ISIS. The fall of Kobane would send the message that ISIS can defeat this resistance and could increase the attractiveness that ISIS itself exerts in Syria and elsewhere, as well as encouraging terrorists to continue their offensive action against other targets. This is unacceptable to the European Union and its partners. The time has come to show with facts how determined we are to contain and defeat ISIS. Kobane is a further example of how it is necessary for the coalition to act on a military level to contain ISIS, but while this military engagement is still ongoing, it must be acknowledged that the deployment of armed forces alone is not enough. Continued commitment and global and coordinated action will be needed to counter the regional threat posed by terrorism and violent extremism, as well as to address the basic instability and violence that have allowed ISIS and other terrorist groups to take hold. This is what the European Union as a whole needs and is committed to achieving. ISIS has been able to proliferate thanks to non-inclusive policies in Iraq and instability in Syria, the result of the brutal war waged by the Assad regime against its own people, massive human rights violations and systematic obstacles to democratic reforms.  Our political commitment must go hand in hand with our diplomatic commitment, our cooperation in the field of security and the fight against terrorism and our policies to promote the socio-economic development of the region. From a military point of view, it is crucial that the decision announced on Monday by the Turkish authorities to authorise the passage of Iraqi peshmerga to Kobane will result in concrete action before it is too late. The EU has publicly called on Turkey to open its borders to ensure supplies reach the people of Kobane. We hope that this appeal will not go unheeded. More generally, we consider the fight against ISIS to be a key element of our foreign policy towards Turkey. It is essential that all regional partners implement the relevant UN Security Council resolutions, including 2170 and 2178, and step up efforts at national level to stem the flow of foreign fighters and prevent ISIS from benefiting from profits from illegal sales of oil and other goods. Turkey has shown great generosity by taking in more than 170 000 refugees from Kobane.
