The European Commission has presented an emergency humanitarian aid package of EUR 3.9 million to support the supply of non-food products and health care, as well as food aid to refugees who are not staying in refugee camps. As you know, the European Union continues to lead the international response to the humanitarian crisis in Syria with the mobilisation of almost EUR 3 billion since 2011. The Commission is engaged in a close dialogue with the turkish authorities on how to improve continued support for kobane refugees in Turkey. However, 7 000 to 10 000 civilians are reportedly still trapped in the city and in need of assistance, and there are fears that ISIS has already committed large-scale abuses in areas around Kobane that are under its control. The dramatic situation in Kobane must not lead the international community to forget the catastrophic situation in other Syrian and Iraqi cities and areas torn apart by the civil war. International efforts for a Syria-led transition remain a priority for the EU in order to maintain the unity, sovereignty and territorial integrity of the country while safeguarding its multi-ethnic and multi-religious character. Lasting peace in Syria is not possible unless the legitimate claims of all ordinary Syrian citizens, including those belonging to ethnic and religious groups including the Syrian Kurds, are taken into account. The EU is determined to support all efforts for a political situation, reached by common accord on the basis of the Geneva Communiqué of 30 June 2012 and in line with the relevant UN Security Council resolutions. To this end, we will continue to give full support to the mission of the UN Special Envoy, Mr de Mistura. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I look forward to discussing this issue with you and thank you for your attention.

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, let me begin by, on behalf of a number of colleagues, to regret that the High Representative, Mrs Ashton, did not deign to come and participate in this last session and at least greet us. This is a tragic example of the lack of dialogue we have had over the past five years. On Kobane and the Islamic State group, many things have already been said, and we are witnessing almost live, unfortunately, the agony of this Kurdish city. I would like to focus my remarks on three points, which are more directly related to what the countries of the European Union can or could do. Firstly, eight Member States are now intervening militarily in this conflict, either by airstrikes, by training Kurdish and Iraqi fighters, by deliveries of equipment, or by these three actions at the same time. Could it not be envisaged - has it been at European level? A slightly more coordinated action, particularly in terms of training? Indeed, the European Union knows how to mount military training operations because it does so in other parts of the world. Could we not use our instruments of the common security and defence policy rather than relying, once again, on an ad hoc coalition under exclusively American coordination? The second point - you alluded to it: turkey's attitude. I have never been under any illusions about the assumption of Turkey's entry into the European Union, but it turns out that, legally and politically, Turkey is a candidate country and, under that statute, it is bound by obligations to converge its foreign policy with regard to the positions of the common foreign and defence policy of the European Union. That is absolutely not the case today and I find that totally unacceptable. Let me say that beyond the European Union, Turkey is a member of NATO and that an alliance like NATO's is based first of all on the perception of common threats. When we see Turkey's current attitude towards Kobane, and more broadly with regard to the organization "Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant", we can ask a lot of questions. Third, and I will end on this, Mr President: our attitude towards Syria. I understand the difficulty of considering that, to some extent, we would have common interests with the Syrian regime, but I do not believe that doing moral zeal to send back to back, permanently, Syrian regime and terrorist organizations is a solution. I fear that this will condemn us to lasting powerlessness in the region.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the Kurdish fighters of the Syrian Democratic Union Party have heroically defended their town, Kobane. In this respect, the S&D and I deplore Turkey’s inaction in the face of this jihadist assault and its refusal to join in practice the anti-Islamic State coalition. As a future candidate for membership of the European Union and as a member of NATO, it is important for Turkey to show readiness to cooperate and coordinate with the EU and NATO. This is not the case right now. Let me say respectfully to Turkey that we do understand its legitimate right to fight terrorists – any terrorism – but, at the same time, it is morally very difficult to accept that failing to support Kobane Kurdish fighters at a critical time could be explained by Turkey. Kobane’s fight is highly symbolic, not because they are fighting for their town, but because it concerns a wide confrontation between all those fighting Islamic State and al-Qaeida’s global jihadist forces everywhere. In recent days, Turkey has finally taken steps forward and this should also be noted by Parliament. Yes, Turkey allowed Kurdish forces to cross its border with Syria to help fight against Islamic State but as Mr Della Vedova mentioned, this should be put into practice and not be just declared. We should also not forget the extensive number of Kurdish refugees in Turkey, which stands today at very high numbers and those humanitarian actions and important contributions from the European side which are also very much needed. I have to emphasise that for us the military operation should have an exclusive aim – the destruction of ISIS and all groups linked to al-Qaeda, and should include all relevant regional players. The coalition should better define the goals of the operation and should also design a strategy to stabilise the region after the war phase.  Finally, do not forget Iraq and Lebanon... (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, it appears that ISIS’s retreat from Kobane last week may have been a tactical regrouping after reports of a renewed offensive on all fronts against the Syrian besieged border town. With estimates of up to 1 000 civilians, many of whom are elderly and vulnerable, remaining still in Kobane, its defence from ISIS is vital to prevent a potential massacre. So I take this opportunity to salute the brave efforts of the Kurdish YPG forces on the ground, and I also welcome Turkey’s belated decision to allow Peshmerga troops to cross the border – though of course it is a little too late for what we would normally expect from a NATO ally. Furthermore, there are still reports that Turkey is failing to effectively prevent jihadi movements from Turkey to Syria, and in addition, the Turkish Government continues to refuse to outline the details of the secret deal regarding the release of its 49 hostages held by ISIS. Sadly, the threat of ISIS continues to grow as they consolidate their powers, and it is clear that we in Europe must do all that we can to support the military efforts of the United States. So I am particularly pleased that my country, the UK, has announced yesterday that it will be deploying intelligence and armed drones across parts of Syria, marking a welcome shift away from the policy of engaging only in Iraq. Credible reports that ISIS fighters have captured chemical weapons in the form of mustard gas from Syria is but one example of the dire consequences of the danger posed by the evil threat of ISIS or ISIL or the so-called Islamic State – call it what you like, but ultimately it must be totally defeated. (The speaker agreed to take two blue-card questions under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – No intention of scoring points; a simple question. With the sorry history of the Middle East and the interventions of the West, do you not agree with me that it would be very well beholden on our leaders, yes, to do the right thing and, yes, to support good against evil and these barbaric people, but would it not be right for them to take a more cautious and careful approach and think very carefully before going forward in any kind of gung-ho manner. Time to think, reflect, but then, yes, do the right thing. Do you agree?

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: blue-card answer. – Well, rather unusually, yes, I would agree, Mr Etheridge, that we have to be cautious. Nobody is talking about boots on the ground, or British troops or any other kind of – American or European – troops that I know of. That may become necessary. There has been a lot of time to think about this. Many thousands of innocent civilians – Christians, Yazidis, Turkmen and Shia Arabs – have been slaughtered by ISIS, and we must now intervene to prevent another massacre occurring in Kobane. My case rests.

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Thank you colleague, Charles Tannock. Having listened to what you said, do you personally support Turkish membership of the European Union, bearing in mind your comments?

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: blue-card answer. – The Conservative Party supports Turkish candidature and eventual membership of the European Union.

name: Fernando MAURA BARANDIARÁN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I shall begin by pointing out my unease at the decision of this House in preventing a resolution on such a sensitive matter. It is irresponsible not to pay well-deserved attention to what is happening in Kobane.  Since 21 September, Kobane has been resisting a terrible siege by Islamic State forces. A life-and-death struggle against barbarism, which is the same as saying against intolerance, against each and every human rights. For thirty days of terror, Kurdish People's Protection Units have defended Kobane. They have fought bravely, without any foreign aid, without Turkey's support, except for some sporadic bombing by the coalition. It is true that, since last Monday, Turkey has made a policy change, a change that could become final in the settlement of the siege on Kobane, a change that consists of freewaying Iraqi Kurdistan security forces and allowing coalition aircraft to take off from their bases. However, we cannot forget that Turkey's policy over the past four weeks has come at a very high cost in human lives and that the ultimate positive solution to bullying on the city is still far from there. But it wouldn't be fair if I just criticized Turkey. We are also here in the European Parliament, and it must be acknowledged that, once again, we have not lived up to what the situation requires. We must therefore react and take urgent action: first, the European Union must exert greater diplomatic pressure for Ankara to re-consider its policies in relation to northern Syria; second, Turkey must hamper the Islamic State's illegal hydrocarbon trading network across its border; third, Turkey must also return to peace talks with the Kurdish people; fourth, the European Union must push for a stronger and more unified response to the threat of the Islamic State, and more forcefully support the coalition. I will not tire of demanding a true common foreign and security policy that allows us to anticipate and be prepared. We can't pay ourselves to "as usual, we're late." And there is also the aim of alleviating the humanitarian situation.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, every day Kobane becomes a little more a symbol, a symbol of resistance against Daïch, a symbol of Kurdish resistance. Why then does the international community, and especially the coalition of the same name, not treat the fight against Daïch in Iraq and Syria in the same way? In both cases, the Kurds are on the front line. Of course, the Iraqi government has requested this intervention, but not Syria. We all know why. The fight against Daïch must be coherent. This monster did not come out of nowhere. It is indeed the result of the deterioration of the situation in Syria, of the way in which the international community has, without reacting, allowed the Syrian people to be massacred by their dictator. This monster, Daïch, has long been helped and probably still is, directly or indirectly, especially by the Gulf powers. Daïch is a barbaric, terrorist organization that is now out of control.  There is an urgent need to react and it must be said loud and clear, especially to Turkey, that its procrastination is not in order and that it cannot claim to start a peace process with the PKK and refuse any help to their Syrian friends. Weapons, like all Kurdish fighters, not just Iraqi peshmerga fighters, must be able to actually cross the border, in the only place where it is possible, that is Turkey. At the moment, these are largely just words. We cannot, at times, salute the courage of the Kurds, sometimes call them terrorists according to internal interests in Turkey. It is time to call for the PKK's exit from the Union's terrorist organisations, including to help the peace process in Turkey. It is time to help the Kurds without delay in their fight against Daïch for the benefit of all minorities and democrats in Syria as elsewhere. We must react quickly to avoid a second Mosul. In Kobane, there are more than 10,000 people waiting and at risk of being massacred at any time.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the When we discuss the situation in Kobane, our focus must be on the safety and life of civilians in and around Kobane. This means to the Turkish Government that all people fleeing the embattled Kobane region must be taken in. Turkey has taken in refugees from Syria in a very generous way and we must also support them in this. It is also to be welcomed that Turkey has finally opened the border to allow Peshmerga fighters to go to Kobane, because it is a question of preventing the advance of clearly identifiable ISIL fighting groups into settlement areas. The Council of Foreign Ministers has called for the border to be opened, but it has not explicitly addressed the situation of the Kurds. However, if we are looking for a viable solution, the question of cross-border support for the Kurds or the identity of the Kurds in the region must not be left out. The EU should also work to reopen the peace process between the Turkish Government and the PKK. The EU should also make it clear to the Turkish Government that the toleration of ISIL's thriving trade in archaeological treasures or other goods through Turkey's informal economy urgently needs to be stopped. We hear of progress and regression in the pushback of ISIS in Kobane. But there are other very negative news, such as the capture of the small Kurdish town of Karatapa by ISIS on Monday or the current siege of the Yazidis. We must prepare for a multi-year fight against ISIS and, as the Council of Foreign Ministers rightly pointed out, we need a sustainable solution, and that can only be a political solution. The EU needs a comprehensive regional strategy for Syria and Iraq. And this must include elements such as strengthening the central government in Iraq and the continuation of the Geneva Conference in Syria, led by the UN and involving the region's neighbours. This includes Iran.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, until a few months ago, Kobane, this name was just a dot on a map of Syria, unknown to most. A lost outpost of a stateless nation, of a land of its own oil-soaked misfortune, on which many have long set their eyes. Ironically, the Arabic name of the city is Ain al-Arab, the eye of the Arabs. The interested eye of those in Qatar and various Persian Gulf states have allowed so-called charity and benefactors to cheerfully stuff the pockets of ISIS. Perhaps it is because the example of democratic self-management and the strengthening of women's rights implemented by Syrian Kurdistan, where many are even soldiers, is an uncomfortable comparison. So it agrees that it should be eliminated as soon as possible, perhaps for someone to look around while 12-year-olds turn around with Kalashnikovs and hand grenades, while terrified women are sold in cages at the market, it is all the lesser evil. The hard and indifferent eye of Turkey, a candidate for membership of the Eu ropean Union, which has been watching a horror film for far too long. Only now has it finally agreed to allow Iraq's Kurdish peshmerga to pass through Kobane to allow them to defend their besieged Syrian brothers. But how many lives could have been saved if he had done so before? How? If it had not deployed tanks, infamous minefields at the border, to prevent the Turkish Kurds from going to fight against an enemy that disasfies all forms of humanity. How? If he had not repressed in his blood, more than 30 dead, the protests against these atrocities. The distracted and superficial eye of the West, which should still feel ashamed for forgetting for too long a tragedy in a region that means the West in Kurdish, Rojawa. Were those men, women and children tortured, raped and dismayed by ISIS in recent weeks really an acceptable price for not having the courage to bang their fists on the table of a prominent NATO member? Did they not even deserve a resolution in this Parliament? The hypocritical eye of the entire international community ...

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Castaldo, I would like to thank Mr Castaldo for his You have not exceeded the speaking time. I have now admonished you three times. We have a lamp up here – so that the new colleagues know that too. Please listen to me! We have a lamp at the front that lights up when the interpreters are no longer present. And if you want not only your Italian compatriots to understand what you have to say here, then you have to speak slowly, at least not so quickly that you can no longer translate it. You now have 30 seconds left.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Finally, the hypocritical eye of the entire international community, an increasingly immovable and impassive eye on one of the many humanitarian disasters announced. Hypocrisy, to deny it would be hypocritical! (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, I obviously agree with my colleague Castaldo. My question is this: should we not take action against Turkey and stop all accession negotiations with Turkey?

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, in my opinion, the foreign policy of any candidate country must absolutely be consistent with the foreign policy of the European Union. If a country, at present, does not wish to intervene and does not wish to avoid such a humanitarian tragedy, we should be open to any measure that might prevent it from having this type of behaviour, which is not at all consistent with a bid to join the European Union.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, it has been shown that the so-called 'jihadists' are the creation of the United States and its allies, who trained, equipped and financed them. Today NATO, the European Union, the United States and their allies are using ISIS as a pretext by continuing interventions, both in Iraq and Syria, to control the rich sources of the wider region. Among their allies is Turkey.  Especially for Turkey we would like to report that since 20 October the Turkish seismographic vessel 'Barbaros' has entered the Cypriot Exclusive Economic Zone, accompanied by two warships. This challenge is a dangerous development. Turkey violates Cyprus' sovereign rights and is during the occupation of a large part of the island. The people must condemn the European Union's attitude to Turkish aggression in Cyprus, which has been far from diminished by Cyprus' accession to the European Union.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Mr. President, Kobane has become a symbol, a symbol of resistance to the fight against the so-called Islamic State, and such symbols of resistance give special strength to those fighting the more powerful aggressor. Those of us who still remember the war in our corner of Europe also remember the heroic resistance, e.g. Vukovar against a more powerful aggressor, and that is why we know how important it is for the international community to show solidarity towards the victims, in this case, the people of Kobane, who are victims of violence and a new form of extremism. Of course, ISIS is a global security threat and wants to spread not only in Syria and Iraq, but the idea of a caliphate goes even to the south of Europe - it's a crazy idea. However, recruiting fighters on the European continent itself is already a destabilising factor. Of course, if we knew that ISIS controls not only territory but also resources, so it can also be financed in this way, and the fight against the Islamic State has shown that it has borders in our relations with regional partners as well, and I agree that we must revise relations with Turkey, Erdogan's Turkey and the policies it leads from the Balkans to the Middle East.  But what I want to emphasize here, is that we also have to look at the humanitarian dimension, and here the European Union has a leading role - €3 billion is a bailout - from the Commission, the Member States. Europe provides water, food and medicine to refugees from Kobane and surrounding cities. So this aims to send a clear message to residents: you are not alone, Europe is with you. I think we need to do our part, through the budget to pass financial aid for the people of Kobane, and later for development.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. President, respect, Mr. Stier, I want to ask you if it seems to you as well as me that the international community that failed in the case of Vukovar, we know how much it failed in the case of Srebrenica, when tens of thousands of people were killed in the wars in the Balkans, does it seem to you that this scenario is now being repeated beyond the borders of Europe, and the international community is discussing here, but the question is how much it works?

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. Jakovcic, I think that the international community could have done a lot more, that is, that the danger of the Islamic State was underestimated. I also believe that in the international community we have to speak with one voice and that is why when we have situations like the policies that Erdogan's Turkey has led so far, it sets a very dangerous precedent. So that's what we have to work on, and Europe must also respond unanimously if we are to be effective.  (A felszólaló hozzájárul egy, az eljárási szabályzat 162. cikkének (8) bekezdése értelmében feltett kék kártyás kérdés megválaszolásához).

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: Mr President, I was now thinking that, for us, Kobane has been described here as a symbol, the symbol of a whole resistance, as the last line separating us from the terror of the Islamic State, a strip of land which is both a frontier for us and yet surely for the people of Kobane this resistance has been nothing more than the defence of their lives , of their families, simply the resistance to be able to survive. And in this debate we talked about Turkey, also about the United States; with Turkey, by the way, I think we need to be aware that we need a smart demand, because We need Turkey.  But I am much more interested that we are talking about us, about the European Union, as Minister Della Vedova has done. There is no doubt that we have acted late and warmly, there are undoubtedly still many Member States that are resisting entering this task and that we need them. That we need strongness and we need action, and we need humanitarian aid. Right now that is essential and urgent, not only for the people who are suffering, but also for the neighbouring countries that are making a huge effort in the care of refugees, which are numbered in impressive numbers. We ourselves would not be able to care for that number of refugees.  So Kobane is a symbol, but unfortunately the complexity of the problem we face in that region is much greater. Islamic State is currently controlling large areas of Syria and northern Iraq, and its threat is growing and very violent. Terror spreads, and the death of innocents, too. Human rights violations are massive, in Syria, in Iraq, at the hands of virtually all contenders. It's very complex. That's why complexity requires our action, the defense of the future, which is what we're playing for, and for that we need our diplomacy, our politics, our resources and our intelligence.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking The victim of the Smolensk Polish, President Lech Kaczynski, said that the reasons in the modern world are not evenly distributed. Those who fight for freedom and defend freedom are right. That is why the Syrian city of Kobane, so close to the Turkish border, captures our imagination and mobilizes us to act. I am glad that the last few hours have brought the actor, who was necessary to relieve the situation of the city and the terrible humanitarian tragedy of the predominantly Kurdish population, entered the game. I am pleased that peshmerga fighters have been given the opportunity to move within the borders of Turkish territory.  All this is not enough. Our mobilisation is needed, because ISIS must be decisively defeated in these areas and in Iraq, in other places where it is trying to gain ground. There is also a need to limit the financial capacity of this terrorist organisation.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Mr President, I will not repeat the rather precise description of the situation made by many of you. I will also not repeat the objectives that were set out by many of you and which to a large extent – not always, but to a large extent – I share. I need to point out though, that we are facing the trauma of the inhabitants of Kobane, the trauma of the defenders of Kobane. We are also facing the trauma of the families of people who were executed in a barbaric way, but we are also facing one more trauma. We are facing a trauma of a lack of a comprehensive EU strategy on Syria, on Iraq and, of course, a strategy that would also deal with the grave situation in Kobane.  I thought, Mr President, that I would not even ask for speaking time, because I expected to forward a number of questions to the High Representative. I find it a disgrace that we have not seen her so far in this new European Parliament; I find it disrespectful to us and also to the families and defenders of Kobane. I therefore wish to ask the Italian President when it is we will see a proposal for a real, comprehensive strategy that shows that the European Union has an active common foreign and security policy. This is something that I am missing. We have seen bits and pieces, but nothing comprehensive; nothing that would show activity and the ability to avoid a trauma similar to Srebrenica. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – You spoke of a need for an EU strategy in dealing with the Middle East and the various problems arising. Does that include an EU military strategy?

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: blue-card answer. – First of all, I am not proposing a strategy, but maybe we will not see the High Representative for some time and I might sit down and draft something. But to answer your question, this is an issue which has to be assessed and evaluated with all the risks – advantages, positives and negatives – and this is something that should be debated. I might have a personal view on that.  I think that we have reached a certain point where basically we cannot just pretend that nothing is happening on the borders of the European Union. But this has to be done in a complex and cautious way – the way that has certainly been described. I am sorry, but this is not a question that can be answered in half a minute.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: Mr President, this Parliament is very much about being outraged or shocked, but when we have to look for the causes, we always look the other way. The situation in Kobane is desperate: hundreds dead and more than 250,000 refugees. But it's not a catastrophe, it's not an accident. And it pains me to point out that Turkey has a lot of guilt in the origin and emergence of the terrorist-integrist problem, because of its loathsome role as a regional "thug" through Syria's interference and destabilization, training and arming so-called rebels and blocking any peace initiative. Now we celebrate allowing Kurdish guerrillas to enter. I can't celebrate a murderer s leaving murder alone when he decides it himself. Turkey has been seeing with criminal passivity how IS criminals did the dirty work against their enemies. Turkey is a NATO country and its foreign policy, which sometimes borders on international crime, has serious implications for all of us here and for the countries of the area. Added to this is the disastrous Western strategy: decades of policies based on the destruction of secular national identities, especially in Iraq and Syria. It's time to stop feeding the fire with fire. The European Union must pressure Turkey and the Gulf countries to stop funding terrorist groups and destabilize the area, help rebuild Iraq's political unity, provide a solution to Syria under international and United Nations law... that is, to do something serious and with a future, rather than to watch the brave guerrillas and the brave Kurdish guerrillas make Kobane the Stalingrad of the Islamic State. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: blue-card question. – My colleague, would you agree with me that Syria is ruined? Hundreds of thousands have died; millions have been made refugees; Iraq is divided along ethnic and religious lines. Why do you ask for Turkey to join in this battle? Do you want... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Alyn SMITH
text: Mr President, we Scotsmen are noted for our brevity. Minister, it is difficult to know where to start in such heartbreak in the Kobane situation and the fight against ISIS generally, but I will focus in the time available on conflict oil. because I think this is an area where the EU as a whole can make a real difference in the fight against ISIS. As you said yourself, ISIS derives some revenue from the sale of conflict oil but actually, more importantly, uses oil refineries in its territory itself. That gives it a degree of operational independence, an energy independence which needs to be curtailed. ISIS controls three main refineries, two at Syria’s Deir al-Zor and one near Mosul. They have been degraded by air strikes but the issue is the importation into ISIS terrority of mobile oil refineries. This is not complex technology. It takes barely 10 days to put a mobile refinery together and on to a lorry, and that is giving ISIS real operational independence, so a very concrete question for you: will the EU step up cooperation, particularly with Turkey, Jordan and the KRG to stop the importation of this technology to ISIS-controlled areas, because if we can choke that off we start choking ISIS itself.

name: James CARVER
text: Mr President, my thoughts and prayers go out to the brave and innocent people of Kobane, who continue to suffer at the hands of Islamic State. They have now been under siege for over a month, and the situation continues to look desperate. There was some calm over the past few days as brave Kurdish forces appeared to be successfully pushing these murderous barbarians back, but – as we speak – IS have renewed their assault. Turkey, an official EU candidate country, stood shamefully by and callously watched the horror in Kobane for too long, even though it could have intervened. David Cameron’s Conservative Party is politically allied to the governing Turkish AKP, whose officials have previously found a voice to claim that women should not laugh in public. And as the world has now seen, they have remained deathly silent for too long, watching Kurds fight not just for their lives but also for the very existence of their culture. This refusal to act swiftly raises serious questions over their status as potential EU members and, indeed, over British support for Turkish membership. How can the Conservative Party seriously support people who act in such a manner? IS may be fighting for Kobane now, but we know that they will not stop there. They will continue to slaughter innocent people who do not accept their twisted interpretation of Islam until they are stopped. I fear that it is only a matter of time before some of the EU citizens who have been perverted by this warped mindset return to commit atrocities on our streets. I can think of no better reason to stop the free movement of people across the EU than the wish to ensure that citizens from all 28 Member States are protected from these poor examples of so-called humanity. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Alyn SMITH
text: blue-card question. – I think there are some points in what was said to which to take considerable exception. I am staggered to hear a UKIP Member suggest that the EU should dictate to Turkey what its foreign policy and its engagement in a conflict on its borders should be. Would the speaker not accept that the only influence we possibly have over Turkey is that of EU membership status? (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Smith, I can only allow questions and that was not a question.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Mr President, you have now created a little confusion. Well, be determined to fight ISIS and to act against ISIS, Della Vedova of the Council said here in Parliament today. However, mr President, I cannot see this determination with the best of intentions when it comes to the European Union. Kobane is just one of the problems that ISIS is causing us, because ISIS, for example, intercepted an American supply of weapons today, and there are already reports that ISIS is using poison gas. They are not only from Kobane. The role of Turkey – and I can also say this here, and some colleagues have done so – should be discussed as a separate item on the agenda. I would like to say this, as do groups – ECR or EFDD: let us discuss this in a separate agenda item. In any case, the European Union's payments should be suspended once. That would be an act. But Yazidis are also being persecuted, with 7 000 in number being fought in the Sinjar Mountains, for example. There are already UN officials who talk about genocide, who talk about enslavement, rape of women, and the same picture exists almost everywhere. We have to deal with this and, above all, with Turkey. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Mr Mayer, I have a question for you. You said there was demonstrable evidence that IS was using poison gas. Can you show me any of the evidence or give me a link to find the evidence?

name: Georg MAYER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you for the question, sir. There are media reports on this today. There is no evidence yet, because this was only established yesterday, on Tuesday. But I said that too. I said, "There are reports of this."

name: Michèle ALLIOT-MARIE
text: Mr President, Kobane is a martyr city, it is also a symbol of our powerlessness. It must be acknowledged that our passivity, as the European Union, underlines our lack of a strategic vision on the real risks of the world to come. It also underlines our lack of knowledge of the true aims of a number of fundamentalist and terrorist groups, those of Daïch but more broadly those of Al-Qaeda, Aqmi, Jamaa al-Islamiya, etc. It also underlines our irresponsibility towards our fellow citizens and our children. It is obvious that Daïch's aims go far beyond the capture of the city of Kobane or the massacre of its inhabitants. The fall of this city would be a psychological victory for Daïch as well as for all the movements I have quoted and which pledge allegiance to him. It would also be a powerful encouragement or a powerful cause of recruitment for jihad in general, both there and here. So today I am making a finding: the Americans are intervening, and quite massively, some countries in the Arabian Peninsula are also intervening. Even Turkey today seems to be making a move, and we? What are we doing outside of speeches and a number of humanitarian actions? What do we do as such? There are indeed countries that intervene, but often without coordination and without a real vision of the European Union. This absence underscores the shortcoming of our international and defence policy. Mr High Representative, since she is not here, I would like to ask you whether, in the few weeks she has left, the High Representative intends to finally play her part in the search for real coordination of the actions taken by Member States, in the pressure against Turkey, in the conviction... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Richard HOWITT
text: Mr President, the siege of Kobane is being played out dramatically on our television screens as we all watch the black flag of ISIS from the hillsides across the border in Turkey. In this debate, I join calls for Turkey itself to play a full part in the international coalition. But those who simply want to use this issue to bash Turkey must equally acknowledge that the country is receiving more than 500 refugees a day from Kobane, according to UNHCR, and has given support already to 1.2 million refugees who have fled there from Syria during the past three years. We should welcome the announcement that the Turkish border is open to Peshmerga forces, but remember that there are large numbers of diverse people fighting under the name Peshmerga, which simply means fighter in Kurdish. We have to acknowledge that this is not a conflict between armies, and there is proper concern about the rules of conflict being ignored. However, to call the Kurdish fighters terrorists – suggesting this is a fight between one set of terrorists and another, as Ankara has done – risks undermining opposition to IS and risks the progress of the Kurdish peace talks in Turkey too. These risks must be avoided. As the new High Commissioner for Human Rights has said, IS is indeed the antithesis of human rights and ‘a diabolical, potentially genocidal movement’. Europe should support his call for Iraq to join the International Criminal Court to strengthen the legal, as well as the military, fight against them, and as we meet today the US State Department still says there is ‘a possibility that Kobane will fall to ISIL’. But while the battle for Kobane is the focus of our debate today, the violence we want to see ended is that which continues across Iraq and Syria, with battles raging in the east of Syria and in the suburbs of Damascus adding to more than 200 000 deaths since the conflict began. What about the siege by Syrian forces of more than 300 000 people around Aleppo, who are literally being starved to death, and the 200 air strikes they mounted against their own people yesterday alone? So the questions we must raise should also still be about resolving the conflict in Syria, building legitimate opposition, bringing legal accountability for all responsible for the crimes of war and ..... (the President cut off the speaker)

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Ladies and gentlemen, Kobani has gradually become a symbol. The city and by extension all of Kurdistan is virtually the last freeport in the entire region against the IS evil. The international community, ladies and gentlemen, has a responsibility to protect people if their own government defaults. The EU supports the international principle of responsibility to protect. We are very late to that. However, in order to defeat the monster, we not only need military strength, but we also need to convince the world that our model of protecting life, respect and tolerance is a good thing. As coordinator of the Committee on Human Rights for my group, I therefore insist that the European Union demonstrates that universal human rights are stronger than IS barbarism. That it demonstrates its ability to cope with this threat in a coordinated way, that it convinces partners such as Turkey to pour ready wine and put an end to their ambiguous attitude.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: Mr President, what is happening in Kobane is happening almost at the borders of Europe, in our immediate vicinity, a few hours by plane from here, and this must be an obligation for Europe to act in at least three directions. The first of these directions, of course, is our organisation in terms of defence and common security. We will not be able to continue, in the coming times, not to have a common European defence. This is a medium- and long-term emergency. In the short term, we must provide support to all those who are heroically resisting in this city of Kobane. Second, of course, we need to act on a humanitarian level, in accord with the UN principle of responsibility to protect - you have just talked about it. There are thousands of refugees along the border. Turkey must welcome them and Europe must assume its humanitarian responsibilities. Finally, the third direction is that we must act diplomatically. Turkey has played a double game which is not acceptable and therefore we must not accept. We need to exert greater diplomatic pressure. I believe that in the fight against terrorism, there can be no ambiguity. At the same time, we must work tirelessly to restore political stability in Iraq. For Syria, it seems that we need to define the chronological order of priorities and be, let us remember, alongside Lebanon, which is also under attack from the Islamic State group. Finally, at home in the European Union, we need to do a better thing to combat terrorism and, for example, finally put in place a European PNR system that will allow passenger data to be used to prevent terrorism.

name: Sabine LÖSING
text: Mr. President! The people of Rodshawa have many enemies, not just the most horrible, ISIS. This fight is not just about naked survival, but about a wonderful political project, about the experiment of a free society, of participation-oriented, non-discriminatory, just democracy. That is what the people are fighting for, and we owe them real solidarity for that. Turkey and Syria are opposed to this project because their nationalism and authoritarian regimes are being called into question. The US is concerned with regaining influence over an area of great economic and strategic importance. NATO airstrikes against ISIS and at the same time attacks on PKK positions by NATO partner Turkey; alleged support to the Kurds and, at the same time, arms supplies to Saudi Arabia and Qatar; Videos of ISIS with German hand grenades. When will these arms deliveries finally be stopped? When will effective pressure finally be exerted on Turkey to immediately stop all support for ISIS and to open the borders to Kurdish fighters, not just the Peshmerga? Immediate action must be taken to withdraw the Patriots and lift the PKK ban. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Lösing, I would like to thank Mrs Lösing for her work on this report. I do not have the words in view of what you are talking about here. Do you really think it is the measures taken by the West to try to help the people of Kobane who are the problem in this situation? Do you really believe that American and European efforts are the problem? Do you not think that it is a terrorism that is inhumane, that we are seeing, that is the problem and that we must tackle it? I am genuinely disenchanted with what you have just said here! Gentlemen!

name: Sabine LÖSING
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I have already given the answer to this question. I really wonder why there is a hypocritical call here for people to be supported against ISIS and, at the same time, as in the last AFET, for example, the EU envoy to Turkey has in no way declared a willingness to change its policy. That is what it is all about. It is now a question of putting pressure on Turkey. Why didn't that happen? All I can say is: why does the German government not agree to withdraw the Patriots? That would be real pressure on Turkey. There are enough fighters to defend Kobane. Why are these fighters not allowed through the borders? Why does Turkey continue to have the ability to support ISIS? These are questions I ask. I am truly appalled that these issues have little understanding.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul There is a great deal that has been said and much that I can support. I would therefore like to mention something that no one has talked about before, and that is that we are not just going to talk about the Kurds, but we actually have to talk to the Kurds as well. Nor should we distinguish between the Kurds who are good Kurds, so to speak, and who are then in Iraq, and those who are bad Kurds in Syria, because Turkey does not have this fear of touch with everything related to the PKK and PUD. We're not going to make that difference, we're going to have to treat everyone equally. Today, it is the emergency aid to Kobane that has the highest priority. It is both humanitarian aid, but also support for the Kurds to be able to resist in Kobane. In the long term, however, we must also look at what happens next. We must also support the democracy-building, secular, multicultural, democratic and autonomous region that is being built in Rojava, that is, Western Kurdistan – the Kurdish part of Syria.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for several weeks now the media and Western governments have been focusing on the Kurdish town of Kobane in northern Syria, besieged by the Islamic State group.  If Kobane is indeed a humanitarian tragedy since 300,000 Kurdish refugees have crossed the Turkish border to escape the IS massacres, one can still wonder about the magnifying glass effect on Kobane.  For the Kurds of Syria, first of all, Kobane represents only a small proportion of the Kurdish population in northern Syria, the towns of Afrine, Aleppo and Al-Hassaka are also heavily populated by the Kurds. As for the Battle of Kobane itself, it is just one of the many battles that are being fought in Syria right now. It can even be said that it is not the most essential for Syria's political future. On a strategic level, the outcome of the fighting between loyalists and rebels for control of Handarat hill overlooking Aleppo is, for example, a much more important issue than the struggle for Kobane. Other battles between loyalists and rebels, between rebels and IS, between IS and loyalists, between the Al-Nusra Front and Hezbollah are taking place everywhere.  This magnifying glass effect on Kobane is reinforced by the fact that it is easy to shoot images from the Turkish hills while journalists no longer go elsewhere inside Syria. A ebb of the "Islamic State" group in Kobane is of course desirable and the National Front supports the French strikes against IS but the reality is more complex, a reality that the American and European governments refuse to state. Victory against the Islamic State group will not happen without close cooperation with the Syrian government. So we have to get back to realism and cooperate with Syria to defeat IS.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: Mr President, again we need to talk about this House of IS, which poses a serious threat. Fortunately, in Kobane his forces are no longer being imposed, thanks in particular to the bombing campaign of the international coalition and the struggle of the Kurds. What is happening in Kobane is important, but we must not forget other areas of conflict: the Iraqi region, for example That of Ambar, where IS unfortunately remains very active and is getting closer and closer to Baghdad. Without prejudice to military action in Iraq, where the reconstruction of the Iraqi army seems crucial to me, we also need political solutions. IS is closely linked , it was remembered here earlier, I think by the Italian Presidency - with Sunni discontent in Iraq. That is why we need the new Government to carry out an inclusive policy and regain Sunni and Kurdish confidence.  The situation in Syria is very complex, it has also been said here. In addition to the need to counter IS, we must continue to seek a political transition. Moderate forces that have unfortunately lost all prominence in recent times must be helped. And we must continue to support the efforts of the United Nations special envoy for this political transition.  Actors in Syria should not be exclusively Assad and IS. To defeat IS and safeguard the territorial integrity of Syria and Iraq, we need the collaboration of all states in the region and, of course, Turkey and Iran. No state in the region should benefit that IS can prevail and found a new Afghanistan over former Iraqi or Syrian territories, or mixed from both countries. We, the European Union and the Member States, must continue to seek solutions for the region, also in close coordination with the United States. IS, in addition to its destabilizing flaws throughout the area, can also be a global threat in which European fighters are present for more inri. Winter is coming, the humanitarian crisis is deepening, and that is why we also need to place special emphasis on it and help some populations that need us.

name: Kati PIRI
text: Mr President, in the last weeks we have witnessed a humanitarian crisis unfolding in Kobane. Around 200 000 people have escaped the terror of Islamic State, seeking refuge in Turkey. As has been said already by many previous speakers, Kobane has become the symbol of the fight against this terrorist organisation, which poses a threat not only to the security of Syrians, Iraqis and countries in the region, but a threat to all of us. That is also the reason why we have to be united in our fight against IS. The situation in Kobane has already deeply affected the internal situation in Turkey. We witness different groups within Turkish society attacking each other and putting extra pressure on the settlement process. It is of crucial importance that the peace process remain on the table and that all sides continue with the road map that is to be set up. It is our moral obligation to support the Kurds fighting off IS and defending their city in Kobane. What Turkey has done in terms of taking up a huge number of refugees from Syria is to be commended, and I also welcome the latest statements that not only humanitarian aid can pass through the border from Turkey to Syria but  also the Kurds from Iraq will be allowed to reinforce the Kurds in Kobane. We have to jointly ensure that we will not allow Islamic State this important symbolic victory, as it would also certainly set back the morale of the Iraqi Kurds.   Not neglecting the situation in Kobane, we must also take into account the overall situation. The threat of Islamic State has certainly not diminished, also in Iraq, where it has even become bigger in some parts of the country. Last but not least, let us not forget that a large part of the funding of this terrorist organisation comes from the illicit sale of oil and goods. We have to ascertain that EU Member States are in no case involved in the illicit trade and all channels used by IS to sell this oil need to be closed off.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Mr President, I would like to ask the Council a clear and simple question. The question is: is candidate country Turkey, together with the European Union, fighting ISIS in full or not? I ask that question, Mr. Council representative, because observers in the region with which I am in close contact told me years ago, and to this day, that Turkey is fully responsible for the current human and logistical strength of the Islamic State of ISIS. So against this background, I ask the question: is Turkey actually fighting ISIS with us or not? I also ask this question with extra urgency because my observers said yesterday that there is also considerable sympathy for ISIS in Turkey. What exactly is that? A very dubious case. Finally, the threat of ISIS affects the entire region. The Council knows that, too. How much does the Council assess the danger posed by the presence of ISIS and its allies in Gaza and Sinai? And what strategy does the EU propose in the face of this further destabilisation of the region? Because that is also the case. [The Speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: blue-card question. – Whilst everybody is very quick to blame Turkey for not taking part in military action, the question I pose to the House is: those of you that were here previously, what did you do to stabilise Iraq? The destabilisation of Iraq has created this situation in Iraq. What did you do to try and stabilise Iraq?

name: Bas BELDER
text: "blue card" answer. – With all due respect, I do not understand your question at all. I have been walking through this for a few years in this Parliament, longer than you in any case, and I have always pointed out turkey's dubious role as a candidate country in terms of joint European security and foreign policy. And that was often at odds. I have always pointed out to the Council, but it was very quiet about it. Baroness Ashton, the great absentee, was also very quiet. It's an extraordinary constant I hear. Nothing.

name: Javier NART
text: Mr President, Mrs Ashton is an ectoplasm, so it is difficult to talk about it. He's not here, he's not expecting it. Let's move on. It is surprising that our European External Action Service is first surprised by the existence of the DAESH army. It's impossible to improvise an army! Even the world's least competent army sergeant will say that managing 4,000-5,000 fighters for 1,000 kilometers requires massive logistics.  Where was our foreign policy, our foreign policy services, that they didn't know? Where was our European External Action Service that did not know what Maliki's sectarian regime means? Where was this service, which did not know what was happening in Al-Anbar province, where isIS progressed? Where was the European External Action Service when the attack on Fallujah, the Fallujah insurrection, occurred in January, which was ISIS' first warning? Second question: Kobane. I'm shocked by the scandal, because it's only known because we have it in front of our eyes on television. But Kobane—or Ain al-Arab, as the Arabs say—is the consequence of all the conflict in the arc that runs from Aleppo, through Deir ez-Zor, to Baghdad, to the vicinity of Baghdad. So let's stop thinking that with Kobane we are making a symbol, because I want to talk about the category, and I want to refer to the category. This Parliament, on 18 September this year, issued a resolution requiring a stoppage in logistical aid to DAESH. I am stunned when the Council of Europe, on 20 October, says that they will begin immediate action. But what are we talking about? As we speak, DAESH does; and I want no more condemnations, no approvals, no solidarity, no music: DAESH is confronted with deeds and not words. And, of course, my absolute rebuke to mrs Ashton's ectoplastic er, which is neither nor has ever expected it.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: Mr President, as we speak here, Kobane resists with the limited means available to him. Only the unitary response of Kurdish forces has so far prevented another massacre like the one recorded this past summer. And it is the Kurdish people who must be able to count on the means to resist and defeat, both in the face of the threat of the Islamic State and in the face of the attitude of the states occupying their territory.  The responsibility of the international community is evident, including that of the European Union. But the powers, NATO, do not act to protect the Kurdish people but to respond to an uncontrolled situation, another, caused by their policies in the Middle East and thus protect their own economic and geostrategic interests. Ladies and gentlemen, the rights and future of the Kurdish people are at stake, rights which have been trampled on for decades in the face of international and European passivity or complicity. And it's about those rights here, at the end of the day.

name: Michel REIMON
text: Mr. President! We agree that we all want to condemn the murderers and mass murderers of ISIS. But that is relatively easy, and they will not listen to us. I have also heard a great deal of criticism of Turkey, which is also relatively easy to make, even though I share much of that criticism. I think we should be more courageous in talking about our own role in this. How credible can our criticism be if we strengthen border protection in the Mediterranean, if we let women and children who make it out of Kobane, who make it to safety, then drown in the Mediterranean and do not save it. The European Union should be a model for dealing with refugees from this crisis region. We should think beyond Kobane right now – the disaster will pass. We should tackle two things in the long term: first, stop funding ISIS. This is about oil smuggling, which is most likely to come to Europe. Secondly, we need a long-term reconstruction plan for this region. Millions from Europe must go into the construction of the region and not into warships to fend off refugees.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Mr President, anyone who believes that Kobani is far from the geographical area of Europe must reconsider immediately and quickly. The number of European jihadists, according to the US counterterrorism centre, is significantly high. It is confirmed that holders of European passports fighting as jihadists in the ranks of the extreme Islamic State are a direct threat to their country of origin and beyond.  The long-suffering Middle East has overcome the myth of The Lernia Hydra. The Western world, using security, democracy and human rights as a pretext, has for years been discovering threats such as Saddam, Assad, Iraq, Iran, Syria, Palestine, Jordan, and intervening. Any such intervention, however, creates new enemies with greater hatred, extremism and a motive for revenge in place of the old. The Islamic State - although it is wrong to call an extremist terrorist organisation a 'state' - poses an asymmetric threat to Europe and the whole world.  The 15-member Security Council said the Islamic State must be defeated and the intolerance, violence and hatred it espens. Deliberately, however, he does not see the future shift in risk through the movement of populations and their activity first in Europe and then around the world.

name: Emil RADEV
text: When the terrorist organization Islamic State in Iraq and Syria was renamed only The Islamic State, none of us could have guessed its geopolitical effect on the situation in the Middle East, the war in Syria or the fragile stability in Iraq. Suddenly, the terrorist organization of an idea has become a brutal reality and an important participant not only in the above regions, but also with influence on international partnership relations. In this order of thought, Kobane is a symbol of the destruction and destruction of man's fates, but also of the power of the spirit of a people. The outcome of the battle for the city will inevitably be strategically important in the fight against Islamic State. If Kobane falls, the chances of Syria and Iraq falling under the control of the terrorists increase. If Kobane is rescued, hope will be given to thousands of peaceful citizens, regardless of ethnic and religious background, that Islamic State can be defeated by united forces.  National strategic interests must therefore be put aside for the sake of the common goal – defeating Islamic State and saving thousands more lives. It is important that all together – the US, European countries, Turkey and other coalition partners – provide the necessary support to the Kurdish population leading the fight on the frontline. I welcome individual actions by individual countries, but I also insist on a clear strategy of the international community to fight The Islamic State. This battle is not just the people of Kobane, it is a battle of all of us, and we have a moral obligation to win it with united forces.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, having in fact not made a deepening capable of understanding the many differences inherent in the changes involving the Arab countries, today we are forced to discover that extremist radicalism has seized Islam and has now become the first enemy, first and foremost of muslims. ISIS's action increases confusion in the area and destabilizes more deeply than it hits militarily. That is why it is a serious danger, but we must not regard it as a clash of civilisations, but as a political project that must be absolutely defeated and we must act on several levels.  There is not only the military option, it will only be possible to win this battle if the countries in the region are the main protagonists from Turkey and we must be aware that it will not be possible to achieve results unless the essential military aspect is accompanied by an adequate political process that helps the destabilisation of the area by trying to positively overcome the articulated map of fears and interests within the international coalition.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: Genocide is currently taking place in the Syrian city of Kobane. Islamic State thugs have for months beheaded, shot, crucified hundreds of men, kidnapped thousands of women, girls and children. Kurds and Yazidis, Christians, victims of this genocide, have lived peacefully on these lands for millennia. This genocide against Christians, Kurds and Yazidis in Kobani, in Syria and Iraq was carried out by the criminal organisation Islamic State with the complicity, assistance, military and logistical assistance of the Republic of Turkey led by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Kobani is an example of Kurdish self-rule, and this is why Erdogan has been idle and has watched the massacre carried out by his Islamist-backed Islamists over the peaceful population. This is part of his non-Islamist politics. Turkey's policy in the region is directed against the interests and security of the European Union, in particular against the interests and security of Bulgaria and the Balkans.  I demand that this chamber strongly condemn the genocide perdained by The Islamic State and loudly condemn and rebuke the complicity of the Republic of Turkey and President Erdogan in this war crime against humanity.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: Mr President, today we were listening to the plans of Commission President Juncker, and you would not have known that the world was on fire from hearing that. There was hardly a word on the urgent need for us to have an effective and common foreign and security policy. Now we are literally watching yet another disaster unfolding in Kobane, and we should be urged to be more than bystanders. The time it takes before decisive action is taken to protect the people in Kobane resembles the world’s paralysation in the face of the war in Syria. Remember the arguments used not to take effective action: if we removed Assad, then the Jihadists would take over? Today we still have both, along with 200 000 dead, millions on the run, and girls and women – particularly vulnerable – in an unacceptable manner being enslaved, raped and married off. The EU must work with Turkey and avoid strengthening jihadists, who are also funded by actors in the Persian Gulf that we still consider allies. We must end this crisis, which is caused by misguided jihadists also from within the EU.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: We express our strong solidarity with the people of Kobani, victims of inhuman and violent armed terrorist groups. It is important to condemn all forms of terrorism, including state terrorism. The population of Kobani is the victim of jihadist armed groups with sophisticated weapons and a totalitarian ideology, which have been armed and financed by the allies of the United States of America for three years, where, in fact, yes, Turkey has also played an important role, with the support of the Governments of the United States of America and the European Union. This was the confession made this month by the Vice-President of the United States, Joe Biden.  Of course, there will be no more interference, more war, more weaponry and more division and destabilisation of the Middle East that will solve the problem. It is precisely the causes of the proliferation of terrorism that must be combated. So that the same historical processes are not repeated, so that we learn from them and that the political responsibilities that are in plain sight are not whiten.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if genocide is taking place at a short distance from Europe's border in Kobane, the surreal absence here in the High Representative's Chamber raises the question: where, if any, is Europe's foreign policy? Turkey has already conditioned its possible direct participation in coalition operations and the creation of a buffer zone on the border with Syria and a no-fly zone that Syria has always seen as a threat to its sovereignty. On the other hand, sunnis fear pro-Iranian Shiite militias at least as much as the warriors of the Caliphate, and in this situation it will not be easy to counter the Islamic State. The kobane affair reveals the real role of Turkey, which has even dug a wall at the border to prevent the passage of refugees' cars from Kobane. She refused to open a humanitarian corridor and behaved ambiguously about the passage of jihadists that Erdogan called tourists, even encouraged to cross the border to take down the Assad regime. Are we sure that the real border objective of this conflict is the defeat of the Caliphate or not the creation of a new Sunni state entity between Syria and Iraq? Are we sure that isis can really be defeated without Syria's involvement?

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: Mr President, Syria has become a major humanitarian challenge facing the world today. The war there has killed hundreds and thousands; it has displaced more than 6.5 million people inside the country and it has forced more than three million to flee for their lives beyond the borders. The flagrant violation of international law by all sides in the Syrian conflict must be confronted and referred to the International Criminal Court.  The rise of ISIS, the continued activities of al-Qaeda, and the growing strength of Boko Haram make it clear that there is no room for complacency among the international community when it comes to the growth of extremism. We must unite, we must mobilise to confront this threat and we must do so with a real sense of urgency. Everywhere we look at this time we see a world beset by warfare and terror on many fronts, heart-rending reports of escalating casualties and refugee numbers, the slaughter of innocents and the suffering of children and vulnerable adults in northern Iraq and Syria.  The town of Kobane has become a crucial symbolic battleground in the war against ISIS. Having been under siege for a month now, it is heart-breaking to see mothers, young children and vulnerable adults involved in defending the city, which has come under sustained attack from ISIS fighters. Over 180 000 Syrians have been displaced to Turkey by the fierce fighting in Kobane alone and yes, the Commission has increased its humanitarian budget for the Syrian crisis in 2014, but we must question whether we doing enough to stop the ISIS advance. We must question whether we are doing enough to help the three million refugees, many of them children, who are now spread across Jordan, Turkey, Lebanon, Iraq, Egypt and parts of North Africa.  More pertinent is what awaits the people who remain in Kobane, a besieged people short of fuel, food, weaponry and without adequate international support. We must not just question, we must act. We have a duty to act, and this Union has a moral obligation to help civilians in Kobane to do everything in its power, from both a humanitarian and political perspective, to stop the advance of ISIS and deal with the refugee crisis that is threatening to tear that region apart.

name: Neena GILL
text: Mr President, we have a desperate situation in Kobane, therefore it is crucial that we bolster groups in Iraq and Syria who are fighting IS. We also need to make sure that we have sufficient safeguards in place through a coordinated approach, not just to avoid arms falling into the hands of IS, as has happened to a batch of US weapons dropped in Kobane on Monday according to reports that I have seen. When we talk about the threat posed by IS it is crucial that we do not forget that the Assad regime is partly responsible for their success. It has been fostering the development of IS over the past years, as part of its strategy to create an illusion that on the one hand opposition groups who are fighting for democracy and, on the other hand, terrorists, are one and the same.  Therefore, I welcome Monday’s decision to further strengthen sanctions on the Syrian regime. It is clear that to me we need to offer full support to the moderate Syrian opposition in its goal to ensure inclusive and democratic political transition, and we need to urge the Iraqi leadership to make sure that all groups in society have substantive participation in government. A unified response to ISIS will only be possible if these conditions are met.

name: David CAMPBELL BANNERMAN
text: Mr President, I had the privilege to be elected as the new President of the EU-Iraq delegation last week. I made it very clear that our priority must be to destroy ISIL in Iraq and Syria and wherever ISIL resides, including on our own streets in Europe. Mosul has just held the last Christian mass after 1 600 years. Even babies are being beheaded and 1.8 million people are internally displaced in Iraq. I strongly support US, British, NATO and Arab nations’ air strikes against ISIL, but we are facing the equivalent of a core of 30 000 ISIL troops. It cannot be done overnight.  I had the opportunity to meet the Prime Minister and Foreign Minister of Turkey two weeks ago, with whom I directly raised concerns about Kobane. Turkey’s very positive announcement to allow Iraqi Kurdish fighters across its border into Kobane, particularly with their sensitivities about the PKK, is most welcome.  We should support the Kurdistan Regional Government but not get too close to the Iranian regime. In this regard we should say that the enemy of your enemy is not necessarily your friend. I intend to play a constructive role to ensure that all tools – military, political, economic and humanitarian – are used to destroy ISIL and to protect minorities from these purveyors of evil.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Mr. President! The absence of the High Representative today is truly inexplicable. It was their last chance to appear in this Chamber. That is really incomprehensible. Similarly, the absence of foreign policy remarks in Jean-Claude Juncker's programme this morning has shown that this Parliament is actually the wrong place for debate. There is no common European approach. The Council is doing nothing, even though countless EU KORs are certainly going back and forth between the foreign ministers and you have the feeling that something is being done. Nothing happens. What is needed is instead a special NATO summit. Only in NATO can Turkey really be caught at the portepee, there it cannot escape, there it can be asked to take a clear position against ISIS. That is the only chance we can do it. The European Union – and I very much regret this as a member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs of this House – is the wrong place for the debate. This debate belongs in NATO, because NATO is the only organisation that can regulate the whole thing. The Council is doing nothing. The High Representative is absent. I think that says it all.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Mr President, the Islamic State's attack on Kobani is a gradual evolution of the United States' intervention in Iraq. It is also a gradual development of the effort of the United States and Turkey to impose their own view on the 'Syria' issue. Today, all of them are called upon to face what they have created. That is why the Kurds have become the symbol of resistance. In this context, Turkey, fearing a greater Kurdistan, is accused of not understanding what to do, while at the same time, instead of zeroing in, as it proclaims, its problems with its neighbours, it is multiplying them. Instead of attempting what it proclaims, it opens up new adventures by sending its ships for research in the Exclusive Economic Zone of Cyprus, violating every principle of international law.  We are on the side of the Kurds and we call on the European Union to contribute to the embodiment of this right with respect for human rights and the decisions of the United Nations.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: Mr President, DAESH's fight for control of Kobane is of dual importance: strategic, for the control of illegal and political clandestine supply routes, because of the provocation also for Turkey on Syrian territory. The shadow of the PKK prevents – that is what Turkish analysts say – the necessary response from a country that has one of the most powerful armies on earth. Authorizing the passage of peshmergas, in my view, is insufficient. Meanwhile, Abdullah Ocalan, the leader of the PKK, remains in permanent prison, in life imprisonment, on the island of Imrali in the Marmara Sea. That's what I say it all about. Meanwhile, DAESH has already killed seven hundred people and produced a mass displacement of majority Kurdish populations in Ain al-Arab. In my view, fighting peshmergas and those to come need swift and effective military help. By air, coalition attacks are insufficient and DAESH continues its indiscriminate attacks on civilians. What is happening in Iraq and Syria? Beheadings, sexual slavery, child recruitment, kidnappings, massacres of religious minorities—more than two hundred thousand dead according to the United Nations; 6.4 million internally displaced persons in Syria, 5.2 million people in Iraq and 11 million Syrians need immediate humanitarian aid as winter comes. The European Union has contributed EUR 3 billion in aid to Syria and Iraq, but the situation continues, it is not contained. More donors and more military determination are needed from the coalition. The integrist virus of the purported caliphate spreads and must be neutralized, it must be stop before it invades with terror countries there and here. There they exterminate, but here they will end up making effective what is no longer a threat, but a real fact: the European Union's intelligence services no longer doubt that they will attack here. All that remains to be known is when and how, what day and what country. We necessarily have to react, Mr President.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Mr President, one of the real tragedies of Kobane is that it has also served as an enormous distraction. The international media has a front row seat on the hills in Turkey and beam with their tele-lenses and dishes the daily destruction into our living rooms. But we are witnessing a microcosmos of the war and thereby forgetting the bigger picture. This war in Syria has been raging on for more than three years, with over 200 000 dead and millions displaced. Yes, ISIS is a big threat to the stability of the region – but what stability, I may ask? ISIS has also contributed to the diplomatic resurgence of President al-Assad. We must not forget that he started the war against his own people, and now he is coming very close to being courted again. That must not happen, dear colleagues. I sincerely hope that Federica Mogherini, the new Foreign Affairs Commissioner, will bring a decisive European voice to the table – a voice that has been absent for too long. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: the blue card. "There are indeed quite a few fireplaces next to Europe today that are not bothering us, but so far, thank God, we do not have any bigger problems inside Europe. Today, Europe ensures its security in cooperation with the NATO system. Do you think we need to improve cooperation with NATO in the future, or should Europe develop its own security system and, let us say, ensure security within Europe while at the same time helping to ensure global security?

name: Eugen FREUND
text: blue-card answer. – I see clearly that you are trying to put me on the spot, but in any case I think that there needs to be close cooperation with NATO in all respects. Mr Lambsdorff has pointed out – rightly so – that NATO has to play an important role in this affair, particularly as far as Turkey is concerned. But I still think that the Europeans have to get their act together and have to see what they can contribute in order to solve problems like the ones that are immediately in front of their doorsteps.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: In recent weeks, I have seen shocking videos, photographs of the appalling behaviour of Islamic State rebels, beheadings, torture, beastly speeches. We really have to try to stop it. I express my deep disdain for this situation and pray these days for God's empowerment of those people in suffering and inhumanity. Kobane lies in a region where there is a mixed population of Kurds, moderate Muslims and Syrians, as christians are called in this area of the Middle East, where there are one million. Until now, they lived there in peace and had equal rights. As the European Union, we should, firstly, reveal to the public the identity of the representatives of the so-called Islamic State and label them criminals. Declare their actions crimes against humanity and drive them to an international court in the future. Secondly, to help, both financially and materially, activists of democratic initiatives in the Kobane region. Thirdly, to help the official representatives of Syrian Christians, who are also in exile in Brussels as civic associations, with both financial and material assistance, and fourthly, to call on Turkey not to support the Islamic State in any way.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
