Mr President, precisely this social exclusion, on religious grounds, 'Christian inreasure', led to an altercation in 2009 between the Pakistani Christian Asia Bibi and some of his fellow villagers. What followed was a pure legal rape invoking a toxic blasphemy law, and the death sentence was signed against Asia Bibi. To this day! What does Asia Bibi expect from Western Christians? I quote her literally: "Prayer and a call to their governments to protect persecuted Pakistani Christians." That is why I am addressing the 28 Member States of the European Union today with the pressing request: demand that the Pakistani judiciary have a clean procedure against Asia Bibi and demand that the Pakistani authorities treat Pakistani Christians as full citizens. With this Pakistani self-cleansing, Asia Bibi will surely be released and Pakistani Christians will surely become free citizens!

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Mr. President, I signed a petition along with 150,000 other Christians seeking clemency for Asia Bibi, a Catholic and mother of five, who was arrested in June 2009 and then sentenced to death on a false blasphemy charge against the Prophet Muhammad.  No matter that there is no clear evidence, she has been in prison for five years, and she has been accused falsely by her neighbors who insulted her, for being a Christian. Asia Bibi was asked to be freed if she passed into Islam, which she refused and she publicly confessed her faith in Jesus Christ.  The fact that two politicians who expressed support for her were executed also speaks of their disregard for the rights of religious minorities in the area. This requires concrete moves by the United Nations and the European Union. I ask that the persecution of Christians be put to an end and that Asia Bibi be released, because for 5 years the innocent resides in prison and must not be punished, especially not by the death penalty because she publicly professes her faith in Jesus Christ.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: Mr President, we may condemn capital punishment as such, yet there is a world of difference between executing a person for murder after due process and killing a person for criticising an ideology or a religion. Therefore, we should not discuss the death penalty as a whole. We must rather ask whether it is acceptable to sentence people to any kind of punishment for blasphemy. It is wrong from the point of view of freedom of speech, but also because many barbarian practices such as child marriage are deeply rooted in religion. It is in practice impossible to criticise these practices without criticising their religious foundations. Many European countries have their own blasphemy laws. They should be repealed and we should set an example to the rest of the world.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: First of all, I thank my colleague Van Dalen for his initiative to put this item on the agenda. For serious reasons, I was unable to attend monday's sitting, but I sent a letter to the President of Parliament to condemn the death penalty for Asia Bibi at the beginning of the part-session, while at the same time backing the inclusion of this item on the agenda in the letter. In recent years, we have witnessed a number of murders and death sentences based on alleged blusphemy. The fact that no death penalty has yet been carried out is no excuse. I ask how many people could have saved their lives if the European institutions had taken a timely and principled position. I ask the leadership of Parliament, the Council and the Commission to respond, let us not miss another opportunity. In his speech, the President of the Council said that Baroness Ashton had spoken on this case. My question is why her position has not been widely published.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, believing, practising and spreading one's faith is a fundamental human right and cannot be subject to any kind of limit and control. Unfortunately, this is not the case in Pakistan, which sentences a woman, a mother of a family, to death for talking about her religion, Catholicism, to Muslim work colleagues and who, faced with the proposal to convert to Islam in exchange for freedom and life, has courageously refused. The choice of supreme court is the international credibility of the Pakistani judicial system, in the application of the anti-blasphema law. With regard to minorities, of course, but towards the citizens all. Asia Bibi is the victim of an unjust law, an unfair trial and we cannot let fundamentalism triumph. Europe must play its part.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the death penalty is a medieval, inhuman, illogical instrument. It is absurd that we are still discussing this in 2014, when 140 countries around the world abolished it de facto and de jure. Asia Bibi, if we do not act now, will be brutally killed by the Pakistani state for offending the Islamic prophet Muhammad, who was sentenced to death in 2014 for blasphemy. You really have a hard time believing it. The history of Asia Bibi is emblematic of the collective madness that meanders sneakily for our planet. A woman, a mother of 5 children, beaten, imprisoned, raped and arrested and then sentenced to death without a shred of evidence, just because she was Catholic. A disgrace! We should never, ever negotiate any economic agreement with those who still use the death penalty, a barbaric and inhumane means still in use, unfortunately, in some sixty states including Pakistan. The right to life is not touched!

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council (on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/ High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy). - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome the strong commitment to the case of Asia Bibi and I am sure that the dialogue between the European Parliament and parliamentarians in Pakistan can also help to promote change. I repeat that the European Union is constantly committed to promoting human rights in Pakistan and defending them at every opportunity: with the government, with human rights defenders and with other stakeholders. To this end, we will make full use of all the instruments at our disposal: démarches, declarations, dialogue.  The forthcoming visit of the President of the Senate of Pakistan to Europe at the end of November, in addition to the visit to Pakistan next week of the EUSR Stavros Lambrinidis, will be a useful opportunity to discuss these issues.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The debate is closed.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on European IS fighters (2014/2901(RSP)).

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. - This is indeed a very serious phenomenon that we are debating here today. It is a serious threat to the European Union, and we saw what happened in Brussels only half a year ago when a returning foreign fighter opened fire in the Jewish Museum in Brussels and killed four people. We need to step up our efforts to stem the flow of foreign fighters and we need to work together in the European Union. First of all, we need to ensure better information exchanges between the Member States, notably by establishing appropriate mechanisms. One such mechanism is the passenger name record data that the Council mentioned. PNR data could be an essential tool to carry out trend pattern analyses, identifying potentially high-risk travellers. This enables the authorities to better detect those foreign fighters travelling to and from the EU by air that were previously unknown to law enforcement agencies. PNR is also a very important tool to detect traffickers and drug smugglers. Of course, an EU PNR needs a clear legal framework and coherent data protection safeguards across the EU in line with Article 8 of the Charter, as interpreted by the European Court of Justice. EU legislation must lay down clear and precise rules governing the scope and the application of the measures, and imposing appropriate safeguards so that the persons whose PNR data has been retained have sufficient guarantees to protect their personal data against the risk of abuse and any unlawful access or use of that data. I really hope that the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs can look at this again. As you know, Member State after Member State is developing its own PNR system, and it would be much better to have a joint system with common rules, not least when it comes to data protection. Another strand of action is the detection of returnees from conflict zones to Europe, and therefore issues of border security and border management play a role here. The Schengen Information System (SIS) is an effective tool for the detection and disruption of suspicious travel by sharing information about foreign fighters. It allows today for specific action to be taken on the basis of alerts. The Commission is making efforts to accelerate and improve the information exchange on SIS alerts among Member States, and it is crucial that Member States use all the possibilities offered by the system today. It is also important that Member States carry out minimum checks on persons as required by the Schengen border code and systematically check the travel documents of all persons at external borders against the relevant databases. There are voices calling for a revision of the existing framework on this, but it is important to first look at how we can use in an optimal way the existing tools and measures and make the best of them. The situation is urgent and the Commission is, of course, looking at technical discussions, but for the moment we do not plan any initiatives in this area. You must also understand that the Commission reserves its position until the next Commission is in place. Looking forward, aviation security capacity-building in third countries is a priority. The Commission stands ready to support work in this field highlighted by the European Council in August. We will continue our work on detection technologies to make sure that our own aviation security is as strong as it has to be. A very important strand here not to be forgotten, because it is key, is preventive work. We need to address, as the Council mentioned, terrorists’ use of the internet. We know that many of these organisations recruit via the internet. That is why we have started a dialogue with internet providers to see if we can cooperate in developing counter-narratives online and in cooperation, for instance, with returned people who can tell their stories. As you know, we also created three years ago the radicalisation awareness network. It plays a very important role in helping local actors and Member States to improve the tools and understand the root causes of radicalisation. We have networks working in all Member States with families and victims to draft counter-narratives, to pool the research, and we are working on exit strategies and will very soon be setting up a sort of centre of excellence that will be at the disposal of Member States for all this. At this point I would like to reiterate that security and fundamental rights are intrinsically related here. Combatting racist and xenophobic crime, intolerance, discrimination, including promoting integration and social cohesion, is a key element of EU policies. It is very important not to stigmatise any group here. We will also do everything to give priority to the enforcement of the Framework Decision on combatting racism and xenophobia by means of criminal laws. Honourable Members, Member States are meeting a lot to discuss these issues. The Commission is trying to be helpful, creating forums for the exchange of information. We need to step up our action here to combat this dangerous phenomenon of foreign fighters. We should use the existing tools at our disposal to the maximum extent made possible by border measures and national databases. We must also facilitate and promote European action, for instance a European PNR would be important here. We need to reinforce and spread the very important preventive work that has already been going on for a couple of years. This is the only way that we can jointly address this threat.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, on behalf of the PPE Group Monika Hohlmeier will actually speak. I greet the President-in-Office of the Council and Commissioner Cecilia Malmstrom, thanking him for the work he has done so far, in these years, and wishing him many successes in the future. Serious and constant human rights violations in Iraq and Syria under DAESH control have become a clear threat to international security. We are faced with acts of extreme cruelty: mutilations and beheadings of civilians and soldiers; sexual slavery of women; recruitment of children and kidnappings. In short, they are dedicated to generating terror with targeted or mass killings of civilians, also causing mass displacements of population: thousands, millions of displaced persons and refugees. The recruitment of fighters by the so-called Islamic State is not an isolated event throughout history: large international conflicts with certain Islamic countries throughout often become a good opportunity for the recruitment of jihadists. It happened in the 1980s with Afghanistan, in the 1990s with Chechnya, and it happened again in the 2000s with the Iraq war. But the big difference with all these conflicts is that the terror generated by DAESH is on track to outperform all those experienced in previous decades. This terrorist group recruits its members through a studied and lengthy work of recruitment through social media, which began even before the outbreak of the Syrian conflict. We are faced with a serious threat that increases day by day. The number of European fighters is estimated at 3,000, including 300 Belgians, 700 French, 500 from the United Kingdom, 51 from Spain. It must be acknowledged, ladies and gentlemen, that the return of these fighters to Europe after having participated in armed conflicts and receiving military training poses a grave threat to our security. The Union must therefore face and face this great challenge without ambages. And as I have said many times before this House, the best tool to combat them is the prevention and action of the intelligence services. Yes, we are definitely going to support the European PNR. President-in-Office of the Council and Commissioner Malmstrom, it is anachronistic and it is useless that there are thirteen PNRs funded by the Commission or that countries such as France or the United Kingdom have their PNR. I will support Timothy Kirkhope's initiative and I will do everything I can to unlock something that remains dead, sadly dead, since April 2013. So yes to the European PNR; not only to detect those who return, but also to detect those who come out or intend to leave. Yes to SID alerts and also to incentivize and promote greater aviation safety.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to make one comment straight away. What the Council and the Commission have presented here will not help to put an end to the murder in Syria. As the previous speaker said, it is a question of possible increased security in Europe, of nothing more and nothing less. However, we must not, of course, underestimate the danger posed by people who are prepared to commit violence and their supporters. But people must be able to trust that all the measures we take are based on respect for European fundamental rights. Extremism is not Christian, Jewish or Muslim. It is about power, it is about rejecting our common European values, about our democratic systems. We must defend and protect them. Surveillance of suspects is legitimate, but people must not become suspects simply because they belong to a particular religion or ethnic group. This obscures the view of other possibilities. I am thinking, for example, of the Nazi underground in Germany, whose members were able to murder undisturbed for years because certain criteria were left out, even though there were indications. The idea of withdrawing travel documents, which is currently under discussion, is critical not only because of freedom of movement. Even worse is the issue of a replacement identity card. This stigmatizes people without being charged or tried for a crime. Finally, what is wrong with our societies when young people, when our citizens seem to become increasingly radicalised and turn away from our democratic systems, when many have a good future perspective? If we do not find answers to this question, we will lose the fight against radicalisation in Europe.

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, European citizens are being radicalised. They are travelling to Syria and then they are being trained, with possible motives of one day returning to our cities and streets to harm and kill us. They want to replace a Europe of freedom and peace with fear and destruction. They call themselves the Islamic State but they do not represent the Muslim faith. They are criminals and terrorists and I believe that we should refer to them as such. There is no place for this in Europe. We have dealt with such behaviour before and we will do it again by working with our communities and our young people and addressing the problems at their source. The words condemnation and education are not enough.  Leaders of the European Council, the UN Security Council and the airlines all want an EU passenger name records agreement in order for law enforcement authorities to capture EU foreign fighters and address the chaotic information exchange system that they currently face. A patchwork of 14 different PNR systems not only leaves gaps in security for terrorists to exploit, but it leaves gaps in our data protection for travellers. The issue of PNR is often presented in a polarised way, but I believe you can protect the civil liberties of the individual while protecting the safety of us all. I urge Members to look at this agreement again. As rapporteur I would like to assure you that I will make sure we hold ourselves to the highest possible standards and put in place the toughest data protection rules we can. We must never compromise Europe’s hard fought-for civil liberties. It is also our primary duty as politicians to protect those who have elected us and to deal with and bring to justice those who seek to do us harm.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Mr. President, the assessment of experts and competent institutions is that the danger that threatens the European Union is great, and equally the capabilities of defending against this danger are very small and according to these assessments one of the reasons is the lack of cooperation between states and institutions in the fight against this phenomenon and this phenomenon should not have happened in order for cooperation between states and institutions in the security field to develop.  There was talk here that preventive action is needed in the strategy to combat radicalism of the European Council mentions the need to educate educational institutions, social and health services, religious communities to combat this problem. Of course, it is easy to say, this work is very complicated, the education itself takes a long time and the implementation of what has been learned and the skills that have been learned even longer.  But even more important than that is creating conditions in which radicalism will not occur. Radicalism of every kind occurs in conditions of social exclusion and especially poverty in these last years of the economic crisis. And that is why the key question is how to eradicate the conditions in which this type of radicalism is developing, but also every other radicalism, and therefore I remind that ten years ago European leaders said that they have failed to integrate immigrants into their countries, even those who have lived in these countries for years or more, and I think today's situation is no better than those last ten years and therefore I call on the Council , the Commission and Parliament to work to create social inclusion conditions in Europe and eradicate poverty, which is one of the conditions and fertile soil for the growth of radicalism.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, today we see Frankenstein's father wondering why what he made is a monster. Really, how much more vulgar must the policy you pursue be to be forced to link it directly to its effects? Twenty years now, with various imaginative complaints, you and your allies have been bombing the entire planet with nukes and chemicals, killing thousands of civilians you offensively call collateral damage.  You throw democratic institutions in the trash, you take out elected governments, you threaten peoples and you make nations poor.  And all this to make the seven or 17 sisters grow their profits.  And you wonder why the Taliban, al-Qaeda, and now the Islamic State were born. You wonder why far-right and anti-European people sit next to you. You wonder why European citizens go with the barbarians by renouncing this volume of culture that you produce. Don't be any wonder. Your policies are the main spawn of all these monsters. The only hope is the struggles of the peoples and the only solution is to overthrow you.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I very much endorse the comments of Ms Sippel and I would add that winning safety at home will be impossible unless we win the argument abroad. In our dealings with ISIS, above all else we must win the moral argument and understand that ISIS, so recently formed as an entity – such as it is – is not a thing in itself: it is a symptom of a wider problem partly brought about by our actions in the Middle East.  The roots to this go deep. Having grown up in the region myself, I am slightly familiar with it. The very existence of many of the states we are dealing with goes back to the historic actions of a number of our Member States, not least my own. Even in today’s New York Times a foreign fighter is quoted as saying ‘ISIS is the divine vehicle that will dismantle the European borders drawn by Britain and France at the end of World War I’. This goes back a very long way, and unless we comprehend the causes, and also much else – and I disagree that a massive security infrastructure at home is the solution when the causes are deeply rooted elsewhere – that disjoint in our values, because we are not seen as being impartial, is exploited by recruiters in highlighting our selective and partial application of our own much-vaunted values in our dealings with the region.  Even now we see that, while some rightly condemn the barbarism of ISIS, we are rather quieter in condemning similar actions by a number of our allies. Even today in Syria we are seeing air strikes rightly targeting ISIS, but leaving Syrian forces free to attack the civilian population. We might win a battle but we are not winning hearts and minds, and until we do so we are not actually going to tackle the real problem.

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – It is a sad fact that hundreds of men and women have been radicalised enough to leave the UK and fight for ISIS. Many a family has been left heartbroken and devastated in my country and in Europe. Our interfering has destabilised the whole region and dramatically changed lives. Since the Iraq war our reputation lies in tatters. Previous to the invasion, Iraq did not have al-Qaeda or ISIS. Libya lies completely broken. There are already enough combatants and our involvement will encourage further radicalisation and fundamentalism, not least because air strikes will lead to innocent civilian deaths. We must not be seen as those leading a new crusade in Muslim lands. To prevent this from happening I am holding a conference in London on 5 December on the radicalisation of the youth. The chief guest will be the Grand Mufti of Egypt, Shawki Ibrahim Allam, and the Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby. We must find a solution and we must act now.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of the majority, these Islamist fighters are your creatures. They are the results of your complacency, your shortcomings and your inconsistencies.  They are first of all the result of your complacency in the face of the massive immigration policy, which has brought and naturalized millions of uprooted people to Europe. Many are of Muslim origin and, for some, religious extremism is now a factor of cohesion, affirmation and revenge. They are also the result of your terrifying spiritual failure despite the presence of a huge group of so-called Christian Democrats, a deficiency of which is still given here with the exhibition of a hideous and offensive picture for the suffering Christ and his mother. How can we reproach these uprooted people for finding their religious ideal in the sacrifice offered to them rather than in our values and traditions, which you methodically destroy?  Finally, they are the result of your political and strategic inconsistency. Several European states, including my own, have encouraged, as in Syria, the fight against legal regimes, albeit authoritarian but religiously tolerant. How can we, for example, today, call these young men terrorists because they came to fight against a regime that we were in Syria, ourselves, about to strike? Things being what they are, it is not so much to prevent them from leaving that you have to devote your efforts, it is to prevent them from coming back. Foreigners who have gone to the Middle East to serve this barbarity should not be allowed to return. Dual nationals must be stripped of their European nationality and also denied readmission to our states. This will be much more effective than the cosmetic measures you may be about to take.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done on this report. I am somewhat appalled at the way we are talking about the fight against IS fighters among us colleagues. I sometimes ask myself the question: does something have to happen in Europe before we react? Or is it perhaps wise to agree on a reasonable, measured catalogue that does not automatically assume that you are taking away your passport from unsuspecting people? If a passport or a travel document is taken away, then there must be very clear criteria behind it, that someone wants to leave for Syria accordingly comes from corresponding very suspicious circles and accordingly has also potentially already appeared as a Salafist or as someone who has shown himself to be very violent. I do not want us to ask ourselves in hindsight what we could have done, but the task we have is to ward off crimes and, accordingly, to ensure that serious criminals, when they return to the European Union, are arrested, put a stop to them and do not give them any opportunity to spread throughout the European Union. That I agree that we potentially also need to think – not just potentially – about how it can happen that a small, radical group of people is on their way, that is right. But to say that Europe's young people are on their way is certainly wrong. But thank God it is a very small but extremely brutal, a horrible, a torturing, murderous and raping force. I think it is wrong to trivialise these or not to take measures into account. We have to keep a bit of an overview, that is necessary. That is why we also need to exercise greater caution at the borders, as well as to take a list of measures in which we have the opportunity to prevent crimes against our own people.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr. President, Madam Commissioner! I believe that we agree that we must do everything we can to combat this monster by all means at our disposal. However, we must not fall into the illusion that we can cope with a few targeted air operations of these forces. The tightening of border controls, which has been repeatedly hailed as a panacea, will only partially solve the problem, because IS is not a wild individuals, but a criminal, ideologically blinding organization about which we know far too little – about the motives, the interdependencies and their anchoring in certain milieus. To defeat such a threatening enemy, we need detailed knowledge. Until recently, the intelligence services, which often have an abundance of information about ordinary citizens, were largely obscuring the menacing nature of IS. We must also note with regret that our allies in the region often do not distinguish themselves clearly and clearly enough from these declared enemies of democracy. This must be called for very clearly and, for whatever reason, there must be no tactical game with IS. Above all, however, it is a question of preventing IS from recruiting a significant proportion of its criminal operatives in the West. We must not allow young men and women from our cities to be recruited with primitive propaganda. We must fight, together with the leaders of the Muslim communities in our Member States, to ensure that these milieus are dried up – with passion and empathy, and not by marginalising these people. There are already a number of Member States where such prevention work is successful. The fight against IS is a comprehensive one, and it needs the entire arsenal of our attention.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: Mr President, people who join ISIS, or blow up buses and trains in Europe for that matter, are not generally uneducated, unemployed victims of discrimination. They are people driven by ideology and faith. We must pay attention to what contributes to the radicalisation of second-generation Muslim immigrants in Europe. It has been revealed in recent years in several European countries that Muslim fundamentalists have infiltrated or taken over public schools, mosques and immigrant organisations and used them for preaching jihad, hatred and violence. Muslim clerics who are banned even in Islamic countries are free to operate and preach in Europe.  This low-intensity jihadism is one contributing factor in radicalisation, and it seems clear that our tolerance and cultural relativism are being abused in a very cynical manner.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the latest Amnesty International report reveals further disturbing contours of the abhorrent terrorist activity carried out by the Islamic State, the jihadist movement which, unfortunately, at the moment also seems to attract too many foreign volunteers. Shocking, for example, the figure for some 3 000 fighters enlisted in isis ranks is European. This is perhaps due to the fact that ISIS considers itself a state and not a movement. A manipulated and corrupt idea of a state that wants to destroy the states that actually exist. It must be made clear that ISIS is not a state, there is no personal element, there is no spatial element, no organizational element. ISIS has no people, no territory and no sovereignty. ISIS is just a machine of death, of terror, but also of propaganda. It posts Hollywood-style internet videos and attracts young Europeans all too easily influenced. This too must be condemned and stopped. Europe must commit itself because when local objectives are achieved, the terrorists will move the action here to us. Jihadists have as much time as they want, as they reason in terms of generations.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, we are all watching with horror and indignation, condemning and doing well, the unprecedented phenomenon of young people from European countries fighting alongside jihadists and even committing crimes that have nothing to do with either europe's culture or customs. But how many of us have wondered why this behaviour occurs. It is a fact that europe's young people no longer grow up with the principles and values that created European culture.  Loving your country is considered nationalism and fascism. Denying the invasion of your country, and in Europe, hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants with different cultural backgrounds from third countries is considered racism. And yet the majority of young Europeans fighting alongside the jihadists are second- and third-generation Muslim immigrants who have been influenced by Islamist propaganda. So if we do not get rid of all these foolish commitments, hesitations and complexes immediately, then we are not going to solve the problem, no matter how repressive measures we take.

name: Frank ENGEL
text: Mr President, there is no doubt that the phenomenon we call the 'Islamic State' is a phenomenon that simply goes against all our convictions. It is a murderous phenomenon, which respects nothing but its narrow and perverse ideology and which opposes the model of civilization that is ours. Therefore, in order to combat those who are leaving to support IS, and to combat this phenomenon, I do not believe that we should begin once again by apologizing for the shortcomings of our societies, insufficient tolerance and understanding, and disengaged young people who need other models, values and orientations. I believe that we must face the truth, namely that many countries, supposedly allies of the European Union, have supported, around us and for decades, and which continue to support all those who destroy and all those who also plan to destroy us from within. I do not agree with Mr Gollnisch and others, who want to focus on non-return. Personally, I would like to focus on non-departure, the reasons for departures and their organisation, because it is not young people who leave Europe with tour operators who sell them package holidays in Syria. These trips are organized by allies of Europe, such as Qatar, and other countries that continue to deny their involvement in the destructive logic that is beginning to surround us and which, in the end, may very well be right about us. You have to look the real opponents in the face.

name: Ana GOMES
text: The recruitment of European jihadists fighting on behalf of the so-called Islamic State, which is not Islamic State, or other terrorist organisations, shows that the challenges to our security and global security depend on the resolution of conflicts in the neighbourhood, particularly in the Middle East, and shows how we need an intelligent and strategic security and defence policy that integrates the external and internal dimensions. Jihadists returning to Europe or those who may still be intercepted here can only be treated with respect for the principles of the states of law, which we are, and specifically in the framework of criminal law, being brought to justice, punished and then, where appropriate, helped to reintegrate socially. Withdrawing passports or nationality, as some wrongly advocate, will not only not solve the problem but it can aggravate and export to the neighbourhood. We must learn from the mistakes of the past in the fight against terrorism. It will not be effective and will not distinguish us from terrorists if it is not carried out in strict respect for fundamental human rights. The so-called foreign fighters are not foreigners, they are in fact European. We need to understand and combat the contexts of social discrimination, unemployment, religious intolerance and other forms of alienation that predispose them to be recruited. In view of the real threat they pose to Europeans and other peoples, the European Union needs to work a strategy that implies substantive means to coordinate the contributions of the intelligence services, but also from the police, judicial, social services, educational agents, community, to programmes to prevent radicalisation and deradicalisation. The fact that we are confronted with European jihadists also reinforces our responsibility to implement an effective common foreign policy that effectively resolves or helps resolve conflicts, reflecting the holistic approach we have talked about so much but we have barely moved on, from Iraq to Syria, through Palestine, Libya, looking at the rest of Africa, North Africa and beyond , and without forgetting so-called countries our allies, such as Saudi Arabia and Qatar, which have been funding and providing the means for recruiting young people around the world for terrorist networks.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: Mr President! The fundamentalist Islamists of the Islamic State pose a huge threat! Not only for those people who are unfortunate enough to be caught up in the terrible situation in Iraq and Syria, but also in Europe. From Denmark alone, it is estimated that more than 100 Islamists have gone to Syria to fight for this terrorist organisation, which is behind terrible crimes. What can we expect when these people want to return to Europe in one way or another? What I fear we can expect is a major terrorist threat that could hit us all. When we don't know, but the potential is there. That is why it is super important that we have control over who enters our countries. Unfortunately, external border controls designed to guarantee Schengen have collapsed. We see Italy, which in large part does not even register the illegal immigrants entering the country. And that is why, until the threat from IS is combated, we must now demand that the national states be allowed to carry out border controls so that we have an effective weapon against terrorism.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr. President! 12,000 fighters from 74 states are fighting and killing in Syria and Iraq. We do not know how many of them actually come from Europe. We do not know how many of them have dual citizenship. They are brutal, murderous and raped, and even disguised Kurds, according to the latest press reports. They are a lasting threat, a threat with European passports. It does not help, Mrs Sippel, to ask, "How could it happen?" It is the ill-advised products of a multicultural society that we, who stand for the identity of the peoples, did not want. How long should they retain dual citizenship? How long should they be able to derive rights from it? Finally, the question: what measures, what protection, are we taking to prevent these people who leave from leaving, day after day, as refugees, as asylum seekers, from returning to Europe to threaten us here?

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, representatives of the Council, I would like to thank the Council for his work and for her work on the Our motto of the Union 'United in Diversity' concerns and includes a credo for national, ethnic and religious tolerance and diversity in Europe. This is also a task for us in Europe, a task to fight fundamentalism and, in particular, Islamist fundamentalism. This is because we can reasonably assume that around 3 000 people with European passports in Iraq and Syria are fighting brutally and hatefully against freedom, tolerance and diversity. In concrete terms, this is an enormous challenge in terms of security policy, and it is today, now, not just tomorrow, to protect our citizens, our families in Europe! If only 10% of these 3 000 Europeans return, then we have hundreds here as ticking time bombs. ISIS is already advertising that acts of terrorism by these fighters bring Islamic glory and glory to them. Here with us! I warmly welcome the decision of EU interior ministers to effectively protect our external borders with enhanced security screening. The fundamental right to ensure the best possible security calls for the advancement of EU security initiatives, such as the targeted evaluation of passenger data. The terrorist who carried out the attack at the Jewish Museum in Brussels travelled from France to IS territory via Turkey and to Europe via Turkey and Frankfurt. This is also where our coalition partner, our coalition partner in the new Commission, must show movement. Because decisive and concrete action is our responsibility. Let us prevent the recruitment of Europeans here with us! Yes, but let us not neglect the external protection of Europe's borders, because that is electoral aid for the populists, who then win many votes in elections.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: Mr President, we have witnessed a surge of young people travelling to join ISIS, many of whom are born and raised in European countries. We must ask why these young people are joining ISIS’s ranks. Some feel targeted and isolated, do not feel understood or valued either by their own communities or by mainstream society. Groups like ISIS can still fill this void by spreading their false narrative using social media tools that young people communicate through, creating a false impression that they are joining a fight for a good cause against oppressive regimes. The current approach of asking families to turn in their own children has failed. Families are lost; we need to help them re-connect with their children through better communication. ISIS is only Islamic in name and not in its actions. We all have our role to play in exposing their false message. The mosques must play their part in achieving this by standing up against ISIS and reaching out more to engage young people. Media must stop its biased coverage, which further devises extreme reactions, and replace it with an alternative, fair account of what the Islamic faith really is. Accounts of Europeans who have faced ISIS atrocities could help build their alternative narrative. It is important that the Middle East countries have joined the coalition in fighting against ISIS. We also need to increase security measures to prevent Europeans travelling to join ISIS. The EU must coordinate achieving these goals and share best practices. It is not enough to merely legislate against these youths, we must win the war too. The war is not led by the West against Muslims, it is the whole world against ISIS.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: Mr President, we are European states of Greco-Latin culture and Judeo-Christian religion. We are also a continent that has welcomed an immigration that has somewhat assimilated in the beginning and which, today, is in the midst of negative assimilation, with the consequences of what we are experiencing today.  Yet, even the European Court of Human Rights had noted, the explicit references to the introduction of Sharia law are incompatible with our values. However, in our neighbourhoods, in our countryside, today, many preachers advocate precisely this radical Islamic law without our politicians ability to appreciate this danger. It is for this reason, moreover, that we, the National Front, in France, have been called an Islamophobic party, when we were simply a party of Islamic-critical democratic vigilance, just as we can, I think, criticise all religions.  If we do not end dual nationality, if we do not abolish the Schengen agreements, if we do not put states like Qatar and Saudi Arabia under severe vigilance, and if we do not follow the United States in all circumstances in external conflicts, I think we will have a bleak future for our states and our continent.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Mr. President, on the one hand thousands and thousands of people want to move into the European Union and achieve dreams of freedom and material prosperity here. On the other hand, young people born in Europe are recruited as fighters for a terrorist organisation that fights against European values itself.  That seems like a paradoxical situation at first glance. I think they are both actually hungry - some are hungry for freedom and material prosperity, and these others are hungry for ideals. I know some will say that European Fighters of the Islamic State are victims of perhaps discrimination, poverty - it certainly helps to recruit them. However, they are not going to the Islamic State to solve their material problems, but, here you see, that Bilal Bosnic, the leader of the Wahhabi movement in Bosnia and Herzegovina who recruited over 100 fighters, said, "We believe that one day the whole world will be the Islamic State." So these distorted ideals, that fanaticism is what led him into this battle. Who instilled that in him and the others? I think in addition to these questions of the intelligence community's affairs, security measures, which are of course necessary, we must also answer certain foreign policy questions. So, we have to ask ourselves the question of whether we know what Saudi Arabia has financed in Bosnia and Herzegovina, right on the border with the European Union. I think it's a legitimate and important issue. Of course we must also strengthen our integration policies, but religious identities are not problems here - in Croatia, a Christian or predominantly Christian country, the Islamic community is well integrated. Sometimes the bigger problem is postmodern arrogance that considers any public expression of faith retrograde. But what matters most: we must strengthen our attachment to our European values of tolerance, the values we must stand for unless we want young people to go into every extremism from populism to, unfortunately, this path leading to the Islamic State.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, there have been a lot of things that have been said here, but Perhaps I would like to clarify one piece of information I have from yesterday from people working in the field of security. Not only 3,000 people are fighting for IS anymore, but three and a half thousand. These are all EU citizens, and I ask: Have we neglected prevention? Maybe we'll win the war in Iraq or Syria. Maybe we can defeat IS, but the problem was here, and it's not going to change. We need to focus on prevention, we need to really draw contemporary Islam into the debate and we need to talk about what to do next. War crimes, ladies and gentlemen, are not war crimes that we know from World War II or World War I. These are images of the present, where people are executed only on suspicion of collaborating with one side or the other. Head-butting, mass shootings, shootings of Christians. Even today, these people have more than 5,000 victims on their hands. And with many of the victims today, we can't even prove what happened to these people. These are crimes that are really very cruel. And I want to end this speech in one word, ladies and gentlemen, it's not just about harsh punishment, it's about prevention. Prevention and discussion with people who want to live in Europe and want to help us build a strong and prosperous Europe. That must be our job.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Thank you, Mr President. Thank you also to Mrs Malmström for her presence here. We have missed her colleague Ashton node in the previous three debates. I thank you very much for the respect you do show to Parliament by being here and discussing these important issues with us. We adopted a resolution just before the summer recess indicating the urgency of the fight against IS in Iraq and Syria. Since we adopted that resolution, more than 1,000 jihadists have left Europe for Syria and Iraq. We must have a coordinated European approach to tackle this problem. As Jean-Claude Juncker rightly said in his speech this morning: IS is an enemy of the values of Europe and IS is an enemy of everything That Europe stands for. The 2013 Council adopted four priorities for such a coordinated approach: prevention, information exchange, criminal justice and cooperation with third countries. I now wonder: what is the state of this approach and have concrete results been achieved? A specific question I would like to ask is about Europol's focal point for travellers. The purpose of this is to exchange and analyse information about suspicious persons who may wish to leave. Are all countries now active in this network? If not, do you believe that participation should be required to ensure the most efficient approach possible? Point two: does this system also apply to returning jihadists? Can we also monitor people returning from Syria and Iraq through a European register in which all countries participate? Finally, I would like to join my colleague Frank Engel: we must fight ISIS in Syria and Iraq, but we must also pay close attention to the reasons on which young people are radicalised in our own Member States and the ways in which organisations are given the space to facilitate and organise travel to Syria and Iraq from our own European countries. Member States must also take responsibility and take important steps on these issues.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: Mr President, the compilation of accurate statistics in relation to the numbers of actual foreign fighters is problematic, due to the secretive nature of those travelling and many of the circuitous routes such individuals take in reaching their destinations; but it is happening and there is no doubt about it. We hear various reports of figures, in their thousands or hundreds, I do not know, but certainly it is happening. The phenomenon of individuals travelling from all over Europe to the fighting has affected the majority of European states and it is one to which Ireland, my own country, gave priority during their recent Presidency of the Union in 2013. In that context, Ireland was successful in gaining the agreement of Member States to carry out a review of the strategy for counteracting radicalisation and recruitment to terrorism. A primary point of focus in this review was the foreign fighter issue, and a number of initiatives have been developed to combat this phenomenon, including: community relations, which I believe are very important; media campaigns; enhanced tracking of movements; engagement with third countries, notably Turkey; and engagement with internet service providers to curb radical on-line content. It is widely accepted that this problem cannot be resolved by security-related measures alone and that a key issue in addressing it is a programme of proactive engagement with the communities affected. Meaningful engagement with these communities is an essential part of the process, in order to avoid any sense of profiling of stigmatisation of sectors of the population. The protection of fundamental rights and recognition from the outset that the majority of people wish to go about their daily lives in peace and to play a productive part in society is enshrined within this engagement. The growth of extremism which we are now witnessing across the reign is a cause of considerable concern, which I know is shared by all of us in this room. The blood lust and inhumanity which ISIS is displaying in Syria and Iraq has shocked and appalled all civilised people. The destruction and displacement of the ancient Christian communities of northern Iraq has been harrowing to witness. All of this taken together harks back to a mentality and a culture which we thought had long been consigned to history. It is a frightening new reality for the world and one which we must address head on.

name: Emil RADEV
text: Unfortunately, there are hundreds of Europeans in the ranks of The Islamic State who reject European values and recognize other, extremist values and norms. To me, this is proof that the terrorist organization has become an idea, hardly a mirage. The question is how to debunk this mirage. One way is through coercive measures that have been talked about lately, such as restricting the right to travel for people suspected of terrorism. Or through the accelerated adoption of the Passenger Information Directive, as called for by the Council. However, these measures must take into account fundamental human rights and the protection of personal data and there must be sufficient guarantees that they will not be misused.  However, the above proposals are short-term solutions to a much deeper problem – a number of Europeans feel excluded from European society and are looking for another opportunity for personal realisation, be it through terrorism. I sincerely believe that in a tolerant and inclusive society, the number of people who want to join terrorist organizations is significantly lower. I also believe that violence can be prevented with more respect for different cultures.   The number of Europeans in the ranks of The Islamic State, to me, is proof that, unfortunately, Europe has a long way to go before the European values enshrined in the fundamental treaties are fully accepted. Until then, however, coercive measures may prove to be the only way to ensure European security.

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: Mr President, when it comes to counter-terrorism, there are three basic pitfalls to avoid. The first is ignorance, and I have heard many approximations this evening in this debate, the second is naivety, and I have also heard a lot of very naïve words, and the third is widespread stigma, of which I have also heard some examples. The phenomenon of European fighters in jihadist movements has always existed. It is not new in itself, but it is new in its scale and the means it uses, that is, the mass communication technologies that are used to convert and radicalize fragile elements of our society. In the face of this extreme threat, terrorist in nature, which plays on the emotional and the spectacular, each institutional level must take its responsibilities. It is not necessarily at the collective level of the European Union that the best solutions lie, we must be aware of this. The June 2013 findings are good conclusions which, I believe, contain a fairly accurate diagnosis of the steps that can and should be taken. However, the main implementation of these measures is the responsibility of the Member States because the pillars of internal security - i.e. intelligence, the police and the judiciary - are the Member States. I do not believe at all in the effectiveness of bureaucratic, hasty and ill-suited European mutualisation. Efficiency depends on better cooperation between the judiciary, the intelligence services and the police, not the establishment of a new bureaucratic European superstructure. In this regard, I wonder, like many experts, about the usefulness of giving Europol a pilot role in this coordination. I do not think that is Europol's job and I believe that the national intelligence services are much better equipped for that. A final word on the responsibility of the European Parliament. Parliament must be more active and expert on these issues and not get lost in completely vague, smoky and naïve theological debates. I believe that we should take responsibility by quickly adopting the NRL because it is one of the tools we have to effectively strengthen the fight against terrorism. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: "blue card" question. "Mr. Danjean, we know each other a little bit. You talk about naivety, because you see the consequences, while I see the causes. The causes lie in a real naivety of the European Union and also, unfortunately, of the government you supported in France. My question is very simple. Do you think it was smart, useful and bold to go after all these Maghreb countries: Tunisia, Libya, Egypt and, in the Middle East, Iraq and Syria? By destabilizing these governments, you have created the causes of your current problem. Unfortunately, I think it's too late and you should have thought about it before. So will you continue to support this American policy of eradicating just those states that maintained stability in the Middle East?

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: "blue card" answer. Mr Ferrand, your question is irrelevant because the debate on the conflict in Syria, on the armed conflicts in Iraq, syria and elsewhere, took place earlier, but you were not present. Right now, we are talking about what needs to be addressed and what needs to be addressed today. I was very concrete in my speech. Now, you're making us smoky releases about American politics. That is not the problem.  As I mentioned in my speech, Mr Ferrand, if you had listened well, the problem of European jihadists existed long before Libya, long before Syria and long before Iraq. This is not the root cause of all problems.  If you would like to know my opinion on Libya and on the destabilization of Arab regimes, I do not agree with all the actions that have been taken. I do not agree with any of that. I think a number of plans have been destabilized when they should not have been destabilized. However, to make these phenomena the only cause... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Mr. President, the statistics point indeed to an alarming rise in the number of fighters originally from the European Union fighting on the battlefields of the Middle East. We are talking about thousands of European Union nationals, reportedly as many as a tenth of the forces of the Islamic State. Most European fighters are members of the first or second generation of immigrants from Africa or Asia. This renews the dilemmas about the success of integration policy, but their failure is by no means a justification for the crimes committed.  The problem is leaving, but of course the same danger is opened by their return from the battlefield. I would also like to mention european fighters who are often left out of statistics. These are citizens of aspirant countries on membership of the European Union and bordering the European Union. This certainly poses a threat to the security of those countries or the entire Union.  In the short term, the Union should certainly coordinate national responses to these security threats. In the long term, a development strategy is needed for the Middle East and North Africa. A military victory against dictators and terrorists alone is never enough, because it is easier to remove the top of the regime or terrorist organization, than the political, economic and social circumstances in which they were held.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Mr. President, according to one study at a University college in London, there are currently about 3,000 foreigners from Western states actively in the ISIS group. The military significance of fighters from the west in Syria and Iraq is not so crucial, as ISIS has more than 10,000 fighters in total. But their departure should worry us, as well as their return to European soil and the potential terrorist activities they are able to carry out.  Here are mentioned numerous measures that we should take, but to date unfortunately we have not taken them. Primarily what is necessary to do in my opinion is to stop trading with the SHEIKHS who fund ISIS and thus allow them to flow money for all their activities. But I would like to warn that crimes against Christians in Iraq and Syria have been going on for 10 years, and the United Nations and the European Union are just noting and doing nothing.  As we debate here, Christian children in Iraq and Syria are crying and claiming the right to childhood. As we argue here, Christian mothers have their children snatched from their arms. While we're discussing this, we're pretending it's not about real people, like it's someone else, when in fact when we were discussing it happened to us, and I think it's time to go from words to deeds.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the ISIS offensive is the most terrible challenge to the West, to its principles, to its values, to all that has contributed positively to the european Union. Little has been done so far, however, in concrete terms other than to act on the emergency front and on the emotional and emotional wave represented by the horrific death sentences carried out blatantly, using the media. Let us look at reality with a lucid analysis, face a common, convinced and compact front, to take up the challenge to our security. Above all, let us develop a European strategy that strangles the phenomenon of the growing conscription of European jihadists, worrying precisely because they are among us and are ready to fight us from within, but above all we stop, we stop overlapping this problem with the very painful problem of immigration, exploiting and bingeingly generalising a tragedy and tens of thousands of deaths, which we kill twice.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Mr President, we can all see what is going on in northern Syria, especially in the town of Kobane, in eastern Syria, as well as in the north-west of Iraq, where the largest Iraqi governorate, al-Anbar, is under the total control of ISIS. How does ISIS make advances despite the air strikes? We see that, each and every day, European Union countries are counting their European citizens leaving Europe to join ISIS. A terrorist organisation that should not have to be named a state; a terrorist organisation which poses a huge threat to the Middle East’s security and stability, to Syria, Iraq and now Lebanon’s territorial integrity and, last but not least, to the security of the whole of the European Union.  European countries should take immediate new tough measures to check and control the threatening situation created by European citizens travelling to the areas of conflict in the Middle East to join ISIS and then coming back to Europe with military training, well-trained in terrorist tactics and actions. Cooperation with Turkey has to be increased as well, in order to strengthen its control of the borders with Iraq and Syria, to prevent and stop potential ISIS fighters joining the areas of conflict and to identify European ISIS fighters trying to return to Europe. We need to see increased cooperation between the Schengen states and Romania and Bulgaria, candidate countries to the Schengen Agreement, in order to take immediate, specific measures to more closely identify and monitor people travelling to Turkey through south-eastern European countries and, of course, suspect people coming back to the European area.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: Mr President, on the issue of ISIS foreign fighters, I would like to point to the situation in our close neighbourhood, the Western Balkans. Between 200 and 600 fighters from Bosnia, Serbia and Kosovo have travelled to Syria since 2012. It is important to say that the home nations of these fighters are taking this issue seriously. Bosnia has passed a law that throws convicted Islamist recruiters into prison for up to ten years. Kosovo has arrested 55 Islamists and Serbia has charged five jihadists. All these countries are considering strengthening their entire terrorism law. We Member States should speak with one voice on this issue and also closely cooperate with our neighbours. We could work more effectively and get better results.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: There is no doubt that the presence of thousands of fighters with European passports in Syria today is a huge problem. It is a problem above all of Western societies. At the heart of this problem is too long patience, too much tolerance, which over the years has allowed people with radical views to preach unhindered in the very heart of Europe; people who do not share our values to impose their values on us. It is time, and it is right as European societies, as national governments, as the European Parliament and as a Commission, to rethink this position, to choose whether we will protect our borders and our citizens, or let these people do whatever they want with our countries. What needs to be known is that these people do not organize themselves. What needs to be known is that the Republic of Turkey is organising illegal fighters towards Syria and vice versa towards Europe. This behaviour of the Republic of Turkey is extremely harmful and dangerous in the first place for Bulgaria, hence the entire European Union, and we need to consider whether this country deserves to be a candidate member and member of the European Union.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, we should all admit that we are facing a very complex problem and that there are no easy answers or solutions here. It is also, as has been said, not a new phenomenon. We have all seen the horrors that are committed in Syria and Iraq by ISIS and other groups. Decapitation, rape and murder of innocent civilians: children, women, men, journalists, health workers. This is terrorism and barbarism. It is clear that it has nothing to do with Islam, and a huge majority of Muslims all over the world are condemning it.  But we do have Europeans travelling to fight with these groups and this is a problem. They commit terrible acts there and they can do us a lot of harm when and if they come home – and by the way there are no indications whatsoever that they come to Europe as asylum seekers. This is false.  We need to create police cooperation, intelligence sharing and in fact we are setting up different platforms where they can share information. From what I hear this is going well, especially amongst the most concerned eight or nine states, but more and more countries in the European Union are concerned about this right now. It would be helpful to have a PNR and I think a system could be set up that is robust when it comes to data protection but still serves its purpose. We can use SIS and border control measures much more efficiently. They allow for a lot of things to be done today, and Member States should make full use of them.  We also need to cooperate more on the preventive side. Local communities, religious leaders, teachers, civil society can play a very important role at local level to identify young people, young men – and women: increasingly there are also young girls travelling to fight – to identify them and prevent them from going when it is possible. We have more than 1 000 experts from all over Europe connected to the RAN network, the Radicalisation Awareness Network, and they can help Member States with advice, setting up local action plans, setting up exit programmes, and advising on how to put up centres where worried families can call: Where do I call if I am worried that my son or my brother is planning to go away? There have to be structures from this and we can share a lot of information and good practices here. Of course, integration and social exclusion need to be given further attention here so we can combat exclusion and ensure that European citizens do not feel the need to leave. We also need, of course, to respect human rights and avoid stigmatisation of certain groups. So we need to act on several fronts, but it would be a severe mistake not to admit that this is a very serious phenomenon.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, very few concluding remarks. Firstly, to tell Parliament that the Council is counting on Parliament's support in the work to prevent young people leaving Europe from 1ing join terrorist groups in Syria and Iraq, to reassure us that they can identify foreign fighters who want to attack our societies and to bring to justice those who have broken our laws. Let us do so, but at the same time we guarantee and defend our common values and the fundamental rights, freedom of movement and freedom of expression that we have dear. We are making progress in a number of areas and we hope to be able to say as soon as – and I come back to a point I raised in my introductory speech – that we can say the same about the progress of the European Union PNR dossier with parliament's support.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council statement, a joint police operation 'Mos Maiorum'.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for this opportunity to present the initiative launched by the Italian Presidency aimed at hindering the flow of illegal immigration, one of the elements.  This joint police operation, known as "Mos Maiorum", is underway from 13 to 26 October 2014. It is the latest in a long line of similar initiatives, in fact the sixth operation of its kind, organised by successive presidencies, since operation Hermes, under the Belgian Presidency, took place in October 2010. Mos Maiorum was prepared on the basis of the guidelines contained in the 2010 Joint Police Operations Guide. The aim of the guide was to implement the Stockholm Programme which, as you know, was partly intended to improve security within the European Union and to combat organised crime. The main objective of 'Mos Maiorum' is to gather information from participating Member States and schengen associated countries in order to weaken the capacity of organised crime to facilitate illegal immigration to the European Union. 'Mos Maiorum' aims to identify the modus operandi used by criminal networks to illegally bring their victims into EU territory and to identify the link between the illegal crossing of the Eu ropean Union's external borders and illegal migration within the Schengen area. These objectives can best be achieved through the exchange of relevant data at EU level and the introduction of a more efficient and comprehensive information sharing model. The implementation of this joint operation does not imply, for the participating States, any deviation from any aspect of the EU acquis with regard to migration flows and the guarantees it provides to the persons concerned. Similarly, the operation has no negative effect on the reception capacity of Italy or any other participating State. In addition, the rules of conduct of the operation clearly provide for all relevant activities to be carried out with full respect for human dignity and human rights, with due particular attention to vulnerable groups. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I hope that this brief presentation has helped to clarify the context of the operation, which aims to dismantle illegal criminal networks that seek economic profit by putting the lives of innocent people at risk. Thank you for your attention.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, as Roman law was collected, the 'mos maiorum' is the custom of the ancestors, a symbol of moral integrity and a set of rules and precepts which the Roman citizen had to respect. Europe is, from its origins, a defence of the rule of law and it must remain so. Immigration must be a matter of state regardless of ideologies or governments. The 'Mos Maiorum' operation, coordinated by the Italian Ministry of the Interior and in which all Member States and Schengen partners can voluntarily participate, must pursue a few objectives to which the Presidency of the Council has already referred, but essentially identify, prosecute and disarm organised crime groups; detect irregular immigrants and gather relevant information for research and intelligence purposes; give a clear and up-to-date picture of the situation in relation to human trafficking operations, its modus operandi, the main trends and possible changes they may undergo, as well as developing joint measures to achieve an impact on irregular immigration, especially on its side of border controls and border surveillance activities. In my view, "Mos Maiorum" should not be understood ely as persecution or as a massive raid of irregular immigrants, but as a real persecution against mafias dealing human beings. Applicable protocols and actions must be produced regardless of the political moment and with a continuity that guarantees its success. This continuity in border control policy can be reflected in the fact that the template to be used by Italians to report on the operational results achieved is similar, if not the same, to that already used in previous operations: the Belgian one, in October 2010; Hungarian "Mitras", in April 2011; Denmark's "Balder" in April 2012; "Aphrodite" and "Perkunas" of Cyprus in October 2013. All these operations have, of course, been involved in respect for human rights. Europe is a territory in which the rule of law must govern. We must worry about preventing deaths and abuses at our borders and, in turn, facilitating the entry and legal defense of those who need our protection. Hence the importance of developing joint and cross-cutting actions at European and Member State level, as well as with countries of origin and transit. We must develop the ambitious proposals contained in the Smart Borders Package and even consider ourselves, Mr President, definitively reforming and strengthening Frontex's capabilities.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Two weeks ago, a description of the mos e-mail operation "Mos Maiorum" was published. The debate on this has been very controversial ever since. Of course, we need police cooperation at European level, and we must also combat smuggling gangs. There are similar actions such as 'Mos Maiorum', as we have heard, regularly under the various presidencies, albeit under different names. However, it is not acceptable for police cooperation to remain our only response to the current refugee dramas – but the impression is once again created. I would like to see more political ambition on the part of the Member States and, above all, a clear commitment to human rights, to the right of asylum, rather than always referring unilaterally to problems. We must observe how 'Mos Maiorum' is implemented in the individual Member States. It is unacceptable that migrants should be stigmatised, criminalised or even traumatised by police. Just last week, we saw police brutally beat up an immigrant on the Spanish border with Melilla. We could not be sure whether he died. In view of the current challenges, we must also once again address the issue of the distribution of asylum seekers in the EU. After all, 'Mos Maiorum' is not just about combating organised crime, it is also about recording so-called secondary migration movements – in other words, specifically asylum seekers who do not apply in the country of arrival, as Dublin actually provides. My own country, Germany, has complained regularly recently that other Member States are not taking their task seriously and would just forward refugees to the north. However, if we now conclude that Dublin III is overburdening the states at the external borders, then we must also come to the conclusion that Dublin is not an adequate response to the challenges. We must distribute vulnerable people fairly in Europe. To do this, we need a distribution key, for example based on the size and economic strength of a Member State, in order to clarify how many asylum seekers each state receives. In the medium and long term, however, we must also find other answers. We need safe routes to Europe, because those that are supposedly illegal are only illegal, because there are hardly any legal ways for refugees to reach European borders, European states at all. We certainly need other legal immigration opportunities for those who are not persecuted but want to work with us. Finally, we must also seriously examine the influence of trade, energy and development policies of the EU and The Member States on third countries, for example, and to what extent we ourselves are also partly responsible for the causes of migration.

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, safe and secure borders are essential for Europe, but undocumented migrants are subject to exploitation, particularly those that are vulnerable and those that are children. Irregular migration fuels human trafficking, modern slavery and child exploitation. This is certainly not the first operation of its kind, but I must highlight that it is almost impossible to have a coherent European approach to immigration – or at the very least good cooperation between our institutions – without communicating with us and without having the respect to at least inform us what is happening. I have read justifications for the secrecy surrounding this operation; many of them sound logical enough, but we are in an elected assembly with co-decision powers and a role in the appointment of the directors and allocation of the budgets of European agencies. When operations are undertaken in a way which is secret from this Parliament, then the obvious conclusion is that something is wrong. The most essential element of any immigration policy is trust by the people of Europe. I believe in a fair but firm immigration system, but I also believe in one which follows the rules, where correct rights are applied and procedures are followed. I would therefore like to ask the Commission and the Council if this is the case in this matter. Such operations should not be interpreted as intimidating to those who genuinely seek asylum and, most of all, the safety and welfare of any child must be at the forefront of our minds in such operations.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. – The hunt for immigrants carried out by Operation Mos Maiorum between 13 and 26 October involving around 20 000 police officers is the clear response of persecution, violation of rights and discrimination to which the European Union has accustomed us when it comes to unwanted immigrants. It insists on the scandalous strengthening of the EU's security and criminalising policy, which treats these people in a totally dehumanised way, when what would be needed was the development of social and fair policies of reception and social integration, as well as the end of interference and conflict-making, of which the EU is responsible, in many of the countries of origin of these immigrants. It's ironic that This is the institution that won the Nobel Peace Prize.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: We are now continuing our debate on the Council statement on the joint police operation 'Mos Maiorum' (2014/2902(RSP)).

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: On the other: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The Council of Ministers has now announced that the purpose of Mos Maiorum is to map irregular migrants, i.e. undocumented people who are in the EU, and in this way it says it wants to get to the criminal networks involved in people smuggling and take huge sums for a place in a crowded, unseaworthy boat that travels across the Mediterranean from North Africa to Europe. This sounds very good, and of course these criminal networks should be stopped! But chasing undocumented people is tackling the problem at the wrong end. As a result, it is the undocumented refugee, or migrant seeking a job, rather than the criminal networks that are in trouble. Simply because the criminal networks and traffickers exist and operate in the Middle East and North Africa, and thus they are outside the field of operation and the scope of Mos Maiorum.  For many people, as Mr Sippel has said, it is that the traffickers are the only desperate opportunity for people to come to Europe, because there are no legal means. Instead of investing in massive deportations of undocumented people, we must now do more to strengthen the legal ways of coming to europe, such as labour migrants, students, researchers, or workers. We must also take our asylum responsibilities seriously. If you eliminate the business idea of people smugglers and instead create legal and safe roads, then we will succeed.
