But then we need to harmonise rules and simplify the rules so that we can welcome overseas workers in a dignified way. With regard to Mr Maiorum, I call for democratic transparency and call for us to be able to check that fundamental rights are respected. There is much to be said, but this operation should be terminated.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Mos Maiorum is a disgrace! Spending resources on chasing undocumented people when we are facing a refugee disaster and 3 000 people have died in the Mediterranean – one of the most dangerous escape routes on the way to Europe. Smuggling networks and organised crime are identified much more effectively in other ways. There is already a developed cooperation for this. Mr Maiorum is a wrong priority, and it shows that we have a fundamental problem. The problem is racism, xenophobia and nationalism. We all know that the hunt for undocumented people is based on the appearance and colour of our public transport, on trains, subways and trams. By doing so, we are further reinforcing racism and intolerance. We create a we and them. That is not acceptable. Our voters want to live in a Europe that stands up for human rights, and offers protection to people who seek it. Our voters look with admiration at Italy's Mare Nostrum, the great effort that Italy has all itself taken the initiative to save lives in the Mediterranean. We also shame that no other Member State is contributing as they should. I believe that the people of Europe do not want a hunt for undocumented people. The people of Europe want a Mare Nostrum plus, and words are no longer enough. We must move from words to deeds. We will have legal ways to get into Europe. We are going to support Italy's Mare Nostrum life-saving effort so that it is not closed this winter, and we are going to abolish the Dublin Regulation.

name: Ska KELLER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Everywhere in Europe, especially in Europe, people who look somehow different are controlled and discriminated against. They are controlled because the Member States want to catch irregular people and criminals. But the people who actually hold them are very often people who need international protection. They certainly don't find really dangerous people, criminals, organised criminals. If they really want to do something about organised crime, then perhaps they should use their limited resources more efficiently and not in such a mass action, which is still very difficult to reconcile with the Schengen Code. People are discriminated against by "Mos Maiorum" because the police pick out people who look different by some definition. This ethnic profiling has already been massively challenged by various court rulings. Now the UNHCR has once again shown the red card to ethnic profiling. How do you, as the Presidency, as the Member States, intend to ensure that the principle of non-discrimination is respected here too? How do you intend to ensure respect for human rights? And how do you intend to ensure – as has already been mentioned – that Parliament is informed in the future? That we do not depend on leaks, but that you come by yourself without us having to ask you, and say: we have something in front of us, what do you say about it? That is what I would hope for from a Presidency of the Council. "Mos Maiorum" not only has a name from days gone by, a name that does not fit at all on such actions, which does not fit at all into the current situation and time, but "Mos Maiorum" also adheres to a completely outdated ideology. Europe can do without this very well!

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, operation Mos Maiorum's police approach to immigration problems, based solely on the anti-crime aspect of trafficking in human beings, free from concrete action in the countries of origin and transit, will not stop the flight, even at the cost of life, of conflicts, persecution and misery in countries close to the European Union.  The irregular migration phenomenon to Europe is also fuelled by the absence of legal channels of entry and by the Dublin Regulation, which imposes too heavy a burden on countries that are subject to the migration emergency more than others.  The Dublin system induces asylum seekers to rely on illegal networks to reach the desired European destinations, even when they would be eligible for international protection in any Member State, since they cannot choose the country to apply for international protection. Almost semi-colonial exploitation and war industries that contribute directly or indirectly to conflicts and miseries, do the rest.  Border and entry states in Europe, such as Italy or Greece, are facing a structural emergency that requires a huge waste of resources and which, we repeat, cannot be curbed by an exceptional police operation such as 'Mos Maiorum'.  It is, moreover, an operation that risks unwittingly fuelling the business of immigrant reception and detention centres, which are increasingly at the centre of organised crime interests and unscrupulous businessmen. This is, I would like to stress, a business on which attention must be paid, not least because it feeds on the skin of human beings, migrants, who often risk falling victim to violations of their fundamental rights. In short, 'Mos Maiorum', in our opinion, is in danger of being a mere media operation, made up of numbers and statistics to be fed to the public, which will not help to solve the problems of irregular immigration and whose costs will, once again, be a cost to the taxpayers of the Member States. I would therefore like to ask whether the Council really believes that an identification and registration operation can contribute to the fight against trafficking in human beings? What if, intellectually honestly, it would not be more cost-effective to provide for ex ante solutions, revisiting the Dublin Regulation, making up for the regulatory vulnus and providing for legal channels of access to the European Union?

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, why is the Italian Presidency proposing this programme? It is very simple, because the other countries have become alarmed. Because the consequence of Mare Nostrum, which opened its doors to 140 000 people, at least half of whom were not traced, has filled Europe with new illegal immigrants. Europe is worried.  It is right to identify those who have entered Europe illegally, but are not mentioned here in the 'Mos Maiorum' programme specifically either the methods or the means, and therefore how this action will take place? Very difficult, very problematic. I'd say it's pure propaganda. It is grotesque that the European Union, having opened its doors to anyone, to mass immigration, should now present us with a police control programme when hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants have entered. Because we are not going to tell the citizens: that through Mare Nostrum at least 70,000 of the 140,000 who have entered the last year have not been traced. We do not know who they are, where they come from, what their criminal records are and also the hygiene and health conditions, in the midst of the Ebola tragedy, which should also worry us about the conditions of those who have entered, even the illegals themselves. Italy therefore proposes a 10-day program when every day they come in and out and we do not know who they are. Italy welcomes thousands of illegal immigrants every day, but has failed to track those who have landed and are welcomed by Italian navy ships and are welcomed into three-star hotels, except perhaps refusing reception. It's pure propaganda and it's very serious especially with the Ebola crisis and alarm.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Madam President, dear colleagues! I would like to begin by saying that I would like to distance myself very clearly from Mr Borghezio on behalf of many people in this House. The right to asylum is a right that we share across party lines, and 'Mos Maiorum' has nothing to do with an attack on the right to asylum. And to put Ebola and refugees in one mouth is simply outrageous to me. (Applause) I am so outraged that I have to let my anger go a little bit. There are political differences of opinion here on factual issues, but this is simply real racism, and in pure nature. We do not want to hear that in this Parliament, nor do we want to see it. I believe that measures such as 'Mos Maiorum' are necessary. However, like Thimothy Kirkhope, I think it is necessary that it would have been better to inform us precisely, because then many misunderstandings would not have arisen, which are now appearing in the public debate. I know that border guards and also police authorities have an extremely difficult task in fulfilling their mandate in the fight against organised crime, since the traffickers have a great deal of financial resources and excellent logistics, and do not shy away from any crime in order to obtain financial and criminal advantages for themselves through trafficking in people. That is why such measures are necessary, even if we would prefer them not to be carried out. However, I would also be equally pleased if, in the context of the fact that we want to better manage refugee flows and not hand them over to organised crime, we would agree as quickly as possible on the possibilities of improved governance, including through legal means, in order to potentially support, in addition to the vehement fight against organised crime, which, as I have said, I support 100% of the risk of organised crime. , also to take away substance, so to speak, by reinforcing legal channels by resettlement and by other methods. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Hohlmeier, you said that this police action was necessary. My question is: do you believe that this will actually solve the migration problem? And do you think it is appropriate to carry out such a measure now, when, on the other hand, people are actually dying at the EU's external borders and that rescue and search operations are actually needed?

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Firstly, 'Mos Maiorum' was created not to solve the migration problem, but to combat organised crime. These are two completely different things. Nobody wants to solve the right of asylum or any question of migration with "Mos Maiorum", because it cannot be solved. This is not the appropriate operation. Secondly, Frontex also has the task of saving people in particular. We have decided this together. Unfortunately, however, we are getting into a dilemma a little bit, because the criminals are trying to exploit it. In other words, our good will is partly exploited. I want to hunt down criminals and save people. That may connect us.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I must begin my speech by trying to make it clear, in my opinion, how serious it is that in this House we can hear such populist words spoken by Mr Borghezio, about the wrong associations and, in my opinion, speeches like this in this Parliament must not exist, because these are speeches that accentuate what discrimination is all about. , what racism is and increase fear within the population by creating false associations. I therefore disassocie myself and ask that words such as these should never be uttered in here, because this House is a Chamber of democracy. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the aims of 'Mos Maiorum', the weakening of the organisational capacity of organised crime and the aiding of illegal immigration, have also emerged very eloquently in this debate. This is a well-established practice, as we have just heard, in an attempt to monitor, collect and analyse information on migratory movements with the ultimate aim of combating traffickers. I do not want to dwell very much on this, but I would rather stress my concerns about the very reason why the Eu ropean Union is taking measures such as 'Mos Maiorum', a deployment of 18 000 law enforcement officers, a gigantic police operation aimed at stopping, controlling , – I insist – and identifying the largest number of migrants present on European territory. But there is a real need for such a deployment for a fight against traffickers that happens once in a while "every time". The risk of these operations being carried out by a presumption of guilt or the danger of migrants is high, as are the risks of weakening the fundamental principle of the free movement of persons within the Schengen area. The external borders of the European Union are the responsibility of all its Member States, in application of the principle of solidarity and the protection of asylum seekers here on the basis of values shared by us cannot be the responsibility of individual governments. We will evaluate and ask for a careful assessment of the results of this operation, and in this regard I call on the Council to present them and share them with this Parliament.  Operation "Mos Maiorum" must give rise to a new reflection on new policies that are not limited to dealing with the emergency of flows, but must lead to a single policy of solidarity, reception and integration.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Dear Sir, Minister Della Vedova, like previous operations, Mos Maiorum is more than just border control. The main objective is to properly trace the illegal people smugglers or people smuggling in order to identify organised crime. I can understand that. Knowledge about the facts gives the possibility to respond more adequately. But Above all, I am left with questions about the legal basis for and practical implementation of this operation. Frontex will only play a marginal role and this Parliament will not be given any information on what will happen to any people arrested. Are there going to be collective evictions? Nor is it clear whether there is a link with the European plans on 'smart borders' in which Frontex will play an important role. I am also surprised that the monitoring and detection of migrant flows is not followed up more systematically, but is apparently based on ad hoc operations such as these. In short, I would like to hear this operation be reconciled with a coherent and efficient migration policy at EU level. I would like to thank the Council for the answers.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Minister Della Vedova did not convince me, I am not convinced by the absurd word "Mos Maiorum". The operation was proposed by the Italian Presidency to its European partners on 10 July in a Council of Interior Ministers, the aim of the operation to eradicate the trafficking of migrants. The result, if we have any imagination, is that fugitives are being pushed more than ever into addiction to criminal networks. When migrants are identified, profiled, I don't know how not to talk about reta. In the meantime, we have learned that italian law enforcement agencies are being charged, as part of similar operations, with identifying undocumented migrants by violence. Circular information notes that we have, of the Ministry of the Interior, order the Italian police to proceed, and I will say: 'the acquisition of photos and fingerprints even with the use of force if necessary'. "Mos Maiorum" is therefore part of a now systemic violence which I call to account to the Council and the Italian Presidency.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul I would like to ask the Representative of the Council here a question if Mr Maiorum is not starting at the wrong end. Because if it is the case that the project, at least according to the Swedish police, is not aimed at chasing the undocumented, but is aimed at finding and combating the traffickers, then I wonder whether we should not really talk about why the traffickers exist. I am convinced that they exist because we have created them by closing our borders. Our closed borders are feeding the industry that the traffickers actually are. Those affected are the people who, for various reasons, have had to leave their homes. It can be because of war, oppression, poverty, conflicts and more. The vast majority of those who come here do not do it because they want to, but they do it because they have to. The only way to get rid of these people smugglers is to open the borders. We must have legal means, both for those fleeing war and for those fleeing poverty. Mos Maiorum is an unworthy way of tackling this problem.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Blue card question. Mr Spinelli, you have done something very, very serious, to the Italian Presidency. So if you have proof that the Italian Government is instructing you to use violence against migrants, use the legal means to do so, because that would be very serious for democracy in Italy. If you do not have them, please do not use politically the desperate fate of undocumented migrants in Europe. Thank you

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Answer to a blue card question. Thank you for giving me the opportunity to specify that I have documents in my hand and that I would like to ask the Commission whether infringement proceedings should not be initiated against such transactions and, on this occasion, I will provide the documents I have mentioned.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: Madam President, this initiative’s purported objectives are to apprehend illegal migrants, gather intelligence and combat the organised crime gangs that trade in people. That is all very well, but migrants stream in from Africa, the Middle East and beyond for a variety of reasons: poverty, oppression and most lately the result of some Islamic countries descending into a form of fundamentalist barbarism. These varied causes need a concerted and coherent foreign policy response by the countries of NATO and the West if we are to do anything to alleviate them.  One of the main reasons that migrants flood to Europe from all corners of the world is the EU’s open borders policy, because once in one European country it is easy for them to make their way to their European country of choice, and in many cases the migrants’ country of choice is the United Kingdom. We only have to look at the chaos and anarchy in Calais where thousands of illegal immigrants daily fight to gain entry to Britain after having travelled across Europe to do so.  We need genuine cooperation among nation states to address the root causes of mass migration and to police our borders, but while we still have an open borders policy in Europe these efforts will be in vain. Britain’s priority should be to regain control of our borders by leaving the European Union. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: "blue card" question. Mr Batten, I am French and I am very familiar with the situation in Calais. I don't think there's any point in throwing up numbers or semblance of numbers. Do you know how many people there are in Calais? Do you know who those thousands of people you suspect are?  I would like a precise answer, because when you throw figures in the Chamber, you cannot afford to say anything and everything. This fuels hatreds and fears, as well as the Islamism you condemn, like all of us.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: blue-card answer. – I am sorry, on the news bulletins for the last few years we have seen hordes and hordes of people in Calais trying to get through to Britain by hiding themselves in vans, in lorries, in anything that they can get into, so there are literally thousands, tens of thousands, of people that have come by that route and are still trying to do so. Also, I do not understand why you would not want me to condemn a form of Islamic fundamentalism which is butchering people and persecuting people of all religions and driving them out of the Middle East.  Are you in favour of that? I certainly am not and I do not know any civilised person who would be.

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: Mr President, because of the European Union's bankrupt immigration policy, no one really knows exactly how many illegal immigrants are in the European Union. Estimates range from 150 000 to 450 000 people. The European Union is responsible for this. The European Union facilitates people smugglers and thus life-threatening crossings in rickety boats because Frontex does not act as border security but as a shuttle service. Immigrants are taken from the sea and taken to European soil instead of back to their country of origin. Once on European soil, they disappear, only to reappeer and apply for asylum miles away within the Schengen area, for example in the Netherlands. The Operation Mos Maiorum is therefore mopping with the tap open. This operation demonstrates all the more the failure of this policy and the need to return jurisdiction over asylum and immigration to the Member States. This is the only way that anything can really be done to control this constant flow of immigration. Give the Member States back their powers over their own borders and bet on reception in the region.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Madam President, the aim of the joint police operation is to fight criminals, smugglers and traffickers. It is not to fight migrants. We are facing very sophisticated, natural organised crime that exploits migrants and brings them to Europe under inhumane conditions. Therefore, I support cross-border cooperation of our security forces to combat the slave trade of our time. Why? Because it operates across borders. We cannot on the one hand be outraged that people are dying in the Mediterranean and on the other hand criticise Europe when we start operations to fight the traffickers.  Of course border police need to check the borders, the external borders of the European Union, and of course we need to interview the migrants too, because they might have relevant information to combat the perpetrators, to identify them – the roots, the methods, how they are paid.  What is important for me is that these police operations are conducted in full respect of fundamental rights and in accordance with EU and international law. Migrants should not be pushed back, in accordance with the principle of non-refoulement. They should be given the possibility of applying for asylum if they think they need international protection. Children especially should be interviewed by someone trained in children’s rights, without a uniform and in a language that they can understand. Police need to share information with each other, because otherwise they will not be able to be effective in combating international crimes. But they should fully respect data protection rules.  Any act of discrimination based on nationality or ethnicity is in violation of European values and laws and it should be treated as such by the Member States. But we cannot put everything in the same box. This is not about migration policy. We have a dramatic humanitarian situation. We need to implement the Asylum Package, we need to have sharing of responsibility among the Member States, we need to create more legal ways to the European Union. But this goes hand in hand with combating organised crime.  I also think, as my colleague Mr Kirkhope and others have said, that full transparency is necessary in this operation, and democratic control. I really do hope that the Italian Presidency will be able to tell us more. I welcome the fact that they have already announced that they will announce the results of this operation in December.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we know little or nothing about Operation Mos Maiorum. What we know, however, is rather worrying, starting from the name, "Mos Maiorum", which evokes the idea of superiority, of the Roman virtus to be affixed to those who come from outside, to the breeds considered inferior. As soon as we heard about the operation, we proposed a question to the Council with some colleagues asking for clarity: clarity on the objectives and how this operation will be carried out, which appears to involve some 18 000 policemen. It is not clear, and this is what I am asking you to report back to Parliament, what frontex's involvement will be and what confusion has been made of it. It is unclear what will happen to the people identified and questioned shortly afterwards. It is not clear what guarantees there are on respect for their fundamental rights, including asylum seekers. It is an operation that seems to be the result of the usual seuritarian logic that in recent years has not only failed to achieve anything, but has made the situation worse, often result in open violations of human rights and the prohibition of collective refoulement enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union and other conventions. A logic that tends to criminalise victims rather than target executioners. We must not forget that the majority of people travelling to Europe are now fleeing war theatres, torture and discrimination of all kinds, and that it is international law that establishes our legal duty, not just our moral duty, to offer international protection. In Europe, with 'Mos Maiorum' we have unclear police operations in common, in Europe we have a cemetery in common: to this has now been reduced our Mediterranean Sea, which is a European sea. But how long will we have to wait to have a genuine European asylum policy in common? And to see Europe focus not only on combating illegal immigration, as it has done so far, but also on creating legal access routes? There is only one way to combat traffickers and organised crime, certainly not to round up migrants in Europe and certainly not to set back the line of intervention as will happen with Triton from 172 miles just 30 miles from Italian territorial waters, if mare Nostrum is renounced. The only way to combat traffickers is to prevent migrants from ending up in their hands, anticipating our intervention, for example by opening humanitarian channels for legal and refugee-protected arrival, or at least safe havens in which to seek asylum in transit countries with the involvement of international organisations. And if we really want to tackle the root of the problem, Europe should take on a ruthless fight against inequality on a global scale, in a world where 70% of resources are in the hands of 30% of the population and we are part of that 30%, I wonder how we can be surprised at migratory flows.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: Madam President! I am afraid that the operation we have been discussing for some time now in this Chamber is only futile symptom treatment. We can already see flyers being shared around these illegal migrant environments, warning against the operation. And that is perfectly understandable, because it seems, most of all, as if the operation is designed as a somewhat warped attempt by the Member States to stem the challenge posed by illegal migration in Europe. What should really have been done was to have effective border controls, an orderly migration policy, a refugee policy that was aimed at helping as many resources as possible for the resources available, that is, helping people in the immediate areas, but now we are resorting to this because you have no other tools left in the toolbox. For me to see is the best way and the most effective way. That, instead of such a police pat-off, national border controls will be reintroduced until external border controls may one day work, and that must be the call that comes from me to this House today.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Madam President! "Mos Maiorum", the custom of the ancestors, may have had at least a power-political meaning in ancient Rome. The state-loyal Cato saw the stability of the giant empire as assured of making Roman legal norms and unilateral fidelity compulsory. With this questionable custom of the ancestors, they drove well for a while, until the shop flew apart and Rome broke up. If the rude police action in 25 Member States is now called 'Mos Maiorum', this is a bad example and, on top of that, a false analogy, because 'Mos Maiorum' in ancient Rome also included the principle of justice. This police action has nothing to do with justice. Driven by blind racism and contempt for human beings, this action is in the smell of completely different terms such as keeping in, cleaning, removing, pushing away, deporting. Refugees are seen by those in power as a threat, disruptive, insecure, annoying, expensive, harmful. That is the spirit. The mendacious gestures of regret about the dead refugees in the Mediterranean are not followed by justice, with the 25 Member States coming together to save lives, but the cleansing of 'Mos Maiorum'. On the basis of Cato, I would like to say that I am of the opinion that such customs of the ancestors must be destroyed.

name: Karima DELLI
text: Madam President, I too am angry. Right now, all over Europe, police are hunting for migrants! This operation, called "Mos Maiorum", aims to learn more about the new routes used by smugglers. But who are we kidding? Do you really believe that we can fight human trafficking by attacking their victims? In truth, this operation is a European-wide hunt. Who decided it? On what criteria? No one knows. The European Parliament should be the first to discuss this. What happens to those arrested? In Greece and Hungary, they are put in prison. Is this European policy? A year after Lampedusa? What is happening today is a disgrace to Europe! These migrants are mostly refugees, they are fleeing their country of origin because they are at risk. They end up in precarious conditions, as is the case in Calais. Tomorrow there will be even more, there will be climate refugees! I say this very quietly to the Italian Presidency: we will not solve the misery of the peoples with kepis and batons on every street corner. Today, it is high time to put in place a dignified European migration policy, based on fundamental rights but, above all, on solidarity.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Madam President, I think that those who confuse the terms 'mare nostrum' and 'mos maiorum' - I like to think it is not done deliberately - must understand that they are two completely different companies. Are we going to ignore the fact that the rescue operation called 'mare nostrum', just for a summer, saved 5,000 people in Italy for a fortnight, or are we going to ignore the fact that in the first half of 2014 6,500,000 people were rescued on the coast of my country, Greece, through a total of 15,000 people crossing the sea border? I say this because by demonizing a new business, I believe that we do not serve its purpose unless we have arguments to criticize with evidence and evidence.  And I say this because none of us here in this Chamber believe that there is an operation on the initiative of Italy, operation 'mos maiorum' whose sole objective and purpose is to dismantle the traffickers of these people, may or may not have distanced itself from methods of racist shades or from a violation of human rights. This will undoubtedly permeate this operation and if this is not the case here we are, after the results which will be published in December, to criticise. But it is or is not necessary to control these traffickers who are members of an international organised crime and we must know that the victims are not only immigrants, they are people of all ages and especially young people, because the majority of these traffickers are criminal organisations which are trafficking in human beings, arms trafficking, drug trafficking, organ trafficking. Organised crime, which also finds ground and application to these traffickers, is absolutely dangerous and must somehow be controlled.  In any case, to say that the road to combating illegal immigration goes through a European compact policy that defines and shields legal immigration, this is also the beginning of the new President Juncker, that is what the new Commissioner Avramopoulos has heard him stress. In any case, we are talking about a Europe which has always been characterised by humanism and the worthy content of its philosophy. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 149(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Blue card question. I would like to ask my colleague whether she has read the resolution of the Council of Interior Ministers announcing this operation 'Mos Maiorum'. There is no need to wait until December, it is very clear what is written, it is not an anti-Mafia operation, it is an operation in which migrants and fugitives are searched, identified, profiled. I would just like to ask you whether you have read the text or whether you are waiting until December to meet it?

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, Mrs Spinelli, you are addressing a colleague of yours who has been a forensic lawyer for thirty years. So I will tell you that yes, I have read this document to which you refer and I will tell you that I have learned to judge by the result and to judge - and very harshly - when in advance I do not have those samples which scare and demonise a new measure which is in the right direction.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Madam President, under the bombastic expression 'Mos Maiorum' there is a police operation which takes place not for the first time. An operation in which the Governments of the Member States of the European Union, not all, agree to put in place an identification which points more to victims of the illicit trafficking of persons than to the mafias behind them and therefore nothing should be objected to because, in principle, it is a legitimate operation of the Council within its competences.  It happens, however, that it causes concern, and for good reasons. Firstly, because the Socialists have been invariably denouncing the prejudged and sesaad view that is being applied on immigration from the Council of the European Union with regard to everything concerning the control of the Union's external borders.  Secondly, because, once again, the person trying to access the Union's external borders is targeted as a propitious victim, not the mafias they are dealing with their desperation.  But thirdly, and fundamentally, because no gate is being left open to regular immigration and, therefore, irregular immigration, which is stigmatized as illegal immigration, is being criminalized.  Above all, we are concerned about the potential threat to fundamental rights posed by the profiling of the racial or ethnic origin of asylum seekers or access to the Union's external borders and, of course, we are concerned that this also has an impact on some particularly vulnerable borders, as is clearly the case with the borders of Southern Europe.  This is the case, why not say it, of my country, of Spain. We have recently met in Melilla some episodes that produce a lot of concern. Under no circumstances does it indicate the responsibility of the civil guard or national police forces monitoring these operations, but for the government chain of command, which, without any respect for the fundamental rights of the persons involved, is making hot returns, prohibited not only by European law, but also by national law , domestic law, the national law of my own country, of Spain.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Mr President, Mos Maiorum is further proof of the lack of genuine respect for human rights in European institutions. Ten days after its inception, there is an opacity as to the conditions under which migrants are arrested, as to the guarantees that should accompany their treatment and as to the length and conditions under which they are detained. Even FRONTEX made sure to distance itself from the operation, stressing that it has no involvement in its organisation.  It is obvious that Mos Maiorum is an attempt to impress cheaply on the part of the Italian Presidency and the Governments implementing it. Instead of police 'sweep' operations that reinforce xenophobic syndromes, it is necessary to have an integrated union migration policy with a fair distribution of responsibility between its Member States. It is unacceptable that all the burden should be imitted only on the Mediterranean Member States and that the core States of the Union which are the real destination for immigrants should remain uninvolved.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: Kif ilna ngťidu f'dan il-Parlament, kwalunkwe inizjattiva u azzjoni fuq l-immigrazzjoni gťandha tťares lejn l-aspetti kollha. Irridu fil-fatt naťdmu aktar fuq soluzzjonijiet bťal li ngťinu lill-pajjiżi fl-Afrika jqumu fuq saqajhom, li nidťlu aktar fil-fond lejn possibilitajiet ta' rotot legale lejn l-Ewropa biex in-nies ma jaqbdux dgťajsa b'sogru u periklu gťal ťajjithom. Irid ikun hemm politika ta' ritorn sigur ta' dawk li mhumiex eliżibbli gťall-protezzjoni. Irridu nkunu iebsa, iva, fil-konfront tan-netwerks tal-żażen li jabbużaw min-nies vulnerabbli u mhux inpożżu l-mira tagťna fuq dawk li huma l-aktar dgťajfa. Kulťadd ra t-trażedja lil hinn minna minn xtutna ta' mijiet ta' nies li jiťu maqtula fil-baťar bla ebda skruplu. Iva, hemm bżonn ta' azzjoni, however huwa essenzjali li kull operazzjoni ssir b'kull respect gťad-drittijiet tan-nies u bir-respect lejn il-prinipèju tal-proporzjonality. Ninnota li l-ażenzija tad-drittijiet fundamentali wkoll żasset il-bżonn li tibgťat gwidi prattiżi fuq kif gťandhom jitmexxew operazzjonijiet bťal Mos Maiorum. Il-messażż huwa- gťandna nirrispettaw dawn il-gwidi f'kull operazzjoni, disrespectivament minn min qed imexxi din l-operazzjoni. Nixtieq ukoll gťal darb'oťra nappella gťal spirtu ta' solidarjetà bejn l-Istati Members. Nispera li operazzjonijiet bťal dawn ma jwasslux gťal riżultat paradoxical ta' żieda fir-responsabilità li jridu jiffażjaw pajjiżi bťal tiegťi, jiżifieri Malta, taťt is-sistema ta' Regolament ta' Dublin. Il-ballun issa qiegťed f'saqajn il-Kunsill u l-Kummissjoni u hawnhekk nixtieq nagťmel mistoqsija lill-Kunsill, gťaliex huwa rrappreżentat hawnhekk: ser tgťinu sabiex nassiguraw li l-Istati Members jwettqu finalment ir-responsabilitajiet tagťhom f'dan il-qasam?

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President! For years, Europe has failed to solve its migration problem. The Member States are not prepared to tackle a major forward-looking solution; By perselet unwaveringly on the development of Fortress Europe, we do not solve any of the problems; on the contrary, the number of people who perisrate in the Mediterranean is constantly increasing. One might get the impression that political marketing is trying to disguise this failure. There is talk of "Mare Nostrum", "Triton" or "Mos Maiorum". Sounds nice. But no "Mos Maiorum" suggests the ability to act. One can argue about the usefulness. We have heard today that many legal principles are also being violated. This must be taken very seriously. Above all, however, we should finally start to tackle the problems at the roots and not euphemistically tinker with the symptoms.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: Madam President, 'mos maiorum' means in Latin 'the custom of the ancestors' and is also the name of a pan-European macro-reed, racist and based on fear. "Mos Maiorum" is designed to terrorize those who have come in search of work, roof and bread, but it also appeals to that fear of the other, the stranger, that fear so well used by fascism and that still clings to the hearts of many good people.  By the way, an imaginary enemy is pointed out, a culprit of the crisis that is not such, while the real enemies, the real culprits look at us from the windows of the towers of the financial neighborhoods and rub their hands knowing that they can continue to steal here, but also there. Wherever we beat to unconsciousness, and sometimes death, on our jagged borders come from. If this is really the custom of our ancestors, I am looking for another adopted civilization that does not cause me so much shame.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: Nilqa' din l-operazzjoni tal-pulizija intraSchengen bťala pass important biex l-Unjoni tiżbor informazzjoni meťtieża biex jiżi żgurat li nażixxu b'mod aktar effettiv fil-konfront ta' kriminalità organizzata li qed tkompli tistagťna mis-sofferenza ta' dawk li jkunu diżà sfaw vittma tad-destin kiefer f'pajjiżhom. Bťala operazzjoni li hija mistennija li tipprovdi informazzjoni li tidentifika l-flussi tat-tranżitu prinèipali ta' illegal immigrants jew irregular permezz tal-art, baťar u l-ajru fl-Istati Members, l-operazzjoni Mos Maiorum hija eżempju żar ta' x'qawwa tista' żżib il-kooperazzjoni fil-żlieda kontra l-kriminalità organized. Madankollu, l-informazzjoni li din l-operazzjoni ppromettiet li tiżbor tikxef il-ťtieża li ttejjeb ir-rabta bejn il-politika interna u external tal-Unjoni fuq kwistjonijiet relatati mal-immigrazzjoni. Fil-każ tat-traffikar tal-persuni, din id-data hija mistennija tipprovdi informazzjoni li gťandha twassal gťal politika u azzjoni Ewropea aťjar u aktar effettiva. Din l-operazzjoni hija ta' ftit jiem, allura issa xi jmiss? Sabiex l-Unjoni tibqa' aťťornata mas-sitwazzjonijiet li qed tikkumbatti, hemm bżonn konsistenza fil-żbir tal-informazzjoni dwar l-influssi migratorji, flimkien mal-analiżi bir-reqqa ta' dik l-informazzjoni. Hemm bżonn ukoll appożżť operattiv lejn Member States bťal Malta li huma l-aktar milquta mill-immigrazzjoni. Appożżż operattiv li jmur id f'id ma' appożżż finanzjarju jiżgura użu aktar effettiv ta' dik l-gťajnuna finanzjarja u riżultati aťjar. Kooperazzjoni żudizzjarja hija meťtieża wkoll daqs kemm hi meťtieża l-kooperazzjoni tal-pulizija. F'dan kollu, however, l-Unjoni u l-Istati Members gťandhom jiżguraw solidarjetà effettiva bi protezzjoni sťiťa tad-drittijiet fundamentali, inkluż waqt il-prożess ta' deportazzjoni u ripatrijazzjoni.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as is clear from the Council document of 10 July last, and as Minister Della Vedova said today, there are two aims of the 'Mos Maiorum' operations: to weaken the role of organised crime in illegal immigration and to collect information on the routes and modus operandi of criminal networks. It is precisely because of the importance of these objectives that we must avoid the risk that these operations will end up harming, above all, those, often minors, who have not yet formalised their asylum applications and therefore the victims rather than those responsible for trafficking in persons. I therefore believe that operations of this kind require transparent planning, with the greater involvement of Parliament, and also require a proper system of guarantees on respect for fundamental rights, so that they can really pursue the primary objective of combating organised crime in illegal immigration. Above all, however, I believe that it is now essential to manage the phenomenon of migration, the provision at European level of measures allowing legal entry, that is to say legal immigration into the European Union.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I share many of the criticisms, concerns and suggestions made by my colleagues, Kyenge, Schlein, Chinnici and then Giuffrida. This operation, over and above good intentions, is likely to have very different results. It is good to know more about this migratory phenomenon, sex, origins, methods, it is a good thing to make serious and effective policies, it is good to fight against the crime of traffickers in these networks, but the risk is that everything will be resolved in a large police operation that leaves more gaps than solutions to the problems, with all the risks that were mentioned of making victims twice victims , starting with minors, this recall is very timely. Unaccompanied minors for whom no one is really making an effective policy. However, I would like to mention two aspects to put it a little positive: the first, if 25 countries come together, come together on a somewhat restrictive aspect of migration policy, perhaps we can think that the desire to have a real European migration policy is born; the second, very briefly, we can hope that there will be courage, foresight and common sense, simply for Europe of a forward-looking policy that tackles libya's black hole, that creates that humanitarian corridor, landing there, not only patrolling the coasts, but landing in the country where it is possible to disembark in order to really create the preventive action that was said by all my colleagues.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: The presidency tal-Kunsill Ewropew qed tgťid li l-operazzjoni Mos Maiorum gťandha tindirizza-σ-σrieki tal-kriminalità u anke tiťbor informazzjoni dwar rotot ta' immigrazzjoni illegali. Imma nistaqsi, fir-realtà qiegťed isir hekk? Gťaliex qed nifhem li din l-operazzjoni tista' twassal biex immigranti li daťlu f'pajjiż u mbagťad imxew lejn Member States oťra jerťgťu jintbagťtu lura fil-pajjiż fejn l-applikazzjoni tagťhom żiet ipproèessata. Gťaliex? Qed ikunu meqjusa bťala illegali, u fl-opinjoni tiegťi, bir-rispett kollu, dan mhuwiex aèettabbli. Din il-miżura kienet tagťmel sens kieku l-appell ta' dan il-Parlament biex jiżu ażťornati r-Regolamenti ta' Dublin ittieťdu bis-serjetà mill-pajjiżi li qed jimblukkaw dan il-pass fi ťdan il-Kunsill. Kif inhuma l-affarijiet illum, din l-operazzjoni tfisser li dawn in-nies jerżgťu jintbagťtu lejn il-pajjiżi tal-fruntiera. U min-naťa waťda, min se jgťin lill-pajjiżi tal-fruntiera? U min-naťa l-oťra meta ser naraw proposed konkreti li jindirizzaw is-sitwazzjoni trażika li gťandna fil-Mediterran? Meta se jkollna rispons wieťed Ewropew? U meta min ifittex l-ażil ma jerżax jintbagťat lura lejn il-pajjiż li daťal fih l-ewwel? Iè-σittadini tagťna ddejqu jisimgťu kliem fieragť u diskorsi sbieť dwar responsability sharing. Iridu jaraw bidla, iridu jaraw ugwaljanza vera u jridu jaraw riżultati f'ťarsien sťiť gťad-drittijiet tal-bniedem.

name: Kati PIRI
text: Mr President, of course it is a good thing that people smuggling is being tackled. Right now, criminals are exploiting the desperation of migrants. However, in this kind of action, I fear that not only the smugglers will be dealt with, but also the undocumented migrants will be labelled and treated as criminals. The Mos Maiorum operation therefore raises many questions. For example, I have serious concerns about political accountability, transparency and democratic control, as well as the risk of discrimination and racial profiling. It is unacceptable that this type of joint police operation is not at all subject to democratic control by the European Parliament or by the national parliaments, even though such actions do raise many questions. Such as: What happens to the detained migrants who do not have the right papers? What happens to the intelligence gathered during previous operations? And does this not lead to repressive actions that in turn lead to a greater sense of hostility towards migrants in society? A first step towards transparency has been taken by holding this debate here this evening and I hope that the Council will come up with concrete answers.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, operation 'Mos Maiorum' was announced in detail on 3 October, when 366 dead migrants were commemorated in Lampedusa in fine words. Since then, however, more than 4,000 people have died at sea in a year and nothing concrete has been done to stop the massacre, indeed after 3 October with "Mos Maiorum" the migrants seem to have returned enemies, amid the alarms of associations and networks that protect the rights of those who just want to escape wars and miseries. Not only that, Triton will leave in November, but it will not include the skills of Mare Nostrum, who has saved hundreds of thousands of lives and will not even cover the journey of action. It means – this is the tragic ending as it is predictable – that the numbers of the massacre will probably increase. Nor can a gigantic police operation in a week put an end to the criminal business that speculates on immigrants, and then it is time for Europe finally to take responsibility. Let Italy not be left alone, take the legal and humanitarian path to fulfil a dutiful principle of solidarity. In a word: go down the road of the humanitarian corridor.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: Mr President, there is talk of illegal immigrants, but the word 'refugees' is beginning to disappear, because it implies responsibilities in international human rights. "No one takes care of illegal immigrants and is expelled": these words are by Caddy Adzuba, journalist of the Congo and Prince of Asturias de la Concordia award.  "Mos Maiorum" means racism means associating the idea of the immigrant with the criminal. It jeopardizes the right to non-discrimination and freedom of movement; In addition, 'Mos Maiorum' joins the policies of the European Union and some Member States such as Spain where the principle of non-recoy or the right of asylum is not respected, with so-called 'hot returns', which are the vivid image of a European Union that can no longer give human rights lessons to anyone.  Mr Pons said the other day in this House, with all the cynicism in the world, that Africa had to be given hope, but what hope are we giving him? We exploit their resources at source, we are complicit in corrupt states, and when the pressure of hunger, poverty and death pushes them to jump fences, to play their lives in boats, we lock them up, expel them and abandon them to their fate. There is a need to change the political tendency to make others suffer.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, Mos Maiorum is a police action by some Member States of the European Union to tackle the enormous social problems created by the famous Dublin II, that is, a wrong method. Because Dublin II has trapped thousands of refugees in the countries of the European south, in countries such as Greece, which has become a repository of souls of thousands of people who want to go to the countries of the European hard core.  However, the issue of thousands of illegal immigrants and refugees cannot be dealt with by Mos Maiorum police 'sweep' operations, without control, without transparency, without guarantees for the protection of human rights. It can be addressed by abolishing 'Dublin II' and establishing a key for the distribution of illegal migration flows in all the countries of the European Union on the basis of their economic strength, extent and population.  Because Greece, Italy and the other countries in the European south cannot afford other refugees and illegal immigrants. The countries of the European hard core must therefore also assume their responsibilities on the basis of Community solidarity.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the aim of operation 'Mos Maiorum' launched by the Italian Presidency and planned by the SISDE from 13 to 26 October is to stop irregular migrants, combat organised crime and collect information for investigative and intelligence purposes. According to the document adopted by the Council, the operation is carried out in close cooperation with Frontex, although frontex has made it clear that it has had no role in the planning and implementation of the operation. Closer cooperation with Frontex would perhaps have been desirable. "Mos Maiorum" is launched after the end of Mare Nostrum which, as is known, has not been replaced by a similar rescue operation despite saving the lives of about 150,000 people, a paradox indeed. Europe cannot continue to tackle the problem of immigration, only through police operations. The European Union cannot look the other way at the tragedy and death of so many people, it absolutely must have a migration policy that is consistent with its founding values and based on the principles of solidarity and acceptance.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: Mr President, it is curious that the first to translate the Latin phrase and to speak of the custom of the ancestors was Mr Díaz de Mera. Of course, he has forgotten the aspect of Auctorites, of military position of that Roman tradition in the face of Hellenizing customs and Asian thought currents, that is, fear of the other, to whom he arrives from outside, as if there was an "inside" and an "outside" and, in response, closing the door. That's the mos maiorum. Mr Díaz de Mera, talking about respect for human rights when we have just seen another video portraying the repression of the civil guard on the Melilla fence is an absolutely unacceptable sarcasm. Listen, for once, to Commissioner Malmstrom: she has just said that force should not be used to deter unauthorized border crossings. Neither the savage crackdown on the fences nor 'Mos Maiorum' fulfils that premiss, so I appeal to the Commission to act. Fences and "Mos Maiorum" are a disgrace.

name: Soraya POST
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul I would just like to point out that this is not a new operation or a new project. It has been going on for years under various presidencies. What's new is that this secret operation has come out. It is well understood that Frontex is moving its activities into cities and into rural areas. So how do you point out what you're looking for? Well, you go at people who you guess could have something fishy to themselves.  What does this lead to? Well it leads to both psychologically and physically insulting, in many cases, innocent people. What else does it lead to? Well, this leads to an increase in racism and xenophobia in the various states. I am glad that we have been made aware of this so that we can act. I think it is shameful for the Council not to consult Parliament or the Commission before doing these kinds of operations.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Thank you, Mr President, thanks to Parliament and to the honourable Members who have spoken in a very serious debate on dramatic issues which, first of all, certainly highlight how the context within which the European Union, as such, today, deals with the issue of immigration is, to say the least, incomplete. The Council considers that the conduct of 'Mos Maiorum' contributes to the objective of greater security within the European Union, through strictly proportionate and necessary means, without compromising the protection of third-country nationals concerned. The implementation of Operation Mare Nostrum, and I say this also as a member of the Italian Government, among other activities clearly demonstrates Italy's attitude towards those who seek to reach its borders and was an operation on which we have received a great deal of criticism for its effectiveness in terms of saved human lives and for any kind of attraction that this could have had.  I would like to specify that it is made clear in the rules of conduct of the operation that no person concerned will be subject to discriminatory treatment on grounds such as sex, race, ethnic or social origin, or religious origin. The collection of information about the persons concerned or their nationality, gender and age is not associated with the identity of the person. The operational instructions of "Mos Maiorum" expressly stress that no personal data must be included in the relevant forms and if this happens such data would not be processed by the Italian authorities and recall that in the cases that arise the criteria of the relevant case law of the European Court of Justice and the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg will certainly be used in strict compliance. The Presidency is also convinced that operation "Mos Maiorum" will contribute, as in the case of similar previous operations, to providing the necessary information for operations aimed at dismantling criminal networks that endanger the lives and well-being of so many people every day. A successful outcome of the operation would also benefit all those and above all all those who are vulnerable and at risk.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The debate is closed.)

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on: - the report by Petri Sarvamaa, on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, on discharge 2012: Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications (COM(2013)0570 - C7-0329/2013 - 2013/2241(DEC)

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, in April this year 30 agencies were granted discharge for the implementation of 2012. Parliament, however, postponed the discharge for the director of BEREC, the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications. The problem with BEREC last spring was not one major thing, but several smaller issues that when taken together showed significant shortcomings in the office’s administrative culture. Budgetary planning, recruitment, internal controls and procurement were all issues that Parliament demanded be addressed.  The key arguments for postponing the granting of the discharge until now were the following: the committed appropriations carried over did not correspond to legal commitments; and difficulties in the planning and/or implementation of the body’s activities, as the carryovers for 2012 were mostly related to delayed recruitment and the absence of an effective policy to ensure the timely presentation and reimbursement of mission costs.  There was considerable room for improvement regarding the preparation, execution and documentation of procurement procedures. Recruitment procedures examined showed significant shortcomings and a number of outstanding issues as regards the internal controls were also found. But since April, the BEREC office got a new administrative manager and during the summer the agency took action to solve the remaining problems. The Court of Auditors evaluated the measures taken in its report published during the summer. Normally the Court reports would only be available in September, but since BEREC specifically requested early publication the report was published in July. I can tell you that it was very positive reading. Most of the issues were addressed and have been solved. In fact out of the 13 comments that the European Court of Auditors had in both, four of them in 2011 and nine in 2012, 10 have been completed, one is partly completed and two are ongoing. In the case of the two issues that are still ongoing, the office has taken measures and the Court points out that there is significant improvement in both areas, so we can expect swift correction to this as well.  All in all I can say that postponing the discharge last spring was indeed called for, it was necessary, it was justified, because the number of problems was so high, but BEREC has now acted and has acted swiftly and in a thorough manner to make up for its shortcomings.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Artist. - Dear Mr President, dear Colleagues, Firstly, I would like to thank the Court of Auditors, the Committee on Budgetary Control and, last but not least, Bogusław Sonik, the original person responsible for the report. We will close the process for almost a year in tomorrow's vote by refusing to give the Council's final report for the fourth year in a row if we accept my proposal from the presenter and the proposal of the Committee on Budgetary Control. My new fellow Members may not know this, but the rejection of the Council discharge is nothing new, as the European Parliament has refused to grant the Council discharge for the previous three years. This decision was taken essentially in the commission and in plenary because the Council refused to cooperate with Parliament during the discharge procedure.  The European Council does not attend the commission hearing on the grounds of a gentlemen's agreement reached in the 1970s and refuses to cooperate with the relevant commission. The fundamental problem is that the Council does not recognise that Parliament has the right to conduct the closures against it, as it does for all other EU institutions, even though this right of Parliament has been certified several times. Most recently, in a letter of 23 January 2014, the European Commission clearly stated that all institutions are subject to the closure procedure in the same way, and this of course also applies to the Council.  Our commission requested information on a number of issues in question, but the Council did not provide Parliament with the necessary documents on any of the following matters, so we were unable to carry out the discharge procedure on its merits. Serious shortcomings can be heard in relation to the council's so-called 'Building of Europe'. The building in Schuman Square has been built since 2008. Despite repeated requests from the commission, the Council did not provide information on the costs of the project so far, as well as on the total amount of the investment and how it was funded. The construction is linked to the purchase and demolition of the so-called 'Résidence Palace' building, which was previously partly located on the same site, and the council office also refused to provide information on the costs associated with it.  As far as the strategy for restructuring the Council administration is concerned, the Committee on Budgetary Control has also contacted the Council on several occasions in relation to the savings made, but to no avail. Without answers to these open questions, we cannot propose granting discharge. On this basis, my fellow Members, as a proposer, which was also supported by the Committee on Budgetary Control, is that Parliament should not grant the Council discharge for the financial year 2012.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to try to dispel some of the misunderstandings that exist between our two institutions on the issue of discharge and the budget of the Council and the European Council. First of all, I would like to stress what unites us: the European Parliament and the Council both attach great importance to the principle of sound financial management of the European institutions. But, of course, it is the Commission's budget that is in the spotlight for its political and operational dimension and value. Both Parliament and the Council want all the financial operations of all the European institutions to be properly, properly and soundly run. And both our institutions should be particularly careful to seek high quality standards in the management of their respective budget sections of the European Union. Article 319 of the Treaty clearly defines a single discharge procedure for the entire Budget of the European Union. Following the presentation of the Annual Report of the European Court of Auditors, the Council approves a recommendation to Parliament for the discharge to be granted to the Commission as to the implementation of the budget. Finally, Parliament adopts this discharge decision. Parliament has also developed a practice involving the adoption of individual discharge decisions relating to the budget of the other European institutions. This is a practice which, as has already been said, is not required by the Treaty and therefore not binding. From the Council's point of view, the discharge procedure is only that relating to financial and budgetary management, and does not extend to individual initiatives or policies in general. Recently, for a number of years now, the Council has shown a major imbalance between what Parliament feels it should examine in relation to the Council's budget and what Parliament itself makes known about its management. Your report today reflects these two points that remain between our institutions, and it is on this basis that you are today called upon to vote for the fourth time on a decision refusing to grant discharge in respect of the implementation of the European Union's budget section relating to the Council and the European Council. However, I consider in all sincerity that there could be a way out of this situation. I noted with interest paragraph 21 of the draft report we are debating today, and I quote from a passage in the report: 'Parliament and the Council could make some progress by establishing together a modus vivendi procedure with a list of documents to be exchanged in order to fulfil their respective roles in the discharge process.' In fact, this solution is not very far from what the Council has proposed on several occasions in the past, for example in the draft Memorandum of Understanding sent in 2011. If Parliament is now interested in discussing a list of documents to be exchanged, we could obviously sit down and discuss openly the details of that list. Personally, I could also imagine going beyond that. Instead of a complex bilateral procedure, the Council could unilaterally make additional financial information available on the websites of Parliament and the Council. I would call this proposal a 'friendly competition' between our two institutions to make our financial management even more transparent. The Italian Presidency is ready to explore every possible solution for a modus vivendi on the discharge procedure, also in agreement with the other two presidencies of our trio: Latvia and Luxembourg. Of course, this modus vivendi should have the placet of both our institutions: Parliament and the Council. A minority of people in both our institutions would not be enough.  After these more conceptual and general comments, allow me to return for a moment to the specific discharge process for 2012, which will in principle be concluded with today's vote. I would also like to point out that the Court's audit of the 2012 implementation of the European Council and Council budget found no serious shortcomings or errors. In its annual report, the Court referred exclusively to two marginal weaknesses in the design of a procedure. In addition to this problem, the Court made no comment concerning the accounts of the European Council and the Council or the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions. This is therefore a good result that you should take into account when you vote. Thank you very much for your attention.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to express my thanks to our rapporteur, Mr German, for his clear words. However, I would also like to thank the Council for the new mode that has been proposed. It sounds quite dramatic if we do not relieve us for the fourth year in a row. We do not insinuate that the money was misused to a large extent, that it was misused or that it was even defrauded. That is not what we are concerned about. No, representatives of the Council, it is a question of transparency. I find it highly unsatisfactory that, in the past, the Council has simply failed to comply with our request for information. Who can even understand how the money was used in the construction and refurbishment of the Council building and whether the tenders really got things right? After all, the Court of Auditors has also found something on the subject of calls for tenders. I think it is the job of a democratically elected Parliament, the European Parliament, to be behind. It would really be a good sign in our dealings with each other if the Council recognised this and cooperated with us on budget discharge. Yes, you are right: there is no binding obligation – not at the moment. That is why I would like to mention your offer to really implement documentation obligations in the interests of transparency, which we may then be able to impose on each other. I do not think that we in This Parliament can stubbornly stand up either. In any case, this is also the concern of my group, and we will perhaps also take back our demands on the depth of information somewhat. I believe that we owe this to the European taxpayer and to the citizen, because this is really about the sensible use, about the trustworthy use of European funds. Once again, I would like to express my thanks to our rapporteur, Mr German, for having spoken so clearly. But the bottom line is that I am hopeful that we are on the right track.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, first of all I would like to convey to you the complaint about the timetable at which we are conducting this debate, I would not say that with nocturnity and alevosía, but at least yes with nocturnity; and, of course, that the vote will be tomorrow rather than today accompanying that of the budget, which would surely have given us a little more visibility into how the European Union's budget is prepared and also well managed. On the other hand, I would like to thank the Italian Presidency for its presence. I believe that historically we have always complained that, at the time of the adoption of the Council's discharge, the Presidency was not here, and I also thank Mr Della Vedova for his words and his offer, which I hope we can use to improve not only relations but above all transparency. I would like to say - and thank - the two rapporteurs, Mr Sarvamaa and Mr Deutsch, who presented us here today with two examples of how Parliament controls and controls the budget and also protects the financial resources of the European Union. In the first case, the case of ORECE, the Agency for European Regulators for Electronic Communications, has identified not major problems , as Mr Sarvamaa has said very well , but small ones which, as a whole, generated an impression of not good management and, above all, that could lead to the growth of greater problems. I think it has been done very well, in frank dialogue with the Court of Auditors, with the Commission and with the managers of BEECE, to improve public procurement, the selection of staff, the prevention and management of conflicts and, above all, greater visibility as a body of the European Union, something that is also of interest to THE ORECE and which , precisely, I understand — and I congratulate Mr Sarvamaa on his good management and the shadow rapporteurs, as well as the ORECE managers themselves, has been improved. A good practice of how with small steps and with good dialogue you can improve transparency. On the opposite side, a bad practice of the Council, which continues to be used not to recognise the democratic and healthy right for the European Parliament to audit the accounts, especially in areas where, it is true, no illegality has been raised, and we recognise this, but there are small mistakes pointed out by the Court of Auditors in proceedings or in conception regarding public procurement and building policy. These are small things, but just as THE ORECE has achieved a great step in terms of transparency, in the case of the Council it would also be expected. Therefore, Mr Della Vedova, I also take your word for it and, from this group, we will try to improve that visibility and transparency.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I counted that there are twelve Members in the Chamber of the European Parliament like the twelve apostles. I do not go into who of us is Judas, but this turnout is indeed not particularly nice, although on the other hand, indeed my esteemed predecessor is right: we should have had this debate much earlier. Thank you to the Representatives of the Council for being present! There are as many as nine of them – it's a strong representation.  I wanted to emphasise that my parliamentary group, the Conservatives and Reformists, takes the view that it is necessary to vote against discharge in respect of the implementation of the European Union budget until the European Court of Auditors in Luxembourg issues a statement of assurance for the implementation of the Union budget as a whole. This means that the ECR Group will vote in favour of the draft report, which refuses to grant discharge. The reason for refusing discharge is – and we know this, especially members who have been in the European Parliament for a long time – the repeated difficulties encountered so far in discharge procedures. These were due to a lack of cooperation with the Council. If that's going to change now – great! Parliament refused to grant discharge to the Secretary-General of the Council in the implementation of the 2009, 2010 and 2011 budgets and ferred them for 2012. I would like to stress that the Council has not given any answer to Parliament's questions, hence our decision.

name: Michael THEURER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteurs for their work and then complimenting the Italian Presidency. The fact that you are here this evening is a positive signal. In my capacity as chairman of the Committee on Budgetary Control, the Committee on Budgetary Control has organised a hearing on the legal position of the European Parliament in the context of the Council's discharge. And if we look into the Treaties, it is clearly stipulated that in the budget discharge procedure the Council makes a recommendation, but the discharge is clearly located in the European Parliament, the directly elected Members. This is not reciprocity, it is an asymmetry. And how the European Parliament, under its own competence, designs the discharge procedure, how we divide it up, how we discuss it, is clearly the competence of the European Parliament. That is why I do not understand the Council's reservations about another discharge procedure, nor do I understand why the Presidency and the Council do not pass on the information requested to Parliament. As the rapporteur, Mr German, has pointed out that the gentlemen's agreement, if it did exist at all, dates back to a time when the European Parliament was not directly elected. We have had very different circumstances since 1979. We have had the Treaty of Lisbon since 2009 with a clear strengthening of the European Parliament, and in the light of this, I would like to appeal to the Council: please get involved in a sensible, proper discharge procedure! It is not acceptable for ministerial officials to want to control the European Parliament's budget. On the contrary, every public expenditure by the taxpayer must be controlled by directly elected Members, by democratically legitimised representatives, including the Council budget and the Council budget. This is what we, as the European Parliament, are fighting for in the spirit of democratic control of transparency and accountability.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Mr President, commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. – Honourable Mr President-in-Office, esteemed colleagues, a few words on the report on the Council discharge, which is this evening's topic.  I was president of the Slovenian Court of Auditors for nine years, and when I read my colleague Deutsch's excellent report, I could not believe my eyes, and I was really surprised.  The Council therefore refuses to cooperate with Parliament on its discharge, refuses to explain how it spends taxpayers' money and builds many buildings, a huge lyoh building that is thought to have already cost EUR 330 million by now. However, it does not give any precise breakdown of the final or actual costs, and the question is whether the Council should not also be a model for financial transparency and the first in openness, an example to all other institutions in sound financial management and accountability, not only of course To Parliament, but also to the general public. And what's in that building, in that egg, of course, the windows on all sides, and we're still wandering in the dark about the clarity of the costs that have been spent.  I understand what we have heard before, that this story is long and complicated and that this old gentleman's agreement is behind it, but of course it has to be said that the world has changed tremendously since then, at least the expectations of financial accountability and transparency are much greater and the public is also, of course, demanding maximum transparency.  The central institutions of the European Union, however, must set an example for others and make every effort to be credible in the eyes of taxpayers and voters. And therefore, of course, as long as that is the case and as long as the Council does so, all of our group will vote against granting discharge to the Council for the financial year 2012, as well as next year and a year after, if the Council does not change its tactics, and here I think That Italy has a historic opportunity to take a step forward. And I think there's a way out of this and, of course, where there's a will, there's a way. Thanks.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, as my fellow Members have said before, I remain sad to have to speak to such an empty Chamber, and this is not the first time I have ever heard of it. I have been here for a few months and I learn that for the sixth year running the European Parliament has proposed in the first instance that discharge be postponed for the Council's budget. Basically, the Council does not recognise Parliament's role as the ultimate discharge representative and has set in fore a whole process with various rapporteurs or legal experts to try to understand who is right between the parties.  I do not want to take sides openly in this power game, because I see this as an insult to the taxpayers of European citizens, who want extreme cooperation between the actors in the institutions. I believe that, as in a team, everyone must cooperate as best we can in order to achieve the maximum, and so Parliament is in a sense right to protest, not granting discharge, since the request made to the Council does not seem to me to be such utopian. Unfortunately, I note that this game between the institutional actors during each debate comes to an end. In this case and in the trialogues, it is evident that the European project is perhaps a little too ambitious and slow to move forward. On the one hand, we have the Heads of State who are highly Pro-European in the election campaign and are pushing for this to exist, for it to be standardised in a single flag, but then the unification processes encounter major problems and contrasts. Perhaps we are close as borders but we have too many economic differences, too many cultural differences that have their roots over the centuries and in history and national interests that are more or less right to defend and protect. And then there are those powers of interests, various lobbies and globalisation with its greed that so easily penetrates the hearts of those who should make politics more justly, protecting the weak and solidarity, delegated by such a high honor of representation elected by the people.
