In short, in this small battle of principle between Parliament and the Council, there is the reason for the failure of this institution, the too many differences and the forcing applied without taking into account the damage it causes to those who dream of a true Union of peoples from the outside, in the name of brotherhood, solidarity and sustainability.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: President-in-Office, thank you for the floor. While new times are facing us, they require the prescribed approaches when certifying discharge. The transparency of our action is very important, because it is the only way to gain greater citizens' trust in the European Union.  The European Parliament, the Council and the Commission have also concluded an interinstitutional agreement on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management. The agreement is thus binding on all institutions. Now we are in front of a problem where the Court of Auditors has noted for several years in a row that the Council is not giving further answers to the Court of Auditors' recommendations. Once again, we are in front of a situation where the Council has still not informed us and prepared a written explanation on the use of budgetary resources for the purchase of the 'Residence Palace' building. Nor did it explain what the measures would be implemented during the construction of the Europe building and did not elaborate on the costs incurred so far and other financial statements in this regard. These are just some of the examples that demonstrate that the Council does not cooperate and does not take into account the opinions and requests of the Court of Auditors and the European Parliament. Because of this situation, we are not giving the citizens of the Union a good signal. Parliament has already refused discharge for 2009, 2010 and 2011 and is now refusing to grant the Secretary-General of the Council discharge for the implementation of the Council's budget for the financial year 2012, again, for several or less the same reasons, which have been explained several times here.  The Council must act with its resources in the spirit of a good master and perhaps act in this way, but the use of these funds must be exercised. The Council must be aware of this and therefore must start to cooperate. We have a duty to establish all the facts that are relevant for the adoption of the correct discharge decision, so before doing so, we must determine with the same care whether the Council is really using the funds properly, and the Council must give us real, correct and complete information. However, the Council is not involved in this. It seems that we do not have the right instruments in our hands to encourage the Council to cooperate, to present and explain everything we ask for. The functioning of all the institutions, I reiterate, must be transparent, but there must also be smooth cooperation between them.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Mr President, Mr President, I would like to thank the president for his I would now like to return to the agencies. The agencies are legally separate, independent legal entities established by the EU institutions to perform certain tasks under EU law. BEREC, the body of European regulators for electronic communications, is one of the decentralised agencies that carry out the tasks in the field of technology, science and administration and assist the EU institutions in implementing policies. In doing so, they promote the pooling of expertise and expertise available in EU institutions and national authorities, and cooperation between the EU and the governments of EU countries. The decentralised agencies will be set up indefinitely in the various countries. The majority of agencies were relieved by us in the spring of this year – except for BEREC. As has already been pointed out today, it was not because there were gross errors here, but because there were a number of small inconsistencies or failures, which took time to be clarified. I believe that this must be noted: inaccuracies in budget monitoring, the need for improvement in the preparation, implementation and documentation of procurement procedures, a lack of information on conflict-of-interest policy, a lack of transparency in financial statements, etc. BEREC has, of course, been given the opportunity to comment on all these allegations. That is what they have done, and we received an Office report in July, and it shows that most of these allegations have been rectified and that there will be improvements here in the future. We therefore believe that, according to this report, BEREC should be granted discharge. I must also say today that I would like to express my sincere thanks for the cooperation with the agencies, but also for the good cooperation with the Court of Auditors, my fellow Members. I believe that in this way we can ensure that European taxpayers' taxpayers' tax resources are used in a meaningful and efficient and beneficial way.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: Mr President! For once, it is a pleasure to stand in this Chamber and talk about openness and transparency! Because when it comes to the other EU institutions, this Parliament can obviously figure out how to make demands, be tough in the felt and demand action now. And I am therefore pleased and support the efforts of my colleagues to get the Council to provide the information that they should. I just think that one should be a little more thorough in your attitude to openness and transparency. That is why, as a member of a group that is in favour of a thorough reform of the way we can deal with the European Union, I will fight for us to remember transparency and openness when it comes to key lobbyist registers when it comes to ensuring that, for example, there are dissens in the European Court of Justice and when it comes to ensuring greater transparency of votes in this House. However, it has been an uplifting experience to hear the few colleagues present here today – we are probably only a ten pieces left in the Chamber – and I will keep you up on these things when we come to parliament ourselves. When one finger is pointed at others, five people typically turn back on one even in this House!

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Mr. President! I would also like to express my sincere thanks to the Council, because the constructive offer to achieve discharge together is very important for all of us. The European public is no longer concerned that discharge should not be granted. It is therefore a question of developing alternatives to actually achieving this discharge. We also recognise the principle of the separation of powers, and we know that the European Court of Auditors is indeed looking very carefully. That is why we are focused on using the funds in order to be transparent with the citizen accordingly. We have, of course, also seen at BEREC that the European Parliament also deals with problems and does not want to act as a criminal authority here, but that we want to learn together, that we improve and that incentives are created so that the European public can see that good work is being done here, that transparent work is being carried out and that we can understand what has been decided. That is why it is also a question of a long-term strategic attempt to avoid mistakes made in the past in building policy. Here, of course, Parliament is happy to take new steps in the area of building policy in cooperation between the institutions. We are happy to accept the Council's proposal to make a serious attempt, just as BEREC has succeeded in granting discharge to the Council as well.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I wanted to make it very clear that we are debating a very good report by a very good Member, Mr Deutsch, thank you very much for that.  In the report, we can read what are the legal bases on which the European Parliament has the right, or even the duty, to ask the Council to provide the relevant documents for debate and, if necessary, to grant discharge. The report clearly shows what has been lacking, which is why, on the one hand, I welcome the declaration made today by the Italian Presidency, but I have heard this from the Greek Presidency not so long ago. This means that you, as The Lords Presidency, do not have much to say there, there is someone else in charge. However, let us look at what is important from our point of view, namely public money. Citizens, taxpayers, people have the right to know how money is spent, and here in Parliament, and in the Commission and in the Council, and for that reason the Council cannot be taken out of this general principle. This is a question of the quality of our Union, and on this basis, as requested by the rapporteur, the refusal to grant discharge is justified, although the legal value of this is, it is a completely separate matter and perhaps this should be a subject for our reflections for the future.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the institutions of the European Union must act transparently and be accountable to the citizens. This also applies to the European Council and the Council, which think they are above control. The European Parliament has the power to grant discharge to the European Council. In his report, Mr Tamás Deutsch records specific observations and refers to the Court of Auditors' well-documented opinion on the european Council's omissions. A European Council that at every opportunity shakes its finger at the people and scolds them. So the European Council thinks it can do whatever it wants. He denies control over the amount of money spent on the 'Europe' building and the 'Residence Palace'. Mr President, no one is above control. Transparency everywhere and in everything. No discharge to the European Council and the Council for the implementation of the 2012 budget.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have listened very carefully to the speeches. If there is a political will to find a modus vivendi between Parliament and the Council, then we will be able to find solutions. From this point of view, our two institutions should avoid conflicting. The Council is acting in good faith and has no doubt that Parliament is doing the same.  Interinstitutional contrasts are not useful for common objectives and for the European agenda in general. We are all interested in sound financial management and public accountability of the Eu ropean Union institutions. That, I believe, is what the citizens expect of us. Thank you once again for the opportunity to speak in this debate. Thank you for your attention.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, while not in any way overlooking the importance of the Council discharge, I will still concentrate on the agencies because that was my role in the procedure this time.  The European Union agencies have an extremely important role to play. They impact directly on the daily lives of our citizens and they perform important tasks. They perform technical, scientific and supervisory tasks helping the Union institutions.  But even more important, from the budgetary control perspective, is that these agencies, which now number over thirty, function properly and efficiently. In order for this to happen the agencies should seek and deploy best practices. The combined budgetary impact of the decentralised EU agencies is almost EUR 1 billion per year. So the efficient and prudent operation of these agencies is not irrelevant at all to EU taxpayers.  And it is not just budgetary discipline and solid planning that we in the Committee on Budgetary Control are interested in. It is about potential conflicts of interest; it is about procurement and contract management; it is about lack of transparency and rigour in recruitment. It is also about excessively high carry-overs and troubles in verifying grant transactions. To sum it up, this is about looking after the EU taxpayers’ money, seeing too that our common resources are used wisely. It is all this that makes the discharge process really important for all of us. And it is that which makes me so happy tonight to conclude this debate on my behalf by noting that this particular agency, BEREC, now deserves our discharge.  Last, but certainly not least, I am really happy and satisfied to see the Council here in this Chamber tonight.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Artist. - Mr President, my fellow Members, I would like to thank you for your support. First of all, I would like to thank my colleagues for their support, for their valuable thoughts now in terms of what has been said in plenary and for the joint work they have done in the budget committee in the past. I think that I am convinced that the current state of play, the fact that the two fundamental institutions of the European Union, the European Parliament and the Council, the European Council, cannot agree on the procedure for the closure procedure, is a poverty certificate for both institutions and, as we often say, is a very bad message to European citizens. Moving the current state out of this deadlock is the start of a dialogue and the development of an agreement that can finally resolve this situation, which I think is one of the most important tasks for us MEPs in the parliamentary term ahead.  As Mr Liberadzki said, there have been several proposals from Council representatives that give us confidence, and we still regard his proposal at today's meeting of the Italian Presidency as such, the credibility of which will be given by the substantive negotiations in the weeks and months ahead and, hopefully, by the agreement. However, in the current situation, we have only one instrument, the only instrument for Parliament, which is that discharge is now definitively rejected, i.e. in the relevant second discharge report, I propose that the Council grant discharge for the financial year 2012 be rejected in tomorrow's final vote.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The joint debate is closed.  The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 23 October 2014. The next meeting will take place tomorrow, Thursday 23 October 2014 from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing.– Ladies and gentlemen, in my opinion, the discharge for BEREC was justifiably postponed in spring 2014, as there were clear reservations about the poor implementation of projects, conflicts of interest and transparency and tender and recruitment gaps. However, BEREC has clearly demonstrated that it is willing to accept our complaints and transform them into positive results. Thanks to this, I can recommend that he be discharged. There is a need to continue the pressure on the Agency to further improve the areas criticised (financial transfers, low transparency, high conflict of interest). On the contrary, the Council is the least transparent body that consistently refuses to cooperate with Parliament. Parliament must make clear its dissatisfaction with the state of cooperation and communication with this institution and must refuse discharge. Representatives of the Council do not participate in cont meetings and do not answer our questions. This is unacceptable and completely undermines the legitimacy of this institution! Non-transparent expenditure on EU funds which is not supervised cannot be suffered. The Council has consistently made mistakes in the area of public procurement, and Parliament has no control over this. Every European institution is accountable to its citizens and is subject to their control, and the Council is by no means an exception and should not place itself in a superior role! It therefore has a duty to cooperate, in a spirit of transparency, with the representative of EU citizens, with the European Parliament.
